PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CHANEY; CROSIO; FILING; KERIN; PROSSER; SHACK; TUCKEY
PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided medical benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Chaney (from 199 citizens), Mrs Crosio (from 17 citizens), Mr Filing (from 714 citizens), Mr Kerin (from 41 citizens), Mr Prosser (from 232 citizens), Mr Shack (from 226 citizens) and Mr Tuckey (from 200 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all innocent human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights.
That the first duty of the Parliament and of the Government is to protect this right to life.
That in 1989/90 alone Medicare provided medical benefits for almost 70,000 abortions at a cost to taxpayers of $7.8 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of unborn Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin (from 88 citizens), Mr Cadman (from 135 citizens), Dr Hewson (from 25 citizens), Mr Kerin (from 95 citizens) and Mr Tickner (from 165 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby;
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights;
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life;
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect;
That in 1989/90 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 69,587 abortions totalling $7.8 million;
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every human being, from the first instance of fertilization, is of unique and precious value, not only to him/herself, but also to his/her parents and to the community at large.
That every abortion kills a human being before his/her birth.
That the right to life of all human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights according to article 3 of the 1948 UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
That the primary duty of the Parliament is to protect this inalienable right to life of all citizens, born and unborn.
That in 1989/90 alone, medical benefits were paid for almost 70,000 abortions at a cost to Australian tax-payers of $7.8 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of all Australian citizens before birth by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare and by other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: DOWNER; DUNCAN; GALLUS; MCLACHLAN; PROSSER; SCOTT; WILSON
PETITION.TITLE: Petition Against Government Funding of Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:
Every abortion kills an unborn human baby. More unborn Australians are killed every year (80,000) than the Australian death toll for the whole of World War II (30,000).
Australia's population is aging. Our live birth rate is below replacement level.
About 98 percent of abortions in Australia are performed for non-medical reasons (see SA Health Commission statistics).
Post abortion depression is a silent epidemic and is linked with the growing incidence of child abuse by mothers who have previously had abortions.
The Australian Government should not fund the killing of future Australian citizens.
Mothers with problem pregnancies need positive help to carry their babies to full term.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
pass the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990, and
help pregnant women with problems to continue their pregnancies.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Downer (from 12 citizens), Mr Duncan (from 70 citizens), Mrs Gallus (from 58 citizens), Mr McLachlan (from 20 citizens), Mr Prosser (from 30 citizens), Mr John Scott (from 44 citizens) and Mr Wilson (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
requests the Federal Government to denounce those parts of the Convention which could undermine the parent-child relationship.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bilney (from 96 citizens), Dr Catley (from 60 citizens) and Mr McLachlan (from 14 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That attention is drawn to Australia's location and involvement in the Asia/Pacific region where there exists a number of actual and potential conflicts, along with several countries which can ill afford to pay for the importation of military equipment yet feel obliged to do so.

That Australia is increasing its role in the arms trade in this region, and in particular, it is supporting and participating in AIDEX 1991. The arms trade is detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from health, education, social welfare, and is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of people of the Asia/Pacific region.
The petitioners therefore appeal to the Australian Parliament to:
Stop all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people.

Direct those Government Departments participating in AIDEX 1991, i.e. Defence, Austrade, Industry, Technology and Commerce, to cancel their bookings for space at the exhibition and withdraw their support for AIDEX 1991.
Redirect all monies currently being used in promoting the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
Explore the possibilities of setting up an Agency for the development of techniques for conflict resolution.
Increase overseas aid to counteract the reduction since 1983/4.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Campbell (from 54 citizens), Mr Fife (from 65 citizens) and Mr Tim Fischer (from 21 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
A humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Attention is drawn to Australia's increasing role in the militarisation of the Pacific region and in particular to the current Government-led arms export drive.

The arms trade is not only detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from socially beneficial areas--for example, health, education and social welfare--but is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of the people of the Third World.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
Cease all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people.
Direct all Federal and State Government Departments and instrumentalities to withdraw from participation in and support for AIDEX and similar arms fairs in Australia and overseas.
Close down AIDEX 1991.
Establish a register of all applications for arms transfers and offset agreements which would be subject to public scrutiny.
Redirect all monies currently being used to promote the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia and Slovenia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That 92% of Croatians who voted in a referendum on 25 April 1991, supervised by the Constitutional Court of the Republic of Croatia, declared their support for Croatia as a sovereign and independent State and their opposition to Croatia remaining in the Yugoslav Federation;
That 88% of Slovenians who voted in a referendum democratically expressed their support for Slovenia as an autonomous and independent State;
That both Slovenia and Croatia have declared themselves to be independent Republics and that each Republic is prepared to defend its territorial integrity.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should request the Australian Government to:

Establish diplomatic relations with the legitimate representatives of each Republic and of any currently subjugated country whose residents by a democratically expressed popular vote have declared their wish to be independent; and
Establish trade relations with the Croatian and Slovenian Republics, to take advantage of the very favourable attitude which exists between the people of these Republics and the Australian people.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dawkins (from 822 citizens), Mrs Kelly (from 1,712 citizens) and Mr McArthur (from 260 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that every abortion kills a baby
that in 1989/90 alone the Federal government paid for 69,587 abortions through Medicare
that to pay for the killing of unborn children is to endorse each such act of killing
that the protection of human life is the first duty of parliament and government

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian parliament will act to protect the right to life of unborn babies in Australia and cease to subsidise the killing of unborn children through Medicare by passing the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill and in any other way possible.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Catley (from 226 citizens) and Mr Snowdon (from 62 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all innocent human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights.
That the first duty of the Parliament and of the Government is to protect this right to life.
That in 1989/90 alone Medicare provided medical benefits for almost 70,000 abortions at a cost to taxpayers of $7.8 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of unborn Australian babies by ceasing to subsidise abortions through Medicare by passing the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990 and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members in the House of Representatives assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesman-like leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:-

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Catley (from 20 citizens) and Mr West (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which wars such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:
(i) call on the Federal Government to outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations, government and private.

(ii) call on the Federal Government to lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology to unstable regions and to countries with dictatorships.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Steele Hall (from 38 citizens) and Mr John Scott (from 134 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon Honourable Members to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Canberra, in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(a) We believe that Medicare should not fund abortion.
(b) We believe that we, the tax-payers should not have to bear the cost.
(c) We believe in protecting the rights of the unborn child and are against abortion on demand.
(d) We believe that human-life itself should not become subservient to financial considerations.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:
(a) Introduce new legislation protecting the rights of the unborn child and look upon the fact that it is a human life at stake.
(b) Amend Medicare legislation to not fund abortion.
(c) That we, the tax-payers not pay for abortion on Medicare.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House their deep concern that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
(1) (a) makes inadequate provision for a subjective judgement by parents as to what is in the best interests of their children,
(b) makes inadequate provision for parents to use their discretionary powers to act on such judgements.
(2) creates the potential for conflict between parent and child (rather than the atmosphere of happiness, love and understanding mentioned as valuable in the preamble).
(3) will produce closer monitoring by Government agencies of relationships between parents and children.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that:
(1) By Act, Parliament ensure that all international treaties (excluding national security) are debated by the Parliament.
(2) The Parliament take action to have the Convention amended in order to pay the highest regard to the importance of the family unit, and to the rights and responsibilities of parents.

PETITION.TITLE: Deportation of Lucio Teseo
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled:
The petition of citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House:

That Lucio TESEO, currently serving a four year nine month criminal sentence in the Fremantle jail, for the wilful unprovoked assault of his infant daughter, Eleonora, causing her to be permanently physically incapacitated, is to be released from prison early in 1992.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House direct the Minister for Immigration to deport Lucio TESEO following his release from prison, for the future safety of his ex-wife Liliana and their two daughters.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of citizens of Australia resident on the Central Coast of New South Wales respectfully showeth that we condemn the Labor Party's proposal to turn our backs on our history and declare Australia a republic, now or at any future time.

Our great nation was settled by British pioneers, either voluntarily or forcibly, and it to these people and that country that we owe our heritage. Our men and women fought bravely under the banner of the Australian flag, which bears the Union Jack proudly in its top left hand corner, in several great wars, they fought for Monarch and country. This is our free and democratic tradition.
This flag must remain our emblem as a tribute to those who laid down their lives on and off the battlefield for our freedom.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House does not allow this destruction of our connection with the great and noble British Empire of which we are so proudly a part.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS Television: Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of country areas of the State of Western Australia, draws to the attention of the House the continued delay in the often promised S.B.S. Television to country areas of Western Australia, being areas with a lack of alternative Television programmes.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to revise the proposed scheduling provisions in order that S.B.S. Television is made available to as many country areas of Western Australia as possible by December 1991.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom 0055 Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the readily available range of sex and fantasy audio text services transmitted via Telecom through the use of the 0055 prefix.
We express deep concern that these messages could be easily accessed by young people, and that the transmission of such messages will lead to a decline in the moral standards of all Australians.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to--move to immediately disband this `adult' information and entertainment service.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom 0055 Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the readily available range of sex and fantasy audio text services transmitted via Telecom through the use of the 0055 prefix.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to move to disband this `adult' information and entertainment service. Your petitioners are deeply concerned as to what effect these messages have on our youth and Australia's moral standing.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom 0055 Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
(1) Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

(2) The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
(3) These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the House, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to remove these services so that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: War Widows
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of Victoria, draws to the attention of the House the fact that all widows of ex-servicemen who served overseas or in any declared war zones do not receive the war widows pension.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House grant a war widow pension to all the widows of ex-servicemen who served overseas or in any declared war zones.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport Task Force
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament:
We, the undersigned petitioners, reject the final report of the Brisbane Airport task Force, because it failed in its basic charter to "minimise the impact of aircraft noise on surround communities.

It failed to recommend their own conclusions that an extended Cross Runway would "significantly reduce aircraft noise" and that an extended cross runway could operate as the "main or supplementary runway," which, along with the Main Runway would enable 80% or more planes to go in and out over Moreton Bay, as promised.

Although it rejected these solutions because the cost would be $105 million, it recommended that a future Parallel Runway be built at a cost of $395 million (today's price) which could escalate to double or more in 15 to 20 years, thus forcing north and southside citizens to suffer increasing aircraft noise with no end in sight.
We urgently request that money be made available for an extended Cross Runway as the most cost effective and practical solution to Brisbane Airport noise and safety.
We also request that changes be made to flight paths over Hemmant, Tingalpa and Bulimba-Balmoral, Morningside areas.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service and should therefore be properly funded to continue to provide the same comprehensive range of services;
that the ABC should not be subject to the 1.25% efficiency dividend for the 1990/91 financial year;
that the ABC be provided with supplementary funding to avoid the need for the proposed cuts in staff and services;
that the ABC be provided with fully indexed funding for the next three years with an agreed formula for indexation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Disadvantaged Schools Program and Country Education Project
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned citizens call upon the Commonwealth to:
Keep the Disadvantaged Schools Program and Country Education Project as Commonwealth Special Purpose Programs.
Increase funding by at least the Consumer Price Index annually.
Ensure that funding for schools be made available to schools, not diverted to pay Ministry employees.
Ensure guidelines are followed and the State Committee permitted to meet.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: ABC Television: Investigation By Ombudsman
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, are deeply concerned by the continued political biases and deplorable disregard for common decency displayed by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Further, we are alarmed that the Corporation is able to conduct itself in this manner without accountability to an independent authority.
We believe that it is totally unacceptable that a publicly funded body can undertake any action it chooses, free from public complaint and scrutiny.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the members of the House of Representatives will act to empower the Commonwealth Ombudsman--either of his own intention or in response to a complaint from a member, or members, of the public--to investigate any action that relates to a programming decision of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Hospitals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
(1) They are completely satisfied with the existing Repatriation Hospital system.
(2) They are aware that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs have guaranteed on a number of occasions:

(a) no Repatriation General Hospital will be transferred to a State until a satisfactory agreement has been reached on matters such as priority of access and quality of health care for Veterans and War Widows and unless the interests of hospital staff have been adequately safeguarded; and
(b) no final decision will be taken if the R.S.L. has reasonable cause for dissatisfaction with the proposed arrangements.
(3) They have reasonable cause for concern that integration of Repatriation Hospitals into State systems will represent a serious erosion of their rights and privileges.

(4) They are also aware that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the S.A. State Government have agreed that one criteria that must be met prior to the transfer taking place, is that the ex-service community is satisfied with the arrangements.

(5) After almost three years of consultation, the majority of the ex-service community of South Australia have decided they are not happy with either the arrangements for the transfer or the proposed Patient Private Health Scheme.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will propose and pass a motion that "the existing Repatriation Hospital system be retained under the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government to ensure Repatriation General Hospitals remain centres of excellence for the health needs of the Community".
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House that the ban on political advertising denies Australians the right to Freedom of Speech, may be unconstitutional, and contravenes Australia's human rights responsibilities. Your petitioners therefore ask the House to reject this legislation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS Television: Northern Rivers Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the Northern Rivers region of NSW, being therefore, electors of the Divisions of Richmond and Page, draws to the attention of the House that the Region meets the necessary criteria of population size and ethnic mix for provision of the SBS Television Broadcasting Service, and that because of the current "Commercial Television Equalisation Program" a unique, cost effective opportunity exists for this service to be provided.

Your petitioners therefore respectfully request the House to determine that the SBS Television Service be extended to this region, in conjunction with the aforementioned "Equalisation Program", within the next twelve months.

PETITION.TITLE: Ukrainian Independence
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(1) That Ukraine, a nation of 53 millions, one of the ten largest economic entities in the world, with a land area the size of France, and a foundation member of the United Nations, which suffered 7 million dead in the forced famine engineered by Moscow in 1932-33, 6 million dead at the hands of the Nazis in World War 2 and an as yet unknown number of deaths from the nuclear fallout of Chernobyl, declared its independence on August 24, 1991.

(2) That the Ukrainian government has exercised its sovereignty by nationalising assets of the Communist Party and taking control of industries and resources on the territory of Ukraine, appointing a Minister of Defence, establishing a defence force, taking steps to introduce a national currency, beginning the withdrawal of Soviet nuclear weapons from Ukrainian soil, and concluding treaties with neighbouring countries such as Poland and Hungary.
As Ukraine has demonstrated control of its territory, we call upon the Parliament and the Australian Government to immediately consider:
(a) recognition of the declaration of Ukrainian independence, and,
(b) establishment of an Australian diplomatic mission in Kiev.
And, your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon Honourable Members to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Save The Husky in Antarctica
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain Citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House their deep concern for the safe return of the Husky dogs from Mawson station in Antarctica, which under the terms of a recent International Agreement for the Protection of the Environment in Antarctica are to be removed from Antarctica by April 1994.

Your petitioners therefore Pray that as a final tribute to the integral role played by the Husky dogs, supporting many successful Australian Antarctic Expeditions, the dogs be brought to Australia where they may be housed singly or in teams according to options available.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Consumer Goods
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to proposals to introduce a 15% consumption tax on gas, electricity, wood, transport fares and entertainment which will create hardship for pensioners who have to pay this out of their pension. Many may have to do without heating, hot water and cooking.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will not agree to such a tax.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Consumer Goods
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House proposals to introduce a 15% consumption tax on bread, milk, eggs, meat, fruit, vegetables and clothing which will increase food costs for those who have low incomes and have to spend most of their income on food, heating and clothing.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will not agree to such a tax.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: $3.50 Co-payment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled:
This petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully points out--
(1) During the last election the Government campaigned to defend Medicare.
(2) The opposition parties had no such policy.
Your petitioners therefore require the House to reverse the 1991 Budget decision to impose the $3.50 Medicare co-payment.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could, if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ownership of Press
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia wish to draw the attention of the House that we are deeply concerned at (1) concentration of ownership of the Press which is unprecedented in Australia's history and unparalleled in any Western Democracy--(2) The unacceptable concentration of power, the restrictions on the diversity of information and ideas, the barriers to entry and other aspects of market failure, the diminished localism of content and accountability, the debilitating impact on journalistic culture and the conflicts of interest which this concentration of ownership involves.
Your petitioners respectfully urge the House to support the establishment of a Royal Commission to inquire into the Press including:
(a) The extent of concentration in the ownership and control and the affects of that on:
(i) The provision of accurate, fair and comprehensive news;
(ii) the diversity of opinions and the opportunities for expression; and
(iii) the practice of journalism; and
(b) the regulatory framework in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Ukrainian Sovereignty, Independence and Nationhood
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:
that we the undersigned, deplore the Soviet Union and Russia's continuing attempts to deny Ukraine its rightful sovereignty, independence and nationhood.
Your Petitioners pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should:
Support Ukrainian/Australians in pursuit of sovereignty, independence and nationhood for Ukraine as proclaimed in Kiev on Saturday August 24, 1991.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray:

"May your kindness, O Lord, be upon us who have put hope in you; May the Lord give strength to His people; May the Lord bless His people with peace, Save your people, O Lord, and bless your inheritance. Amen.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Defence Forces: Erosion of Conditions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(1) that serving members of the Australian Defence Forces are frustrated and disillusioned at the continuing erosion of their conditions of employment, benefits and entitlements traditionally provided in recognition of the burdens placed on themselves and their families by service in the Defence Forces;

(2) that the Government's decision to discount by 2 per cent the retirement benefits of members of the Australian Defence Forces has broken a trust that should exist between servicemen and the Government concerning the financial security of themselves and their families in retirement;

(3) that the Government's decision to discount the retirement benefits of members of the Australian Defence Forces has seriously lowered the morale and commitment of servicemen and will further increase the number of experienced servicemen leaving the Defence Forces.

Your petitioners humbly pray that you establish or expedite reviews of conditions, salary, allowances, entitlements and benefits for servicemen and reverse the decision to discount by 2% retirement benefits for servicemen.

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia and Slovenia: Wollongong Area
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

We as Croatian residents within the Wollongong area and surrounding suburbs draw to the attention of the House the current campaign which is being waged by the Communist Government of Serbia and its agents against the aspiration for independence for the Republics of Croatia and Slovenia.

We particularly draw to your attention the fact that Croatia and Slovenia have satisfied the conditions of international law for independence, and that they have made every effort to enter into meaningful dialogue with their opponents in Serbia. These have been to no avail.
Your petitioners therefore urge that the House as a matter of urgency offers immediate recognition to Croatia and Slovenia as sovereign nations.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, I present the report, incorporating a dissenting report of the Committee, entitled Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service together with a video recording and the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As well as presenting the Committee's report today, I have presented a video on the report produced by the Committee and the Parliament's Sound and Vision Office, specifically for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The video deals with those aspects of the report which address ways in which the Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service could be improved to provide better service for those people. The Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service, run by the Australian Electoral Commission, was set up to provide Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in traditional and remote communities with electoral information and education and to encourage their enrolment.

SPEECH.PARA: AIEIS differs from other similar programs which preceded it in that it gives responsibility for delivery of electoral information and education to Aboriginal and Islander people themselves. This is done by educating selected community members, called community electoral assistants, as resource people for their own communities.

The Aboriginal Electoral Information Service was reviewed by the Australian National University's north Australia research unit in 1987-88. The report of that review--the NARU Report--was referred to the Committee of the thirty-fifth Parliament by Senator Robert Ray, then Minister for Home Affairs. It was referred with expanded terms of references to the Committee of the thirty-sixth Parliament by Senator Nick Bolkus, the Minister for Administrative Services.

The work of the Committee has been greatly assisted by those who made submissions, particularly by the contributions of many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people with whom discussions were held in Canberra and during two site inspections in north Queensland and Western Australia. These site inspections were a critical source of information to the inquiry and gave the Committee the opportunity to meet members of Aboriginal and Islander communities and to talk with many people who are served by AIEIS and some of the community electoral assistants who work with AIEIS. The site inspections were undertaken so that the Committee could test out in the field the observations made in submissions.

A primary question facing the Committee was whether there is a need for the service being provided. The inquiry has convinced the Committee that such a need does exist. As a group, Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders are electorally disadvantaged. Factors which contributed to this include a lack of general education, restricted access to general electoral education services offered by the AEC and remoteness of location. I think in this regard it is salutary to remember that compulsory enrolment for Aborigines was introduced only in 1983. It is for that reason that there is still a great need to provide assistance to many of the people in isolated areas. Eight years is a short period for people to come to grips with the details of the democratic process. Enrolment for the three levels of Government is confusing for many, let alone the intricacies of different voting systems.

The Committee has therefore recommended that the program be continued. It has also recommended that the program's name be changed to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Electoral Information Service so as to reflect more accurately its target clientele. The objectives of the AIEIS program include both electoral education and enrolment. There has been, to date, a conflict of views within the AEC concerning the relative importance of these objectives. This conflict has affected relations between AIEIS officers and other AEC staff and, in part, hampered the efficient operation of the program.

While the Committee certainly endorses the importance of enrolment, it believes that enrolment is only the first step and should be accompanied by education. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended that the Australian Electoral Commission formulate a clear policy giving priority to education and information in the AIEIS program.

The conflict over the focus of the program is symptomatic of other problems faced by AIEIS. The Committee noted several deficiencies in the AEC's management of the program which is not conducive to the efficient and effective delivery of the service. AIEIS has been adversely affected by inadequate staffing, insufficient management commitment to the program, vague lines of authority and poor program evaluation.

The Committee has made a comprehensive series of recommendations which address these concerns. These relate to the full and continuous staffing of the program; the demonstration by the AEC management of an appropriately supportive attitude to AIEIS; administrative changes which will establish clear lines of authority and control; and improvements to reporting and accountability mechanisms.

Another matter of concern to the Committee is that because of its limited area of operation the AIEIS program is not reaching the majority of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. To ensure access to the service provided by AIEIS for all Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, the Committee strongly recommends that the Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service be extended to the States now not covered--that is, New South Wales and Victoria--and to urban areas, and that the AEC seek funding for this from the Federal Government.

The Committee is pleased to be able to report that its inquiry has already resulted in some favourable outcomes in respect of the program's expansion. A submission to the Committee by ATSIC prompted the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) to approach Senator Bolkus concerning the possibility of extending the program. At Senator Bolkus's request the AEC developed and has received budgetary approval for a proposal for an extension of the program and extra funding. Sufficient funding will now be available to employ at least two more field officers.

The Committee would also like to see the program's scope expanded to include information on State and local government and the role of political parties and has made a recommendation to this effect. In moving around and talking to the Aboriginal people I found a tremendous amount of confusion, but also a great willingness on the part of many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders to participate in the democratic process. I must say that I have seen a marked change in the willingness of these Australians to participate in the democratic process from the time I was shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and I think we should encourage it as much as possible.

Certain aspects of the way the program operates in the field could also be improved to make electoral information and education more accessible to people. The Committee has recommended that greater emphasis be placed on fostering wider community support for the program and developing greater community participation. Greater use should also be made of visual media such as videos, comics and T-shirts, as these have been identified by Aboriginal and Islander people as valuable educational aids.

During the Committee's investigation it heard much about the role played by AIEIS in the conduct of the first ATSIC regional council elections held on 3 November 1990. Many regional returning officers and ATSIC officials told the Committee that AIEIS played a vital role in the success of those elections and that in fact polling could not have gone ahead in many places without the presence and dedication of AIEIS field officers and community electoral assistants. The information, education and enrolment functions of AIEIS were also crucial in preparing people for the elections.

The Committee strongly believes that access to electoral information and education is a right of all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Only with the provision of such education and information will they become full participants in the government of this country.

In addition, this inquiry impressed upon the Committee that, in places where AIEIS has operated well, there is among Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders a new enthusiasm for democratic processes and an eagerness to participate in them, both as electors and candidates. This has left the Committee in no doubt that the Aboriginal and Islander Electoral Information Service is a worthwhile program.

Accordingly, it urges the AEC to address the problems identified in this report and to take steps to improve AIEIS so that it provides all Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders with an efficient and effective electoral information and education enrolment service. The report embodies the unanimous views of the subcommittee comprising myself, Senator Kernot and Senator Beahan. When the report was considered by the full Committee it ran into opposition from two members, Senator Kemp and the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), who have included a dissenting report, the differences being largely due, I believe, to the fact that the hearings and visits appropriately were completed not by the full Committee but by a subcommittee. I move:
That the House take note of the report.
(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —-The time allotted for statements on this report has expired. In accordance with sessional order 102B, the debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:

(1) having been appalled at the coup in the Soviet Union, congratulates the Soviet people and elected leaders, such as Mr Boris Yeltsin, for their amazing courage in standing against force of arms to resist a return to dictatorship;

(2) urges Soviet leaders to continue the reform process which will give freedom and democracy to the Soviet people and a market economy which can maximise the economic potential of the Soviet Union to the benefit of all its people;
(3) recognises the pain and stress involved in restructuring the Soviet political and economic systems and urges the West to actively support such change; and

(4) further urges the Soviet leadership to free those republics, such as the Baltic States, which have been historically independent, were illegally incorporated and wish to return to the status of independent sovereign nations.

This notice was given on 22 August this year in the aftermath of the coup which all of us had watched with a great deal of concern, anguish and, of course, in the end with a great deal of pleasure and relief. We all had respect and admiration for the courage of people like Boris Yeltsin and the Soviet people who stood against the force of arms to resist a return to dictatorship. We saw the tanks on the streets; we saw the barricades that were erected; and we noted the tragic loss of life associated with those events.

We have seen the pace of economic and political reform in the Soviet Union in the last few months accentuated recently by the radical progress in arms reduction which has been greater than many of us and many analysts could have hoped for as little as two years ago, particularly when we saw the way in which the Soviet Army was behaving, in the Baltic states, in particular, where they occupied with great ferocity so many of the public buildings and places with a view to enforcing the regime.

At the time these events were taking place, I offered some words of caution, and I still do. The coup that we saw showed the fragility of the Soviet Union itself. It could have been successful, Mr Deputy Speaker. It was a matter of great concern that, with just a little more force and a little more ruthlessness, and if we had seen in cities like Moscow and Leningrad the same sense of purpose that the regime in China displayed in relation to taking people's lives and using troops hardened in warfare, it may well have been a different outcome. While communism has been abandoned, it is not yet certain, in my view, that democracy as we know it will or can prevail or that the process of reconstruction will not prove to be too awesome a task to achieve.

These are some of the notes of caution that I think we have to display ourselves at this time as we watch events still unfolding. At the time of the coup that saw the Soviet Union teetering once again on the brink of totalitarianism, I raised the fear that we could be lulled into a false sense of security because it seemed that the coup had been so resoundingly crushed. I urged vigilance and continued concern.

There are two reasons why it is more important now in the harsh reality of the aftermath of those events that we keep these matters in mind. The first is political. The coup attempt was clearly a watershed in the process that began with Gorbachev's accession to power. The leaders of the coup had previously supported the need for economic reform, but they faltered when it came to some of the major obstacles in that process: the growing challenge to the authority of the Communist Party represented by the rise of people such as Boris Yeltsin and the democratically elected mayors of Leningrad, now St Petersburg, and Moscow; and the apparent disintegration of the Soviet state, represented by the secessionist movements in the Baltic republics but also elsewhere in the Soviet Union.

The failure of the coup has left the forces of revision in disarray. It needs to be understood that some of the structures of power which they utilise to make their abortive bid still remain--the army and the KGB. The only one that seems to have been seriously attacked at this point in time is the Communist Party. Many of those structures of power are subject to the control of the office of the Mayor of Moscow, Gavriil Popov, and the office of the President of the Russian Federation, Boris Yeltsin. While this may make them appear more benign, the power structures remain. I think this should lead us to treat the situation with some caution.

There is still government by decree and the newly formed Anti-Constitutional Activities Committee is consumed with purging government posts of the now banned Communist Party members. Democracy is unlikely to flourish where freedom of speech and association is still not permitted, even if it is by the enemy. Despite the impressive display of unity exhibited during the resistance to the coup, the new leaders have now to show some unity of purpose in grappling with the real dangers posed to their embryonic statehood. The economic crisis, social disorder, ethnic discontent and the national dissolution threaten to consume them before they have even begun the process of reform.

In ethnic and political terms, turmoil rages in Central Asia. Protesters are in the streets of Tadzhikistan after the republic's communist dominated Parliament failed to meet opposition demands to replace the newly installed communist President. There is a vicious conflict in Azerbaijan over the territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, which lies in the muslim Azerbaijan, but is also claimed by Christian Armenia.

There are many new, emerging republics which contain ethnic minorities, and the challenge to each of them is to ensure that the rights of minorities are fully protected. The nationalities question long proved to be a thorn in the side of the old regime and its collapse will invariably mean that the long oppressed minorities will want to reclaim and assert their cultural identity in any new order. It must be assumed that there will be an increased potential for bitter conflict as a result.

Surely the single most urgent problem facing the Soviet Union is in relation to its economy. Honourable members will recall that President Gorbachev and the republican leaders were about to sign a new union treaty ceding more control to the republics when the abortive coup was staged. Mr Gorbachev and Mr Yeltsin are now in the process of drawing up a new version of the treaty. All the republics recognise the need to maintain economic ties with Russia, even if they sever political links, and it is perhaps the only way that economic disaster can be averted.

Respected economist Grigory Yavlinsky has drafted a 500-day plan which calls for a rapid lifting of price controls, a quick switch to private control of most industries and private individual property. Several of the republics have indicated that they will sign the treaty before October 15.

These measures in themselves create enormous upheaval to which no obvious solution presents itself. The success of this radical plan is largely dependent upon ratification by Russia. As yet, Boris Yeltsin--there were some alarming suggestions that he had suffered recent bouts of illness; he is on holidays until later today--has not indicated whether or not Russia will support this move. The task of reconstruction will be made all the more difficult if a consensus cannot be reached on the future political structures and relationships within the new union.

The Ukraine, a republic--a matter of some comment and a resolution that I hope to move on another General Business Thursday--has indicated that any political and economic union must not too closely bind it to the Russian Federation. The Ukraine's aspiration for independence is very clear. As a region which produces nearly a quarter of the Soviet Union's food and a quarter of its coal and is responsible for a fifth of its machinery and chemical industries, its role in the current economic and politic negotiations is crucial. It also has nuclear weapons on its territory, although I welcome the comments from its leadership that it would prefer to see those weapons removed.

An economic and political treaty which provides for mutual cooperation between the republics is essential, but it is still a long term objective. In the meantime, the Soviet Union faces famine this winter and it has an external debt problem of quite significant proportions. The immediate crisis is still to be diverted, even with the provision of emergency aid by the United States, Japan and the European Community. Each of these states and units has pledged a total of something in the order of $A12 billion worth of food, medical supplies and aid to promote trade and economic activity and technical assistance.

This week, over 10,000 delegates--economic officials and senior bankers--will be attending the annual conference of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to discuss, amongst other things, the Soviet Union's need for loans to meet repayments on an $82 billion foreign debt and a huge infusion of capital to convert to a market economy. Academic and financial experts estimate that the Soviet Union will need up to $251 billion over the next 10 years if it is to rescue its economy. I think that demonstrates the enormity of the task that faces the Soviet Union.

The problems of the Soviet debt will be further exacerbated because of the collapse of Soviet trade, a big fall in its oil output, the requirement to meet principal and interest repayments of over $10 billion this year, and the withdrawal of short term credit loans by commercial banks. On top of this, there are concerns as to whether the debt will be divided up amongst the constituent republics or treated as a whole. The industrial powers have yet to endorse Moscow's application for full membership of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, which would allow the Soviets to borrow from organisations but with G7 backing. The IMF has created a special associate membership for the Soviet Union that will give it access to the Fund's technical expertise without, at this stage, entitling it to loans. The special access will allow Moscow to ask for technical assistance in budget planning, banking, management techniques and information in other fields needed to convert the former communist superpower into a free market economy.

However, full membership of the IMF will require key economic data on the Soviet Union to be provided, something which has not been made available for decades. In full membership negotiations this data will have to made available, including information on the size of its gold reserves, before any assessment can be made of the quota of capital to which the Soviet Union would be entitled if it ever moved to full membership. Of course, provision of this data would prove testing for glasnost. The task ahead is daunting and there is no guarantee that it can be achieved. We have no choice but to support actively the change that will bring about democracy for the Soviet peoples and a market economy that can maximise its potential.

The final part of this motion relates to the Baltic states and our desire to see their recognition. Happily, in the time that has elapsed since placing this motion on notice the Soviet Union has recognised the independence of the Baltic states. In the aftermath of the coup, Boris Yeltsin announced that the Soviet Federation recognised them as independent states and thus all but assured survival of the three new states as it triggered off a growing wave of international recognition. Australia belatedly recognised the Baltic states on 27 August. The Soviet Union recognised the independence of each of them on 6 September. The three states have since been admitted to the United Nations. The Soviet Union and Estonia reached an agreement in principle earlier this year that Soviet troops would be withdrawn. This accord is the first of its kind to lay down the specifics of a military pull-out from any of the three republics. It is believed that withdrawal could be completed within 12 months.

There is great cause for optimism. However, like the Soviet Union, the Baltic states desperately require international assistance. Although the richest of the Soviet republics, their industrial base is still antiquated and in need of support. I could go on to discuss ways and means by which Australia can offer assistance. The Baltic states have problems with populations of minorities, and I think Australia could offer a good deal of advice, because of its own multicultural background, on ways and means of adjusting to this reality. We need also to assist with expertise to ameliorate the serious problems they face in reconstruction. We need to assist in training their work forces and developing trade relations. I certainly hope we can establish consular and full diplomatic relations, which will enable each of those new countries to relate fully to Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —-Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It gives me great pleasure to second the motion, Mr Deputy Speaker. This is essentially a motion calling for the reform of the Soviet empire, its democratisation and its dissolution into nation states, and I support it.

SPEECH.PARA: My lifetime has witnessed the decline of many Europe-based imperial systems. In fact, I spent much of my youth in the capital of the largest--London--and hardly a year went by without the announcement of another province departing; usually a member of the royal family went and pulled down the flag. Hardly a year went by without reports of battles in distant lands as imperial forces tried to hang on or, more usually, tried to construct a post-imperial structure closer to London's liking. I would have to say that, in retrospect, the British Empire was dismantled in a tolerably civilised way by the historical standards of other empires, including those of the Dutch, the French and the Portuguese. And we are about to make an assessment of the costs of dismembering Moscow's empire.

A considerable volume of literature is devoted to the rise and fall of empires, to such an extent that it is nowadays divided into theoretical and methodological categories, with people having different opinions and with controversies raging in academic journals. But the essential story on the rise and fall of empires appears to be this: a state emerges with the power, energy and ambition to dominate its neighbours; it establishes a regional or wider hegemony; it then grows flabby on the fruits of exploitation; its subject peoples revolt; and it then tries to find its way in the world with a lesser status in terms of prestige, power and wealth. This, I think, is what is happening with the Soviets.

I first visited the Soviet Union in 1968, and then again in 1973. I would say that it was then at the apex of its imperial power and probably of its wealth, too. In 1979 I made the train journey from Khabarovsk to London, and got off at a number of places in the Soviet Union, including Moscow, where I spent some time at the state university. I must say that at the time the signs of decay were pretty unmistakable, and they had already occasioned widespread debates within the Western specialist literature of Sovietologists about the future of the Soviet Union.

This was not just idle academic speculation, because it emerged 10 years ago--that is, in the 1980 presidential election campaign in the United States--as the Republican strategy for defeating the Soviets without resorting to war. What the Republicans intended to do was confront the Soviet empire militarily, particularly on its edges, by supporting subject people's revolts; blockade the economy by depriving the Soviets of access to modern technology and Western capital; and confront them in an arms race in which, if the Soviets tried to match the United States, they would probably go broke. I must say that, whatever my reservations at the time might have been, the strategy worked.

By the early 1980s, the Soviet empire in fact comprised three separate parts. The first was the Soviet state proper, which was autocratic, run by the nomenclatura, centrally planned, and had a population that appeared cowed and sullen and an economy that appeared stagnant. The second part was the satellite system that had been acquired, mostly in the 1940s by force majeur, mainly for security reasons and had been created into a system of mini-Stalinist states called the People's Democracies of Eastern Europe. The third component was the broader empire that had been acquired after 1950, in the Third World mostly, which was characterised by loose alliances, such as that with India; military marriages of convenience, such as those with Vietnam and Cuba; subsidised states which had grown up in Africa and the Middle East; and, by the early 1980s, the failing war of conquest in Afghanistan.

When the Brezhnev dictatorship, which had lasted for nearly two decades, ended with his death in 1982, it was clear to most Western economic observers that the Soviet empire was overextended and facing decline. This was admitted by the Soviet leadership, however, only in March 1985 when Gorbachev came to power in the Kremlin. To his credit, between 1985 and 1989, Gorbachev undertook a number of reforms which made him Man of the Year in a number of Western places--including Time magazine--without, unfortunately for him, gaining him corresponding popularity status within his own imperial state.

However, the reforms were to be welcomed and I think they should be remembered. He cut a number of arms control deals with the West--from his point of view, to save the Soviet budget. He withdrew the Soviet imperium from the Third World, cut subsidies to clients and slowed the massive transfers of Soviet arms to Third World clients--again to save money but with a corresponding benefit to the international system. The full effects of this withdrawal are still being worked out. I had the good fortune to attend the CPA conference in India a couple of weeks ago and it is quite clear that that country has been forced to cut its defence budget as a result of the changed relationship with the Soviet Union and is now having to relate to the IMF financial structure as a result of the absence of effective Soviet subsidies through trade relations. So the full effects of the withdrawal of the Soviet imperium are still being played out--in the Caribbean with Cuba, in South East Asia with Vietnam, in the Indian subcontinent particularly with India, and in the Middle East--and I think most of the effects will prove to be beneficial.

In 1989, the Soviets encouraged an acceleration of the process of change and reform in the eastern European people's democracy, so-called, they being the second component of the imperial system. They hoped to see emerge more popular reformist-type socialist regimes, and they put up alternative communist candidates for leadership. But they had seriously underestimated the unpopularity of these mini-Stalinisms. They watched with dismay but, again to Gorbachev's credit, with inactivity as the communist system itself was everywhere swept aside.

Domestically, coming back to the imperial state itself, Gorbachev had undertaken the two reforms of perestroika and glasnost with a view to reinvigorating political life and, more importantly, bumping up economic activity in the face of economic stagnation, which had by then been going on for nearly a decade. These reforms failed in the critical tests. Soviet economic output and per capita incomes did not go up with the Gorbachev inspired reforms; they actually declined. By 1990, the Gorbachev leadership faced the critical question of how to continue to reform the Soviet state proper--which was all they had left because it had been shed of its strategic and imperial ambitions.

Unfortunately, the story now takes a bad turn. Gorbachev chose to lurch back to the hardliners in the nomenclatura. As I have noted in this chamber on a few occasions over the last year, Gorbachev reverted to repression. In the constituent national republics, notably the Baltic states, he used the world's diversion to the Gulf war to try to reconquer Lithuania and, during the same time, democratically elected politicians were again repressed. Shevardnadze said as much during his resignation speech of last year when he warned that Gorbachev was again reverting to the old hardliners in the nomenclatura, and the possibility of a coup had come into existence. Unfortunately for Gorbachev, however, the five years of reform that he had led were now too strongly in place for him to stop them and, as in the classic French cartoon, he was now shouting, `Wait for me, I'm your leader'.

By mid-1991, the cutting edge of change had moved away from the Gorbachev forces, I believe, and had become the constituent national republics which were each demanding freedom from Moscow, which was now represented by Gorbachev. Gorbachev had become the defender of the system. It was, indeed, the proposal to cut a new federal deal by the Treaty of Union which triggered the coup, since the plotters viewed such a deal as a step from which the Soviet Union could not recover--and I think they were probably right. What they underestimated was their own incompetence, as the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) has quite rightly pointed out.

Boris Yeltsin, during the abortive coup, symbolised the forces which defeated the coup of 19 to 21 August because by that stage he, in the democratisation of the political process, had displaced Gorbachev--not just because Gorbachev was detained in the Crimea but because Yeltsin was actually a popularly elected politician and because he was the leader of a proper state, the Russian Federation, and not of the Soviet imperial system. As this motion notes--and I agree with it entirely--he displayed enormous courage in confronting the armed forces that he did. At the time, he was not to know the outcome was to be as beneficial as it was, and I might note that so many citizens have come forward in the process of the democratisation of the communist system that one's faith in the basic integrity of human nature has been reasserted.

The defeat of the coup has ensured the departure of nation based republics from the Soviet state, although I think the pace and degree of their departure will be determined by the degree to which they were integrated into the Soviet system. The three Baltic states got out pretty easily and pretty quickly, and I am delighted to say that Australia recognised them very early.

I personally do not expect the Ukraine to be very far behind. It is a nation of over 50 million people which has been most cruelly treated by the Stalinist system. It has legitimate aspirations to independence which it has declared. It has a referendum coming up in December to ratify this, and as soon as the result is known and the Ukraine meets the formal legal requirements of defined boundaries, a clear population, a government in control, and one capable of undertaking foreign relations, then I for one will be urging the Australian Government to recognise it as soon as possible and to establish diplomatic and trading relations with the Ukraine.

The future of the other states, I think, is more difficult to anticipate, and I concur with some of the remarks made by the honourable member for Dundas. It should be borne in mind that the decolonisation processes involved with other European imperial systems have also created difficulties, both in the former colonies and in the former imperial society. I do not believe Australia has fully recovered from its presence in the British imperial system, and the British themselves, 50 years after making the decision to decolonise, are still sending members of the royal family to far-flung places to pull down the flag.

Armenia and Azerbaijan, as the honourable member for Dundas has pointed out, have problems of enclaves and territorial difficulties. The five muslim states of Central Asia will have difficulty moving out of the Soviet system because of their low level of economic development and their integration, particularly in the energy distribution system. Moldavia may choose to join with Romania, and Georgia obviously has difficulties with its internal political process, which is leading to civil conflict. I think the Russian Federation under Yeltsin is destined to go its own way eventually, and I hope it does so without traditional Russian-style hegemonic ambitions with respect to its neighbours. This motion rightly congratulates the defeat of the coup, and I support it.

I mention three short term difficulties to which I think we ought to pay some attention. First, the huge arsenal that was built up by the Soviet system, which is by and large now surplus to requirements, needs to be looked at very carefully, particularly its nuclear component. I am delighted not only that President Bush made an offer of very rapid demobilisation of nuclear strategic arsenals mutually but also that the Soviet Government quickly acceded to this in a very positive way. Secondly, we should support, I believe, the orderly departure of nations such as the Ukraine from the Soviet state and establish diplomatic and trading relations with them as soon as it becomes possible.

Thirdly, we should note that the people, particularly of the Russian Federation, have absolutely no experience whatsoever in the operation of a democratic political system or a free-market economic system, both of which they are trying to establish. As a result, I believe it will be incumbent on the West, for good reasons of strategic self-interest, to provide financial and economic assistance while the Russian Federation in particular makes the transition from its past imperial system to a democratic and market oriented economic and political situation. That is going to encounter obstacles, and economic assistance will ease them through these.

I am delighted to note this week that the G7 group of leading industrial nations is putting together a $9 billion economic assistance package. At the Japanese Embassy last night I was assured that the Japanese will be putting up $2.5 billion towards this without any preconditions and without any notice being taken of the claims they make on the famous four islands. This is in recognition of the overall need for the West to ease the transition of the Soviet state from its previous imperial status to one of an ordinary country with which we can all do business in an equitable and friendly manner.

I believe that we in Australia should be prepared, whatever difficulties we may see ourselves as having economically--and they pale into insignificance compared with the countries we are talking about this morning--to provide whatever assistance we can. Last year we agreed to contribute to the European Bank for reconstruction in eastern Europe. I think things have moved much more quickly since then. The situation is now better and, in some ways, more desperate. The kind of assistance that West Germany gave to East Germany to produce the unified German state is not likely to be available to many of the other territories of the former Soviet imperial system. We have a strategic self-interest in ensuring that this transition is made as easily as possible.

I point out that the break-up of the Soviet empire is likely to present new challenges to Australia as agricultural economies such as the Ukraine, the Soviet Union and to some degree India, which have been stifled by their planning system in the past, are likely to become much more productive under a free market system and we are going to have to compete with their products on the international marketplace. Compared with the opportunities and beneficial effects of this change, I believe the economic competition that is going to be offered is of marginal importance.

The strategic threat of the last 40 years of generalised and even nuclear war has now been greatly reduced, and democracy has spread to another half billion human beings. I commend this motion, and it gives me great pleasure to have seconded it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am pleased to support this motion before the House today. It is a great opportunity which we as an Australian Parliament have to express our views on matters such as this. This motion was brought into the House on 22 August by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock)--about three days after the coup attempt occurred. It shows the sort of initiative which he has taken in this regard and his interest in these matters. His initiative has given us an opportunity to debate a topic in a bipartisan way. It is a great opportunity for Australia to express its profound feelings about the fact that the coup was not completed and did not take hold.
