I think that is something which we as Australians, who live in a territory which has not known any substantial disturbance, do not appreciate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to highlight a few points which are outlined in the motion before the House. Firstly, I would like to dwell on the amazing courage of Boris Yeltsin, which has been mentioned in the motion. Before I do that it would be interesting to look at his background. It fleshes out and gives us a little more appreciation of the nature of the man whom we see as a figure looming very large in the Russian republic. We trust that his health will stand up and that he will continue to be a force for freedom and democracy in that part of the world.

Boris Yeltsin has been hailed as a would-be dictator by his enemies and the only true democrat by his friends. He started his life as a gang fighter in the Urals. He got good marks at school in everything except discipline; he got a teacher dismissed for making the pupils bring food for her pig, and he faced up to men who claimed they had the army and the KGB behind them. He was a very strong willed character very early on in life. Obviously, that strength of backbone and the fact that he was a person of independent thought has served the Russian people very well in 1991.

Further, we find that basically he had a pretty rough childhood, breaking his nose in one of the many gang fights and losing two fingers when he hit a stolen grenade with a hammer. I am not sure whether he was worried about the same reaction when he decided to stand up to the Soviet Union tanks when they rumbled towards the Russian Parliament in August. Nevertheless, after surviving a grenade attack initiated by himself, we find that as a teenager he threw himself into sport and became a women's volleyball coach before settling down as a civil engineer.

That is a very sketchy background to this man whom we now look upon and admire for his amazing courage. The motion is quite right in congratulating him for his amazing courage. We have to recognise that there had been 70 years of an authoritarian, repressive, dictatorial, inhumane system in the Soviet Union and that it had not effectively been broken. On 19 August a coup occurred. The democratically elected President of the Russian republic had to make a choice. Was he going to go forward with his desire for freedom and stand up for democracy or would he have to buckle under?

When we remember some of the history of how repressive that regime has been in the Soviet Union, recognising that that system literally starved millions of its own people down in Georgia and the Ukraine at one stage, apart from many other aspects which we know only too well, we admire Boris Yeltsin because he did have the courage to stand up and take on the instigators of the coup. There was one TV program which I vividly remember and in which Yeltsin was standing up and he gave all the body language that, come what may, he was not going to be moved. It was that sort of courage which many of us will remember him for, no matter what his contribution is going to be in the future.

It does take tremendous courage in those circumstances, when one's parliament is surrounded by tanks and by people who are willing and ready and have others behind them in another political system ready to give the order to fire and to use their military might to bring down a fledgling democratic system, to stand up to them. As members of parliament, we should admire the courage shown to us by Boris Yeltsin in this coup.

The second part of the motion expresses the hope that there will be a continuing process for freedom and democracy. That is something which we take for granted. Yet, the Soviet Union, which comprises a large surface area of the world--whether we can call it an individual unit is hard to say--has not experienced that sort of freedom for 70 years, has not experienced what it means to go through elections, and in many respects probably does not have the skills nor the resources to handle the freedom which is now available to its people. We certainly wish the Russian people well in that fledgling start to experiencing true democracy and freedom. It will be an experience which will go on for many generations.

Why do we say this? I believe we say it because we as Australians and as members of an Australian parliament believe that individual people, by experiencing freedom and democracy, get the greatest sense of fulfilment for their own personal lives and for the community in which they live. That is why we believe in freedom and democracy, because it brings a sense of self-fulfilment, self-esteem, of being in the community, of working through ideas together, rather than feeling dominated by people in positions of power. Instead of being spectators or people cringing on the edge of life, people in a democracy are able to be participators. It is this process which is now becoming available to the Soviet people, and all Australians should encourage and do everything within their power to assist those people to reach the fulfilment which we experience in this great country.

The third point in the motion is about the pain and stress which will be involved in restructuring the Soviet Union. Indeed, there will be immense pain and immense stress. We only have to think about the social changes which will occur during that process--that an archaic system is being changed into a modern one; that people will realise now that they are not going to be chased at night by secret police and that that fear can be removed. But for many people in Russia that fear is etched on their minds, and it will take years for them to change their attitudes and behaviour into positive attitudes and to begin feeling and experiencing what genuine freedom is all about. It is not something that can happen overnight. We ought not, as the West, expect that technological changes, industrial relations changes, social changes and democratic changes can take place overnight. We need to be patient, we need to be encouraging and we need to be sympathetic to the processes and the difficulties and stresses which will occur. I have great pleasure in supporting the motion. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I also wish to support the motion. In so doing, however, there are some emphases I would like to make which are missing from the motion. It is all very well for us to urge various things on the Soviet leaders and on the Soviet people. I join others in congratulating leaders such as Mr Boris Yeltsin on their courage in opposing the coup. It would have been fine if there had been some recognition in this motion of some of the responsibility of the West for its failures with respect to the Soviet Union.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, I will refer to what is almost universally accepted as having brought on the coup--the failure of the West to give any significant aid to President Gorbachev when he went to the meeting of the G7. He put the case very clearly and said, `Look, the situation in the Soviet Union is very serious. There are conservatives who are trying to bring back the old regime. It is essential for us to do something, and I appeal to you to give us that assistance'. Unfortunately President Gorbachev got very little assistance; in fact, he was sent packing and told to go off and bring in more reforms. As a result, the conservatives in the Soviet Union were able to rally their forces and managed to achieve the coup.

Fortunately, not only for the Soviet Union but for the whole world, the coup was defeated. I say `fortunately' because one can imagine what might have happened if it had continued and succeeded. In terms of world events what would have happened is almost too difficult to contemplate. A dictatorship of the kind proposed by the coup leaders--if they had the power to impose it--would have resulted in the Soviet Union immediately breaking up into individual republics. We would have had wars everywhere, we would have had attacks on the Baltic states, we would have had crises with the West and we would have had crises in the Third World. It is quite clear in some respects that we do not quite recognise the enormity of events which occurred in terms of the overthrow of that coup.

One writer said that he remembers the 1917 revolution being described as the 10 days that shook the world. In some respects the occurrence of the Soviet coup and the overthrow of that coup I believe will be recorded in history as of similar significance in terms of the direction taken by the Soviet peoples and the Soviet Union.

I will now refer to the second aspect of the motion; that is, encouraging the move towards freedom, democracy and a market economy. Before the coup President Gorbachev was encouraging all of those things. It is all right to encourage those things in theoretical terms and say that this is what is needed. Indeed, there were significant moves towards more freedom through the concept of glasnost, more political participation, and there were some moves towards a market economy.

Essentially, the problem faced by the Soviet Union, and indeed the problem it continues to face, is this: how does one transform a huge confederation of states such as the Soviet Union into a market economy? That is easy to say, but if we ask people how this is to be done in terms of either a general theory or a practice, it is a much more difficult situation. While people in the West were urging this transformation, very few were prepared to put down a blueprint as to how that should be achieved.

If we look at what has happened with the economies of eastern Europe that have tried to achieve this transformation, we see that very often they have made a stab in the dark. Each of them has tried different ways of achieving this transformation; I do not think any of them have been overwhelmingly successful. Some have put themselves in very difficult positions, such as Poland, which has difficulties with its economy.

So it is one thing to say that this transformation should take place; it is another to work out and secure ways in which it should take place. I do not say that this is entirely a responsibility of the West. It is also a responsibility of the thinkers, theoreticians and planners in the Soviet Union. On that score, there is no doubt that they failed dismally. Let us hope that a restructuring of the Soviet economy will be achieved in a quick way and that it will be done in accordance with some blueprint that makes sense.

The challenge for the Soviet peoples and the Soviet Union is more than that. At the same time as it is trying to effect this transformation, it has to work out the correct formula in relation to the nationalist ambitions of the various peoples and states that constitute the current Soviet Union. As everyone is aware, a large number of those states now want to be independent nations. This is true of the Ukraine, it is true of Georgia, it is true of a number of others. The question then is: what sort of political structure can there be that somehow keeps a confederation or unity of the Soviet Union and yet allows self-determination and independent nationhood for these countries that wish to have it?

These are some of the biggest problems facing the modern world in terms of international relations. It is interesting that while many of us in the West wish for some peaceful outcome, an outcome that somehow keeps together the Soviet Union but also allows for independent states, we have not been too forthcoming with formulas as to how this should take place. I do not know, from the reading I have done and from the studies that are coming out of various institutes around the world, including institutes of international relations, whether much advice has been given to President Gorbachev, for example, about how this is to be done.

The Soviet peoples have had to face one crisis after another: the transformation of the old Stalinist system, the transformation of the economy, and now the question of how to have a confederation of states that on the one hand are independent countries to a considerable degree and on the other hand are able to work together. These are the challenges being faced in the Soviet Union at the moment. They are momentous challenges not only for the Soviet peoples but also for the world. If they are not achieved properly, there will be a lot of strife. One issue in relation to achieving this is the protection of the minorities in each of those states. If there are going to be independent states, there will be minorities in each of them. It is not enough for the international community to say, `This is an internal matter'. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Like the other participants from both sides of the chamber in this debate, I begin my remarks by congratulating the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) on his initiative in putting this notice of a motion on the Notice Paper and for giving the Australian Parliament the chance to express its support for the great changes that are going on today in the Soviet Union. I see these great social and economic changes as fundamentally and essentially being a quest for freedom. The upheaval in the Eastern bloc is all about the peoples of those nations and their quest for freedom. I think that once again it demonstrates that one can brutally suppress the human spirit for decades, but one can never truly extinguish it. I believe that is the case because the essence of man, woman and humankind is the quest to be free. To flow on from that, the human quest for all of us is to live in a society of free people.

SPEECH.PARA: From my political beliefs, I do not think one can go past the statement of that great nineteenth century British philosopher, John Stuart Mill. To paraphrase the essential political statement about personal and political freedom that he put down in the treatise on Liberty, he said that people should be free to do whatever they want to do providing it does not adversely affect or interfere with anybody else doing exactly the same. For me, that has always been my fundamental tenet in politics when addressing questions of personal and political freedom. In a bipartisan sense, that is why we are supporting this motion.

Looking at its first proposition, we were appalled at the coup in the Soviet Union. We congratulate the Soviet people and their elected leaders, such as Mr Boris Yeltsin, for their amazing courage in standing against the force of arms to resist a return to dictatorship in that country.

Looking at the second part of the motion, we also urge the Soviet leaders to continue the reform process which will give freedom and democracy to the Soviet people. I do not think one can go past Churchill when considering democracy. Democracy is not perfect; nothing that humankind can devise is perfect. To paraphrase Churchill, he said, curiously, that democracy is the worst system known to man but for all the rest. It is a curious way to talk. Basically, he was recognising the fact that democracy is not perfect, but compared with every other political system yet devised by mankind, it is far superior.

We should always remember, when we take for granted the democratic system under which we live in this country, that the fundamental right of all of us is that on a regular periodic basis we can come together and choose who are to form our governments. There are no tanks rolling down the street; there are no Molotov cocktails being thrown in suburban lounge rooms; no-one gets killed; no-one is incarcerated.

For my money communism or Marxism, or the practical application of it over the last 70 or 80 years, has been one of the cruelest hoaxes. It has been one of the greatest outrages and it has been one of the most profound tragedies of the twentieth century. It has led to millions of people living in conditions of economic servitude and millions more living in actual incarceration and slavery. It has led to the death of yet millions again under those systems. If one goes back to the fundamental Marxist theory--because theory is all it ever was--Marx predicted the so-called withering away of the state instruments of Government with free men supposedly thereafter living in a system of communal fraternity.

I say it was a cruel hoax from the beginning because, like any other millenarian movement, many of them religious-based promising heaven on earth, no such thing was ever envisaged in a practical sense--never mind the excesses of so-called Stalinism. One of the most fascinating things arising out of the changes in the Soviet Union is that documentary evidence is now coming to light that even Lenin never, ever pretended to believe in such nonsense; that, from the beginning, Lenin had in mind the prospect of establishing cynically a totalitarian government by the elite over the masses. Millions have been deprived, downtrodden; they, so labelled by the theorists as the proletarian masses, were seduced--if not duped--by the belief that their position could be improved through a false concept of a class war. Those who were not duped or seduced were bludgeoned into submission or eliminated.

This so-called theoretical concept of communism or Marxism has been one of the most profound tragedies of history. It is tremendously encouraging for all of us to see the peoples of the Eastern bloc, who have been subjugated under that system for the last 70-odd years, now throwing it off, and throwing it off so comprehensively.

In this motion we urge the Soviet leaders to continue to work towards a market economy which can maximise the economic potential of the Soviet Union to the benefit of all its people. Like democracy, free markets are not perfect, either. Free enterprise is not perfect; it is just that it achieves better outcomes than any other economic system devised by mankind.

We should look at the comparisons over the last 50-odd years. Despite all of the anti-United States propaganda that we hear from time to time, look at how the United States economy and the outcomes it has been able to achieve for the vast majority of its people compare with those of the Soviet economy. There is absolutely no comparison. This comparison comes into even sharper relief when one compares the West German economy with the East German economy. Both sides of this nation emerged from World War II in an absolutely appalling condition. Yet over the last 50 years there have been completely different outcomes due to completely different systems. The free market economies have won out every time, hands down.
The third part of this motion recognises the pain and stress that will be involved in the restructuring of the communist countries of eastern Europe. I agree with the honourable

member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous): unless we support them, we cannot just optimistically and enthusiastically talk about the changes that these people are moving towards. They will require financial and economic assistance, and social and economic expertise. That is why this motion is bipartisan. Look at what is now being achieved in East Germany because of the support of the old West Germany. These countries are in a unique position. They have come together as one new Germany. Not every country has the same opportunity. But we in the West will have to support the Eastern bloc as the countries come to grips with these changes in their quest for economic and social freedom.

Finally, this motion urges the Soviet leadership to free those republics that have been under the Soviet bloc since World War II. I have said that I believe the essence of mankind is its quest for freedom. The logical extension of that is for mankind to freely associate as a race or as an ethnic group, as an historical nation, in that modern concept that we know as a nation state.

I certainly support that last request in this motion. These changes must continue, not only in the Eastern bloc but also in Asia, in Africa and in South America. Hopefully, when they do we can look forward to the world being not only a freer and better place for all of its citizens, but also a much safer one as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace Mr E.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As I sat in my office considering what I would say in relation to this motion currently before the House, the first thought that came to me was the absolute consistency of the old adage, `The glorious uncertainty of politics'. As we have seen recently, both at home and abroad, political climates can change with almost obscene haste. Political icons can be torn down in the twinkling of an eye, and seemingly impossible political scenarios can become a reality virtually overnight. Even so, the changes that have taken place in the USSR over the past few months are of breathtakingly enormous proportions. Such has been the incredible haste of the pace of change in the ex-communist monolith that part (4) of the excellent motion of the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) is now semi-redundant, despite the fact that notice of the motion was given on only 22 August.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the long awaited and lifelong dream for many Baltic states refugees who fled to Australia in the wake of the shameful German-Soviet annexation--the granting of independence to Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. Notwithstanding this fact, the motion of the honourable member for Dundas deserves wholehearted support in this House. It is a motion which registers our disgust at the reactionary coup that could have hurled the world back into the Cold War had not the Soviet people and leaders such as Boris Yeltsin risked all for the new order.

It is also a motion which offers encouragement to the various Soviet leaders to continue the now inevitable push to a market economy, which recognises the stresses and strains which will be felt by the Soviet people during the difficult restructuring process. At the present time, as the coup euphoria dies and the realisation of the hard slog ahead sets in, those are important points which need to be seen to be coming from the West.

Although the honourable member for Dundas has not specifically mentioned it, I believe that he has meant to include the majority of the Soviet armed forces in the congratulatory first point of his motion. Obviously, without the support of the Soviet officer corps and their men, the coup would not have been halted and the world would now be mourning another Tiananmen Square-style communist massacre.

When one considers the hitherto privileged position of the armed forces in the old communist USSR, the restraint and social responsibility exhibited by the army during the latter stages of the coup was an incredible phenomenon. It was a response which showed in dynamic terms that the flame of freedom, when allowed to flicker, is an incredibly difficult force to extinguish. Although many mocked him for being too slow and too careful, Mikhail Gorbachev deserves much of the credit for the existence of that flame--mainly through his glasnost and perestroika programs. That Gorbachev was criticised for the slow pace of reform and yet faced the reactionary coup demonstrates the enormity of the challenge which he faced all along.

The fact is that almost all of us saw the coup coming, such was the discomfort being felt by the Kremlin godfathers. How many of us, however, could visualise the dramatic events of the last night of the coup when the perpetrators bundled themselves into their black limousines to seek their President's forgiveness--a truly amazing occurrence, followed by an even more amazing chain of events in the next few months. It is this chain of latter events which should not be forgotten in our consideration of this motion.

As honourable members will appreciate, we are now watching the unravelling of more than 70 years worth of shonky deals and outright land grabs in central and eastern Europe. The threat of a nuclear holocaust may have receded very sharply with this process, begun by the de-Stalinisation of Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, the overthrow of Ceaucescu in Romania, and the reunification of Germany.

The threat of less total conflict, however, has not necessarily gone away. Europe is a hotbed of ancient ethnic rivalries, which in many cases have been fuelled by the ravages of war and the arbitrary imposition of national boundaries. The break-up of Yugoslavia stands as an excellent and horrific example of the possible ramifications of the unleashing of those pent up ethnic frustrations. In the power vacuum which has been created by the failure of the coup in the USSR, there has occurred a natural realignment of political strengths along ethnic lines.

In the earlier post-war days there was some discussion of the changing of national boundaries, and ethnically based republics were faced with the actual possibility of walking away as independent states. Although much of this earlier emotive talk seems to have settled down, it now must be recognised that the USSR is still in a state of considerable flux. On 24 August the Ukraine announced its decision to operate as an independent state and several other republics are considering their options.

To add to the confusion, there is considerable doubt as to the status and role of the central government and the President, Mr Gorbachev, himself. Although those matters will no doubt be sorted out in time, a great deal of goodwill is going to be necessary from all sides. The various players in the USSR will need to understand that, with each defection from the fold, the combined economic might of the United States will be reduced, and this must have strong ramifications on the union's ability to remain as a world superpower.

For the West, there are also many and varied challenges. We will need to reward a region that is breaking from its horrific past by ensuring that the progress of reform is given every chance to succeed. The West will need to be careful that it is not overly harsh in its judgment of the speed of reform, nor too easy in its help so that reform is unnecessarily delayed. Above all else, however remote the possibility, the West must ensure that it does not exacerbate ethnic tensions nor encourage the last vestiges of reactionism to have one last tilt at the reins of power. The honourable member for Dundas has moved a motion that is worthy of bipartisan support in this House. It is an appropriate motion for a most important occurrence in the scheme of things, and I therefore recommend it to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House commend to the Government the introduction of a scheme modelled on the British tax exempt special savings account in order to facilitate both the growth of domestic savings and the encouragement of Australian investment in Australian domestic industry.

In the financial statement and Budget report of 1990-91 the then British Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major, introduced into Britain a novel innovation called tax exempt special savings accounts. They were explained in paragraph 4.08 of his Budget statement in the following terms:
Savings

Tax Exempt Special Savings Accounts will be introduced from 1 January 1991. Individuals will be able to deposit up to #9000 over a five year period. In the first year up to #3000 may be deposited and in subsequent years #1800 (#150 a month), subject to the overall limit. Provided no withdrawal of capital is made during the five years, the interest will be totally exempt from tax. There will be an option to withdraw some interest as it arises, but if capital is withdrawn early, then all the interest will be subject to tax.

Subsequent to the announcement in the Budget, the tax exempt special savings account scheme was introduced and the British Government published information document IR114 entitled TESSA: Tax Free Interest for Taxpayers. This sets out the key points of the scheme that is now operating, and I will go through the key points one by one so that what is a quite novel idea is explained to the House.

Taxpayers are limited to one account. A person can open only one account with either a bank or a building society. No person can hold more than one TESSA account at a time. Husbands and wives can each open separate accounts; one account is held per taxpayer. As the Chancellor said in his Budget Speech, a person can deposit to a maximum of #9,000 over five years--#3,000 in the first year and #1,800 in the second and subsequent years, to the #9,000 maximum.

One cannot retain tax exempt status if there is any withdrawal of capital. The scheme envisages access to interest under some circumstances during the period in which funds are held in a TESSA account. However, once capital is touched the special tax exempt status falls away and the account is held simply as an ordinary bank account.

The accumulated funds are held tax free at the end of five years. The information brochure gives a number of examples explaining how the system will operate and the like. Later in my speech I will go through examples of tax accounts now operated by various banks and building societies and the kinds of financial benefits that flow to investors in these portfolios.

The tax exempt status is preserved on death. I think the important point in terms of arguments about intervention in markets and the like is that the TESSA scheme is market driven. It depends on the economics of the investment industry where funds will be invested. Building societies and banks determine the rate of interest payable, how often the interest will be credited and whether the interest rate will be fixed or variable. In practice, there has been a scramble to invest in TESSA accounts. John Major, in introducing this scheme, called it an opportunity to revive the culture of thrift and to do something about the low domestic rate of savings.

In Australia we have the same need to accumulate greater national savings to back up what we would hope would be more investment in our infrastructure and industry. There is a secondary reason, other than the increasing accumulation of savings, which in itself is important. There is also the question of equity, particularly equity for the small wealth holder. At the moment, different forms of holdings of wealth are differentially treated. For example, if one is very wealthy and is able to invest in land or property, to an extent one's wealth holdings are sheltered because even under the capital gains system one is taxed only on the post-inflation earnings. In other words, one discounts the capital gains for inflation and the gain is taxed only after that. The small wealth holder who has $5,000 or $7,000 in a bank pays tax on every dollar of the interest. There is no deduction for the inroads of inflation. So there is a corrosive and unfair difference between the two forms of wealth holding.

When we take out the things that are politically unacceptable to deal with, we see that the level playing field is even more distorted. Of course, the one area that is peculiarly exempt, even from capital gains tax, is the family home. I am not suggesting in any way that something should be done about that, but because the family home is tax exempt and because that is where many substantial wealth holders put most of their wealth, the distortions and differences in the tax treatment of small wealth holders and large wealth holders are exaggerated. TESSA is a way of addressing this problem.

Most economists would say that there is a real and proper requirement, on a horizontal equity basis, to treat savings in a more appropriate way. It would be too costly to index savings across the board. That is the reason why governments and oppositions have not put that up. If it is costed out, it is seen to be extremely expensive. The equity principle is accepted, but the cost measure is too difficult. The TESSA scheme, however, is beautifully targeted because of its cap of #9,000--translated to Australian dollar terms, its cap of $30,000, similarly structured, might be appropriate--protects the equity interests of small wealth holders and at the same time increases national savings.

Has this scheme worked? Certainly it has. In Great Britain there has been a flow of investment funds into TESSA accounts. Rates in those accounts are very competitive. Vivien Goldsmith, the money editor of the Independent on Sunday, said in an article of 20 January 1991:
The TESSA scramble for funds is sending the rates sky high. It has been very popular.
Lindsay Cook, an author in the Guardian, said:
As Tessamania continues, several institutions have this week improved their tax-free accounts or introduced new ones.

If we go through the press clippings from Britain we can see the comments of financial analysts looking at the various maturity values of TESSA accounts. For example, an investment of #9,000 over five years in, for instance, the Cheltenham and Gloucester Maxi account would mature at a value of #15,153. That is a very substantial gain when we consider that the base capital investment is #9,000 and that the money accumulated is interest free.

I am suggesting also that we should be able to consider as a gloss, perhaps, integrating the TESSA scheme with the model Canada has adopted. In Canada, superannuation and investment funds are directed that, if they invest overseas, they have to reinvest a certain component of their funds in commercialising research and development and in small and medium size business in their own country. I am not arguing that institutions should not be left to invest as they see fit, but I do think a proper gloss on this to direct it to targeted investment which will help Australia's industry infrastructure would be appropriate. That would mean adopting an approach, with the flood of money that would go in, which would say that, if fund managers are going to invest, say, 25 per cent of that money offshore, they have an obligation to put at least one per cent or 2 per cent into fund-managed accounts that go towards Australian small business and commercialisation of research and development, where we singularly lack capital and where every effort to attract it has to date been futile.

Finally, I do not run away from a good idea, from whatever source it comes. The source of this is the British Conservative Government of John Major--the then Chancellor of the Exchequer, now the British Prime Minister. I believe that the devil sometimes does sing very good songs and I am not prepared to block my ears to them. I believe that this is a creditable and sensible solution. I commend it to the Ministry and members of this House to consider.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Is the motion seconded?
—-I second the motion and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) knows my antecedents. I found his final comments interesting but he knows that, given my antecedents, I am going to oppose his motion. I think we should be clear what the motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House commend to the Government the introduction of a scheme modelled on the British tax exempt special savings account in order to facilitate both the growth of domestic savings and the encouragement of Australian investment in Australian domestic industry.

I accept that the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) has put forward this motion with very good intentions, obviously to try to help the savings situation which we all know is not particularly good. As it happens, we serve together on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. We were in Queensland last week and we discussed this matter briefly en route from point A to point B. I know that the honourable member for Denison was a little surprised when I told him that I was going to oppose his motion. The point that I make up front is that, however well intentioned and well motivated, we have to look at the practicalities and the down side of some of these specially directed initiatives from government. I want to look briefly at the detail of the scheme, explain why I believe that it is not relevant for the Australian situation, and suggest what I think should be done to attack this particular area of concern.

Let us look at the scheme. I have a copy of the legislation and the regulations from the United Kingdom on the tax exempt special savings accounts, which are known, obviously from the initial letters, as TESSAs. The object of the scheme is set out as follows:

Tax-Exempt Special Savings Accounts (TESSAs) have been introduced from 1 January 1991. Provided certain conditions are met, any interest or bonus payable on such accounts is exempt from income tax. The relief aims to encourage the savings habit, particularly among small investors, and to boost longer-term savings. It is also designed to help non-taxpayers, such as many married women, who under the composite rate tax system before 1991-92 could not reclaim tax accounted for by banks and building societies on their deposit accounts.

The way that this scheme is meant to operate is as follows: any interest or bonus payable on a deposit account for a period when it is a TESSA is disregarded for all income tax purposes. To be a TESSA an account must satisfy a number of conditions--it must be with a building society or an institution authorised under the Banking Act; it must be identified as a separate TESSA account; it must not be a joint account; it must not be held on behalf of another person; it must not be connected with any other account held by the account holder or any other person; it must be transferable from one society or institution to another; and the account holder must not simultaneously hold another TESSA. An account continues to be a TESSA for five years from the day of its opening or until the account holder's earlier death. A TESSA ceases to be such, firstly, if more than #3,000 is deposited in the TESSA's first 12 months, or more than #1,800 in any of the succeeding periods of 12 months, or more than #9,000 in total and, secondly, if a withdrawal is made which causes the balance to fall below an amount equal to all the sums previously deposited plus the basic rate income tax on previously paid interest or bonus. It goes on for some pages to provide a fair amount of prudential supervision provisions, which I have to say seem to require a quite significant amount of additional bureaucracy.

So what we are essentially talking about is one account per person, for very small amounts, with limited flexibility. This is to overcome a specific problem of small savings in the UK tax rules and to encourage savings among the UK's small savings population, which is much larger than applies here. But there is no mention--although it is in the motion--in the legislation from the UK about encouraging industry investment. There is no information, of course, about the rates to be applied, and one assumes that those would be normal market rates.

Why is the scheme not relevant here? As I have said before, I accept the good intent, but it is a contrived scheme. It is the Government saying, `We will have a special little category which has to be specially policed and have special rules and regulations, reporting arrangements and all the rest of it'. So there is bureaucracy there, and we are out there interfering in a small sector of the community. It is more government intervention and it is more bureaucracy. There is no genuine incentive for people to increase their savings by significant amounts, because it is such a small amount. The benefit might, of course, be consolidations of savings for investment. But the banks in this country, certainly at the moment, are not in a position to do that, and they are holding back from a lot of that investment. I suggest that, if the scheme were applied here, it would not directly cause the banks to release lots of large capital into the marketplace for investment.

The honourable member for Denison said, `Perhaps we should be saying that there would be conditions. You have to actually allocate it to this small firm or to small business or whatever'. But we are then back into this whole business of picking winners and who gets the money and who does not.

So it is an artificial scheme for the less well off, when really I would suggest that the aim should be to make those people a lot better off rather than just putting a bandaid on their present situation. So what should be done? Essentially we should be looking to improve people's income and to provide some incentive. There are two ways of doing that: firstly, we get the economy going, rather than the flat earth policy we have at the moment and, secondly, we reform the tax system. To get the economy going we have to do the things that we on this side of the House have been talking about for some time and which the Government has been talking about but, unfortunately, has not done. We have to have that industrial relations reform and sweep away a lot of the archaic work practices so that we can get some competitiveness into our industry, get some profit and get some earnings up, because it is only when we are profitable and successful that people will be better off--and then they do not need the contrived schemes.

We need those micro-economic reforms which everybody talks about but which are coming so slowly. I happened to be at a dinner last night with MIM. The point was made that, for example, in the land transport area we urgently need significant reforms in road and rail. If we look at just the cost of doing business through the waterfront or across the Tasman, we see that we are just not competitive. Privatisation, contracting out and smaller government--that whole range of areas--are the things we do to improve everybody's wealth, rather than singling out one small sector of the community.

It is not a question of wanting more government and more public servants, because we already spend far too much on administration. If we look, for example, at just administering the Department of Social Security--just the administration costs of that Department, not what it pays out in benefits--we see that we spend $1.3 billion a year. That is the equivalent of building Parliament House every year. We have to get away from special schemes, the administration, the controls and all the reporting; we have to liberate a lot of the opportunity rather than having more government intervention and more administration. It is an attitude. We have to fix the basic problem, not just make it more comfortable.

Governments are not the only ones who care. We care too, and we want to help on these issues, but we have to have proper long term solutions. On the tax front, of course, we have to reduce the tax take. We want to provide some incentive for people. We want to shift the burden from incomes to spending, so that there is some incentive to invest in that business, to work that hour's overtime and to save. We do not want to have special little schemes just for one sector of the community. We have said that we will replace the wholesale sales tax with a goods and services tax so that we have a fairer and more equitable system and so that we get the black economy and those who are rorting. The better off in our society will pay more tax rather than the 10 per cent that they are paying at the moment, because they are the people who spend. And obviously there will be an offsets package. It is better to do that and have a better arrangement for everybody across the board rather than to have a contrived scheme such as the TESSA scheme.

In conclusion, I understand that the motion is well motivated. It might be appropriate for the UK, but I would suggest that it is not appropriate here. It is more government intervention and more bureaucracy. The proper route is to improve people's lot overall with all the reforms that I have talked about. We need to restore some pride, some incentive and the standard of living in this country. We have to ease the tax burden for all rather than create another special little category. Regretfully, I urge the House to reject the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have pleasure in seconding and supporting the proposition put forward by my colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr). Perhaps what is required is to remind the House exactly what is being suggested. The honourable member for Denison is suggesting in this motion that the House recommend to the Government the introduction of a scheme modelled on the British TESSA scheme. But, importantly, the reasons for doing that are to facilitate both the growth of domestic savings and to encourage Australian investment in Australian domestic industry. I hope to have time to get to that latter point, because I think that is the important aspect the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) has overlooked in talking about the scheme's relevance to the Australian situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, in my speech on this year's Budget I said amongst other things that the Government should give consideration to tax exempt special savings accounts, similar to those operating in the United Kingdom, to mobilise the savings of small investors. So there are a number reasons why we should consider this type of fund, including both the individual interest and the national interest.

In this place I have often quoted parts of what I believe to be a fairly important House of Representatives committee report, that is, the report titled Constructing and Restructuring Australia's Public Infrastructure. That report was tabled in November 1987 and the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) played a major role in its compilation. The report highlights the need for Australia to ensure that it looks at infrastructure, not only at providing new infrastructure but also at understanding that infrastructure has a life and will need to be renewed. The challenge for the nation will be to seek proper sources of funding to enable that to occur.

That report talks about a scheme that is similar to the British TESSA scheme and has been operational in Japan--the Maruyu scheme, established in 1967 to encourage small savers to invest in government bonds. However, it is interesting that the report also attempts to put that scheme in the cultural context of Japan. I quote from the report as follows:

Japan's rapid post war growth has been financed almost entirely from domestic savings with virtually no net reliance on foreign capital. . . The most striking factor is the array of savings schemes on offer which are tax free up to a certain income level.

As has been indicated, one of the problems with our present tax environment is that it is so distorted that it penalises Australians' attempts to increase their savings and, even worse, in relation to the savings that small investors might put forward, it works against them in an inequitable fashion because those who have the ability to save larger sums of money are able to enter into a host of schemes offering generous tax breaks. In looking at this scheme, we should try to address some of those inequities in our present tax treatment of savings.

I now turn to a point which I have often made about superannuation funds. One has to understand that superannuation funds and a scheme like TESSA would be given tax relief, and because of the tax relief that those funds attract, it should not be too much to expect that, subject to the proper prudential requirements, the funds might at least in part direct their resources to socially responsible investment. It is very important in the present Australian context to look at domestic sources of funding for a whole range of projects, whether they be public infrastructure or the type of industry research and development that is required to place Australia back on its feet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford Mr F.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is not often that I agree with an idea put forward by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), especially in view of my recent attack on his preposterous proposal to introduce a wealth tax. However, I support this motion, with some modifications which I will explain. Apart from essential reforms in industrial relations and the restoration of confidence and employment opportunities in Australia, we urgently need the overhaul of the iniquitous taxation system. In particular, we must do something about the appalling level of savings in this community. Domestic savings are a disgrace. The malicious treatment meted out to those who still manage to save is nothing short of a national disgrace. The plundering of people's savings by inflation and through the taxation system has of course encouraged people to spend rather than save. Indeed, it is hard to imagine a system which would do more to undermine the potential wealth creators of a society than that which we have at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout the 1980s we have been virtually forced into an orgy of spending. Unlike Australia, most other developed economies do not treat their citizens with such contempt. In Britain, a person can now open a special TESSA account and receive tax free interest for up to five years. In Japan, many people contribute to economic growth and wealth creation by investing in Maruyu accounts, as mentioned by the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins). In a Maruyu account not only is the interest mainly tax free, but as well deposits of up to $100,000 or $200,000 can be invested securely with no threat to one's social security entitlements. The savings accounts are a basic strength of the Japanese economy. Loans from such funds would, in an Australian instance, be available at interest rates of less than 5 per cent, preferably 4 per cent. Initially, capital would be available for export industries, then for import replacement, and it would then be available to develop Australian owned industries.

The major aim of a plan like this is to encourage savings in Australia and simultaneously stimulate the development of particular industries which create wealth and offer genuine employment opportunities. In practical terms, such a scheme could be administered through the Commonwealth Development Bank, although the desire to pick winners--so beloved by the central planners of the twentieth century--must be avoided at all costs. One has only to look at the sorry spectacle of WA Inc., Bannon's State Bank and the debacle of Cain, Jolly and Kirner's destructive socialist fantasies to see what happens when governments attempt to go into business.

The misguided disciples of central planning would, in fact, contribute enormously to the future prosperity of Australia if they would only heed the words of one of America's great presidents, Calvin Coolidge, when he asserted in the mid-1920s, `The business of America is business'. He meant precisely that; he did not mean that Uncle Sam should go into business.

For the proposals mentioned to be successful, capital invested in such tax exempt accounts must be largely invested in existing businesses that have survived in this hostile environment for at least five years--hopefully 10, 15 or 20 years. Lending would only be on the basis of fixed assets, such as machinery, plant and buildings. This means that, even if a business failed, the fixed assets would always remain. In these circumstances, there would be little, if any, financial loss and minimal risk to any investors. If the Commonwealth Development Bank is used to administer the scheme, all major investment and lending decisions could be made by an independent board of directors with some members nominated by business associations. The new fund should be exempt from all tax and dividend obligations until it is well established.

We are told that unemployment is officially at 9.8 per cent, but we all know that in reality it is considerably higher than that. Australia's farmers and small businesses have been devastated by high interest rates ever since increasing government imposts and a deliberately engineered recession were brought into being. It is imperative that something be done immediately to end this haemorrhaging of our business base, our farming families, and the continuing loss of one of Australia's most precious assets--its intellectual property.

Let me conclude with an example from my electorate of Dunkley, wherein there is a company which produces crystals for lasers to standards which are widely recognised as world class. Recently, this company established a factory in Singapore, where finance was available at 2 per cent, compared with 16 per cent in Australia at the time. We hear constantly about the level playing field for industries. Such a scheme would be the first step in establishing such a level playing field. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses its deep concern at:
(1) the continued inflexibility of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services in the interpretation and implementation of the Disability Services Act;
(2) the fact that this implementation policy has led to growing waiting lists for disability services;
(3) the claims by the Government that its policy is based on the expressed wishes of disabled persons and their families;
(4) the fact that only a small proportion of persons with a disability are receiving a service under the rigid service-type guidelines used in implementing the Disability Services Act;
(5) the fact that this Government appears to be demolishing much needed halfway houses and sheltered workshops; and

(6) the intransigence of some Departmental officers in reviewing and approving existing services for funding under the Disability Services Act and the authoritarian attitude adopted by some officers in dealing with members of the community.

This motion, as the House will note, does not seek to condemn the Government, nor does it seek confrontation. Rather, it expresses the deep concern of people with disabilities, their families and service providers at the continued inflexibility of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services in the interpretation and implementation of the Disability Services Act, the intransigence of some departmental officers in reviewing and approving existing services for funding, and the inconsistency of decision making between State offices of the Department.

The Disability Services Act has opened up new options for people with disabilities, and this the Opposition applauds and approves. However, we believe that there is still a need for services such as sheltered workshops, hostels, nursing homes and activity therapy centres to be able to coexist alongside the new services. Yet we still find resistance on the part of the Government to encouraging or continuing these services.

We acknowledge that in recent months, because of pressure from parents, service providers and the Opposition, the Government appears to have heeded the call for a rethink on sheltered workshops and other existing services, and has recognised that the transition date of 30 June 1992 will need to be extended.

When the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) set up the National Technical Assistance Workshop, he made it clear that he wanted fresh advice on sheltered workshops, not just some more of the thoughts of his Department.

At the NTAW workshop held last month at Mount Eliza in Victoria there was overwhelming support from service providers for the concept that sheltered workshops which did meet enhanced consumer outcomes and not just the current minimum outcomes should be eligible for funding under the Disability Services Act. Providers felt that all services should be judged on outcomes. There was a strong call for the Government to set down clearly what are the criteria for eligibility. I understand that Government representatives did advise that in fact the drafting of eligibility criteria was currently in train. There was also a plea for the transition date to be extended.

At the same time as this workshop for service providers was taking place, a parent group, Australian Parent Advocacy, was taking its campaign around the country with a central theme that the Government must start listening to parents. Parents rightly feel that they are not being consulted sufficiently, and are not being involved in the process of change. Yet they are the people who have had the closest involvement with their sons and daughters and who have used their knowledge, skills and energy to establish safe environments to ensure that minimum levels of education and care were set. They are the people who are taking the risks. Their needs must be understood; their voices must be heard; they must be supported. The role of the professionals and bureaucrats should be to facilitate decision making rather than to make those decisions themselves. Parents must be consulted and informed; they must be part of the process.

Resolutions passed at the Australian Parent Advocacy annual general meeting, which preceded the campaign, called on the Government to consider uniform guardianship laws for responsible parents right around Australia; recognise that Australian Parent Advocacy is a national parent body, the only one of its kind, and embark on honest inclusion of parents, the primary care givers, in policy development; review its departmental service type guidelines, which are more attuned to Canberra-based ideology than need; realistically assess the growing waiting lists for existing prescribed services; and extend the transition date pending the results of that review and assessment.
The APA President, Mrs Mary Walsh, said that her organisation is about families. She continued:

An intellectual disability is a family disability. We do not expect a greater share of the welfare cake than the next person. In a climate of recession and soaring unemployment that would be unrealistic, but we do expect Canberra to stop dismantling good existing services. We challenge the politicians to face reality.
I want to assure Mrs Walsh that this is one politician in a group of politicians in the Opposition who wants to face that reality.

On her campaign around the country, Mrs Walsh found the following perceptions among parents. Firstly, they realise that the bottom line is a lack of money. There will never be enough, and this could probably get worse when the States accept the responsibility for all services other than employment. Secondly, parents are fed up with having to deal with continually changing departmental staff. Thirdly, there is a concern that unionisation may not be voluntary, and that valuable work options might be lost if unrealistic union demands are allowed to be made.

So, once again I say to the Minister that parents of disabled children are desperately worried about what will happen to their children after 30 June next. They need the Minister to spell out clearly whether he intends to fund sheltered workshops and other existing services. Some have already been forced to close down because of lack of commitment and assistance from the Government, even though the Government has promised repeatedly that no service will be closed.

I mentioned in the House only last month that one such sheltered workshop which is operated by the Nambucca and district branch of the Challenge Foundation of New South Wales has just suspended its services because it is unable to meet its growing debts. Although the Department was closely involved in the establishment of these services, there has been confusion and conflicting advice on restructuring and reluctance to give financial assistance.

This is the position in which sheltered workshops around the country find themselves. The Government is cutting down on funding and backfilling, thus making workshops non-viable. In the case of Nambucca, the Department then had the gall to express concern about the impact of the suspension of operations on the clients and the apparent lack of opportunity for them to make decisions and choices in areas which affect their lives. There are many such sheltered workshops around Australia encountering the same treatment from this Government and the Department.

I give another example that was drawn to my attention only this week. The Gilgandra Challenge Foundation, caring for 32 intellectually disabled adults and children, will close at the end of October because of financial problems. It had a total trading deficit of $27,000 last year and a projected deficit of $158,000 this year because of the flow on of award increases in New South Wales.

The Department sat on its hands, in spite of consultations and knowledge of Gilgandra's problems. Eventually it offered a bandaid solution of $30,000 to help the organisation through to the end of its financial year, on the condition that it restructure its staff and apply for the 3 per cent superannuation payment available through the Federal Government. It is interesting to note the response by the Department, having made that agreement to give $30,000 on the Friday. On the Saturday, a departmental spokeswoman, Ms Robyn Green, put this comment in the paper:
We just wanted to know where the $30,000 would be spent. . . I don't think that is unreasonable.
We also wanted a new projected budget taking the new wages situation into account.
Then she showed her prejudice by saying:
I believe the decision to close the service is coming from the Challenge Foundation's head office in Sydney.

She then quite rightly mentioned that Gilgandra did not want to see the organisation closed, nor did the community, but that is what happened. The anger she expresses there I think is a false one, based on a prejudice that the Department knows best and services will abide by what the Department says.
What this organisation and many others like it need is security of funding and an ongoing contract. Its spokesman, Mr McCutcheon, said:
People can't be kept dangling on a string, not knowing if the service will still be there in a week, a month or a year.

He is angry and frustrated by the failure of Government departments to listen to reason, and that anger is shared right around Australia. The Department cannot understand this, or perhaps it refuses to understand.

Because of time limitations, I have time to mention only a few of the examples of the intransigence of departmental officers. The officers in Western Australia took issue with the views and opinions expressed by the Disabled Workers Union during a recent radio interview. In letter to the union, one officer stated:

In general you stated that you were opposed to the stance the Commonwealth Government was taking in regard to providing people with disabilities employment options in non-sheltered settings. You also expressed your opposition to people with disabilities having the opportunity for generic union membership.
The officer continued:
With regard to your recent comments, it would appear that the Disabled Workers Union is not furthering the Principles and Objectives, and as such calls into question future funding.

That is blackmail of the worst order. My colleagues and I, in all of our time in this Parliament, cannot remember it being a proper act of government to threaten people with a loss of funding because they criticised the approach of the government of the day.
I want to give one more recent Queensland example. I quote from a letter that has come into my possession from the Community Living Programme Inc. The main parts state:
More than that, we were given repeated assurances in a lengthy consultation process that we would receive sufficient funding to enable the program to continue in its present form.

We were not aware of the cut to our funding until Friday 16th August six weeks after the end of the last funding period. We were being given interim funding at 1990/91 levels and were advised the reason for the delay was in Head Office, awaiting the Minister's signature. We received the information about the cut via the electoral office of the Member. . . The Department of Community Services, Health and Housing had not advised us in any way of a substantial cut in funding up to that time.
That meant a reduction in funding of some $50,000 to $60,000 to carry on a service on behalf of the Commonwealth.

I should like to raise yet another matter of concern which is very current and on which once again the Government seems to have set its own agenda without sufficient or meaningful consultation with consumers, carers or service providers. I refer to the consumer focused funding approach which the Government introduced on 1 July this year before its own consultation process had been completed. This approach is in operation in Canada and New Zealand and is not an unqualified success. In fact, it was introduced in those countries as a cost cutting measure. When questioned about this funding approach during Senate Estimates committee hearings last month, the departmental officer admitted that neither the guidelines nor the form of legal contract between the program and the service provider had been finalised. Yet this approach was introduced in July 1991 before consultations had been embarked upon. I understand that it has little support around the country among consumers, carers or service providers and it has not been trialled properly.

It would certainly seem that this system is about bureaucratic empowerment rather than consumer empowerment, and that is what social justice is about. It is also seen as the icing on the cake in a series of cost cutting measures by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. The motion that we introduced earlier expressed the major concerns of consumers, families and carers. I think these should be taken into account.

Having listed the concerns of those people, I come back to the remarks that I made at the beginning of my speech. In recent months the Government does appear to have been listening to the people out there, and I reiterate the offer that I have made on many occasions: the coalition would like to work with the Government on a bipartisan basis in setting objectives for the future and ensuring that all people with disabilities receive services appropriate to their needs and aspirations and that there is a choice and diversity of program.

I commented at the beginning of this speech that we do not seek confrontation on disability services. I have mentioned the concerns of most of those engaged in providing and receiving those services. The Opposition has made positive suggestions for changes to the Disability Services Act to address those concerns to make the Public Service--the departmental officers--more accountable and responsible.

However, I get alarmed by comments which receive wide circulation and which are intended to be spread wider and so cause unnecessary concern and agitation to people with disabilities and their carers. I refer to comments on the marginal effects of the goods and services tax on people with disabilities. In reply to a dorothy dixer in this House on 10 September 1991, the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services made such comments deliberately. His answer was hypothetical. He has no idea or knowledge of the details of the Opposition's proposed goods and services tax and his comments were designed to cause agitation to the Opposition--which they did not--but they caused major concern to those people with disabilities and their carers. His comments were cruel, careless and heartless. Again, one must question his and other Ministers' interpretation of social justice.

The goods and services tax is part of an Opposition policy initiative designed to make more funds available to people with disabilities, not to reduce the amount of income available to these people. Let every Australian face the fact now: this country is in debt to the rest of the world to the tune of $162 billion. We have the highest real interest rates of any developed nation in the world. We have almost 10 per cent of Australians--nearly one million--unemployed, and we have a taxation system which is unfair and discriminatory, as well as optional for some. We have a growing internal black economy, and some of our richest citizens are not paying tax.

The Liberal and National parties recognise that changes are necessary to bring Australia out of recession and to protect those less fortunate in our society. I can assure the Minister in this House that we have an overwhelming commitment to people with disabilities and would ask him and other members of the Labor Government not to victimise those people with totally false assumptions and allegations about Opposition policies.

I pledge that a coalition Government will listen to people with disabilities and their advocates. We will listen particularly to the concerns of parents and we will listen to the voluntary and charitable organisations which provide the services. We intend to work together with all those elements within the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Is the motion seconded?
—-I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Labor vision of a socially just society is one where all Australians can share equitably in the distribution of resources, especially in employment opportunities. The package of new labour market and income support arrangements, known as the disability reform package, was introduced in the 1990 Budget. This package will bring into sharper focus the special needs of clients with disabilities and is an outstanding illustration of the Government's broad approach to reform. Building on the foundation of the disability reform package, the Government is now turning its attention to tackling the next stage of the reform process--overcoming the barriers that exist in the workplace for people with disabilities. I wanted to say that at the outset of this debate today.

SPEECH.PARA: There were six issues of concern raised by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). Not so long ago I had a meeting with the Parent Advocacy Association in Bundaberg. It was not the first, but one of many meetings. With that group and with other concerned parents I have discussed and gone through the process and the position of the Government. I have done so along with members of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services whom I would like to compliment on their dedication, the amount of work they carry out and their willingness to travel the length and breadth of Queensland, and I am sure other States--I have not travelled in those other States in considering this issue--to explain the reform process to concerned parents and friends of people with disabilities.

There have been some misconceptions. I think some of those misconceptions are understandable because people are reluctant to change and are concerned about the way in which changes will be implemented. It is true, as the previous speaker said, that in order that we get proper change for the better there needs to be consultation. That has been the case; that has been ongoing for years. It will continue.

By June 1992 the Federal Government will be spending $390m in the disabilities area under the new program. That is an increase from the previous program of 1986-87, which allocated $126.7m. That is an increase of around three times in the amount of expenditure in the disabilities area. That indicates the determination, compassion and understanding that the Government has for the needs of people in this area. Most of us are touched by friends, relatives or close acquaintances who are disabled, whether it be intellectually disabled or physically disabled. In the physical area there will be more disabilities because of modern science and, unfortunately, accidents, particularly automobile accidents. Sadly, that is a growing area.

Ten issues were raised by Parent Advocacy both in newsletters it sent out and in discussions with me. I would like to go through some of those concerns and some of the concerns touched on by the previous speaker. Before I do so I would like to point out another thing that the Government has done to try to help gain better opportunities for people to go into the work place--that is, to honour the Florence agreement which has the effect of removing tariffs on educational, scientific and cultural goods designed especially for people with disabilities, thereby enabling them to have better opportunities in the workplace.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Sales tax on motor vehicles was good, too.

—-On top of that, we have removed the sales tax on those vehicles. It previously did not apply to them. That is something that should be recognised. It is rather hypocritical that at the same time that we are removing these imposts, the Opposition is locked into a policy of a consumption tax that will impact not only on the disabled but on all Australians. No matter how many times members of the Opposition say otherwise, they will tax the people who can least afford it while the people at the top end of the market will get an exemption. They do not like it because they know that when the general public understands what this sort of tax means they are going to be as popular as Saddam Hussein. That is the bottom line.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not like people standing up and telling the truth. As the honourable member for Dawson knows, for 12 months in this House when he was crying about drought I exposed drought rorts and he did not like it. If he does not like the truth, that is too bad. I will not use the disabled people for political purposes. Those opposite can run around promoting anti-government and anti-departmental things as much as they like. At the end of the day they will be judged by a tax they are locked into, whether they like it or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is disgraceful.

—-The honourable member for Dawson should look at his own Party in Queensland if he wants to talk about disgrace. The biggest branch he has got is in Boggo Road. This brings me to the first issue that has been raised by Parent Advocacy, and continually raised.
—-Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. What the honourable member has said is an absolute disgrace and is not true. I ask him to withdraw it.
—-And unparliamentary.
—-The honourable member for Hinkler is not contributing to the decorum of the place by referring to groups of members in a derogatory way.
—-I will withdraw, because I am not sure which is the biggest branch of the National Party.
—-The honourable member should withdraw unreservedly.

—-Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. As I understand it, you said that the honourable member for Hinkler has reflected on members of the House. From my understanding of what the honourable member is saying, he is reflecting on former members of the Queensland Parliament.
—-No, he talked about the honourable member for Dawson.

—-The Minister would be aware that references to groups of members are regarded similarly as references to individual members, and the same applies to former members. I ask the honourable member for Hinkler to withdraw.

—-Mr Deputy Speaker, for the process of debate I will withdraw. I am pleased that I am on this side of the House and not associated with the National Party in any way. I would hate to be closely associated with those people who are in disgrace in Queensland. If those opposite want to talk about disgrace I am happy to talk about it any day of the week, whether it be on drought rorts or on anything else.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to get to the first point that has been raised by Parent Advocacy in its newsletter; that is, the effect of rising unemployment levels and the economic downturn on supported and open employment opportunities for people with a disability. The issue here is more one of discrimination against people with disabilities in the open labour market. Participation rates have not tended to rise even in times of economic boom. The Government is currently addressing this issue through marketing and union-employer awareness programs, such as the Employer of the Year award of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). While it is recognised that the current economic climate is not conducive to full employment, it is expected that people with disabilities should compete for and secure their share of available jobs with the support offered through the funded employment programs.

The employment programs funded by the Commonwealth provide the support necessary to enable people with disabilities to obtain and retain integrated employment opportunities in the general labour market. This support is tailored to individual needs and may be ongoing or time limited as required. The Government's overall social justice platform looks to a long term permanent change in employment opportunities for people with disabilities and in the attitudes of employers and the community.

While there are some who say that people with disabilities cannot possibly compete or cope with people without disabilities for employment, I do not agree. I will use three examples to prove that conclusively: one of the greatest women this century, Helen Keller, had severe physical disabilities; the greatest President the United States had this century, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, was disabled; another man who had greater disabilities than either of those two, and who has been an inspiration to the world, was Christie Brown. A great movie which won some academy awards called My Left Foot was made about Christie Brown only two years ago. I recently had the privilege of meeting the producer and director of that film. It has touched the hearts of everybody and has demonstrated that people with disabilities can achieve. We wish to see that those people have the opportunity to reach whatever heights they desire in our society. That is what this motion is about; that is what our Government is committed to.

I do not believe we have a monopoly on wisdom in trying to create the best package. I object to anyone on the other side of the House, or anyone anywhere, saying that we do not have the compassion or the will to do so.

The second issue raised was a refusal to extend the transition date beyond 30 June 1992. The Government is committed to the consideration of a range of options available for pursuing the principles and objectives of the Disability Services Act, while providing ongoing funding for sheltered workshops after June 1992, provided they meet minimum outcomes and continue to improve the quality of their services. To assist services in this change process, the Government has provided $3.1m over the next two years to the Australian Management College, Mount Eliza, to establish and support a National Technical Assistance Unit, NTAU. The NTAU will offer sheltered workshops technical advice dealing with financial management, business development and marketing in a competitive environment. The work of the NTAU is also expected to guide transition arrangements for sheltered workshops.
