The Government has also given repeated assurances that no service which meets certain minimum standards of quality related to the observance of basic human rights and has committed itself to a continuing process of change towards meeting the principles and objectives of the Act need have concerns--I emphasise the words `need have concerns'--about continued funding after 1992. Funding at ministerial discretion should not be construed as making the program vulnerable or insecure. This Government, with its commitment to social justice and record of introducing positive new initiatives for people with disabilities, would not arbitrarily withdraw funding. The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) has also given public assurances to this effect. I would like to stress that again.

The third issue raised refers to a refusal by the Government to table guidelines for the DSA. The Disability Services Act, enacted in 1986, focused for the first time on the needs of people with disabilities rather than service providers. The DSA seeks to open up more possibilities and choices for people with disabilities, enabling them to pursue a valued lifestyle. In implementing the DSA, the Government has emphasised innovation to allow for maximum flexibility during the transition phase of services moving towards the DSA. As program parameters become more settled, then the Government will act to develop section 5 guidelines under the Act.

The fourth issue deals with a lack of guardianship rights. The Government is aware of the need for uniform guardianship legislation through Australia and that conditions of guardianship orders should be portable between all States and Territories. In recognition of the importance of the issue, the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services put the matter on the table for discussion at the recent Council of Social Welfare Ministers. A decision on the issue has not been released at this stage.

The fifth issue refers to a supposed lack of meaningful consultation. I have commented on that matter previously. The handicapped programs review generated close to 1,700 submissions from individuals and organisations--5,000 people participated in open public consultation and 3,500 people participated in workshops and seminars. As the first major consultation on disability issues, the recommendations flowing from the review have significantly shaped current Government policy. As I have said, ongoing consultation has occurred through a number of initiatives. I would like to list some of them: the Disability Advisory Council of Australia; the Disability Services Advisory Committees, DSACs, in each State; Ronalds Consultations on Employment; the Advocacy Movement and consumer input to reviews of services.

The National Technical Assistance Unit will be consulting in the next few weeks with consumer and parent representatives--some of that is already happening--including Australian Parent Advocacy, on issues associated with the transition of sheltered workshops, and will be providing advice to the Government to assist its consideration of future developments in the disability services program. Recent consultations include consultation on two new initiatives conducted by the disability services program. These initiatives include consumer focus funding, CFF, and individual needs analysis, INA. Consultations have been taking place over the period June 1991 to September 1991.

There are several other points, but I will not have time to comment on them. I stress the fact that the Government is working with all groups and this ought to be above politics, but there are some in the community who are frightening people unnecessarily. I will continue to stand up and say that a goods and services tax on the disabled and on every person in this country is not good for Australians. If the Opposition does not like it, that is too bad. It can whistle three bars of Dixie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-That was probably one of the most shameful speeches I have ever heard in my short time in this House--that the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) should so use people with disabilities for his own political agenda. Talk about frightening people. That was one of the best efforts I have ever heard to frighten a group that is in no position to fight back. I hope the honourable member for Hinkler is extremely proud of his performance!

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to support this motion by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) because it raises some matters that have arisen in my own electorate. I have no particular expertise in the disability area, but many people, usually parents or families of people with disabilities, have come into my office and raised their problems with me. What I am getting from them is enormous confusion. They really do not know what is happening. On the one hand, they are subject to the rhetoric about all the good things that are supposed to be happening in the disability area as a result of the Disability Services Act, but families especially are finding that not only are they no better off than they were before but many of them are a lot worse off. They do not know where they stand.

They were promised so much but they have got so little. One of the reasons why they have got so little is that a lot of the money that has been put into the disability area has gone into specialised areas such as deinstitutionalisation, which in itself is very positive. With the money available going into institutions and into moving people out of institutions, those families who have been looking after people with disabilities for many years have nowhere to go for their funds. A few people who yell the loudest get large sums of money. In my office recently I had 14 parents of children with intellectual disabilities. One of those parents said, `I have done all right; I got $40,000 for my child. But I feel very ashamed when I look at everybody else in this room'. Indeed, it was an uncomfortable situation: she had got $40,000, and none of the other parents in that room had got anything for their children.

Some of the services that have been approved by this Government need an enormous amount of money, and putting that sort of money into some people means that others simply do not get anything. The same thing has happened in the work area. I am aware of one workplace where the subsidy for each person in the workshop is $14,000. That is not their pension or for their accommodation; that is simply the subsidy to keep them working in this one workshop. While those few people are being subsidised at $14,000 each, in South Australia 2,000 people with intellectual disabilities have absolutely nothing to do and nowhere to go during the daytime. Of course, that number will increase with the restrictions on sheltered workshops that have come about.

The feedback I am getting from families in my electorate is that they simply do not understand what is happening about sheltered workshops. They have children, many of them adults, who are presently in those workshops. The children enjoy them, they enjoy going there, and they believe what they are doing is a contribution to society. They enjoy the wages they get, they enjoy the activities, and they enjoy the social contact. They are absolutely terrified that these workshops will close down and they will have nothing. I do not think any of us have any fight with supported employment, with open employment. It is a marvellous ideal, but an ideal is worth absolutely nothing if we cannot realise it. What we do is leave the people in the community with the promise of something better but in fact give them something worse.

My time is almost up and there is so much I would like to have covered in this area. Let me just say that I wish this Government would concentrate more on what is best for people with disabilities and their families and less on the philosophy, the grandstanding, and would look to their welfare instead of to the welfare of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I find the hypocrisy of the other side absolutely amazing in relation to the treatment of disability services, the Disability Services Act and its implementation. Might I say at the outset in regard to parent advocacy that the most vociferous critics of the Disability Services Act are led by a person called Mary Walsh, who was a National Party candidate at the last election. This kind of political grandstanding should be exposed.

SPEECH.PARA: At the heart of all this lies an opposition to the essence of the Disability Services Act. The Disability Services Act is about equity and opportunity for everybody in this community, irrespective of the kind of disability they have. We have a whole range of examples of what has happened and of the excellent opportunities that have been created for people. However, we also have megalithic structures, particularly in Queensland, where for 30 years we had a State government that failed to address any of the disability services issues and so created a monster private provider, particularly in the form of the Endeavour Foundation. It was a leader in education for disabled children when it was first established. Indeed, early in the 1950s it was a leader in the way in which the disabled were educated.

What has happened is that the rest of the world--the community, education and other processes--has moved down the track another 40 years. The Government must respond to that, and it has responded, as well as to the needs and demands of those individuals. Of course, if one has a monolithic structure one has power bases and, indeed, an enormous amount of money, power and control over people's lives. One cannot expect this to be handed over to individuals.

To say that things are not happening is absolute and utter nonsense. We have seen the rise of a whole range of respite care services which assist people with very young families. I have a respite care centre in my electorate for children up to 12 that specifically addresses the concerns of families with young disabled children. It enables the family and the siblings of the disabled to have a break from each other. It also encourages an amount of independence in those children when they have a day away, a weekend or whatever. A whole range of families use that service. This is part of what we are talking about--developing independence at an early age and making sure the opportunities are there.

We should also look at the way in which employment opportunities have been created. I find it quite extraordinary that it seems to depend on the will of the provider as to whether the spirit of the Disability Services Act can be addressed. I can cite three enormously successful transitional operations in my electorate, one of which, Keystone, is in the poorest and most disadvantaged part of my electorate and is supported by the National Party's very own Senator Bjelke-Petersen. It has embraced the Disability Services Act with great alacrity.

Keystone has found a way to give people an opportunity to move into full and supported employment. Indeed, the person who now answers the Commander telephone system, who can handle all four lines as they come in, take messages and do the work, is a former client who had been condemned to routine work in a sheltered workshop for no money at all. That person was working only for the invalid pension at a cost to the taxpayer. Young Natalie is now the receptionist there and can answer the phone, take messages and do all that work. Surely those on the other side of the House are not saying that such people should be denied access to real wages and the opportunity to work.

At the heart of this motion is a denial of the rights of individuals to move into full employment, to be able to work, to do things. The issue of flexibility was raised by those opposite. The inflexibility is in these monster megalithic foundations that have been created to give power to numbers of people to control those in sheltered workshops. We were told by the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus) that people actually enjoy sheltered workshops. The same argument was used in the Industrial Revolution when they tried to move children out of the mines--that children actually enjoyed being there. What sort of nonsense is this? We are about dignity, about the rights of individuals and the rights of all people to have an equal opportunity in employment and not to be condemned to this nonsense of working in sheltered workshops at a cost to the taxpayer.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Riggall Mr J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and congratulations on the sterling job you are doing in that position. I wish to speak about the Disability Services Act and a very real concern that exists in the community. Unlike the previous speaker, the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), with her righteous indignation about how good the Act is, I have concern for people in the community, real people who are trying to resolve their problems. It seems to me that the Act has put in an unrealistic expectation--
—-It is not an unrealistic expectation.
—-I see the honourable member for Forde is still waffling on. It is a pity she will not keep quiet. If she does, she may learn something.
—-She is a slow learner.
—-I know she is a slow learner; but we cannot help that.
—-We are into personal abuse now as well, are we?

—-No, I thought we were just stating facts. This is a very serious subject. Unfortunately, the Government is trying to close sheltered workshops which are meeting a real need in the community. People who are working at those places certainly need the opportunity to go into the community, but many of them need that work in the sheltered workshops. That is something that is most important to them at an individual level.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently I went to see the family of a young man named Chad. Chad is a handicapped child of 14 or 15 who is in respite care for six nights a week. The family live in absolute terror that this respite care could be taken away from them at any stage if a more worthy case came along. That would be a tragedy. Imagine that a child who needs to be looked after professionally on a 24-hour basis could have that care taken away by a stroke of a bureaucratic pen. The family live with this day after day. To add to their woes, some two years ago the mother of the family had a brain tumour. There was evidence to suggest that the brain tumour was brought on by the stress of her family life.

The family came to me and said, `We are in financial trouble. We owe some money for the respite care and we really cannot pay it'. Could I get any money to help this deserving case from the bureaucratic services that I went to? No. The husband was looking at having to throw away his job to go home and look after young Chad. Eventually, I found help for Chad from a multinational company which looks after its people. It had the compassion--which the bureaucracy did not have--to take the financial worries away from one of its workers. The union movement was also involved in this case and it also showed compassion by looking after young Chad. Today that child is still in respite care six nights a week. The family are still struggling on, and they are still uncertain of their future. It is a tragedy that should not have been placed upon that family; one they can do without.

The Government is very keen to talk about sheltered workshops and social justice; but where is the social justice for all those people who cannot get into sheltered workshops, those people who are on waiting lists and are falling back on the resources of their families? Where is the social justice for them? Where is their level playing field? It is not there. So we find this ongoing tragedy time and time again at a personal level.

One of my centres in Warragul, the Mawarra centre, recently had trouble getting funding from the Government because of a bureaucratic muck-up. However there is not time to go into that now. I received a letter, which reads:
My son, who is intellectually disabled and lives at home with us, needs this service--
that is, respite care--
so we can have a holiday and some rest within the family.
The letter concludes:
We need this service. We need your help.
It is most important that a government have compassion, that a service have compassion, and that it be delivered on an individual basis for families. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) calls on the Government to review the standards applied by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to consumer goods imported into Australia; and
(2) contends that the minimum standards applied to imports should reflect the minimum standards applied to exports from Australia of comparable goods.

In moving this motion I believe I am touching on a matter that is of widespread concern to the Australian community, particularly to primary producers. It is widespread enough for the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) to volunteer to second the motion and for me to feel that I ought to recognise the role of the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), whose particular interest in quarantine standards initiated this motion.

My interest in this matter arises from my involvement in the horticultural industry of the Riverland in South Australia. As you would be well aware from your primary production experience, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Riverland of South Australia is a fruit-fly-free zone in Australian terms. So I am very familiar with what it is like to live in an area that enjoys a particular advantage and maintains that advantage by the strict policing of quarantine standards. In the Riverland and in South Australia standards are applied to the movement of fruit and, as people in the gallery and honourable members would be aware, there are roadblocks to make it difficult for people to bring what might be contaminated fruit in or out of that area.

This intention to isolate an area and maintain its advantage is known as `quarantining' and has been known as `quarantining' since the word first came into existence. When `quarantine' was first used it referred to the time--originally 40 days--during which a vessel suspected of carrying an infectious disease was kept out of contact with the shore of the country that the vessel was intending to visit.

The need for effective quarantining in Australia is beyond dispute. It is supported by all Australians, even those who are inconvenienced at immigration barriers by our quarantine techniques. The reason for this motion is that there are real inconsistencies in the way in which the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service polices quarantine in this country. I first became aware of these inconsistencies as a result of the experience of the dried apricot industry and particularly the Angas Park dried fruit packing company, which is in my electorate. Mr Blenkiron, the General Manager of Angas Park, pointed out to me that the quality of dried fruit allowed to be imported into Australia was not good enough to be exported.

I got into some trouble in this House when I mentioned that imported Turkish dried apricots reminded me of nothing more than little shrivelled orange balls. That prompted a phone call from the Turkish Ambassador, who was a shade indignant. Whether he was right or wrong--and I have no doubt that what was imported was perfectly edible material--those apricots would not have met the minimum inspection standards applied by AQIS and would not have been good enough to be exported. That is the fundamental inconsistency that we believe ought to be addressed by the House and the Government and that this motion endeavours to focus on.

I am not seeking some sort of non-tariff barrier that makes it difficult for people to bring product into Australia; I am simply saying that what we regard as the minimum standard for exported goods ought to be applied to imported goods also. The stance of my Party and the coalition on GATT has always been consistent. We want a similar consistency to be expressed by AQIS.

Frankly, I am asking: who inspects the inspecting authority? We have come to the point where the producers in Australia are now asked to pay 100 per cent of the cost of having the goods that they have prepared for export pass meat inspection standards. One hundred per cent of that cost is borne by the producer. The producer rightly says, `It is time I had some say in the way that export and those export standards are applied'.

I am aware that the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) has asked that there be a review of AQIS. The company, Ernst and Young, has handed down a review of AQIS procedures. Ernst and Young claims that the difficulty that we have with 100 per cent inspection charges being borne by the producer is that those charges have placed a greater burden on the inefficient producer. The real problem is that there has been too little flexibility in AQIS; too little opportunity for a producer to say, `This is the standard that I believe I have to maintain at export. This is the way that I am going to go about maintaining that standard by inspection'. There is too little flexibility and too few modifications. Companies which once shared their inspection costs with the Commonwealth find that they now have to bear 100 per cent of that cost without any right to say how the inspection should be carried out.

The problem, of course, is even more acute in the meat industry than it is in the horticultural industry. Last night in the Appropriation debate, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) spelled out the example of AQIS inspectors who were receiving a salary of $34,000 a year--note that--but are being charged out to the company, by AQIS, at $68,000 a year. He pointed out the fact that 25 per cent of AQIS meat inspection staff were not actually inspecting at all. This, of course, was part of the reason why the salary of meat inspectors had been so dramatically loaded and it provided such a burden to meat processors and abattoirs around Australia.

It is a small wonder that the Federal Council of the Australian Meat Inspectors calculated that government inspection costs and statutory boards account for 5.5 per cent of the meat industry's turnover. It added, as a rider, that in the best years that the industry had enjoyed, the operating surplus had been only 5.7 per cent.

There is an old political adage that says that power corrupts and absolute power corrupts absolutely. One of the dilemmas facing AQIS is that it has absolute power. It is AQIS that says whether or not a container of fruit, vegetables or meat will meet a particular standard and whether it will, therefore, go to the market or whether it will stay, be rejected and be a total loss to the processor. AQIS determines whether a particular export will go ahead or stop.

As the honourable member for Gwydir has pointed out in this House, we had the situation in Cowra where an abattoir, which was ready to roll with 180 men waiting to work, decided to go ahead and process. When the eight normal inspectors were not available to inspect the meat, the abattoir employed two other fully licensed and qualified inspectors, processed for the day and, in the process, slaughtered and packed the carcasses of 131 cattle and 2,200 sheep worth almost a quarter of a million dollars. It then had AQIS say--after it was inspected by licensed inspectors, but not those on the AQIS roster--that it could not go ahead. I think I can be forgiven for asking whether, in this instance, there was not just a bit of monopoly power being exercised.

The plea that I want the Parliament and the Government to consider is the right for producers, in fact, to negotiate the way in which they go about their inspections. Every exporter has a vested interest in maintaining quality; that is what allows his market access. By comparison, every importer poses a threat to Australian consumers. I insist that the standards that apply to our imports ought to be at least as rigorous as the standards that currently apply to our exports. That is the responsibility that AQIS ought to be exercising and reviewing as it looks at its role in Australian exports.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Is the motion seconded?
—-Yes, I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: --I rise to speak in the context of Australia's urgent need to develop an export ethos. Unless Australia develops an export ethos and unless every citizen in this country realises that we, as a nation, are going to survive on exports--exports are our very lifeblood and the backbone of every job in this country--then we are doomed to be a Third World country. I think we need to look very carefully at anything that impedes exports.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sad to have to say that I have to concur with the previous speaker, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). AQIS does not have a good record. It will say that it is diligent, that it works hard and does its duty. I am sure, in its own eyes, it does. I think we need to have a look at a few of the records. When we examine specific cases, we see significant abuse of power. It is true that since July 1980 AQIS has been inspecting imported foods. It is interesting that after inspecting 2,500 consignments, 8 per cent did not come up to Australian standards. I suspect that it has inspected very few of the imports. By its own inspection, it is clearly shown that there is a real problem there.

I am concerned about the export side. There was company in Mildura, an area on the Murray Valley, that was very seriously affected by the decision of the Government to allow imported dried fruits. Imported dried fruits often did not meet the same standards of Australian dried fruit. Rather than simply go broke, the farmers in that area sought to find alternative markets. Some enterprising people hit on to the table grape market. They went to Europe and studied it. They found that people in Europe, in fact, liked the sultana grape and that Europe, particularly France and Britain, import a lot of sultana grapes from Spain and Italy during the season. Therefore, they arranged with Mayne Nickless Ltd to send three container loads to London which fetched record prices.

They then ran into the problem of AQIS. It said that no grapes could be exported unless they met a certain size. This was clearly nothing to do with AQIS. It was something that should have been decided by the market. There was no health question there whatsoever. If the market in Europe did not like small grapes, then so be it. I think European consumers are apparently more sophisticated than the North American consumer because they like the flavour in the grape. There were people in Australia--forces which I believe were mainly in the Victorian Department of Agriculture--who wanted to produce in Australia these very large plastic blobs of water which pass for American table grapes. They were not liked, particularly in Europe. The fact that our product was acceptable was decided by the market paying the premium price for those three container loads.

The inhibitions put on the export of those things have cost those growers in Mildura a fortune. It has driven them into the hands of the banks. With banks being what they are in this country, the growers will probably never recover. I believe that there is room there for clear action against AQIS. I think there ought to be a mechanism where it can be sued for this sort of behaviour.

In respect of meat exports, we are now talking about allowing the Russians to modify whalers and operate them as mobile abattoirs outside the national limits in international waters. It is simply not possible to slaughter mutton in Australia, no matter how cheap the sheep are, to supply this vast market. The reason it is not possible is that the abattoirs have to meet these Department of Primary Industries and Energy standards; standards which the Russians say are not necessary for them. These standards of the Department, of course, are far higher than meat that is slaughtered in Australia. We are actually saying that it is all right for Australians to eat this meat, but any foreigner who gets Australian meat must have a higher standard. That is bizarre nonsense and I think it is quite offensive.

It is quite possible that the reality is that they are concerned about the Americans. The Americans are the great users of the non-tariff barrier. It is quite possible that the Americans simply say, `If you are going to have two marketing standards, we are not going to allow you to get beef into the United States'. If that is the case, then we ought to be coming out and saying very clearly that that is the case. We will be pinning it on the Americans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Atkinson Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I welcome the opportunity to speak in today's grievance debate. I wish to use this time to bring to the attention of honourable members the Hawke Government's severe mismanagement of the Australian economy. I wish to remind the House of the list of broken promises which have become the hallmark of the current Federal Government and why the Australian Labor Party is not fit to form government in Australia at either State or Federal level.

SPEECH.PARA: I have just finished reading a very important book. I have yet to reach a conclusion as to whether the book is a comedy or a tragedy. It is certainly an important historical document. It is important that its contents be brought to the attention of honourable members. I am referring to the book entitled Australian Labor Party Platform, Resolutions and Rules, 1988. I will quote some extracts from the book and honourable members will quickly appreciate my dilemma in deciding whether the book is a tragedy or a comedy. Chapter 7 deals with the Labor Party's approach to economic matters. Paragraph 10 states:
Labor believes that economic policy should be directed towards

(a) the development of a strong competitive Australian economy capable of achieving full employment and high and consistently improving living standards, with the elimination of poverty treated as an urgent priority;
Paragraph (c) states:
The restoration and maintenance of full employment, with unemployment seen as a denial of the right to share equitably in the nation's resources.
I also quote from chapter 8, which deals with employment, education and training. Paragraph 2 states:

Labor is committed to the restoration and maintenance of full employment. Unemployment is a major source of inequality and poverty in our community. As such, full employment is crucial to the achievement of Labor's economic, social and cultural goals.

It would be a gross understatement to say that the rhetoric contained in this 1988 document has not been matched by the Government's performance in the years following the 1988 ALP conference held in Hobart. Tragically, for so many Australians, the reverse has occurred. In August 1988, 632,000 Australians were out of work. The 1988 ALP conference committed the Federal Government to a policy of full employment. Yet, in August 1991, there were 841,000 Australians registered as unemployed. What is worse, it is quite possible that because of this recession the registered figure will exceed one million. And we all know that the real figures are much higher than that.

Indeed, the unemployment crisis facing Australia today is so severe that, if we were able to form a queue of all those currently unemployed standing one metre apart, that queue would stretch from Melbourne to Sydney. That is a national disgrace. So many Australians are unemployed because of the policies of this Labor Government because of the recession we had to have--the same people who promised full employment only three years ago.

The ALP conference of 1988 should not be remembered only for its commitment to full employment. The conference also made some very important statements about the role of small business in the Australian economy. Chapter 21 is devoted to small business. Paragraph 1 states:

Labor recognises the importance of maintaining a strong, viable and diverse small business sector. It accounts for more than 95% of all businesses in Australia, over 50% of private sector employment and 40% of value added.
This quote from the ALP's 1988 document is laughable when one considers the damage inflicted upon small businesses by the policies of the Hawke-Keating Government.

When assessing the damage to small businesses by government policy a very accurate barometer is the statistics dealing with bankruptcies. In the financial year of 1987-88, there were 8,504 recorded bankruptcies in Australia. Three years after the Labor Party conference in Hobart, with its rhetoric about the importance of small businesses to the Australian economy, the annual bankruptcy figures have reached a staggering 12,991.

The 1987-88 figure of 8,504 represented a 13.5 per cent increase on the previous year, while the 1990-91 figure of 12,991 represents an increase of 52 per cent on the previous year. With these figures in mind, how can any member of the Government have the temerity to claim that the Labor Party has a commitment to small business in Australia?

A more detailed examination of the bankruptcy figures is a worthwhile exercise. It is interesting to compare the figures during the Fraser Administration with the figures during the Hawke Government's term in office. This is particularly interesting, because we all know how often Hawke Government Ministers stand up in this place and blame the Fraser Government for all of Australia's economic woes. They blame a government which has been out of office for over eight years. In that period we have been saddled with nine Budgets from the Hawke Government: eight from Treasurer Keating and one from Treasurer Kerin.

Let us consider the facts. During the Fraser years, there was a total of 30,945 bankruptcies, with an average of 3,868 per year. During the Hawke Government's period in office, there have been 60,089 bankruptcies, or an average of 7,511 bankruptcies. The figures have doubled. The bankruptcy figures I have revealed are further evidence of the total failure of the Hawke Government, which is more interested in playing its grubby numbers game to see who will spend Christmas in the Lodge.

I come to this place from small business. I am a manufacturer and I therefore have an acute awareness of the pressures and impediments which this Government has imposed upon small businesses. I also represent an area of Melbourne which has the highest concentration of manufacturing businesses within Australia--and they are hurting. So many have gone to the wall, and many are beyond recovery. For a long time small businesses in this country have had to contend with the decline in consumer spending, with high inflation, with high interest rates and with high taxes. That is not all. Let us not forget the administrative burden of the one per cent training levy on businesses with payroll taxes in excess of $200,000. Let us not forget the compulsory superannuation imposed upon businesses but with no link to productivity increases.

In this Budget, the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) had the opportunity to show that he would be different from the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), and that he would attempt to help, rather than hinder, small businesses. But no! Instead of Budget initiatives to encourage and assist businesses, we see the imposition of a 5 per cent occupational superannuation policy--a decision that will break the back of small businesses. It will send another 100,000 workers into the ranks of the unemployed. It will add from 2 per cent to 5 per cent to our inflation rate.

Earlier this year I challenged the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the then Treasurer to leave the dream world of Canberra and come to Melbourne to visit my electorate of Isaacs. The Prime Minister is a former resident of the seat of Isaacs, so it should be a nostalgic trip for him. I invited him to witness the damage being caused by his Government's economic mismanagement. Once again I extend the invitation. I would be delighted were he to bring the Treasurer with him. If the Prime Minister is willing to leave the comfort zone of Canberra and venture into the real world, I will show him the crisis that he and the former Treasurer have created. I will take him to the industrial estates of my electorate so that he can see how many businesses have closed down completely.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Shame!

—-It is a shame, as the honourable member for Corinella states. The Prime Minister can talk to the businessmen and ask them why their factories are operating for only two or three days a week. I will take him to meet the businessmen who are in the invidious position of needing to close their doors but not being able to because they cannot afford to pay the redundancy packages, the long service leave or the accrued holiday leave. They just stick it out hoping that the tide will turn. But there is little prospect of that occurring with this mob running the show. The Prime Minister would have a very difficult time explaining his Government's performance in the area of small business. He would be compelled to admit that his Government's actions fall far short of the promises and the rhetoric of its 1988 document. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I want to raise again the issue of Austudy. I have spoken on this issue on a number of occasions in the chamber and I welcome the opportunity to do so again. I am aware that a range of additional improvements to the Austudy scheme were introduced by the Government in the August Budget--improvements that included the rural hardship provisions. I welcome these Budget changes, particularly those which will assist the rural sector of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I wish to bring to the attention of the House a problem which has been raised with me on a number of occasions over recent months. This is a problem affecting people who, having left school previously, now wish to return to school to further their studies. A large number of people who have left school before completing 12 years of secondary study are either unable to proceed with their chosen career path or have not been successful in finding full time employment. Some of these people make the decision to return to school to further their education and to extend their work related skills. A large majority are young people who left school at an early age for various personal reasons, including breakdown in the family unit or plainly and simply because the family needed them to enter the work force in order to contribute financially to the family budget.

Over the last 12 months the cases brought to my attention show clearly that these young people have had gainful employment since leaving school. However, I have found that all too often that is not full time employment, a 37 1/2 hour week. These young people have secured work either on a permanent part time or casual basis, earning enough from their part time or casual work to make them financially independent. They are being paid the higher penalty rates applicable to casual and part time work and are financially better off than some of their counterparts in full time employment. These young people have been able to earn more than they would have received if they had relied solely on the Job Search allowance. Taking into account their earnings for each fortnightly period, which were over the allowable limit, they have received no Government financial assistance under Job Search. They have therefore been fully self-supporting and independent of assistance from their families in the time immediately prior to their returning to study.

The difficulties for these young men and women arise when they apply for Austudy assistance. Upon applying for the independent rate for Austudy assistance an assessment is made on the basis of hours worked each week by the applicant. Under the eligibility criteria a minimum of 37 1/2 hours per week must have been worked by the applicant to be deemed as eligible for the independent rate of assistance. In the majority of cases a minimum total of 37 1/2 hours or more was not worked each week. Therefore, assessment of their applications at the independent rate is denied--even though the applicants have been self-supporting in this period with part time or casual employment. Assessment must then be made of parental income. No provision is made for the applicants making a reasonable wage from their casual or part time earnings in this period, nor the fact that they have been fully able to support themselves with their earnings from their casual and part time work.

When one takes into consideration Australia's present employment climate, eligibility for Austudy payments based solely on hours worked before independent status can be deemed to have been reached is not a fair means of assessment. This clause must be removed from the Austudy criteria immediately so as not to discourage our young people from returning to study.

Assessment should be made on wages earned. This is only fair. The question should be asked as to whether a livable wage was earned each week from casual or part time work by the applicant, and not what hours were worked per week by the applicant. In many instances, above award wages and penalty rates paid to casual and part time workers make it possible for a wage earner to live comfortably on the casual wages earned. The wage earned by a person, not the number of hours worked, is taken into account when assessment is made for financial assistance under the Job Search allowance.

I believe that this same assessment should apply and that it is only fair when a person applies for assistance under the Austudy program. As a government, we must continue to look at ways to encourage young Australian men and women to return to study. Young people must be encouraged to return to school to further their work related skills to enable them to compete successfully in Australia's competitive job market. The Government must remove from this system the very things that discourage young people from returning to education.

As I have done on a number of previous occasions, I would like to draw to the attention of the House the plight of people who are ineligible for Austudy benefits as they are just over the allowable income threshold. In my electorate, some people wishing to go on to higher education have had to leave the rural and community areas to set up a second home in the metropolitan area. These people come from varied backgrounds. Some are the sons and daughters of farmers and others are the children of battling wage earners, such as steelworkers, who find the costs of setting up a second home a financial drain on the family budget.

Rental accommodation in the metropolitan area is expensive and hard to come by. The cost of living expenses, such as utilities, clothing, food and travel expenses, adds up to a considerable sum of additional money which needs to be found each week by the family to support the student living away from home. An average working-class family with other children living at home to consider also cannot support the additional cost of a second home for a long period without a drastic change to family life. Many families are doing without just to provide the basic essentials for a child living away from home.

Therefore, I once again raise the question of a tax zone allowance being introduced for anybody who lives outside, for example, a 150-kilometre radius of a suitable educational institution. Changes should be made to enable people to claim under the taxation system the costs of setting up and maintaining a second home for educational purposes if they are unable to claim assistance under the Austudy program. The cost of maintaining a second home is prohibitive to people from all walks of life, be they farmers, BHP workers, BHAS workers, railway or powerhouse workers. All have the problem of providing assistance to their children if they go on to further education.

Some make the choice to uproot the family from their country home and move to the metropolitan area. We on this side of the House talk about decentralisation and how important it is for people to remain in regional and country areas. If we are not going to give the basic support for young children to have as equal an opportunity as their city cousins in an educational program, we are certainly not carrying out our policies and are denying them that opportunity.

As a government, we must urgently consider the problems being experienced in an attempt to provide assistance needed. I call on the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) to look closely at these anomalies in the Austudy scheme and make the necessary changes to ensure that any person wishing to return to study will not be penalised for doing so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-During the winter recess I took advantage of study leave and visited Hungary, Czechoslovakia and what was formerly East Germany. With the developments that have taken place in these countries since the momentous events of the past two years, it is immediately apparent on the streets of Budapest and Prague, for example, that a grim and dour system is being replaced by bustling signs of capitalism. Street vendors are plying their wares everywhere and Western goods seem to be available at most shops, certainly in the tourist areas.

SPEECH.PARA: After 45 years of communist control, suspicion of capitalism remains strong and hopes for a quick transition to a market economy are being somewhat dashed as disappointments and bitterness are emerging. There is a prevailing grimness in that the period of transition for many of these countries is going to be much more painful than anticipated.

By any measure, eastern Europe is in the grip of a paralysing recession where GDPs are actually shrinking. People I spoke to believe that the turnaround cannot be expected until well into the middle of this decade. There can be no doubting that the task of reform ahead is gargantuan, and few of us could have anticipated the enormity of the task in turning socialism into capitalism.

In Hungary at the moment, inflation is high and unemployment rampant. Admittedly, foreign investment is growing, although some commentators are claiming that it is much smaller than might have been expected. Paradoxically, the growth of private enterprises does seem to be surging and it would seem that the entrepreneurial zeal of a people suffocated for 45 years is about to be given free reign. That, by any account, is indeed a marvellous thing.

Budapest is a delight in that it is a very beautiful city. Yet, despite the main shopping centres in the immediate vicinity of tourist areas being awash with items for sale, and despite the average Hungarian having access to local clothing and groceries, they clearly have a way to go before they reach the levels of consumption in the West.

Shortages exist, but not as many as one might have expected, and so the picture is encouraging. Hungary did get a head start in reform. As the leading reformer under the communists, it illustrates most vividly the potential that these countries have to adopt a free market economy. For example, prior to the fall of the communists in 1989, Hungary already had rudiments of a stock exchange in place, together with a few small private businesses and state owned commercial banks.

Now, the private sector in Hungary is said to already contribute roughly one third of the gross domestic product and it has attracted more direct investment than any other eastern European country; so far about $US1 billion, according to a recent study. The down side of the equation is that Hungary is also the most heavily indebted of eastern European countries, and we here in Australia know the danger of that. Nonetheless, trade barriers have been lowered and the privatisation of shops and firms appears to be going ahead steadily, if slowly.

At this point, I would like to commend Ambassador Townsend and his staff in Budapest for the marvellous work that they are doing. Considerable business contacts have already been made in Hungary by Australians and we should remember that we owe a tremendous debt to Australians of Hungarian origin in this regard. I hope that we shall continue to build on these beneficial contacts with vigour and governmental encouragement.

Prague, on the other hand, displayed more of the austerity of the past. With little wartime damage, the city remains charming and beautiful, with recent attempts to restore some of its fine buildings giving a sense of renewal. Wenceslas Square, which is known worldwide, remains imposing. Yet shortages are more obvious than in Hungary. Crystal and china of rare beauty and elegance cram every tourist spot, but in the other stores there does not seem to be any abundance or variety of goods at all. Unfilled shelves, limited variety and queues at all counters suggest that much remains to be done if there is to be a consumer led advance into a market economy.

Private businesses still account for only 2 per cent of GDP, as opposed to a staggering 33 1/3 per cent in Hungary. Plans for a stock market have yet to be agreed upon, although a mass privatisation scheme using vouchers is planned for early 1992. This must be watched with keen interest by the West. Trade barriers here have been lowered, although I have been told that relatively high tariffs still exist on many imports that compete with local goods.

Inflation in Czechoslovakia is dangerously high and unemployment is rising as the effects of the loss of the Soviet markets and the move to capitalism cause their hiccups. The Czechoslovakian Government has taken certain measures but they really have to move urgently with their privatisation planning of large undertakings. As the Economist magazine mentioned:
Thousands of firms are now drifting in the limbo between a command economy without commands and a market economy still lacking the spur of private ownership.

One becomes conscious of the lack of interest by the European Community, certainly on trading matters with any of the Eastern trading nations. `Miserable' and `selfish', are words one hears from those East Europeans who talk about trade. It has a familiar ring for Australians when one thinks of the incredibly huge farm subsidies enjoyed by the European Community's continental farmers.

As far as eastern Germany is concerned, it is in a far more favourable position, of course. Saxony has been termed the boom state of the East. Already an integral part of the new Germany, it is somewhat breathtaking to realise that since union only a year ago there is a net increase of 40,000 local private firms in Saxony alone. Some $US12 billion has been invested by West German firms. There are the never-ending antique shops or second-hand shops here matched with exciting displays of items that are managing to compete with established companies not only in western Germany, but in western Europe as well. Even so, former East German industries appear to be on the verge of total collapse.

My reason for visiting Dresden stemmed primarily from my long time interest in the reasoning behind British wartime policy to virtually obliterate this city during a bombing raid in the final stages of the Second World War--I have not had that properly described to me yet. Dresden was a city of legendary beauty in its heyday--Florence on the Elbe, as it was known. Having a tradition of being the powerhouse of Germany before 1945, it is fascinating to see that firms such as Volkswagen have started building $US3 billion worth of car plants to take advantage of the traditional skills that have survived the communistic disease of 45 years.

It is obvious that the state of Saxony will be the centre of attraction for all other eastern European ambitions--cities such as Dresden, Leipzig, Chemnitz and Zwickau will be the spots to watch. It is ironic that Saxony has the same official unemployment rate as Australia--around 10 per cent. For my part, I have more confidence in the capacity of Premier Biedenkopf of Saxony to redress the position than I have of the Hawke-Kerin or the Hawke-Keating Government to improve Australia's employment situation. Even though that Premier believes western Germany has to transfer $100 billion deutschmarks or $US60 billion annually to eastern Germany for the foreseeable future, I believe he will succeed--these figures do not take into account the burgeoning tourist industry and Dresden's plans to take advantage of it all.

But for all the economic reform problems, so too are the urban environment problems massive. Eastern Germany probably exemplifies the region's problems as well as any other state, with certain sections of rivers far from crystalline, lignite mining areas cratered like the moon's surface and not the least of all this being the sulphurous clouds of smoke billowing across the border from neighbouring Czechoslovakia's coal plants. Saxons estimate that over half of their air pollution emanates from such plants. That is the horrendous legacy of environmental degradation left by 45 years of communist rule. The sorry state of the environment in this part of the world is palpable evidence that bureaucratic regulation, central planning and a poor economy do not go hand in hand with environmental protection.

In the short time remaining to me, there are two aspects I would like to mention: one is the problem of property ownership and the second is the problem of the absence of institutions and institutional law to service and consequently control a capitalistic system.

The first is the question of private ownership, but I shall take my time and refer to this in more detail at a later stage. In talking to a number of people while I was there, I was very distressed to find that there was a certain anti-semitism creeping into negotiations. It is my sincere hope that this is not a reality and I would commend to the officials in the countries I visited to be vigilant in this regard.
I would like to conclude by quoting from an article in the Economist I read recently which says it all:
Eastern Europe has embarked on a difficult journey towards liberal democracy and a market economy. The faster it goes for that goal, the better its chances of getting there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise in this debate to make a public call for an inquiry into the price of liquefied petroleum gas in Queensland by the Prices Surveillance Authority and I specifically target the gas companies, not the petroleum industry. There is clear evidence that has been gathered by the Central Queensland Consumers Association, by the Motor Traders Association of Queensland and myself that consumers throughout central Queensland and Queensland generally, particular outside the metropolitan area of Brisbane, are being forced to pay exorbitant prices for both domestic and auto gas.

SPEECH.PARA: I place on record my appreciation for the excellent work that has been done by the MTAQ because its service station division during September did a quick survey right across Queensland and came up with some very interesting information about pricing practices.

The price of LPG, for instance, in Brisbane at the time was 24c a litre. In Rockhampton and Mackay it was 43.9c. In Townsville and Cairns it was 43.8c. In Mount Isa it was 48.9c. In places such as Goondiwindi it was 42.9c. In south-western Queensland areas it was between 44c and 49c. On the Gold Coast and the Sunshine Coast it was 31.9c. In your own electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker, it was 30.9c. That is significant when we compare it with Brisbane at 24c. We should also realise that not so long ago in Brisbane it was 17c a litre--and in some of the southern States it is still around 17c a litre. But in central Queensland, it is as high as 43.9c.

The question that arises is: why are companies like Boral charging this amount of money? They can blame transportation, storage and retail mark-ups, but the MTAQ found, for instance, that the retail mark-ups from the service station proprietors ranged from three to four cents.

So we start to ask why. But we really ask why when we find, using the PSA study that was carried out in August, that the wholesale price--that is, the producer wholesale price of LPG--was $240 per tonne. That is about 12.2c a litre. So we see that in central Queensland the wholesale producer price is 12.2c, but the retail price to motorists is 43.9c.

We can go further. The mind boggles when we come across some of the figures for the price of domestic gas--and there is not much difference between bottled gas and auto gas. The wholesale price is 12.2c a litre--as we found in August--but we find that throughout Queensland, including Brisbane, the price for domestic gas is just unbelievable. The lowest price in Brisbane was 48.7c. Another price found in Brisbane was 52.9c. Keep in mind that the wholesale price is 12c. In Rockhampton the lowest price was 46.85c, but the price rose to as much as a dollar a litre depending on how much was purchased. So if we were to buy under 21 litres, we would pay up to a dollar. The prices in other areas were as follows: Clermont, 83.59c per litre; Mount Morgan, 84c; Gladstone, 86.42c; Emerald, 87.25c; Biloela, 88.02c; Mackay, 87.18c; Sarina, 87.68c. It is quite amazing that, with a wholesale price of around 12c, the retailer--and this is the gas company--is charging Queenslanders eight times that amount, in some instances a mark-up of at least 700 per cent.

These supply companies seem to adjust their price upwards whenever they have the whim to do so. I have had pensioners, taxi drivers and pie vendors complaining that the price can differ by $10 a cylinder within a couple of weeks. They usually sell them in 45 kilogram cylinders, which works out at 88.25 litres. There can be a shift of $10 a cylinder. Again, the delivery prices can change from week to week. Whilst they say, `Well, look it is the first 21 litres', or in Mackay, 23 litres, `that you pay for at 84c and 85c and then it drops down to 55c', a lot of pensioners never use great quantities and so they are always locked into the high price element; they are always paying around 83c or 84c per litre. I suggest that the suppliers are simply taking advantage of the monopoly that they have.

Some suppliers are trying to compete. In Gladstone, in the electorate of Hinkler--which is well represented by Brian Courtice, the honourable member for Hinkler--the Boral gas price was 86.42c, but Elgas, in trying to compete, had got its price down to 58c. The question that arises here is that, if Elgas can deliver that price domestically at 58.1c a litre, why is Boral charging 86.42c? Boral is doing it everywhere. We have seen mark-ups of 275 per cent for auto gas, but when we come to domestic it is up to 800 per cent. Consumers are expected simply to pay this. One can imagine what rural people, those who live on the land who use bottled gas as their main energy source, are paying.

A lot of people said, `Oh, it is because of the war', so we checked back. I realise that during the Kuwait period we did have some problems. I pulled out the wholesale figures for the time. Prior to the Kuwait-Iraq war, the wholesale price of propane was 11.7c a litre. It rose to 19.5c but it is now back down to 12.1c. So the issue is not with the oil companies, it is with the supplier.

We need to appreciate that for the last four or five months wholesale prices stayed around that level. In May the price was 12.6c a litre; June, 11.9c; July, 12.1c; August, 12.1c; and September, 12.2c. So the deregulation that this Government brought about on 1 January has been advantageous in terms of getting competition at the wholesale level because the prices are all around 12c. It has gone wrong at the retail price stage. The gas suppliers who buy from the oil companies are making a lot of money because we no longer control the situation. I think we need to use the Prices Surveillance Act to ensure that we can bring the gas industry--the gas suppliers--under those provisions so that they have to show cause why an increase is necessary.

When one notes also that LPG does not attract any tax, it is clear that there is a major problem. I hear people saying that they want to change from motor spirit, or petrol, to LPG because LPG is so much cheaper. What people do not realise is that there is no excise duty--Commonwealth tax--on LPG. At the moment, the tax on petrol is 26.5c a litre.

Let us take Rockhampton as a quick example. In Rockhampton, LPG is 43.9c a litre, with no tax; petrol is 65.9c a litre, with 26.5c a litre in tax. In other words, petrol is, in effect, cheaper than LPG. But it should not be. If we look at the wholesale price, the base price, we see that LPG should be so much cheaper than petrol. The first reason is that it has no tax and the second is that its producer-wholesale price is so much below that of petrol; yet that is not the case.

I think that consumers have a right to ask why. It is not just a problem in central Queensland. It is not just a problem in the electorate of Capricornia. It spreads across New South Wales; it goes into South Australia; and it goes into all other areas of this nation. I think it is time we did something about it.

I accept that in this instance it is better for industry to work in a deregulated environment. I think that it has been proven that we have deregulated at the wholesale level where we have kept prices at around 12c a litre over the many months since the Gulf war finished, but the retailers--in this instance the gas companies that buy from refineries that buy from the oil companies--are ripping off a lot of Australians. They are ripping off older Australians and they are ripping off motorists, taxi drivers and fleet owners. They are also affecting our tourist industry. If one moves away from the capital cities, one finds that exorbitant prices are paid for bottled gas. It is simply not good enough.

Last night I spoke to Professor Allan Fels of the PSA--he is now also the head of the TPC. I told him that I was raising this matter and I asked him to take up the issue. I believe the PSA, in cooperation with the TPC, needs to look at this because it could well be that some of these gas companies are misusing their market power, in which case section 46 will apply. We need to have the PSA initiate an investigation, even if it is only a trial or pioneer study in Queensland, just to find out who is doing what and why and, I would hope, to do something to protect consumers who are the purchasers of LPG, both auto and domestic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My grievance today is about the dwindling rights of parents and the increasingly defiant stance of government departments in trampling those rights under the weight of ill-conceived regulations, laws and bureaucracy. My attention was first drawn to the appalling treatment of parents when a mother came to me and pleaded to be told where her 15-year-old daughter was living. This family is not a perfect model of family life but I ask: which family is?

SPEECH.PARA: These parents have six children and both parents are unemployed. Five children are permitted by the Government to live with their parents, but one has been bureaucratically abducted. During this year of agony there has been a wall of silence from government agencies. They have said to these parents, `No, we cannot tell you where your daughter is. No, you are not allowed legal aid. No, you cannot visit your daughter. No, you cannot be told why we, the Government, are keeping her out of your care'. If this home is unfit to nurture children, why has the Government allowed five children to stay?

When community welfare officers were asked why this child was given homeless assistance when she had a home, no satisfactory answer was given. When I inquired about the reason for her receiving homeless assistance and asked whether it was sexual abuse, violence or nowhere to sleep, there was a wall of silence. Instead of parents being given their due right, their opinions are ignored or swept aside in these situations.

As a former shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, I can recall countless stories about the Native Welfare Act days in different States of this nation when Aboriginal children were forcibly removed from their families without adequate reason. Today, the same thing is happening, but it is happening to the whole community. Again, it stems from the mistaken belief that governments know best, that people are the pawns of government and that their children can be shifted on the chessboard of life without consultation with parents.

When it comes to making a judgment about the relative capacities of government versus families to nurture our young, I am for families. Today, the removal is not by force but by inducement and enticement by government agencies. The effect, however, is the same--removal of children by governments from parents. I am not saying that the community has no responsibility for caring for young people who have legitimate and verifiable reasons to seek help; it does. Where there is child abuse by parents or others in the community, the community has responsibilities. But what we now have is parental abuse at the hands of government.

The community also has a responsibility to ensure that such abuse is stopped. Parental authority is undermined, family life is destabilised and young people's lives are being decimated by government action. I have examples of young people being counselled in our schools, our courts and our welfare agencies and being told, `You do not have to go home if you do not want to'. This is being said by so-called professional counsellors to 14- and 15-year-old people in this country. It is not isolated. It is occurring in many parts of the country; I come across it repeatedly in my talking with parents, teachers and people who are concerned.

If children take that advice, they are then told about youth centres or other government accommodation centres and a bed is found. Parents are often not told that the child has taken that action. As one parent said, `Ringing a youth shelter is like ringing the dog pound. It is filled with the same emotions'. Parents ring youth shelters in the desperate hope that they will find their son or daughter.

For students under 16, there is no obligation on the shelter to notify parents, only another government agency, the Department of Community Services and Health. Also, parents cannot be contacted without the young person's permission. If permission is not given, no contact can be made. I believe that the way these regulations apply is absolutely disgraceful. Once the Department is notified by carers at the shelter, it also has no obligation to contact parents or police. This means that police often spend days or maybe weeks searching for missing persons because they are not notified by a government department. I have illustrations of that in my own electorate.

Scarce funds are being used and parents' natural rights are being abused. Not only are children encouraged by government counsellors to leave home without reference to parents; government literature also promotes it. In fact, one gets the distinct impression that the Government wants homelessness to be a growth industry in 1991-92. One of its pamphlets states:
Life is tough when you're young . . . if you can't live at home or you have hassles at home.
HOMELESS
Let us know.
It goes on:
We are only here for a year so get your skates on.

The implication there is that, if a lot of young people do not come and use this facility and show that there is a lot of homelessness, then it will not be here next year--`get your skates on--roll up, young people; the long term results depend on you'. Another pamphlet promotes this fact: `you can get a higher independent rate of Austudy if you are out on your own'. Therefore, the word is: `leave home, get higher Austudy and you will be right. Get away from parental authority and any sense of decent standards'. That is what is being promoted. A financial inducement to claim homelessness is clear.

It is hard for one not to come to the conclusion that government agencies are soliciting for clients to bolster numbers so that they will retain funding and thus the staff can keep their jobs. For an increasing number of young people the desire for freedom and independence is being accentuated by lavish government advertising, to those children's ultimate detriment.

In my area there is a growing concern among parents about youth shelters, and rightly so. Guidelines for who is homeless are not being followed. Invalid reasons for homelessness are being accepted. Stealing is occurring, and there is a lack of supervision, leading to drunkenness, drug use and compromising sexual situations. As one parent stated:
In one shelter girls stick knives in the doors in order to prevent being raped in one's bed and in another shelter two male residents shoot up on drugs.

Taxpayers' money is also being abused. For example, a youth worker claims that a 20-year-old youth, fitted for the second time with a hearing aid costing $800, rarely wears the aid because of the lack of supervision and self-discipline. In a second case, a young student was provided with spectacles at a cost of approximately $200--again, they are rarely worn. This is not all. At the same time that taxpayers' money was being used for these purchases, which are probably quite genuine, these young people, who rarely use the aids, had sufficient cash available for drugs, alcohol and other undisciplined activities. A youth worker who has resigned in disgust at the way things are being run says that neither youth should have qualified as homeless. That is where it starts. The guidelines are not being adhered to.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I put it to you that, wherever governments have usurped the legitimate role and responsibilities of parents, waste, chaos, misery and heartache have increased. In this country at this stage young people are being solicited to leave their homes so that they can get more money through Austudy, and the rules are not being applied appropriately. There is a lack of discipline in many of these youth shelters throughout the country. I am sure that my electorate is no different from much of Australia.

The way in which these facilities, some of which are needed, are being run is a great tragedy. In my area there is prima facie evidence of wastage, maladministration and low standards of behaviour in government funded youth shelters. This is jeopardising the lives of significant numbers of young people. I ask that the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe), here at the Federal level, and Mr Jackson, at the State level, investigate the matters that I have raised. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In my area, in the Hunter, we do not have the problem that the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) has. The problem with most of the youth that I come in contact with is their parents. The failure of parents to accept proper responsibility for the raising of their children, the casting out, sexual abuse, physical abuse, denial and rejection of so many young Australians by their parents is not a problem that governments can fix; it is not a problem that members of parliament can fix; it is problem that only Australian parents can fix.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the honourable member for Braddon may have a particular problem in his region, my experience of visiting youth refuges has been a horrific shock to me to learn about and see the results of what parents can do to young girls and to young boys. Overall, we are all concerned about getting the best results we can for our youth. To that extent, I hope that everybody in the community comes to recognise that the problems of Australian youth are national problems for which we all share responsibility, whatever the nature of the problem.

I bring to the attention of the Parliament today the issue of micro-economic reform, how it is spoken about so much by the private sector and how so much of the private sector does so little about it, other than mouth the phrase. It is not some type of new remedy; simply chanting micro-economic reform is not going to produce the increases in productivity, efficiency and competitiveness that this country needs.

Micro-economic reform is improvement in productivity, efficiency, working arrangements, operational practices, marketing arrangements and management at the industry and individual business level. Government can make a contribution in government controlled services and those services operate under government fiat. But at the end of the day, it is the individual managers and businesses that have to get their act together.

Management is far too slow in far too much of Australia to embrace the challenge of improving its performance. So much is spoken about it and yet so little is done about it in so much of Australia. Within that program of micro-economic reform we have to look towards improving the quality of working life, the quality of training arrangements and availability and the quality of leadership from management within each workplace across this nation.

People need to feel they belong to the firm that they are working for. They need to feel that what they are doing is worth while, so that they can be proud of the job they are doing and of the product they help to produce. Within that, the need for quality assurance is an essential part of reform.

Wherever we talk of this throughout the world and around this nation, we find that the two most important things that customers want are, firstly, consistency and reliable quality. Customers want to know that the product or the service is up to standard and does the job for which it is being purchased. Secondly, they want to know that the delivery of that product or service is reliable, so that they can build a business around the knowledge that the materials bought and the components that are being supplied will be of consistent quality and will arrive on time, as required. Then, price may be discussed.

The need for greater and widening quality assurance is an issue that has not yet been developed enough by Australian industry. I have a great respect for the Metal Trades Industry Association. In my view, it is probably the leading employer organisation in this country. It is certainly the most progressive.

I noticed in the press over recent days the comments by Mr Bert Evans, for whom I have a great personal respect, about the slowness in micro-economic reform. He referred to government areas. Certainly in government areas we would want things to go faster but they are improving; for example, on the waterfront and in waterfront related services, where much of the liability is on the private sector and not on government, and in transport generally.

I will sweep past that because I want to come to things that can be done by industry itself and the things that Mr Evans himself has pointed to so often in the past: the process of award restructuring; decentralising the decision making process; getting the people on the shop floor involved in the decision making process; motivating each employee; developing a flexible, trained work force; and widening the use of multiskilling so that people can carry out a broader range of tasks. Progress needs to be faster in those areas.

I want to move on to how that affects my own region of the Hunter. The Hunter is a microcosm of this nation. We have virtually everything the nation has to offer, except deep desert and snow. In the Hunter we are ahead of the rest of Australia in respect of industrial relations, award restructuring, operational changes in the work place and relationships between employees and employees. But that does not mean to say that everything that needs to be done has been done. A great deal needs to be done. But whatever progress we have made, we are generally ahead of the rest of Australia.

The Government, in this Budget, has before it a better cities program. The Hunter and Newcastle will share in that program; I am confident about that. But what I want to see is a better regions program. In the great regions of Australia, especially the Hunter region--the others I will not name--we have people with the skills that are required. We have a reliable work force, a good system of industrial relations and involvement by people in the change and progress that need to be undertaken, good educational facilities, good transport links, a congestion-free port, and a commitment from the people of the Hunter to the improvement of productivity and to the improvement in export effort.

I want to mention two firms. R& Transport is a young Hunter firm with strong management, a desire to do the job well and a firm that is not afraid to look for new opportunities. That firm took advantage of the resources boom of the 1970s and transported construction and fabrication materials to some of Queensland's open-cut mine developments. It expanded in 1984-85 and transfers the main hazardous chemical used in mine explosions--ammonium nitrate. In doing that it broke from its traditional transport base--from road to rail. The firm transports aluminium from the Tomago smelter to Newcastle's wharves. It started that process in 1984.

In the process of change, as a firm based in Newcastle, it has developed a timber importing distribution service in the past two years. It has lifted its productivity; it has offered a service that is reliable; and it has gone from a 1989 normal shipment of 180 loads taking 12 days to clear the berth, to a norm of 330 loads of timber within seven days being cleared from the berth. In relation to this the Assistant General Manager stated:
This has been a demonstration of what can be achieved when all parties agree to work constructively to change some of the older customs and practices.

It has done this by breaking into the Sydney market. Because of the excellent transport links between Sydney and Newcastle, as a result of our $600m national highway investment and electrification of the rail service, it is feeding northern Sydney and north-west Sydney more efficiently, faster and, in price terms, better than can be done through the port of Sydney. That is an example of what can be done.

The firm of Sandvik is another that is involved in supplying the mining industry. That firm, prior to its current ownership, had 20 years of mixed profitability, mostly loss. Managers were not managers in the sense that they are today. Today's managers are actively involved on the shop floor, consulting continually and assisting employees to arrive at solutions on the shop floor. This means productivity gains, and they have been significant.
