The new general manager has concentrated on changing the organisational structure, and the policy is that if managers do not change, or will not change, then you change the managers.

There are no problems with the unions. They work together--site agreements, award restructuring, skills audits are all in place. There is still a long way to go, but good harmony exists. They have gone to a much flatter management structure. The industrial relations matters, in principle, are handled by the general manager himself. On a day-to-day basis they are handled by the supervisors. In most Australian employment places, you will find that most managers do not know how to spell industrial relations and certainly have no knowledge of what can be done on the shop floor.

These are two examples in our region of what can be done. We encourage other firms in metropolitan Australia to look at what the regions of Australia have to offer in terms of work force, skills, reliability of labour, transport links and overall a better level of productivity and of efficiency. I bring this information to the attention of the Parliament today with the objective of making a greater number of Australian firms aware of the advantages and opportunities that are available to them by establishing their operations or transferring their operations into the Hunter region where the jobs are needed. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Last week the Federal Government lodged its nomination of Fraser Island and the Great Sandy Region for inclusion on the World Heritage List. That nomination occurred despite repeated assurances from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the former environment Minister, Senator Richardson, that it would not happen.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to nominate Fraser Island no doubt arose from the Fitzgerald inquiry. Tony Fitzgerald was commissioned to report on the future use and management of that particular region. I do not want to comment today on the merits of his recommendation, just merely to observe that there were many who felt that his recommendations were a surprise and did not reflect the weight of evidence that was put before him.

Nonetheless, the nomination has been lodged. Initially, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) had indicated that it would not be possible for the Government to prepare the necessary nomination papers in order for the 1 October deadline to be met. In making that assessment the Minister was correct. A lot of detailed preparation needs to be done to ensure that a nomination is correct and in order. In addition, repeated assurances have been given to the local community, particularly by the State Labor Government, that there would be extensive consultation in the preparation of management plans and the details of the boundaries before anything would be locked into concrete. Those assurances were repeatedly given to endeavour to allay some of the concerns in the local region.

It came as a major surprise, only a month or so ago, to learn that the Commonwealth had reassessed its position and that the nomination would be lodged in about three weeks. That decision meant that all of the previous guarantees of consultation were to be dishonoured and that the Government would proceed irrespective of local community concerns. The categorical assurances about the detailed consultations were to be overlooked entirely. The Government engaged consultants, as I understand it, to rush the preparation of the nomination, and it arrived in Paris, I understand, by the 1 October date.

This has raised a number of concerns in the local community. Fitzgerald, in his report, prepared a map which recommended the boundaries for nomination. It included Fraser Island, the Cooloola National Park, Hervey Bay and the Great Sandy Straits regions. It specifically excluded the Camp Kerr military training reserve near Tin Can Bay. Tony Fitzgerald did make recommendations about the future use of quite a lot of other Commonwealth property in the area, but he specifically excluded the Tin Can Bay military reserve from his recommended area.

Later, the State Government published what it called an amended map of the proposed area. It was apparently on public display, but I understand that one had to go to the office of the State Labor member for the area to actually see it. That map also did not include the Tin Can Bay military reserve. But, when the nomination was presented to Paris, the Commonwealth had apparently unilaterally decided to add this significant new additional area to the area to be included in the World Heritage Listing.

Despite the community concern about the precise nature of the boundaries, discussions on intricate details about how it would affect individual properties, and even promises from the State Labor member that he would arrange professional surveys to be done so that individual property owners could see what proportion of their property would actually be World Heritage listed, despite all of these discussions about intricate details, the Government unilaterally acted without any local consultation to add a significant additional area to that which was World Heritage nominated.

In fact, that area is not small. It adds 50 per cent to the mainland area of the nomination. It occurred, as I said before, without any local consultation. There had been no public debate; the idea had not even been suggested. The local State Labor members of parliament had not been told, the local shire council had not been told, the Tin Can Bay people had not been told; no local even knew until after the nomination had been lodged. Of course, then, it was too late.

There had not been any local pressure to include the area. Fitzgerald, as I said earlier, had not recommended it; the local community did not want it; even the Fraser Island Defenders Organisation and the radical conservation groups had not been pressing to have it included. The Government took the action quite unilaterally and without apparently any consultation or concern for the wishes of local people.

The Camp Kerr training reserve is no insignificant field for occasional military manoeuvres. It is the Army's major Queensland heavy artillery firing range. It has been bombarded for more than 30 years by heavy artillery, anti-tank weapons, mortars and the like. It is extensively used for training and it is considered to be critical to the Army's operation in southern Queensland.

My predecessor and I have been regularly contacted by people in Tin Can Bay who have been concerned about not only the noise that occurs from the day-to-day use of this particular reserve, but also the shock waves and the damage caused to buildings by the heavy bombardment.
The Army has regularly amended its method of operation to suit the needs of the people of Tin Can Bay. The Army is indeed to be commended on the way in which it has accommodated local concerns.

This reserve is also of great significance to the people of Tin Can Bay and the economy of the local region. Naturally, the local area is delighted to have such large numbers of armed personnel, servicemen, in its region, who contribute considerably to the local economy. The Army does not consider it to be optional. When I was aware that the Fitzgerald inquiry was looking at regions that could perhaps encompass the Tin Can Bay Army reserve area, I wrote to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) raising my concerns that Fitzgerald could conceivably make recommendations which would affect this area and that perhaps his Department should take an interest. He wrote back to me, assured me that that was in fact the case, then added these words:

Wide Bay Training Area is an important training area whose continued use the Army considers essential. It is the only field firing range within one day's drive for Brisbane-based units, including 6 Brigade. Its importance was stressed to Mr Fitzgerald during his visit.

So the Army considers it to be of great importance. The conservationists, it is clear, were also caught by surprise. They are now trying to find reasons to justify the inclusion of this region in the World Heritage listed nominated area. The good old reliable ground parrot, which seems to be a remarkably ubiquitous endangered species whenever any development project is proposed, has again turned up, along with the tusked frog, in this particular region.

Of course, the Army must be environmentally sensitive. War is an environmental disaster and any pictures of an ex-battlefield will certainly testify to that. The Army also needs to be responsible in its use of its training areas. But to suggest that an area that has been blasted, bulldozed, bombed, shelled, mortared and mined and is still regularly used for firing heavy artillery and anti-tank weapons is now suitable for World Heritage listing is clearly a nonsense and makes a mockery of the whole process.

We have been told that it is inconsistent with World Heritage guidelines to continue to selectively harvest timber from Fraser Island and the Great Sandy Region. That is not in order, but it seems to be quite okay to blast the area to smithereens with heavy artillery and still recognise it for World Heritage listing. Is it that our military power has become so degraded that we cannot even injure a frog or frighten a ground parrot any more?

What of the future? Clearly, the environmentalists are unlikely to allow this continued activity in a World Heritage area. There is no doubt going to be massive pressure for change. The convenience of the frogs is likely to be given a higher priority than defence needs. This great pressure to add to the national park land grab is likely to be spread also to Tin Can Bay. The nomination of Camp Kerr heavy artillery firing range has made a mockery of the World Heritage listing guidelines. Its future has been placed in jeopardy, along with the quality of training for our defence forces. It seems we must stop logging and limit tourism and coastal fishing, but it is all right to blast to smithereens an area nominated for the World Heritage List.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My grievance is the soon-to-be-announced Opposition policy on a goods and services tax. I hear that it will be announced on Friday, 18 October. In just eight days the fascinating details of the goods and services tax will be heard. At that time, presumably we will learn the details about three important elements of the goods and services tax. The first element is the rate at which the tax will be struck, whether it is to be 15 per cent or more. The second element is the important question of the number of exemptions that will apply; in other words, whether or not the sale of the family home will be taxed under GST, et cetera. We will learn how fair dinkum this GST tax will be. The third element involves the consequential changes to income tax that will arise because of the GST. What is the nature of the income tax system that we will see announced in eight days time as a consequence of the introduction of a GST?

SPEECH.PARA: Those three elements together will be the areas that I will be looking at because they will indicate the politics of the GST. They will indicate to us where the Opposition is fishing for votes. Quite clearly, an introduction of the GST and a consequential change to income tax will certainly look after those people on higher incomes. I will be very keen indeed to see who it punishes and just how well the politicians on the other side of the chamber here are fishing for votes amongst the lower, middle income earners who, we all know, are so crucial to the next election. In eight days time we will be asking questions of members of the Opposition. Let me pose some others that need to be asked and answered by members of the Opposition.

My big problem with the goods and services tax is not just that it may raise prices; I really ask what it will do for the economy. Will it increase the pool of savings by penalising consumption of Australians? Will it actually do anything to help the Australian economy? For instance, will it improve export earnings by permanently dampening domestic spending? We do not know the answers to those questions. Not even when the Opposition brings down the details of GST, will it be able to answer convincingly that the GST will do anything good for the Australian economy. On economic grounds, it has difficulties. That is why the political questions about where those rates are going to hit people--the political fishing expedition--becomes so important. Economically it is a dead duck. It is not going to assist in any great manner the Australian economy. These things are reasonably certain.

When the Opposition introduces its GST, it will certainly cause a substantial one-off rise in prices that will take some considerable time to wash out of the system. Just at a time when we get an excellent result on inflation, it wants to introduce a GST that will knock that on the head. There is certainty about the fact that the introduction of a GST will raise the rate of inflation for a period of time. The Opposition can call it a one-off increase in prices, if it likes. Terrific! How long is it going to take to get that out of the system?

What are the consequential changes that will occur, for instance, in wages and wage negotiations as a result of the introduction of a GST? We should remember, of course, quite theoretically, that if the Opposition were in government, and did introduce a GST, it would not have that negotiating mechanism to deal with the trade union movement, the accord, to get the sort of trade-off in wage rises that it needs in order to have the GST not feed permanently into inflation. It has a problem. Once it introduces its GST, it is almost impossible for the Opposition in government to negotiate the sorts of wage reductions required in order for the GST not to flow through permanently into the rate of inflation. So it is going to fail on those grounds.

Another thing that is certain is that there will be a large and non-compensated impact on certain groups, such as superannuants. It is arguable that you can compensate, for instance, those who are paid by the Government, pensioners, for price rises. I understand that. It might be difficult to achieve, but theoretically it is possible to compensate pensioners for price rises. But what do we do about the ever-growing number of those who have a superannuation income, who pay for their own pension, and whom the Government cannot pay more to to compensate for prices rises? It is an enormous difficulty.

TALK.START.PARA: —-You give them personal income tax cuts.

—-No, tax cuts are not going to help them. They pay very little in terms of tax. They have an income around $15,000 or $16,000. You cannot compensate superannuants through the tax system and you cannot give them an extra boost to their income as you can pensioners in order to compensate them for price rises.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has a problem. A very large group of superannuants in this country must be disadvantaged by the GST. The Opposition may be able to solve some of the problems, but ultimately if it introduces a GST it will fall because of that group alone. Because the GST will be set at a flat rate, it is by definition a regressive tax. It will affect the poor much more greatly than it will the rich. If, on top of that, it imposes a flat rate income tax, it will be a doubly regressive tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Earlier today in this place I heard the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) and the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) from the Government benches indulge in one of the most pointed, ideologically bound exchanges I have heard in the last couple of years. Their comments related to the underlying rationale of the Disabilities Services Act. They set out to blame, in turn, power-hungry individuals, the Queensland National Party and organisations like the Endeavour Foundation and Australian Parent Advocacy for the ongoing criticism of the provisions associated with the care of the intellectually disabled.

SPEECH.PARA: I have listened in recent weeks to parents and community services groups on both of those issues. One thing is clear--sheltered workshops are dirty words to the Deputy Prime Minister, the Federal Minister for Health, Housing, and Community Services (Mr Howe). How can a Hawke Government, which espouses compassion for and understanding of the needs of the unprivileged and disabled, deny the disabled their right to train, to work, to gain the appropriate living skills and, most importantly, their basic right to choice.

The Deputy Prime Minister, his left wing faction and his departmental bureaucrats all seem intent on opposing the establishment of sheltered workshops and forcing the closure of some sheltered workshops. They are imposing boredom, frustration and stress on families and carers for no other reason than to inject yet another strand of ideology.
Care of the disabled should be above party politics and the Deputy Prime Minister should exercise a larger degree of consultation and bipartisanship on the issue. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-A few weeks ago the shadow Minister for community services and aged care, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), threatened to resign from the shadow Cabinet over tariff cuts--cuts that have benefited the Australian economy. I am calling on him to do the right thing and resign from the shadow Cabinet now because he is supporting a goods and services tax--a tax on the disabled, a tax on every Australian--of 15 per cent, 10 per cent, 12 per cent, or whatever the Opposition wants to make it. It will keep going up right across the board.

SPEECH.PARA: Worse still, the shadow Minister in his electorate of Dawson represents the Bowen mango growers. He is going to put a tax of 15 per cent on the Bowen mango growers, on tomato growers and on all new, young home owners. Worse still, he would put that tax on the tourist industry--an industry that is now bringing in $23 billion a year. It is a tax of 15 per cent across the board that will cause as much damage and havoc as the last cyclone that went through the Whitsunday Islands.

We had hypocrisy from the previous speaker, the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), who talked about compassion. If the honourable member cares about compassion, he will do the right thing in his Party room and roll the consumption tax that is going to help the yuppies in the leafy suburbs but not the pensioners or the farmers. Fifty per cent of farmers will earn no money at all this year, yet the honourable member wants to make them pay 15 per cent more for their food, clothes and everything else they buy. He nevertheless has the audacity to come into this House and talk about compassion or understanding. The problem is that he has the consumption tax monkey on his back and cannot get it off. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —-So we are going to have an election in Tasmania. The Greens are going to move a vote of no confidence in the Labor part of the Labor-Green accord. All of a sudden the wishy-washy Liberals--not like me or the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles)--are coming out and saying, `No, Liberal Party in Tasmania. Do not join them in the vote of no confidence because it is not the right thing to do'. I am sick to death of the people of Tasmania consistently saying to me, `It is the worst government we have ever had in the world, Bruce'. But all of a sudden, when we want to get rid of it, they fall away like leaves from trees.
—-Green leaves from trees.

—-Green leaves from trees. So I say to the honourable member for Braddon and everybody else in Tasmania that we want an election down there. I support Robin Gray 200 per cent, not some of the wishy-washy business people who cry, cry, cry but when it comes to the crunch fall away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The supplement to the draft environmental impact study for the third runway completes the most expensive EIS in Australian history: somewhere around $7m. It should be the last of its type. It proves the pointlessness of proponents preparing EISs and then adjudicating on the objections. The supplement to the draft is a bloated, incompetent response. It provides no effective refutation of the many substantial objections.

SPEECH.PARA: It begins with the presentation of a blatantly biased opinion poll which purports to show that the people of Sydney and those in the noise affected areas are in favour of the proposal. The EIS claims that 170,000 people are in noise affected areas, yet to distort the poll an area containing 700,000 people was polled and two-thirds of these are in the areas east and west of the airport who have been misled to believe that the noise will be substantially reduced in the future. A quarter of a million people north of the airport who are dramatically affected were excluded from the study, further distorting the results. So much for the ethics and competence of the report. And it goes downhill from there.

Australia must have a new modern airport to compete in the twenty-first century. Sydney cannot continue to sprawl and be destroyed by an expanding black hole in the centre. The safety compromises inherent in the third runway are unacceptable. They make a replacement airport at Badgerys Creek inevitable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise to inform the House of a very important occasion that took place some weeks ago--the first ever international family day care conference which was held in Manly, Sydney, and sponsored by the Sydney Family Day Care Association. Honourable members will be interested to know that over 800 people from all States in Australia and some 20 countries were at the conference. These people range from family day care providers themselves to supervisors and other people who are interested in the education of the young and also in ensuring that people within our region have an opportunity to access what is the very best child-care system within our area.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, the Australian Government, through its overseas aid bureau, invited a number of people from Malaysia, some parts of Africa and India to the conference and ensured that they had access to the kinds of programs and systems we have here. Honourable members may be interested to know that the American visitors were, in fact, very impressed with the kinds of family day care systems we have because the systems they have are nothing like ours. There are no controls upon the people who may become child-care providers and there is very little registration. It is entirely dependent upon some of the local areas. In fact, one of the family day care providers from America looks after 35 children. One would have to ask what quality of care that would provide. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In addressing the Appropriation Bill with respect to primary industries last night, I ran short of time. There is a wide range of primary industries at risk if this Government continues with its ineffective policies on anti-dumping and countervailing duties.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year alone we imported $2 billion worth of foreign food. This financial year, Australia is expected to import $3.5m worth of Canadian pork products. Canadian pork is subsidised to the extent of 8.5c a kilogram, with producers also benefiting from massive grain subsidies.

Whilst the USA applies countervailing duties to the import of pig meat into that country, Australia does not. Australia openly invites the importation of subsidised and disease threatening products, to the devastation of our local industry.

While we readily import a possibly diseased product from Canada, a local meat works in my electorate recently had a consignment of beef refused entry into Canada due to the lower case `g' in the kilogram measurement on the cartons. What hypocrisy!

There exists no requirement in Australia to label unpackaged fresh food products. Australian pork producers pay $1.50 slaughter levy per pig towards the promotion of Australian pork. Canadian importers directly benefit from such promotion, with no associated costs. While the `put some pork on your fork' style campaign may entice consumers to purchase pork products, they have no way of differentiating between the Australian and Canadian goods.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would hope that, when the President of the National Farmers Federation and the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), speak to the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), he might have a better understanding about free trade and the position of the GATT Round at the moment. Certainly, if those with the cargo cult mentality in the National Party in Queensland and the League of Rights, the people who actually control those sorts of electorates out there, had their way as a result of their knee-jerk reactions, we would have 80 per cent of our export industry sitting on the wharf because no-one would buy it. Free trade and bilateral trade mean that people actually want to send something back to the country from which they export.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a pity that honourable members do not understand that, but if they were really concerned they too would stand up and roll the consumption tax because that tax is going to be a tax of 15 per cent on farmers. Now that the ball is in the Opposition's court it has the opportunity to stand up and show whether it really cares about farmers or whether it cares about the political career of the Leader of the Liberal Party. If the Opposition wants a Ferrari-led recovery, its members should stick with the Leader of the Opposition, but if it wants to stick with the farmers, it should roll the consumption tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is with sadness that I draw the attention of the House to the tragedy in Port Phillip Bay on 15 August 1991 when three members of the Port Phillip Sea Pilots lost their lives. Captain John Nance, Able Seaman Alasdair Macrae and Coxswain Joe Clayton all loved the sea and died in the performance of their duties.

SPEECH.PARA: The craft in which the tragedy occurred was the John Tobin, which my wife Beverley had the privilege of launching a few months ago. This pilot vessel was designed with the world's best standards as its criteria, with particular reference to the turbulent and often dangerous sea conditions which occur in the rip at the entrance to Port Phillip Bay. The design attempted to take into account every possible eventuality in the precarious transfer of pilots from Queenscliff to all kinds of large ships. The Port Phillip pilots have had continuous operations since 1851, under which a dedicated and efficient service has been provided to allow safe navigational guidance through the many miles of defined channel in Port Phillip Bay.

I trust that honourable members will join with me in acknowledging the devotion to duty of these men and in expressing our gratitude for their selflessness in the execution of their task. The sadness felt by the families of these pilots is shared by me, the seafaring community and the people of Queenscliff.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In regard to the current employment situation in this country, it is imperative that we look at the cost of immigration. Every factor that one looks at and every major study that is done indicates that immigration is impacting very much on the economy of this country and on employment. In Australia, it is fashionable to talk about the great years after the war during the fifties when we had mass immigration. It was a time that was supposed to have brought great benefits to this country. If one analyses economic indicators at that time, one sees that it was a time when Australia slipped furthest down the OECD scale. Immigration did not deliver the better standard of living which people of today believe it did.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that immigration is not sustainable in the present climate. It is also clear that in the long run immigration is not desirable on the scale that we have had it. There is no denying that immigrants have contributed a lot to this country. As an immigrant myself, I feel I have contributed something, but it is beyond doubt that most of the migrants who have come to this country have come here for the benefit of their children. They have come here for the future of their children. Migrants are saying to me today that they fought to come here for their children and they do not want to see that benefit eroded by continued immigration. It is about time that they bit this bullet. It is about time that we had a consensus across Australia on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) said that the debate over the goods and services tax was fairly in our court. I want to remind the House and all Australians that it is interesting to note the people who are playing in that court. I want to give a few quotes. The first one is:

SPEECH.PARA: The great value of a tax of this kind in terms of its efficiency will be its simplicity.
Guess who said that. It was Paul Keating. He continued:

These are the three main advantages of this tax. First, it will allow a more rational indirect tax system than the current anomaly ridden wholesales tax which has multiple rates, numerous exemptions and fails to tax the services sector.
Who said that? It was Paul Keating. Secondly, he said:
It will enable us to generate tax revenues to provide for a major reduction in the marginal rates of income tax.
Who said it? Paul Keating. Thirdly, he said:
It generates tax from those who have continued to evade--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! I suggest to the honourable member that he should refer to honourable members by their appropriate seat.
—-The honourable member for Blaxland. He continued:

SPEECH.PARA: or avoid income tax and provides a useful net dividend--
here is the man who said it--
and earnings from this system from accessing that black economy, will provide net income for the gentleman driving the tram.
Who said it? The honourable member for Blaxland said it. So the ball is in our court, but we have certain players with us who are from that side of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —-What we want to know is whether the Opposition is going to tell us what the tax rate is going to be. Every country with a GST puts it up; it never comes down. The Opposition is going to make one million small businessmen be tax collectors. It are going to run inflation out by 7 per cent. It is no wonder the Opposition is going crook about the business people in Tasmania not wanting to support the Liberal Party. They do not want an inflation rate of another 7 per cent and they do not want to be tax collectors for the yuppies in pinstriped suits.
—-Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I remind him of his statement to this House less than one year ago when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The truth is this: unemployment will not reach double digits.

I ask the Prime Minister: did he deliberately mislead the House? Has he simply lost control of the economy, or is this yet another example of his lack of integrity and of his general economic incompetence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As I have said on a number of occasions recently, all of us in the Government, certainly including me, deeply regret that the recession has been deeper and longer than we expected earlier. I have said that frequently. I take this opportunity on the release of today's figures, which have the unemployment rate going over 10 per cent, to express again the Government's deep regret that those figures have now been reached.

ANSWER.PARA: I have referred in this House previously--I could easily do it again--to the assessments made by the Leader of the Opposition last year and at the beginning of this year about what was going to happen in this country to inflation and interest rates as a result of the implementation of the accord. The Leader of the Opposition made quite unequivocal assertions last year and at the beginning of this year that, as a result of the operation of the accord, we would have massive increases in inflation and further increases in interest rates. The fact is that the Opposition got it absolutely wrong. The fact is that, in regard to economic predictions, the Leader of the Opposition does not come with clean hands.

As I say, we deeply regret that people in this country are suffering at this stage from the increase in unemployment. But the hypocrisy of this man opposite is unbelievable, because the fact is that the policies which the Leader of the Opposition advocates would inevitably lead to higher levels of unemployment.
Mr Nugent interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The honourable member for Aston!

—-One has only to look at the propositions that he is putting in regard to the slashing of government expenditures. He is talking about slashing $3 billion or $4 billion. If he were to bring in a broad based consumption tax in association with the slashing of government expenditure, it is inevitable, as the Leader of the Opposition knows, that the level of unemployment in this country would go even higher. Not only would he inevitably create more unemployment as a result of the implementation of his policies, but also he has no compassion for the unemployed. My colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training yesterday referred to this fact.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Ruddock interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The honourable member for Dundas!

—-He referred to the fact that the Leader of the Opposition would throw the unemployed off the benefit after nine months. There was an interjection which tried to suggest that the Minister had got it wrong and that honourable members opposite would cover by special benefits those who were thrown off the benefit. Let me make it quite clear from what has been said by both the Leader of the Opposition and honourable members opposite what their real position is. The Minister was absolutely right in saying that honourable members opposite intended to save three quarters of a billion dollars by throwing people off the unemployment benefit. That is what was said. Let me repeat what the Leader of the Opposition had to say. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Why not cut off unemployments? We challenge him.
He was referring to the former Treasurer. Those were his words on 22 August 1990. He said:
Why not cut off unemployments? We challenge him. Cut off unemployment benefits after nine months and match our policy. We are saving about $750m from that change.
And just in case there was some proposition that the coalition was going to cover that by the payment of special benefits--
Mr Ruddock interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The honourable member for Dundas will cease interjecting.
—-I remind the House that this is what was said on 19 October 1989:

ANSWER.PARA: What is more, the coalition has no intention of letting the special benefit become an automatic substitute for unemployment benefit.
The simple fact is that this Leader of the Opposition stands up and asks about unemployment in a situation in which it is inevitable that under the policies that he proposes--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Why don't you answer the question?
—-I warn the honourable member for Aston.

—-He would both have an increase in unemployment and throw the casualties of his policies off the benefit after nine months to save himself $1 billion to redistribute towards the privileged people whom he really represents.

—-I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the Speaker of the New South Wales Legislative Assembly, the Hon. Kevin Rozzoli, MP. On behalf of the House, I extend to him a very warm welcome.

—-My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. What information is the Minister able to provide on the basis of today's unemployment outcome? I ask further: what action is the Government taking to assist unemployed Australians to get a job?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the honourable member for Shortland for his question. I guess the first thing that one should say is that one should be cautious about responding to the figures for one month. What has been perfectly obvious on the month by month figures over the past few months has been the extraordinary level of volatility both in the area of changes in employment and therefore changes in the number of unemployed people as well.
—-How do you explain the figures?
—-I warn the honourable member for Dundas.

—-Looking at this month's figures--and I mention them with that initial word of caution--there has been a fall in the level of employment by about 23,000 and a fall in full time employment of nearly 30,000. The participation rate has remained the same and, as a consequence of that, the unemployment rate rose to a little over 10 per cent--10.2 per cent. The number of unemployed persons rose by just over 31,000 to 872,000. I should say that that is well short of the hyped-up, exaggerated figure of one million that the Opposition is so keen to throw around. As the Prime Minister indicated, we take no comfort from these figures. We recognise that those 870,000 people are suffering as a result of the circumstances in which they find themselves.

ANSWER.PARA: I mentioned that we have to treat with some caution the month by month figures. If we look at the trend series, we find that over the last four months the level of employment has been basically static; that is, there has been no decline in the level of employment as indicated by the trend figures over the last four months. That seems to give further support to the idea that the labour market has bottomed or is very close to bottoming. Nevertheless, until such time as employment growth exceeds about 1.7 per cent on an annual basis, we will not be making inroads into the level of unemployment.

The honourable member for Shortland asked what the Government was doing to assist these people to get a job. Firstly, it is worth pointing out that the Government has decided to assist people by providing support particularly to those who have been unemployed for 12 months or more. They are the ones who, having had such a lengthy separation from the labour market, are in a more difficult position than those who have perhaps left a job more recently. Therefore, we have increased substantially the support provided to those people to the point where, this year, there is an additional $200m provided to support training, work experience and other related programs which will provide real benefits to people in terms of assisting them to find the jobs that are available and those that will become available over the months and quarters ahead.

It is important also to recognise that the jobs we should be striving for in the context of the recovery are jobs in the industrial sectors, jobs in the traded goods and services sector, and jobs which are likely to be durable in the long term. The Government has decided not to resort to providing Budget funded, artificially created jobs, but rather has decided to concentrate all of its efforts on trying to assist the real economy to create jobs for people.

The Prime Minister made some observations about the Opposition's attitude to this whole question, and I should just mention in passing that the Opposition has in mind cutting substantially the support to unemployed people provided through labour market programs. I think the motivation for this comes from an expression used by the Leader of the Opposition when he was commenting on last month's employment data. At that time he said:
I think there are people that haven't tried hard enough to look for a job.

That sums up the attitude of the Leader of the Opposition to these 870,000 people; that is, it is basically their fault and therefore he would punish them as a result of the circumstances which they find themselves in. Our approach is of course quite different. We have provided them with additional support in terms of financial assistance for themselves and their families and also in terms of assisting them to make that transition back into the work force.

Of course the honourable member for Shortland has a very real concern for these people. There are particular concerns in regional areas, and I am looking forward to the work of the Caucus committee which is examining this question and no doubt will be putting some propositions to the Government in the weeks ahead. If there are inadequacies in terms of the Government's response to this situation, no doubt the Government will address that question in response to the special committee's report.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Given that the Prime Minister has claimed that no child would live in poverty by 1990, which has been shown to be untrue; that there was no need to fear a recession, again untrue; and that unemployment would not reach double digits, also untrue--I ask him: how can he expect the people of Australia to believe any future statement that he makes on the economy or any other matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As I said in answer to a previous question, if members opposite want to swap predictions, let us do it. So I will just ask the Deputy Leader of the Opposition the question rhetorically--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! Members of the Opposition!
—-We are asked by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to make judgments on the basis of accuracy of predictions. I remind him of his prediction.
—-That was not a prediction; that was a promise.
—-The honourable member has asked his question, he should listen to the answer. I remind him of the prediction made by his Leader on 21 February last year. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Accord Mark VI announced today will lead to higher inflation and higher interest rates. It will increase the likelihood of a major collapse of the Australian dollar.

That is his prediction of 21 February 1990: higher inflation, higher interest rates and a major collapse of the Australian dollar. This is the professor of economics telling his people, telling the people of Australia, what will happen as a result of the accord mark VI. Okay, let us have a look at the facts. Since that statement where the Leader of the Opposition said that inflation would go higher, inflation has fallen. It has not gone higher, as Professor Hewson said it would; it has fallen from 8.5 per cent to 3.4 per cent. He said that interest rates would go higher.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. I refer you to the section of Standing Orders on questions seeking information, standing order 144, and its reference under (g) to hypothetical matter. The Prime Minister is now talking hypothetically. He never got an accord mark VI; it collapsed. What is he talking about? It has not had any economic effect at all.
—-There is no point of order.

—-Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. The point of order raised by the honourable member for O'Connor was clearly frivolous. It was a debating point. He is making a practice of that. He has had 50 points of order, 48 of which have been ruled out. He is simply disorderly.

—-There was no point of order from the honourable member for O'Connor, and I would advise honourable members that they ought not to be making frivolous points of order. However, it is a matter for judgment by the Chair as to whether a point has substance. In the case of the honourable member for O'Connor, it does not. But I would also remind the Prime Minister that he needs to refer to the Leader of the Opposition by his correct title.

—-I have gone halfway through the analysis of the prediction by the Leader of the Opposition. He said that there would be higher interest rates. Since he made that prediction, interest rates have fallen by 8 1/2 percentage points. Yet here is the Deputy Leader of the Opposition getting up and saying, `What about your predictions?'. Okay, some of the predictions that we have made have not been borne out. I am saying that the Leader of the Opposition has been profoundly wrong in the assessments that he has made. If honourable members opposite are in the business of saying that they do not rely on people whose predictions are not borne out, then they should start the process of doing what is inevitably going to happen before next year, 1993, and that is to sack this man and his policy of a broad-based consumption tax which they know will not be worn by their parties or by the people of Australia.

—-My question is addressed to the Treasurer. In the light of today's poor unemployment figures, can the Treasurer advise the House whether the Budget forecasts on the fundamentals in the economy are on track, and are additional measures needed to assist Australia's economic recovery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Today's number of 10.2 per cent on a seasonally adjusted basis is within the Budget forecast which, as honourable members know, was for unemployment to peak at 10 3/4 per cent in late 1991 before beginning to fall in the first half of 1992. That events have confirmed our expectation that unemployment would rise above 10 per cent brings no joy to me or any other member of the Government, and I certainly do not want to understate the cost to those people who have been directly affected. There is a lot of chatter here today about other unemployment figures and, of course, 1982-83. One of the statistics is that the employment ratio now is still well above 1982-83, and that is indicative of the very strong employment growth that this Government gained through the 1980s.
—-Why don't you go back to the 1930s?
—-Fortunately, we are already seeing the early signs of recovery across a range of indicators.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-I know members opposite do not want a recovery. They laugh themselves inane.
—-You live in a dream world.
—-Here is Dr Hewson and Mr Hyde--Dr Jekyll. When the Leader of the Opposition was in honesty mode, this is what he said in a recent speech:

ANSWER.PARA: People, more and more politicians will try to convince ordinary Australians that there is an easy way out, that government can print money here, borrow money there, raise a few tariff walls or develop some gee whiz you beaut industry and everything will be all right. If there was a simple solution to our economic problems, don't you think someone would put it into practice? Let me put it to you as clearly and emphatically as I can, that anyone who says it will be simple or painless to fix our economic ills is a political quack, a charlatan and a snake oil salesman.

The honourable member for Bennelong today is also quoted in the papers in honest mode. So let us not have it both ways. We know what the reality of the situation is. All honourable members opposite want to do is exploit the unemployed and, in terms of their policy about knocking off the dole after nine months, they want to blame the unemployed for unemployment. That is what those opposite want to do.
Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am just waiting for the noise to quieten down.

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Hewson interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting across the table.
—-He has lost his place.

—-I am just waiting for it to sink in that those opposite are exulting in the level of unemployment. Consistent with the Budget expectations that the housing sector would provide an important impetus to growth this financial year, the number of private residential approvals rose in August, confirming a recovery in the housing sector which had been evident with a strong growth in the three months to August. My colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training has pointed out other figures in answer to the previous question.

ANSWER.PARA: The DEET skilled vacancy survey showed a strong rise in the skilled and trade skill vacancy index, the first rise recorded since the September quarter of 1989. The National Australia Bank quarterly business survey for September, which came out early this week, showed improvements in expectations. Trading performance and profitability are expected to become less adverse in the December quarter. A rise in orders is expected in December and export sales are expected to grow significantly in the next quarter. These are early signs of recovery.

Unfortunately, we all know--anyone with any economic wit on the other side would know--that employment always lags. The good news is that the modest pace of this recovery will contribute to consolidating the recent gains we have made with both inflation and the current account. One of the predictions of the Opposition, as has already been pointed out by the Prime Minister, is double digit inflation. We at least have very low inflation, not double digit inflation, with our unemployment figure in this stage of the business cycle and a recession. We did not have a wages blow-out. We are far better placed to recover from this recession.

We are trying to achieve an economic environment which will provide sustainable economic growth. That is our employment objective, and over the first half of next year we will see that being achieved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In view of today's sad unemployment statistics and the need--
—-Who are you asking this of?

—-My question is directed to the Prime Minister. My apologies, Mr Acting Speaker. I will repeat the question. In view of today's sad unemployment statistics and the desperate need to encourage investment in the 1990s and beyond, I ask the Prime Minister whether he agrees with Senator Button's views, which he clearly implied in a letter to the Prime Minister, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: the international investment community considers Australia has not been, and still is not serious about viable and competitive development.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I, of course, have the benefit of having read the whole of the letter which Senator Button wrote to me.
—-Table it and let us all read it.
—-I will not table correspondence between me and Ministers.
—-How can we believe you? Table it for us to see.
—-Order! The honourable member for Mayo!
—-The honourable member does not expect that I would and I do not intend to.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Downer interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! I warn the member for Mayo.

—-Press reports that Senator Button doubts that our business tax system is internationally competitive and may be holding up development are misleading. It is obviously part of the discharge of Senator Button's ministerial responsibility in that portfolio--a job which I believe he does extremely well indeed--to monitor all areas of business policy and business developments and to keep me informed. That is something he regularly does. All Senator Button said on the business tax issue is that some people have suggested that our depreciation provisions fall short of the best treatment on offer by some other countries. That is a view which is held by some sections of the business community, and they are entitled to hold that view.

ANSWER.PARA: I suggest that any fair assessment of our business tax system, however, requires a broader view which takes account of the overall cost of capital compared with that of other countries. Against that broad benchmark, we believe that the overall tax treatment of business is competitive in this country, but we are not simply saying that that is sufficient. As a result of an initiative by Senator Button last night in a Cabinet meeting which went on until about 3 o'clock this morning, but which considered a number of important matters, we considered the sorts of issues which are involved in the question from the honourable gentleman.

Let me say to the honourable gentleman that I do not want to try to have a partisan conflict about this. It is worth looking at, and having a detailed look, I believe, at whether the total business tax structure in this country, compared with others, is competitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —-He was referring to projects, not tax, in the letter.

—-One of the major concerns in the letter is about tax. On the other question of whether there are any impediments in the way of the development of projects by reason of environmental objections and that sort of thing, that is not the main burden of the letter.
—-That is what he said in the letter.

—-It could be said of virtually all the projects which Senator Button has listed and which were the subject of some consideration last night that the concerns really related to the availability of capital and the cost of capital. Because I attach significance to this, as I believe the honourable gentleman who asked the question also does, we have agreed to set up a committee of officials chaired by my Department--
—-Not another committee!
—-Oh, oh!

—-It is all very well the honourable member saying `Oh, oh'. The first step is to have a testing of the assertion that is being made in some quarters by some sections of the business community as to whether the totality of the tax structure is uncompetitive in this country compared with those countries with which we would compare ourselves. It is a relevant concern for people to have. We have set up immediately this committee which will be chaired by my Department and which will also have representatives from Senator Button's Department and from Treasury. We will want that report within a very short period.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr McGauran interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! The honourable member for Gippsland!

—-Let me say to the honourable gentleman that if in that report it were to be established--taking the whole broad range of tax treatment--that we were in a situation where enterprises in this country were at a significant disadvantage, then that is something we would address.
—-That has been known for years.
—-Order! The honourable member for Flinders!
—-Is it just dawning on you?
—-Order! I warn the honourable member for Gippsland.

—-I would suggest that it is fairly difficult to sustain the proposition about an adverse investment climate if we look at the figures over the last few years. Let me go to them. It is all very well making these assertions because we will always have some people from the business community coming along and saying that they want better treatment, a better handout. Let us look at the figures. As a proportion of real non-farm GDP, private business investment has reached record highs in recent years. We are not now speculating, let us look at what happened. It was 12.3 per cent in 1987-88; 13.7 per cent in 1988-89, which is the highest level on record; 13.2 per cent in 1989-90; and 11.8 per cent in 1990-91. Those figures compare with the long run average of 11.2 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: So what is the actual factual position with regard to what has been happening to investment? I repeat: the long term average has been 11.2 per cent investment in this country as a proportion of GDP. The figures for the last four years are 12.3 per cent, 13.7 per cent, 13.2 per cent and 11.8 per cent. When we look at the facts, we are not looking at a situation where, on the evidence, investment in this country has been stultified by the taxation structure. It is simply not the fact because in the last four years, including in this most recent year--1990-91--investment has been above the long term average.

Having said that, I and my Government have not been complacent about it. There are suggestions being made that there are elements of uncompetitiveness in the totality of the business tax structure and that is why we are going to look at it. We will have that report within a matter of weeks. I repeat to the honourable gentleman, who I think is serious about it: if we were to find as a result of that report that some changes needed to be made, then we would obviously seriously consider them.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of comments calling for an acceleration of the micro-economic reform process? What additional steps are intended to accelerate the pace of reform in the transport and communications sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am aware of calls in the direction that the honourable member alluded to. They were made yesterday by the honourable member for Bennelong in a speech in the House. It was a very useful speech in the context of the line of questioning that the Opposition has handed out to this point today. He said, among other things, that we ought to tell the truth about unemployment and we ought not to exaggerate it. That is a very sensible stricture as far as the honourable member for Bennelong is concerned--a member of the front bench. The lie that the Opposition puts forward persistently that at this stage there are one million unemployed in this country needs to be nailed. It has been persistent over the last couple of months. The unemployment level is nowhere near that. It has been a lie perpetrated by members of the Opposition in the hope that somebody will believe it at the end of the day. He went on to say that we ought not be gloom and doom merchants. Today and throughout this week the Opposition has been precisely that in the tone of its questioning in this place, despite the fact that it has had from this side of the House the obvious evidence presented that economic recovery is under way.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member for Bennelong then went on to talk about micro-economic reform and what impact it would have on the situation as far as employment was concerned. To some extent I agree with what he had to say; to some extent I do not. His argument about what would create employment in this country in the long term was that an accelerated micro-economic reform process would do the trick. It might and it might not. It all depends on the broad policy settings under which micro-economic reform is introduced. Of course, with micro-economic reform, in the first instance the most likely outcome is an increase in unemployment. If it has not been structured in an effective fashion by the time a recovery is under way--if it is introduced in a recession--and if it has not been done on a consensual basis, at the end of the day we are likely to find a return to bargaining power on the part of the work force. We will see any particular impact of it blown away at that point.

Contrary to what the honourable member for Bennelong has had to say, over the last couple of years the micro-economic reform process has been dramatically accelerated. We have a series of waterfront agreements in place that will improve productivity by 70 per cent and that have seen a couple of thousand people exit the workplace. In relation to the telecommunications area, I was delighted to get a call from the Chairman of Austel the other day. He was at a very important telecommunications conference in Europe. He said that in speech after speech at that conference people were saying that the legislative basis of the Government's telecommunications micro-economic reform process is that which ought to commend itself as the relevant model to any other country operating, in effect, in monopoly conditions in telecommunications.

TALK.START.PARA: —-And what about the third runway?

—-We are proceeding with the third runway process. As I have had occasion to remark here before, one of the things that this House and this country can be grateful for is that we have at least placed ourselves in a position to consider a third runway proposal which will provide us with an outcome that actually does increase the usage of Sydney Airport. If we had proceeded with the Opposition's third runway we would have had about $400m worth of expenditure to produce no effective increase in movement at Sydney Airport, because it proposed a close-spaced parallel runway, as it boasted at the time. I never listen to the heckling of the Leader of the National Party on the third runway because his policy on the third runway, if it had been implemented by himself, would have been a major letdown to his own constituents in so far as movement at Sydney Airport is concerned. This is the only Government that has managed to identify and get under way the development of a second airport in the Sydney region. We do not wander around the place feeling at all inferior to the Leader of the National Party on the subject of micro-economic reform as far as Sydney Airport is concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: I now turn to the changes we have introduced in aviation. We are now getting some truly astounding statistics as a result of the deregulatory policies that we have pursued. I will cite a couple. A record 382,000 passengers were carried on the weekend of 19 July. That was superseded in the weekend of 20 September, when 414,000 passengers travelled. The average discount on the top 20 routes during the June to August seat sale was 61 per cent off standard economy fares and 53 per cent off during the spring sale.

I go back to the point I made earlier in answer to the honourable member's question about whether or not micro-economic reform actually improves the possibilities of employment. It really depends on the broad policy settings and the extent to which it can contribute to that. As far as aviation is concerned, over the last couple of years we have had demonstrated to us extraordinary price sensitivity. People, on a movement of 10 or 15 per cent in the price of an air fare, will make a determination on whether or not they will undertake air travel either for business purposes or to support the tourism industry.

If the Opposition sticks a consumption tax on domestic aviation in this country, no matter what it might do in improving anything that we have done--I cannot imagine that there is anything it could do to improve what we have done if it got into office--it would immediately reduce the effectiveness of that micro-economic reform by its broad policy settings. Likewise in telecommunications. If it got a price change in telecommunications that improves it by 30 or 40 per cent--the sorts of figures that people have been talking about--but then sticks another 10 or 15 per cent on it, it does not get the benefit of its micro-economic reform.

The experience of Britain demonstrates again and again what can happen with micro-economic reform. We can introduce just about anything we like in terms of changes in work practices in the labour market during a recession; the test is what happens when the recession moves away. The United Kingdom had enormous wage demands go through the system. It was also quite evident--at the very great cost to British industry--that fundamentally there had been no workplace restructuring at all, merely redundancies. Because the Opposition is utterly incapable of either comprehending that or delivering it even if it did comprehend it, everything that it would propose to do in the micro-economic reform area in the recession that it would induce, despite the heehawing going on here about what the Opposition's feelings are about the contemporary state of the economy, would fall flat on its face.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's concern is to seek to address that issue on both the supply and the demand side and to achieve, hopefully, an improvement in the quality of general practice. —-Is the Minister for Resources aware of claims regarding the pace of the Government's micro-economic reform agenda? What micro-economic reforms have been undertaken in the Minister's portfolio? Have these reforms generated new investment? What are the constraints to accelerated micro-economic reform?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting Speaker, this may take some considerable time.
—-Could I say to the Minister that it ought not take considerable time.

—-In the interests of the good conduct of Question Time I will run briefly through just a few points. I am aware of the issue raised by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, and I must say I am surprised. In my own portfolio area--and this is a very quick thumbnail sketch--there has been an unprecedented level of micro-economic reform, and that micro-economic reform has unquestionably led to significant new investment and job opportunities.

ANSWER.PARA: In mining, for example, we have removed all export controls on copper, copper scrap, lead, nickel, salt and zinc, eliminating a range of delays to companies that previously had to wait for export approval. We have relaxed foreign investment guidelines for minerals processing, which has led to faster approval processes for new projects. We have substantially reduced tariffs, removing, in effect, taxes on efficient export industries. In that context, we have thereby brought about a prospective additional outflow of mineral product of about 5 per cent, or about $1 billion, in export income at 1988 prices. We have introduced duty free entry for minerals processing equipment and expanded the range of goods and services exempt from wholesale sales taxes. They have led to unprecedented levels of minerals output.

There is a similar--indeed, I would submit, a better--picture in the petroleum sector. We have deregulated the oil market, we have deregulated the LPG market and we have introduced historic and widely applauded reforms to the RRT, and introduced cross-company deductibility, which has led to significant enhancement of our exploration effort in high risk or frontier areas. We have provided for platform removal. Our new internationally accepted offshore acreage release program is commented upon regularly as the way to go in terms of the RRT changes. The East-West Centre has acknowledged this as being a brave decision and a model for other governments interested in these areas.

As a result, we have more exports; we have generated massive and prospectively enormous new investment. We have higher levels of petroleum self-sufficiency than ever before. We are now described as the fourth most desirable investment destination for offshore oil and gas exploration expenditure in the world, which is an improvement from twentieth in 1989.

In the quarantine area, there are very significant reforms. AQIS meat inspectors in the field have increased productivity by 36 per cent, providing a move towards quality assurance, which is the way to go, and lower service costs. But, more importantly, at 2 o'clock this morning, I might say, I concluded the Cabinet submission which I think will bring in the biggest range of comprehensive reforms in relation to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, so we can have a debate about that in the not too distant future.

Again in my portfolio area, I address the issues of electricity reform, the initiative of the Prime Minister and the Government in the new federalism context. We have gone from the seventh lowest to the third lowest electricity prices in the world, and we will get better.

Working with the States, we have now moved very far down the track towards developing Australia's first national natural gas strategy, which will become a key component of a comprehensive energy policy. By the middle of next year we will have formulated, for the first time since Federation, a very comprehensive national forest strategy. We will have a national energy strategy in place in concert and in cooperation with the States and all key players in that area.

In the electorate of Eden-Monaro we are setting about the biggest reforms--and, I might say, much overdue reforms; they should have been carried out three decades ago--to the Snowy Mountains hydro-electricity scheme. I welcome, quite genuinely, the comments of the honourable member for Bennelong on this point, and I am a bit disappointed that he is not here. But as is so often the case in politics, the rhetoric of the honourable member for Bennelong is not matched by his Party. In particular, it is not matched by the Leader of the Opposition.

Let me just run past honourable members again a couple of those reforms that I have indicated. The changes to the RRT will trigger $1 billion to $1.5 billion in new investment. Who opposed them? Who opposed these internationally acclaimed reforms? Of course, the Opposition parties did, and it was only at the death-knock in the Senate that they allowed them to go through.

In respect of the forest conservation and development strategy, the Leader of the Opposition is on the record early this year as saying he would be constructive about these proposals. What is he now saying down in Tasmania? He is doing a little bit of political pot stirring. He is now saying he will consider the thing in due course and that he does not see the need for it.

—-He remains to be convinced.

He knows nothing about that policy area. He runs off at the mouth in a radio interview. He should do the hard yakka, learn a bit about the issue and make a considered statement.

—-The Opposition opposed the commercial haulage rates for the Moomba-Sydney gas pipeline, thereby making it impossible for the Government to sell that pipeline. In reality the position of the Opposition is no different, in terms of hard reform, from what it has been for decades and from what it has been most recently in the term of this Parliament, when it agonised, divided and eventually self-destructed over the issue of grain transport regulation--a reform which is now showing very real and very tangible benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and concerns World Heritage nominations. What is the Government doing about nominating Kakadu National Park, Fraser Island and the Great Sandy region, and Macquarie Island to the World Heritage List?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am very pleased to inform the House that the Government last week nominated Kakadu National Park, Fraser Island and the Great Sandy region, and Macquarie Island for consideration by the World Heritage committee in 1992. The nominations were prepared in full consultation with the relevant governments, those of the Northern Territory, Queensland and Tasmania, and in fact they have been very supportive of those nominations.

ANSWER.PARA: Kakadu National Park is already recognised nationally and internationally as one of the world's great parks, and the inscription of stage 3 of that park will now ensure that almost all of the South Alligator River catchment will be included in the World Heritage List--a step that was encouraged by the World Heritage committee as early as 1981.

Fraser Island--and I know Queenslanders will be very proud of this--has been nominated for all four natural criteria set in the World Heritage Convention. This is an area of exceptional beauty, and I am sure that it will become one of the world's great tourist attractions in years to come. Because of that, the Queensland Government, in consultation with the Federal Government, is preparing a very detailed management plan for the area.

Our view about all these areas is that of course they must be protected and of course they are great natural assets; but that does not mean that we should try to keep people out or exclude the tourist industry in particular from those areas. To assist in that purpose and in the restructuring, the Federal Government has provided $16.5m, and the Queensland Government has matched that, for a structural adjustment program over three years to reduce the impact that World Heritage may have on employment in the area. Macquarie Island has also been nominated. It contains geological formations of outstanding scientific value. It is also the location for important upper atmosphere and meteorological studies which add to our knowledge of weather and the ozone layer.

I am very proud of these nominations and I hope all members of the House are. I am very proud of our achievements in this area because they add to a very substantial list of successful World Heritage applications. To remind the House, the list includes the World Heritage wet tropics of Queensland, the wilderness area in Tasmania, Uluru, the New South Wales rainforest area and, hopefully by the end of this year we will have a further successful nomination for Shark Bay.
