SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Prime Minister for his failure to provide the leadership necessary to provide real job opportunities for the one in ten Australians now out of work, and for his failure to maintain the integrity of the Budget in the worst recession in 60 years.

Today in this Parliament we have seen an attempt by the Government to down play the significance of the unemployment data that were released earlier today. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) strutted around as if there was no real problem in Australia, as if it was not a very significant issue that unemployment has now reached 10.2 per cent and that, on his own Budget estimates, nearly one million Australians will be unemployed in the course of this financial year.

The Prime Minister spent a lot of time trying to act nonchalantly about that by quoting from the past. He is a great lover of quotes. There is one quote for which he will never be forgiven. That is the guarantee he gave in a statement to this Parliament on 4 December 1990, when he said:
The truth is this: unemployment will not reach double digits.
Here we are, just eight months later, with the Prime Minister being damned out of his own mouth by the release today of the unemployment data, which shows an unemployment rate of 10.2 per cent.

That statement--`unemployment will not reach double digits'--will go down in history, along with the other classic frauds this Prime Minister has perpetrated on the people of Australia. Let us remember some of them. `No child will live in poverty by 1990' was one of the first and most significant classic frauds for which he will never be forgiven. `We will not need to fear a recession' was another classic fraud perpetrated by this Prime Minister on the people of Australia. The daddy of all classic frauds was the one taken into the last election campaign, when he promised to lead the Government after the 1990 election, knowing full well that he had done a secret deal with the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), at Kirribilli House to pass over the prime ministership in the course of this parliamentary term.

This is a Prime Minister who prides himself on his integrity. He struts around the place proclaiming his integrity. He claims to be a man of the people; he claims to be a person who understands the lot of working Australians. Working Australians will never forgive him for those classic frauds he has perpetrated on them. They will never forgive him for the situation he has now thrown them into, with the prospect of one million of them being unemployed. One in 10 already are unemployed in this country, with no real hope under his policies of getting a job in the foreseeable future. Indeed, on his assumptions and using his models, under his policies unemployment will still be above 9 per cent by the middle of this decade. The Prime Minister can sit there and yawn; he can sit there and try to distract, but he will not be forgiven for the significant extent to which he has deliberately and knowingly misled the people of Australia in relation to the unemployment situation, the recession, children living in poverty and so on.

One of the other things the Prime Minister likes to do is to pride himself on being a great leader. He puts himself in the tradition of some of the great leaders of the past. Last weekend he delivered the John Curtin Memorial Lecture. He sees himself as a disciple of John Curtin, one who follows in the tradition established by John Curtin. He talked at length of how John Curtin was the Prime Minister for 1941: he was the Prime Minister in the very difficult circumstances of the war; he set a very clear sense of direction for this country; and he led this country in a very effective way. The Prime Minister went out of his way to create the impression that, as John Curtin was the man to lead the nation in those difficult circumstances in 1942, it is Bob Hawke who is the man to lead the nation in 1991.

This is the man who has created one million unemployed. This is the man who claims to be in the Labor tradition. This is the man who, in the centenary year of the ALP, has constructed the monument of one million Australians unemployed. As far as his place in history is concerned, he will not be remembered as the man who handled our perilous times in 1991 but more akin to the experiences of 1931. If he continues down the policy path he has been following, unemployment will continue to rise in this country. He offers no hope for the unemployed at present.

The evidence of the past few days--as has been the evidence of the 18 months since he won the last election--is that the Prime Minister has lost control of this Government. He personally is starting to show the strains that have been on him and his inability to deliver even simple decisions about the last Budget. His Budget now stands in tatters. A week or so ago he lost his cool and lashed out at the Premier of Victoria because she and some of her Ministers reportedly were part of the leadership contest between him and the ex-Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland.

Now he has Caucus in revolt, a series of midnight Caucus and factional meetings, and open factional warfare. He has demonstrated absolutely no capacity to deliver even some of the simplest decisions of the last Budget. Imagine a situation where the Opposition has decided to do the responsible thing and not play politics on an issue as difficult as making changes to the Medicare system but give the Government full support for the $3.50 co-payment. The Prime Minister cannot deliver even that decision against his Caucus.

A Prime Minister has not been rolled by Caucus since the final days of the Whitlam years. This Prime Minister will go down in history as the second Prime Minister who has been rolled by Caucus--unable to deliver even the simplest change in relation to Medicare, a minor change in the context of what has to be done in this country to rebuild the health shambles that he and his Government have created. All through this uncertainty, factional fighting and Caucus revolt the vulture, the ex-Treasurer, sits waiting to pounce on the carcass of this Labor leader when he trips in the next few months.

It is significant today to look in some detail at the current state of the Budget and at the extent to which the Government has lost control of its Budget and therefore of economic management in the midst of the worst crisis in 60 years. There were two or three key elements in the Budget. The first was the wage assumption, which was plucked out of nowhere: 6 1/2 per cent through the year, 5 per cent in the year as a whole over last year, but no basis for that figure to go into that document.

Apparently there was a meeting at the Lodge. At the time it was not able to hold that meeting at Parliament House because a couple of our union leaders, Mr Kelty and Mr Ferguson, could not or would not cross the picket line. The meeting was held at the Lodge apparently in order to set a new direction for wages policy in Australia. Yet here we are in the middle of October with absolutely no idea of what that wages policy is. All the Budget figuring stems from those wage assumptions--the basis of which we have been told absolutely nothing.

The first reason the Budget is in tatters is that it has a fictitious wages policy and a fictitious wage assumption. The second reason, of course, is that there is this superannuation decision which is nothing more than yet another tax on the business community. The Prime Minister shows the appalling nature of the extent of his lack of understanding of basic economics. But he cannot see that an additional tax on the business community is going in precisely the wrong direction from the point of view of job creation. If he wants to create jobs in this country, he has to rebuild the business sector from the bottom up.

Central to rebuilding the business sector in this country is rebuilding business investment in this country. Despite the figures from some private sector based investment data that the Prime Minister very selectively quoted in the Parliament today in Question Time, the fact is that investment is at a 40-year low in this country. The business community is on its knees. The Prime Minister has seen record levels of small to medium size, and indeed large, business failures. In those circumstances, the last thing he should think of doing is imposing another tax.

The Budget is going to be called into question on that assumption as there have been reports in the media that some in the business community are going to challenge in the courts the decision in relation to occupational superannuation. Again, using the Government's model, we have demonstrated that that decision of 5 per cent occupational superannuation will create an additional 100,000 unemployed in this country; 100,000 more people will be thrown on the scrap heap by a completely misguided policy developed in the climate of the leadership wrangle that took place in June of this year.

The third reason, of course, relates to the Medicare part of the Budget. A major part was the simple decision to impose a $3.50 charge, a co-payment, subject to a safety net in order to start to get some rationality into the system of health care provision. There is a massive problem of overservicing in relation to health. In part, it is true that it is related to the excess supply of doctors but, importantly, price has to be introduced into that system and people have to face the reality that they need to pay for visits to the doctor, albeit quite a small amount, if that system is to start to see overservicing reduced. That is one step, but a simple step. It is only the first tentative step that needs to be taken if the health system in this country is going to be fixed, if the overservicing is going to be reduced and if something is going to be done about the appalling length of queues at hospitals in this country. It is a first step and the Government cannot deliver it and it cannot deliver it in a climate where the Opposition is out there publicly supporting it.

Indeed, people on this side of the Parliament have done more radio interviews and gone out publicly more frequently in support of that decision than have the Minister and the Prime Minister in trying to get that decision through. What hope does this country have for genuine reform when a minor tentative step in relation to the health system cannot be delivered by a Prime Minister who is totally preoccupied in saving his own job and could not care less about the one million Australians he has thrown on the scrap heap?

The Budget is in tatters for three reasons. Of course, one should not forget that the money that was to be raised from the Medicare changes over the next few years was to pay for the mad cities fantasy, which is an idea that has gone down very well, I gather, in the Caucus! It has had a tremendous amount of trouble understanding how on earth one could go into the health area to raise money to pursue some mad cities fantasy which could not even be explained to members and their staff when they met a few days after the Budget. They asked, `Where is the money going? How it is going to be spent? What are the projects that you have in mind?' They received no answers from the Minister's office or the Minister's Department about this mad cities program. There was a commitment of $800m over five years and no concept of how that is to be spent.

Just a few months after the Budget has been handed down, it is totally in tatters. The Prime Minister is totally preoccupied with trying to save his own job. He is doing absolutely nothing to improve the lot of the unemployed and to give them a real chance to get a job in this country. It is absolutely appalling when there is a genuine desire on our part to provide bipartisan support and to get on and solve what is a very difficult set of circumstances in the Australian economy at the present time. We are looking down the barrel of a very different labour market locked into an unemployment rate in excess of 9 per cent and the prospect of over 300,000 Australians facing long term unemployment, that is, being unemployed for more than 12 months.

It is a sad indictment that the Prime Minister does not listen even to his colleagues--let alone anybody else--about the need to put in place an effective job strategy for recovery in this country. Bob Carr, Wally Curran, Joan Kirner, the honourable member for Blaxland, Senator Button and Mr Bannon have told the Prime Minister; why does he not listen to some of them? They all have good ideas. Wally Curran is the guy who destroyed the jobs in the export meat industry in Victoria. He has had a Damascus road conversion and he, too, is telling Mr Hawke that he ought to do something about jobs in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Do you listen to Wally, do you?

—-The Prime Minister is not listening to anybody. He worries about his own job. He does not worry about creating jobs for those one million Australians. There is plenty that he can do in current circumstances to create jobs for those one million Australians. For example, he could start by acknowledging that he does not have a wages policy and that there will be no more wage increases across-the-board unless there is productivity improvement. To give the prospect of a 6 per cent increase in wages in the midst of a recession will be the biggest wage increase, if delivered, in our history in relation to recessions. It will create more unemployment. If he wants to stop creating unemployment, the first stage is to forgo the possibility of any further wage increases across-the-board unless they are related to productivity.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, of course, he could scrap this mad scheme of occupational superannuation, which is a tax on the business community. I am not downplaying the significance by saying that of having an effective retirement incomes policy in this country--one of the most important requirements in the course of the next couple of decades. But there is no way he can try to provide occupational superannuation by compulsion and there is no way he can do it by taxing jobs. It shows an appalling misunderstanding of the nature of business; it shows an appalling misunderstanding of the needs of the Australian people in relation to retirement incomes. If he scraps it, he can save some of those 100,000 jobs that are going to be lost as a result of that decision.

Of course, there are plenty of other things the Prime Minister can do immediately, too, to give us a clear sense of direction and to start to create jobs. He has played around with development projects for years. We have seen some of the greatest displays of hypocrisy here in the Parliament today in Question Time as some of the Ministers have trotted up one after the other--and I was not sure whether there was some sort of leadership contest going on at the time--delivering long speeches, not answers, in relation to questions asked from their side. They were trying to create the impression that they have done a lot of micro reform and approved a lot of projects.

Let me just give the Prime Minister a few challenges. Why does he not start today and formally commit the building of the third runway at the Sydney airport? He took a decision some time ago. He should go out and break ground with a shovel, get the process started and call for some tenders immediately.

Nobody could understand that mad Coronation Hill decision that the Prime Minister took but, apparently, at that stage, Caucus felt sorry for him. It saw him in an amazingly weakened state. It said, `We have to let the fellow have it. We have to give him this one'. Caucus could not understand one argument he put up on behalf of whoever he was putting up those arguments in order to turn that situation around. When I attacked him for the basis of that decision and some of the things that he said about the spirit Bula, I was amazed that I got a letter attacking me. It was not from the Aboriginal Heritage Group but, of course, from members of the Australian Conservation Foundation. Having failed to get Mr Hawke to deliver on the deal in relation to the environment and environmental considerations on Coronation Hill, the Foundation is out there manipulating the black tape element of the decision so as to make sure he delivered against his election promises of last time.

One of Mr Hawke's Ministers stood up here today and attacked me for remaining to be convinced about resource security legislation. It is a sad commentary that that whole issue should ever have existed. It only exists because of the very cynical and dishonest way that the Prime Minister has manipulated the environment and development projects in this country in order to buy votes in selected marginal seats around Australia, rather than looking after the interests of those who are unemployed.

The Prime Minister should reverse his Coronation Hill decision. He should go back and have a look at Wesley Vale and proposals such as that for pulp mills. He should not block them on foreign investment grounds this time, but give them a clear go-ahead. He should go and pick up the three-mines uranium policy which he has said is an illogical policy. He was rolled by the Left on that too. He could not even allow it to be debated at the last Party conference--a policy that he knows is wrong and is costing jobs.

There are three or four immediate things that he can do, over and above the wages initiative and the superannuation decision that I mentioned, in order to start to create jobs in this country. Over and above that, of course, there are plenty of other things the Prime Minister can do. He can embark on a genuine process of reform, including tax reform, which is fundamental to creating jobs in this country. For `Bob Hawke is against tax reform', read `Bob Hawke is against jobs'. There should be no doubt in anybody's mind that this man is not prepared to take that decision.

Again, here we are leading the fray, out there calling the shots, setting the agenda and putting the arguments that he put on consumption tax in 1985. We are prepared to go with them. But what does he do? He takes a cheap, political shot and tries to capitalise, in a cheap, short term political sense, rather than get on and do what he knows has to be done in this country to start to rebuild it.

So we can go with the waterfront; so we can go with aviation; so we can go with telecommunications and so we can go with electricity generation--all the areas where he has been unable to govern this country because he has been rolled by the union leadership or some of his business mates whose interests he has looked after at the expense of the average Australian.

One million Australians are unemployed under the Prime Minister's data. I have noticed that he does not query the one million figure. Some of his Ministers have been put up to start to query it, but on his own numbers in his own Budget nearly one million Australians are unemployed as a result of his policies.

So the Prime Minister must be censured. He must be censured, in the midst of the worst recession in 60 years, for failing to provide the leadership that is necessary to provide real job opportunities for the one in 10 Australians who are now out of work and for his failure to maintain the integrity of the Budget--a document that was brought down just a few months ago and a document which further compounds the basic problems of this country in terms of rising unemployment. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —-Is the motion seconded?
—-I second the motion and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting Speaker--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! Members of the Opposition should not interject. A motion has been moved by their Leader. For the debate to take place it is required that it take place without great interjection.

—-Let me go to what I understand to be the central element of the attack by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). It is in regard to the non-creation of jobs under my leadership of this Government. Let me quietly and unemotionally put to the Leader of the Opposition what the facts are in terms of the job creation record of my Government under my leadership and then, having put what the facts are and having compared them with the record of those opposite, completely destroy his argument by reference to what he has had to say about the incompetence of the Opposition in regard to the essentials for creating employment in this country, which is the question of having an appropriate wages policy.

SPEECH.PARA: First, let me put the facts. Fact one: even with the figures that have come out today, under the period of my leadership since 1983, in each year since we have been in government we have averaged the creation of 172,000 jobs--172,000 jobs a year since I have been Prime Minister.

Fact two: what is the comparison between the rate of job creation under my leadership and the rate of job creation under the Tories when they were in power between 1973 and 1975 and had the great benefit in that period of the economic advice of the present Leader of the Opposition? The comparison is this: the rate of job creation under my leadership of 172,000 jobs a year is three times higher than when those opposite were in government, being advised by the Leader of the Opposition. Those are the facts; not opinions, facts.

It ill becomes the Leader of the Opposition in those circumstances to base his attack on employment and unemployment--as badly as it ill becomes him to start his vastly incompetent attack on me by reference to John Curtin. It is very interesting that he should refer to John Curtin because this week is in fact the fiftieth anniversary of the coming to power of John Curtin. He was appointed Prime Minister of this country on 7 October 1941. There is a great resonance, a great overtone, about this when one compares 1991 with 1941.

How did John Curtin become Prime Minister of this country? He became Prime Minister of this country because, in dramatic events on the floor of the Parliament on 3 October in a situation where the Tories had the responsibility for defending this country in its gravest moment of peril, two Independents crossed the floor and said to the Tories, the Liberals--the UAP as they were then--and the Country Party, `You are not fit to govern. You do not have policies which are relevant to the challenge of the times'. At the time of challenge, when this country was in its deepest crisis of war, the Tories then did not have the policies to meet the challenge of the times. The Independents crossed the floor and said, `Be gone. You are not capable. You do not understand this country. You have no policies which are relevant. Be gone'.

Those are the circumstances under which John Curtain came to power. It is exactly true today; nothing has changed. Fifty years on, the Tories in this country have no policies that are relevant to the challenge of today. Just as they were thrown out properly 50 years ago, so they are irrelevant today.

Let me go right to the very core of the attack by the Leader of the Opposition. The charge against me was that I had constructed a monument in regard to employment or unemployment in this country. I have told him what my monument is; it is 172,000 jobs a year. But let us look at the analysis by the Leader of the Opposition as to what is necessary, what is relevant, for the creation of employment. I will quote from what the Leader of the Opposition had to say back in 1984 about what is necessary in regard to economic policy which is relevant to the creation of jobs. These were the words of the Leader of the Opposition:
. . . the Liberals really need to recognise the wages area as their achilles heel--
those were his words--
and to come up with an alternative.
What did he go on to say? He said:
At risk of being accused of heresy, might I suggest that it may be desirable for them to accept the concept of an accord-type agreement.

There is the analysis of the Leader of the Opposition. He said, `I look at the Liberals when it comes to the question of conduct of economic policy--and what do I find is their Achilles heel? They should face up to the fact that their Achilles heel is wages policy. At the risk of being accused of heresy, might I suggest that it is desirable for them to accept the concept of an accord type agreement'.
Again, what did he go on to say several years later when he had seen the impact of the accord type policy? This is what he said on 23 August 1989:
We have achieved some wage restraint in Australia in recent years and this has contributed to strong growth in employment and a fall in unemployment.

There we have the analysis by the Leader of the Opposition of the weakness of the Liberals' wages policy and his saying that what they ought to do is to have an accord type arrangement. There was an acknowledgment in 1989 of the strong growth in employment in this country and a fall in unemployment. Why was that? It was because the Government had and operated a wages accord policy. There is the real analysis by the Leader of the Opposition. That is when he gave his dispassionate economic analysis of what is required in this country. He was saying that the Liberals were no good because their wages policy was their Achilles heel; that what was needed to cure it was an accord. The analysis of that man was that what was needed was the operation of the accord, growth in employment and a fall in unemployment.

The Leader of the Opposition, having done that, has the temerity to stand up on this occasion and say, in purported censure of me, that my problem is that I am operating under an accord and a wages policy and what a terrible thing it is to have this accord. What note do we take of this man when he says, on the one hand, `We are hopeless'--the Liberals--`because we have not got a wages policy; we are hopeless because we have not got an accord. The Government is good; Hawke is good because he has a wages policy and an accord' and then for miserable political purposes, he stands up here and says, `I condemn the Prime Minister on the grounds that he operates an accord and he does not do anything in terms of achieving employment outcomes'? The Leader of the Opposition is revealed out of his own mouth as a hopeless hypocrite who will say and do anything in a time of pressure to try to save himself from the increasing public evidence that he is on the nose with the Australian electorate, and getting more and more on the nose.

Let me go further. I and the people of this country are entitled to say, `We hear the Leader of the Opposition, who puts himself up as an alternative Prime Minister, attacking the Prime Minister who has a rate of employment creation three times higher than the government of the conservatives advised by Dr Hewson'. People are entitled to then ask: what is it that Dr Hewson is now advocating as an alternative policy? What is it that he would do which would have an impact upon the level of economic policy and thereby on the level of employment? Let me briefly analyse what is involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —-A consumption tax.

—-No, we will come to a consumption tax later. But before we come to that we ask: what is the basic structure of the alternative economic policy? It is this: the Leader of the Opposition will savagely cut the level of government expenditure in the order of $4 billion. One does not need to be a first year student of economics to know that it would be an inevitable fact that if these people were to come in and dramatically slash the level of government expenditure in these tight economic circumstances it would inevitably drive unemployment even higher. There is not an economist in the country who has denied that that would be the impact of the policies of the Leader of the Opposition. So that is the fundamental alternative: a dramatic and significant increase in unemployment under the impact of that budgetary policy.

SPEECH.PARA: But, as has been said by way of interjection, there is worse to come. What is the Hewson panacea for the problems of this country? It is the broad based consumption tax--the goods and services tax. Let us analyse, as I have already done in this place, the impact of that tax in New Zealand. I remind honourable members that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) has said that this is the place that shows us the way to go. They are his words. What has happened? I am not choosing, capriciously, some irrelevant model. I am going to the Opposition's model. Members of the Opposition have said that is the way we should go. So we go there to find out what would be the impact in this country of the imposition of their panacea. As I have told honourable members, in five years there has been a 5 per cent decline in employment in that country; at the same time we have had a 9 per cent increase in employment. That 5 per cent decline represents a loss of one million jobs.

So I say to this man who has launched this censure, `You are a hypocrite because you have analysed your own weaknesses and said that you have not got a wages policy and that it is the accord which has created employment'. I have got that. I pointed out that the Opposition would slash expenditure by $4 billion and massively increase unemployment. I then pointed out, in regard to the Opposition's own model, that with five years of operation of a broad based consumption tax in New Zealand there has been a massive increase in unemployment. That is the alternative prescription of the Leader of the Opposition.

As though that is not enough in itself to totally destroy this man, we come to the further observations about courage. The Leader of the Opposition said that I have not got the courage to make the hard decisions. Well, we have made them year after year and, may I say, that we have made them every time with the courageous support of members of the back bench. They have had to take some very tough decisions. This man stands up and talks about a lack of courage. Let me remind honourable members again of this man's courage. This is the man who said to Beryl Beaurepaire, `Don't you worry about that'--to coin a phrase; I do not know where he borrowed it from, I think he had heard another famous conservative use the phrase--`I'll fix up Jocelyn Newman on this fundamental and terribly important thing of the charge to visitors to the War Memorial'. When the brave man marched into the combined party meeting, Jocelyn did him like a dinner. He did not even have the courage to fight her. Having promised Beryl Beaurepaire that he would take it on and win he was beaten and knocked over by Senator Jocelyn Newman.

The Leader of the Opposition should not come in here and talk about courage when we have had courage in the area, for instance, of tariffs. Those opposite were in office for seven years. What did they do? Not a single thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Nought.

—-They did nothing. We have taken on our own constituency and our trade union movement. We have had the courage to go to them and say, `These are the changes that have to be made. The Tories never had the guts to do it; but we will do it'. Those are the sorts of courageous decisions that we have taken. The Leader of the Opposition does not even have the guts to fight Senator Jocelyn Newman about an admission fee to the War Memorial. Don't come in here to me, you hypocrite, when you have promised your own Party--
—-Mr Acting Speaker, I ask that the Prime Minister be required to withdraw.
—-This is a censure motion.
—-The censure motion is, by nature, robust. I do not think the Prime Minister used the word `hypocrite' directly to the Leader of the Opposition.
—-I say that the Leader of the Opposition's attack falls where it should--flat on its face. (Extension of time granted)

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-I can understand that honourable members opposite do not want to hear much more. I will not go on for very much longer. I will just go to a couple more things that this gentleman dealt with. He talked about superannuation. I will spend a little time on the question of superannuation. The fact is that the organised working men and women of this country in the period since March 1983 have exhibited a restraint and a responsibility unrivalled in the history of this country and, I would suggest, unrivalled in just about any other democracy in the world. That has brought about a reduction of 10 per cent in real unit labour costs. That is the result of the restraint and responsibility of the ordinary working men and women of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The time has come when it is appropriate that that restraint should be recognised in bringing in a system whereby we will ensure that all people in this country will have, as a matter of right, a secure superannuation system. This is not some luxury. This is something which should be regarded as a matter of right for the ordinary people of this country.

Those sitting on the other side of the House represent the privileged sorts of people for whom superannuation is regarded as an automatic right. It should not be questioned that the people that they represent should have protection for their future! On this side of this place we happen to believe that there should not be, as there was when we came to office, this distinction between who had superannuation and who did not. When we came to office it was, by and large, in the possession of the privileged in this country. It was not the right of the ordinary working man--and certainly it was not the right of the ordinary working woman. But we are saying, as a deliberate policy decision, that we will bring about a situation whereby all working men and women in this country will have the right to superannuation.

What does the Leader of the Opposition say about this, coming from the sort of position of privilege to which he has become accustomed? This is what the Leader of the Opposition had to say about superannuation:

People can prepare for their superannuation (by) not only putting it into a few superannuation funds . . . they may save in banks, they may keep their money in a stockmarket and invest in equity themselves.

That is what he is saying to the ordinary working men and women of this country. He knows about the Reuters investment screen. That is the sort of background that he is accustomed to--`We can look after ourselves because we know how to play the stock market'. He is saying to the ordinary men and women of this country, `That is what you should do'. As far as this Australian Labor Party Government is concerned, we say that that is not good enough. If the Leader of the Opposition wants to play his screens, play the stock market, he can do it. But as far as this Government is concerned, we will provide, as a matter of legislation, that all working men and women will have the same right and the same opportunity as the privileged classes that the Leader of the Opposition represents. Those are the sorts of principles for which we stand.

As far as the impact of this proposal is concerned, the Leader of the Opposition in his speech has deliberately misrepresented the impact upon employers of this decision in regard to superannuation. In the discussions we have had with the representatives of the trade union movement--including the discussions that I had with them at the Lodge--they have made it quite clear that, as far as they are concerned, it would be perfectly appropriate and proper for what is paid out by the employers in regard to superannuation to be taken into account in the wages negotiations. We are not talking about double counting. But if one were to listen to this mischievous, misrepresenting Leader of the Opposition, the only conclusion that one could draw is that this was a new impost on top of wages which would not be taken into account.

Any acquaintance that the Leader of the Opposition would have with the truth would be entirely accidental. The Leader of the Opposition comes into this place determined to misrepresent both the achievements and the intentions of this Government. As far as we on this side of the House are concerned, we have said, firstly, that we are proud of the employment record that we have. We are proud of the fact--and perhaps subsequent speakers on the Opposition side will address this factual position that I put to them--that the rate of employment creation under my Government has been three times higher than it was under the Government of honourable members opposite. Will they say why that has been the case? Perhaps they will say whether they agree that it has been because, as the Leader of the Opposition said, their Achilles heel is that they did not have a wages policy--and they still do not have a wages policy. When the Deputy Leader of the Opposition speaks, he may address that.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I will start on that point.

—-Good--and he will not have an answer to it. Not only are we proud of that record, but also we deeply regret at this stage that we have had to slow down the Australian economy. I have said before why we had to do it. It was because our expenditure in fact was growing twice as fast as our rate of production. But I can now say to the people of Australia that the position now is that we have an inflation rate which is significantly lower than that of our major competitors. In this year it will be 3 per cent, as against a current rate of about 4 1/2 per cent for our major trading partners. If we look at the figures in regard to exports of manufactured goods we see that in the last two years we have achieved a 57 per cent increase.

SPEECH.PARA: We should be together--it should not be just this side; it should be Opposition and Government together--in being proud of the fact that Australian enterprises large, medium and small are now, as a result of the changes we have made, taking on the most competitive opposition in the world in manufactured goods. And we are beating that opposition. That is something of which we are proud; the damned pity of it is that honourable members opposite do not share that pride with us. What they want is not recovery but continued recession--because they hope that they will miserably creep into office on the basis of a continuing recession. Unfortunately for honourable members opposite, the signs are there that the recovery is coming. And not only is the economy recovering, but also the Australian people are increasingly waking up to what a bunch of irrelevant and hopeless hypocrites honourable members opposite are. Honourable members opposite will have the same result in 1993 that they had in 1983, 1984, 1987 and 1990--they will be rejected for the irrelevancies that they are. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Prime Minister, during his speech, used the word `hypocrite' directly about the Leader of the Opposition. I am sure it would assist the conduct of the rest of the debate if that were to be withdrawn.
—-I withdraw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Today the unemployment figure crashed through 10 per cent. I ask the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke): what will he do about creating jobs in this economy? People are not interested in the Prime Minister's living in the past, in the 1940s with John Curtin. They are not interested in the personal abuse and the silly political point scoring that laced the whole of his speech today. They are interested in one thing, and that is: what is the Prime Minister going to do about jobs?

SPEECH.PARA: I am very happy to take up some of the political points that the Prime Minister makes. The Prime Minister can demonstrate his real interest in this issue by walking out of this debate, as he will do. But if the Prime Minister wants to talk about comparisons, let me put this figure to him: during the Fraser years the average rate of unemployment was 5.8 per cent. Does the Prime Minister know what it is today, and has been through the period of his Government? It is nearly 8 per cent. The Prime Minister wants to talk about compassion. Let us talk about the people who have been thrown into unemployment as a result of the Government's deliberate policy to engineer a recession. Sure, jobs have been created in the last eight or nine years. We have an economy which, just through population, has grown in size. But at what cost have those jobs been created?

Under this Government's management our debt to the rest of the world has grown from $23 billion when this Prime Minister and the world's greatest Treasurer came into office eight years ago to $130 billion today. This country is literally addicted to debt as a result of the Government's policies. Sure, some jobs have been created, but it has been done at the cost of something like $75,000 per job. Any fool can borrow and spend, as this Government has done in the last eight years. But what has it done to our country? It has literally brought this country to its knees with the recession that we were told by the last Treasurer we had to have. Why did he say that? It was because the former Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, said that this Government deliberately induced this recession.

So what does all this borrowing leave the average family in this country with? The average families in the gallery today are left with a debt of $8,000 for every man, woman and child in the Australian community. That is the extent of the massive hike in debt that we owe to the rest of the world as a result of the Government's incompetence.

From the Prime Minister's contribution to the debate today, one would not know that we have seen the unemployment figure crash through the 10 per cent barrier to 10.2 per cent. One would not know that from the Prime Minister's attack on the Opposition. Given the opportunity to debate an issue which is on the lips and on the minds of every Australian, the Prime Minister's only response was to attack the Opposition. That will do him no good, and those who are unemployed as a result of his policies will take no solace from that fact.

There are 872,100 Australians who are now unemployed. Just in the last month, 31,600 Australians have become unemployed as a result of this Government's policies, many of those 31,600 being people honourable members would know--friends, members of the family, relatives. These are people who a month ago had a job, had the dignity of a job. A month ago they were able to bring in, as a result of their own endeavours, income to support their families. A month ago people making up this 31,600 were able to hold their heads high and make a contribution not just to their families but, through their work, to the future development of this country. That figure includes 8,800 full time breadwinners--fathers and husbands who had a job and the dignity of making that contribution.

A total of 20,800 females lost their full time jobs in the last month--that is, 20,800 mothers or sisters who, until this Government's policies imposed themselves on them and threw them out of work, were able to bring in a dollar and provide for their families, friends, relatives and others. These are real people who were proud of their ability to hold down a job and earn a living--people who had never dreamt that they would be themselves the victims of a recession induced by the Government, forcing them to go down to fill in the form for the social security benefit.

The figures show that nearly 30 per cent of young Australians are now unemployed. I invite honourable members to think of the tragedy that that represents for the future of this country. These unemployment figures are not just figures. These are, in fact, Australians and young Australians looking to make a contribution to this society. These young people are being robbed of the opportunity to work and to contribute to the future of this country, to themselves and to their families. Literally thousands of young Australians, as they look for work, find themselves on the treadmill of social security dependency which this Government is so fond of building constantly and which it has been forced to build on as a result of its policy. Think of how those young people will have their morale crushed--young people who will be scarred for life as a result of this Government's deliberate policy to introduce a recession.

I ask honourable members to set the economics aside and think of the social consequences of putting these young people on the treadmill. Think of the consequences for the crime rate. Think of the consequences for those who might get entrapped in the world of drugs. Think of those thousands of young people only recently described by the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe), the man who claims to have concern and compassion for these people, as the new poor--a direct consequence of the absolute failure of economic policy under this Government.

The official figure of unemployed is certainly 872,000 today, but do not forget the rest. That is just part of the story. The truth is that beyond that many more are underemployed. They would work more if they had a chance. They would put in more if the opportunities were provided. There would be something like 520,000 of those people, in addition to the 872,000. So we have a total of not nearly a million; we in fact have a total of 1.4 million Australians who are either out of work or who would work more if only they were given the opportunity.

What do we get from the Government? Nothing but a political attack on the Opposition, as if that offered anybody any hope. Today, again, we got from the Government just the holding out, the spectre of some hope of some recovery in the Australian economy. The Prime Minister promised us on 4 December 1990 that unemployment would not reach double digits.

That really is the classic completion of the trifecta: no child will live in poverty in 1990, honourable members might remember that; in the last election campaign, Government members promised until they were blue in the face that they would not let there be a recession; and then in December last year they made the claim that unemployment would not reach double digits, and yet it has done so today on their own figures. Now they are standing here and saying, `This is all right; this is what we thought would happen'. For heaven's sake, these guys have deliberately brought on this recession and thrown people into unemployment as a deliberate policy, reflecting their inability to do all the other things that need to be done in the Australian economy.

I ask honourable members to look at the claim of recovery. This is a claim they make week in and week out. I can take honourable members back to 1987 when the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), said, `This is the coming of the golden age'. It is a sick joke. The Government must believe that members of the Australian public are ultimately gullible. In 1988 the claim was, `We are bringing home the bacon'. Even last year as the economy was slipping into recession, the Prime Minister was saying, `Look, the recovery is on the way; things are picking up in the housing sector'. Does that ring a bell with honourable members? That is exactly what he said today. He is just repeating the same old words as the economy dives further into recession.

The Government says that recovery is picking up, inflation is down. For heaven's sake, inflation is down because we are in the worst recession for 60 years--not as a result of any policy of those opposite but because of the recession. The other claim is, `The balance of payments is looking better. This is good policy; we are really controlling this economy; we are fixing the balance of payments'. Sure, imports are down. They were down 12 per cent last time. Why? Because people cannot afford to buy the imports that they otherwise would have. In other words, this is a direct result of the recession--the worst recession in 60 years.

If honourable members want to know where this economy is going, the truth is that we are in a rolling recession. Sure, the figures are up and down a bit, but I ask honourable members to look at the figures that really count. Look at the big income earners for this country. Look at our agricultural industries, the rural industries. They are facing probably the hardest times they have faced since the Great Depression of the 1930s, as is endorsed by the Leader of the National Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —-That is right, minus 16 per cent.

—-Look at investment. There is not going to be a decent recovery, there are not going to be higher living standards for Australian families, unless we can get investment going. The Government's own projection this year is that investment is going to drop 10 1/2 per cent. If we talk to a few people out in the real world, they will tell us that investment is going to drop 16, 17 or 18 per cent. What is the Government going to do about that? The biggest symbol of the failure of economic policy and an indication of where we are going is the fact that unemployment is rising, as the figures show today.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no quick fix and we do not suggest to people there is. But I tell honourable members, as sure as we are all here today, that there are many things that can be done, and can be done now, to provide people with jobs. The damning indictment of this Government, during the worst recession for 60 years, is what we find if we look in their ranks. Do we find Government members talking about a national strategy for jobs? Do we find them talking about making those changes to policy that will give this country a future? No. What we find is incredible factional infighting as the Prime Minister builds up support to retain the top job. Why did we get the superannuation reforms? Because the former Treasurer had promised them to the ACTU and the Prime Minister had to do a deal to keep him at bay. It was made for no other reason but to save Government members' own political scalps--it was not made for the public interest at all. As a consequence of that decision, at the time of the worst recession in 60 years the Government introduces in the Budget a change to superannuation that will see an additional 100,000 Australians unemployed.

There are a lot of things that the Government could do. It ought to change the tax system. We have a massive problem with our foreign debt. The Government thinks that we need, as we obviously do, to boost our exports. Look at Australia's tax system. We tax people who export. Just let that sink in. The very people we want to encourage, we tax through the existing sales tax system. That is crazy.

TALK.START.PARA: —-That is a 5 per cent disadvantage.

—-It is worse than that. We need to encourage Australians in manufacturing to produce more in Australia. We need more of `Made in Australia'. That is a good idea; it means jobs in Australia. We run a tax system under which we give a tax benefit to people who import goods. In other words, we penalise our exporters but we give our importers a tax break. We pick up the paper and we read that another factory has closed down with jobs exported offshore. Why is that happening? One of the reasons is that we run a tax system that penalises the people we ought to encourage yet provides a tax break, with the taxpayers' money, to the people who are importing into this country. We have a tax system that imposes tax on investment. It is an incredible proposition. We are desperate for investment, yet the Government taxes investment. We need to make some changes.

SPEECH.PARA: I say genuinely to the Government, `Here you have rising unemployment crashing through 10.2 per cent. You have an Opposition that will actually support you. Today you ought to take the opportunity to declare that you are for full employment, that you have a strategy to provide jobs and that you have a timetable to implement that strategy without delay'. As I sit down, I say to the Government that we will offer our support. But until it makes the big policy changes, unemployment will continue to rise, and the Government deserves to be censured in the words of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Government is about policies; it is about the cohesion of policies; it is about the whole, not about parts. Government is about people; it is about change and reform; it is about advancing the chances and opportunities for all Australians; and it is about taking long term decisions for the future, explaining those policies to the general public and putting in place the measures that will lead to those better chances and opportunities.

SPEECH.PARA: There used to be a large measure of agreement in this country about the general goals. These were goals shared by all political parties. The way to get there was what we really debated in this House and outside in this very democratic society, a society where government does not take all the decisions. The Opposition parties in a society such as ours have a duty to put up alternative policies and show how they will work, rather than just carping and taking opportunistic swipes at a government.

The reality is that the Opposition's main policies are really anti-Government policies or a string of hardline ideologies. Its policies are really a gaggle of H.R. Nicholls's cliches because the present Opposition is led by a clique of extreme right wing ideologues led in turn by an extreme right wing ideologue. Its policies are nothing but a gaggle of cliches. There is no detail in the Opposition's policies. The centrepiece is a goods and services tax, and it is absolutely incredible that a major political party such as the Liberal Party, which has been kicking round since about 1945, is proposing to the Australian people an alternative as far-reaching as a goods and services tax but still does not have the guts to put up detail.

There is no wages policy, only the ideological solution of total wage deregulation. There is no health policy; it cannot construct a health policy. I do not think there is even any social welfare policy if we take into account the merciless attack on people such as the St Vincent de Paul Society and the Salvation Army by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) when he addressed ACOSS recently. That is the nonsense.

Today, again we have been treated by the Leader of the Opposition, in full irrational flight, to a typical performance. It was a performance short on detail, short on solutions, but long--very long--on personal abuse. It was short--very short--on any policy prescriptions with nothing about how to get real jobs. Of course, we have heard the usual general litany and prognostications from the Opposition. The message is unchanged: slash government expenditure; slash community facilities; introduce an unfair and regressive consumption tax; and privatise, without exception, publicly owned institutions.

Thatcher is the model. New Zealand is the model. What the Opposition wants is an intensification of Thatcher's prescriptions which have failed in the United Kingdom because, in moving to a more market driven society, the UK failed to do what we are doing, and that is restructuring in industry. New Zealand failed because it did not have a wages policy in its essential restructuring.

What we have heard this afternoon is a half-adequate description of computer economics I. What we have not heard is the detail of how the Opposition intends to implement its narrow ideology. We all know--people who have been in politics--that the Opposition's policies will irresistibly lead to higher unemployment. After all, the Opposition is dedicated to slashing close to $5 billion from Commonwealth programs. We all know that the Opposition's policies will irresistibly lead to higher interest rates. After all, the Opposition is committed to 0 to 2 per cent inflation, whatever the social cost.

I do not know how the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) particularly can stand in this place and say that his Party--his so-called coalition--is committed to 0 to 2 per cent inflation and yet is also committed to the introduction of a goods and services tax, when it sees what happened to inflation in New Zealand. For a period interest rates went to 25 per cent and inflation was at 19 per cent. That is the New Zealand model, the model the Opposition wants to inflict upon Australia.
I have got to hand it to the Leader of the Opposition. On some occasions he claims that he is green. It all depends on the audience, I guess. But he did say on 1 October:
. . . I believe in the environment as much as anybody else does, anywhere else in this country.

He is right, and the proof of the Leader of the Opposition's environmental credentials are simple: he is an ardent believer in recycling. He is recycling his consumption tax policy--if we could describe it as that, if we could dignify it by calling it that, because we have no detail--which has been around in his mind for years and years. He is recycling his flat tax policy. That has also been around for years in the Opposition. Joh Bjelke-Petersen probably gave that one to him.

The Leader of the Opposition is recycling his health policy--if there is one. That has been a major recycling effort by the Conservatives. He is recycling his privatisation schemes. He is recycling his industrial relations schemes. Jay Pendarvis is still the hero of the computer worthies of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Where is he?

—-Where is he? He was put up by the Opposition as the token, and then he was wiped off. We all know that the Opposition's policies will irresistibly place the burden of economic change on those least able to protect themselves. The Opposition is dedicated to scrapping benefits for the unemployed and taking the short sword to welfare payments. All of us in this place who have been in politics for a while know that the Opposition's policies will irresistibly benefit those people in positions of privilege and power. After all, the Opposition advocates with this gaggle, this string of H.R. Nicholls's cliches, the further empowerment of the already powerful in Australian society.

SPEECH.PARA: These are the general results of a political philosophy which holds that the devil and the scrap heap take the hindmost. Thinking members of this House and the people of Australia understand that the general thrust of the Opposition's policy approach is unfair, narrow and regressive. But that is about all we know, for we in this House, and Australians in the urban and regional areas, are still waiting for the detail.

The Leader of the Opposition started off today with a childish, immature approach to politics. He was trying, as he did in Question Time today, to pin the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and other members of the Government with statements made some time ago. As we all well know, this is a very childish exercise; anybody can pick the statements of any one of us at any time and show later they were incorrect. I have never come to the conclusion about that sort of nitpicking that people in public life do not believe what they are saying at the time.

There is the much misquoted `children in poverty' allegation that the Opposition loves to trot out, knowing full well, cynically, that if it were in government it would slash social welfare. I will just refer to the family allowance supplement. All the reforms that we have secured in social security and the fact that we have increased the percentage of spending on those least able to cope with the conditions they are faced with in society--all that targeting, most recently exemplified in the family package in the Budget--show that we are doing more and more for the poor, and we are proud of it. The Opposition wishes to slash social welfare, yet it laughs about an honestly made statement, one that we have gone a long way towards providing security for the children of this country.

There is talk of the recession. We have to understand that the 1980s was a long period of growth for many of the countries in the world. It was a decade of unprecedented growth. Policies followed by us and many other countries in the world did not make allowance for some aspects of the growth and the activities of the private sector particularly, in those growing economies. It was not just the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada and New Zealand that took some of the same policy prescriptions; there was also a range of smaller countries.

Part of this was associated with financial deregulation. In Australia's case, the terms of trade collapse in 1985-86, the worldwide phenomenon of the stock market crash in 1987, and the very rapid turnaround in our terms of trade were not fully allowed for. In hindsight, the world's reaction to the 1987 stock market crash was too much. Perhaps the Leader of the Opposition should quote all those people in the United States and the other advanced Western economies who made statements at the time which were subsequently proved to be incorrect. We swapped a tight fiscal policy for what could be seen, with hindsight, as a too soft monetary policy. None of us in the advanced Western countries measured well enough the dimensions of the asset price boom, particularly in central business district management, in equities and in dwellings. The countries of the world with which we compare ourselves all shared that experience.

We are vitally concerned about business investment. The leaks to the newspapers today indicate that. But we have to face reality. I believe in telling Australians the way it is. There is not going to be a lot of investment in the central business districts of our cities. We can see the legacy of that assets price boom, with at least three cities in Australia massively overbuilt. We know the stress that agriculture is going through. We know that there is not going to be a lot of investment there. Through that big boom in investment in the late 1980s, we know that a lot of investment went into manufacturing industry and that there is now low capacity utilisation there.

The point the Opposition fails to understand and fails to make, in its cynical opportunism, is that through the 1980s, through that period of growth, with the cooperation of the trade union movement in this country we achieved more structural reform than we have ever achieved before. State governments now come to us for funds for redundancy programs as they straighten out their public infrastructure. We are the ones who took the hard decisions on tariff reform. We are the ones who have taken the hard decisions in welfare reform. We are the ones who have taken the hard decisions on restructuring, getting a larger traded goods sector. We are the ones who took the fundamental decisions to internationalise this economy and get away from the colonial cringe once and for all. We are the people who have been taking the decisions to make this economy more competitive.

What is the Opposition going to do about investment? It is not saying a word about that. It is not prepared to take reality into account. We know that we will get continuing investment in the mining sector. We know that as the economy grows again there will be investments to take up the slack and pick up stocks. We know that when the Opposition is honest, as the Leader of the Opposition recently was in part of his speech to ACOSS, and as the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was yesterday about the reality of interest rates--all the speculation by the media is silly if we are going to equate any particular interest rate drop with jobs immediately--it understands the situation, but today we saw an example of cynical opportunism.

What is the Opposition going to say? Is it going to say to the business sector that it can have immediate write-off? Is it going to say with respect to depreciation that it can have 33 per cent write-off? Is it going to advocate those sorts of policies and encourage investment, probably not of an optimal nature? The Deputy Leader of the Opposition says that there is a tax on investment. I do not quite know what he means by that. We have always had very good depreciation systems in this country. The taxation reform we put in place for the company sector, the business sector, through the 1980s was unprecedented. We changed the effective company tax rate from 74.4 per cent to 39 per cent. The Opposition could never have even envisaged doing what the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) did for the corporate sector with respect to taxation reform through the 1980s.

It is almost ironic that, while the discipline of the trade union movement meant that profits were vastly increased as we worked with the union movement and increased the social wage, a lot of those profits were frittered away by the private sector and the suboptimal decisions taken. We can go into international comparisons with respect to our taxation system. Overall, we have the second lowest level of tax in the whole of the OECD. These matters are before us.

I could go on, but I am sure that this motion has been seen for what it is by the people of Australia. It is just another example of cynical opportunism by the Opposition. The Opposition does not have one skerrick of alternative policy. We have not seen one detail of its policies and nothing has been said about the future of Australia. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question put.
