TALK.START.PARA: —-I present the report of the Selection Committee relating to the program of business prior to 12.30 p.m. on Thursday, 17 October 1991. The report will be printed in today's Hansard and the items accorded priority for debate will be published in the Notice Paper for Monday, 14 October 1991.

INTERJECT.PARA: Report Relating to the program of

Pursuant to sessional order 28D, the Selection Committee has determined the order of precedence and times to be allotted for consideration of committee and delegation reports and private Members' business on Thursday, 17 October 1991. The order of precedence and the allotments of time determined by the Committee are shown in the list.
1 FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE--JOINT COMMITTEE--Report-- Australia's Current Account Deficit and Overseas Debt.

The Selection Committee proposes that debate on a motion--That the House take note of the report--be resumed at a later hour and the mover of the motion continue his or her remarks when the debate is resumed.
2 TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE--STANDING COMMITTEE--Report--Management of the Radio Frequency Spectrum.

The Selection Committee proposes that debate on a motion--That the House take note of the report--be resumed at a later hour and the mover of the motion continue his or her remarks when the debate is resumed.
3 FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE--JOINT COMMITTEE--Report--Visit by the Defence Subcommittee to Adelaide.
The Committee has determined that statements on the report may be made--all statements to be made within a total time of 10 minutes.
1 FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE--JOINT COMMITTEE--Report-- Australia's Current Account Deficit and Overseas Debt--Motion to take note of paper: Resumption of debate.
The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.
2 TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE--STANDING COMMITTEE--Report--Management of the Radio Frequency Spectrum--Motion to take note of paper: Resumption of debate.
The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.

1 MR LANGMORE: To move--That the House supports the broad thrust of the recommendations of the report on young people's participation in post-compulsory education and training (the Finn Report) and in particular calls on governments to ensure adequate funding to allow implementation of the recommendations so that the targets for access to education and training can be realised by 2001. (Notice given 8 October 1991.)
The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.
2 MR RUDDOCK: To move--That the House:
(1) acknowledges the right of self-determination of the Ukraine;
(2) notes the declaration of independence and that the declaration is to be put to the Ukrainian people for confirmation in December 1991;

(3) believes that, subject to such confirmation and the Ukraine meeting the criteria for independent statehood, the international community, including Australia, should support its independence by diplomatic recognition; and
(4) calls upon the Australian Government in the meantime to support the aspirations of the Ukrainian people by:
(a) establishing a consulate in the Ukraine;
(b) opening a trade office in Kiev; and
(c) ensuring the Ukraine gets its fair share of the training and management scholarships the Australian Government is offering to the Soviet Union. (Notice given 8 October 1991.)
The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.

1 TAX EXEMPT SPECIAL SAVINGS ACCOUNTS: Resumption of debate (from 10 October 1991) on the motion of Mr Kerr--That this House commend to the Government the introduction of a scheme modelled on the British tax exempt special savings account in order to facilitate both the growth of domestic savings and the encouragement of Australian investment in Australian domestic industry.
The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.
2 YUGOSLAV REPUBLICS: Resumption of debate (from 12 September 1991--Mr Kerr, in continuation) on the motion of Mr Filing--That the House:

(1) deplores the violence, loss of life and destruction of property that has taken place in Slovenia and Croatia, where more than 30 civilians are reported to have been killed, largely as a result of the attacks of terrorists supplied by the communist-led federal army and attacks by the army itself;
(2) notes the potential for further conflict if aspirations for self-determination expressed through democratic plebiscites in the Yugoslav republics are confronted by military force;
(3) welcomes the efforts of the European Community to act as a mediator to prevent further conflict;

(4) calls on the Australian Government to support international efforts for a negotiated settlement between the Yugoslav republics which will avoid conflict, achieve the independence which the people of Croatia and Slovenia demand and protect the interests of ethnic and religious minorities; and

(5) further calls upon the Australian Government to recall its Ambassador to Yugoslavia for consultations on how Australia might, consistent with a desire to preserve peace, support the newly evolving, independent states, including the most appropriate time to give diplomatic recognition.
The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—-Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—-I do.
—-The honourable member may proceed.

—-During Question Time the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was asked a question on the predictions of the Leader of the Opposition regarding accord mark VI. I raised a point of order under Standing Order 144(g) which refers to hypothetical matter. As the Industrial Relations Commission had rejected accord mark VI, probably for the same reasons as stated by the Leader of the Opposition, the Prime Minister was clearly dealing with a hypothetical situation.

—-Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. This is not a personal explanation on the basis of being misrepresented. The honourable member has not demonstrated where he has been misrepresented. What he is actually doing is an ultimate contempt. He is simply canvassing a ruling.
—-Mr Acting Speaker, on a point of order--

—-I will deliberate on this first point of order. The honourable member may correct the record where he has been misrepresented, not where the Party at large has been misrepresented. I will hear further, but I suggest that he does not introduce new material in the matter.
—-I certainly do not intend to. As can be seen, I have only 1 1/2 pages on the subject, but I have to state the grounds on which the misrepresentation occurred.
—-No, you don't.
—-One normally does when one reads something from a newspaper, dopey.
—-Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will withdraw.
—-I withdraw.
—-The honourable member should proceed to his personal explanation.

—-Probably for the same reason as stated by the Leader of the Opposition, the Prime Minister was clearly dealing with a hypothetical situation, particularly in his attempt to link current recession induced inflation figures--

—-Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. If anyone has been misrepresented, and no-one has, it would be the Leader of the Opposition, not the honourable member for O'Connor. The honourable member for O'Connor does not come into this House and make personal explanations on the basis of where he thinks his leader has been misrepresented.
—-The Leader of the House is quite correct. However, I am still trying to establish whether the honourable member for O'Connor is trying to correct the record about himself.

—-Mr Acting Speaker, I remind you of the point of order of the present maker of points of order, that my point of order was frivolous. That is an insult to me and my parliamentary credentials, and I am about to correct it. If I can conclude, I will do so.
—-The honourable member for O'Connor needs to get to the substance.

—-That is right. The substance was the point of order taken by the Leader of the House that I insulted this House by making a frivolous point of order. In fact, I want it withdrawn because, quite clearly, in attempting to link his recession induced inflation figure with his accord mark VI, the Prime Minister was dealing with a hypothetical matter.
—-There is no requirement on the Leader of the House to withdraw his intervention. The matter is now concluded.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Higher Education: Quality and Diversity in the 1990s

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I present a policy statement, Higher Education: Quality and Diversity in the 1990s, which outlines the Government's policies and priorities for higher education for the coming decade. The statement incorporates the announcements of the level and composition of enrolment growth, as well as the aggregate levels of funding to be provided under the operating grant and capital programs for the 1992-94 triennium.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the release of the Government's White Paper on higher education in July 1988, Australia's higher education system has undergone a period of unparalleled growth and structural change. This period saw the ending of the increasingly anachronistic `binary' divide between the traditional universities and the colleges of advanced education, and an increased emphasis on the competitive allocation of research funds. One particularly welcome change was the introduction of rolling triennial arrangements for higher education funding.

It has also been marked by very substantial increases in levels of Commonwealth funding support. In this statement the Government is announcing major new funding commitments, over and above those needed to support growth, to enable the system to address the challenges of the 1990s. Total funding for the 1992-94 triennium will exceed $12 billion.

Of particular importance is the Government's decision to provide an additional $70m per year from 1994, approximately 2 per cent of total operating grant funds, to support and to reward measures adopted by institutions to enhance quality of teaching. These funds are over and above normal operating grant funds. This is a key element in an integrated set of initiatives set out in this statement addressing the issue of quality.

The Government is providing a major boost to the higher education capital program for 1994 to facilitate continuing growth in the system and to address the pressing need for refurbishment of existing capital stock. An additional $270.3m is to be provided in 1994, a 27 per cent real increase over the 1993 level. By way of contrast, the 1988 capital program was $94.2m.

In this statement the Government is also signalling its intention to liberalise the capital program, in particular by, from 1992, extending the definition of capital to recognise major investments in course materials and equipment which are genuine capital substitutes and, over the period 1994-96, the incorporation of the higher education capital program into institutional operating grants.

In deciding on higher education growth in 1994, the Government has sought to at least maintain levels of opportunity for undergraduate study for both school leavers and older aspirants, and has decided to provide an additional $41m for some 2,845 new intakes in 1994, including 1,450 higher degree places. This means that the higher education operating resources will have risen from $2,950m in 1988 to $3,700m in 1994. Support for targeted research programs administered by the Australian Research Council has risen from $90m in 1988 to $260m in 1994.

Some of the changes introduced since the White Paper, particularly the annual `profiles' negotiations which provide the basis for the Commonwealth's funding for individual institutions, attracted a degree of initial controversy. However these processes, as they have been refined over the past three years, are now very well accepted by the system. The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, AVCC, in particular, has repeatedly affirmed its support for the profiles mechanism as providing a reasonable balance between the requirements of institutional autonomy and public accountability.

The higher education system has experienced some particular stresses in recent times as a result of high levels of over-enrolment and overcrowding. On 4 October I released a statement which, drawing on data collected by the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the results of a survey of institutions conducted by the AVCC, provided an analysis of the causes of the problem and a strategy to deal with them.

While current labour market conditions were a contributing factor, it is also clear that there are significant deficiencies in some institutions' procedures for monitoring and controlling enrolments. The Government's strategy to ameliorate these problems, which includes giving institutions more flexibility in meeting student load targets, has been welcomed by the system.

The Government announced a range of short term measures to deal with these problems in the 1991-92 Budget context, including an acceleration of the capital program, the introduction of renovation grants on a matching funds basis, and additional recurrent funding to help cope with enrolment pressures.

A further source of tension was the long delay in finalising the salary increases and other matters flowing from the structural efficiency principles. This matter, which was eventually referred to a Full Bench of the Industrial Relations Commission, took far longer to resolve than any of the parties, or the Commonwealth, would have desired. The Commonwealth responded very promptly to the IRC decision on 23 July by agreeing to fund fully the salary increases flowing from the decision. This decision, which will mean average salary increases for academics of 16 per cent, rising to 20 per cent, should help considerably to alleviate the prospective shortage of academic staff to the year 2000.

In considering directions for the future, the Government has been mindful that many of the White Paper changes, particularly the institutional restructuring and amalgamations, need further time to become fully bedded down. It is clear that the system would benefit from a further period of relative stability in these matters. It is the Commonwealth's intention that, in general, the further evolution of institutional arrangements in the higher education system should be on the initiative of the institutions themselves, with the Commonwealth playing a less active role than in the recent past.

In framing this statement, the Government has been mindful of the recommendations of the report on young people's participation in education and training, the Finn review. The Finn review envisages continued growth in all education and training sectors but places particular emphasis on raising the status of and participation in the technical and further education sector. The report also calls for an inquiry into the appropriate balance of participation in the various education and training sectors.

Concern has been expressed in some quarters that higher education could suffer as a result of the renewed attention being given to TAFE. This statement should put any such fears decisively to rest. The 1994 level of growth, as announced in this statement, is the same as that for 1993 and, furthermore, should be regarded as a minimum as it may be revisited following the Finn review of intersectoral balance.

The level of funding I am announcing today supports a series of measures, which are detailed in this statement, designed to promote quality and diversity in the higher education system. These measures can be grouped according to three broad themes:
the need for credible quality assurance arrangements for Australia's higher education system and for arrangements to systematically reward excellence in teaching as well as research;
the changing pattern of participation in higher education during the 1990s and the relationship of higher education to the other education and training sectors; and

the potential for new technologies and alternative delivery modes to transform aspects of the delivery of higher education and to substantially broaden access. Institutions need increased flexibility in the use of funds, particularly those provided under the capital program, if this potential is to be realised.
I commend this policy statement to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--It is very pleasing that the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) has finally produced his paper. It is nice that he has got it in; he has had a lot of extensions on it.
—-I am not a student.

—-It looks like a student essay; in some respects, unfortunately, it is as thin as many a student essay. It has the nice plastic cover that a student essay typically has. It has an attractive title, which I recognise as referring to important values in higher education that have been consistently reiterated by the Opposition but have not figured largely in the Government's statements about its goals for higher education. So it is pleasing to see these values reflected in the title of the paper.

SPEECH.PARA: If one were marking this paper, I think one would have to say that the substance of the essay is not appropriate to the title. There is very little in the paper of any substance which supports the title or which will increase quality or secure diversity in higher education in the 1990s. I think the Minister probably believes that that is the case and is somewhat embarrassed by the thinness of this document, because in his statement to the House when presenting the paper he made a great deal of the funding decisions embodied in the paper but said very little about any of the material set out in the paper under the headings of `Quality' and `Diversity'.

I can only assume from that that the Minister does not believe that the measures he has set out in the paper specifically to achieve quality and diversity will do so. If that is his secret belief, one can only endorse it, because this is a paper which fails totally to address the fundamental structural problems in higher education. It relies for its acceptance in the academic community on some funding decisions that undoubtedly will be welcomed. I have no doubt that vice-chancellors will welcome the moves towards greater flexibility in relation to capital funding and the widening of the definition of capital funding.

There will be general acceptance of and satisfaction with the increases in funding that occur; although, when a paper continually refers to figures relating to triennia and long periods of time, one begins to wonder whether it is not a deliberate political strategy to inflate the size of the funding figures to create a better impression on behalf of the paper than the paper actually warrants. A look at the substance of these measures will show that they are considerably slighter than the inflated rhetoric the Minister has applied to them.

This paper serves only to underscore how the Liberal and National parties have been leading the debate on higher education in this country. It is a paper that is full of plagiarised rhetoric and symbolic gestures in an effort to pretend that the Government is actually proposing some significant freeing up of the higher education system in the interests of quality and diversity. The emphasis on funding decisions in the Minister's statement I think is revealing. The paper fails to address the fundamental structural impediments to quality and diversity which its system of funding and its system of regulation have put in place. Quality and diversity are important values. Indeed, they are vital to the health of higher education over this decade. The paper speaks loudly on their behalf but does little to achieve them.

It is interesting that this paper does not refer in its title to equity or opportunity. There is, of course, a reason for this--and not the reason given in the paper, which is that that has all been dealt with. The Minister knows that it would receive a horse laugh from people around the country who have been reading of the tens of thousands of qualified students who are excluded from universities. Not even this Minister could pretend that this paper has anything in it which will significantly enhance opportunities for the growing number of qualified students whom this Minister will not let into universities. This year the number of students was 30,000. A week ago the Minister announced his solution to those additional students who had crept in over and beyond the quotas he had imposed on universities. He said to the universities, `We'll solve the problem of overcrowding. We'll lock these students out of the institutions'.

The Minister admitted then, and admits in this paper, that there was a flaw in the Government's system of quotas imposed on institutions. I think there was some recognition in this statement he issued that these regulations of the Government provided institutions with an incentive to overenrol. Institutions knew that if they underenrolled they would lose funding and that if they overenrolled they would be fully funded. So they had to enrol up to the base figure. The Government created the problem of overcrowding. It refused to fund the students. Now it says that the solution is to help the universities stop letting in so many Australian students.

The Government has given the universities some flexibility in relation to quotas; that is something. But it is quite clear from this paper that it is determined to maintain its prohibition on the universities offering additional places to Australian students on terms that are acceptable to both the student and the institution. This Minister has no objection whatever to overseas students being admitted to Australian universities for full fees--and there are 15,000 such students in the system, but he has a deep objection to the universities overenrolling some 14,000 students who he says should not be there, and he is determined to prevent them enrolling another 30,000 students whom he says he is not prepared to pay for. He will not allow them to pay for themselves, for business sponsors to pay for them or for them in any way to get access to the public higher education system.

The purpose of this paper is to reiterate the locking out of tens of thousands of qualified Australian students from higher education. The Minister has, of course, released this document in a context which is deeply embarrassing for him and his senior Minister, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), because the Government's most authoritative independent source of advice on policy, the Industry Commission, has just brought down a report on education services. This report damned the Government's funding and regulatory framework for higher education. It said that it was inequitable; that it was choking off opportunities to expand the export sector; and that it was fundamentally flawed.

The Industry Commission said that under the current framework for allocating resources, it was virtually impossible to get any satisfactory indication of what value students placed on the private benefits they get from their university courses and that, as a result, resource allocation decisions would very likely be wrong. That is what the Industry Commission said about the Government's current funding framework--that the decisions would very likely be wrong.

But, of course, the Minister is not interested in that. For ideological reasons, he wants to maintain central bureaucratic and political control over the nation's universities. He cannot afford to free up those institutions to give them a financial independence because they might start doing things that the students or the academics wanted. They might actually start to be able to provide the sort of world-class education that this country needs. The Minister wants to keep them on a very tight leash. Despite all the rhetoric in this document about flexibility and autonomy--rhetoric stolen from the coalition--with one or two minor exceptions, there is no substantive move in this direction.

In its report, the Industry Commission also drew attention to the fact that universities were suffering from the entirely expected rigidities which arise from the Government's approach to the central regulation of industrial relations. I quote from the report:
Inflexibilities in the labour market are also important. Academic salaries are, with some limited exceptions, uniform and unrelated to market demand.

As a result, of course, there is very likely to be a shortage of high quality teachers in those very disciplines where demand is high. The Industry Commission set out--I thought very helpfully--to assist the Minister in finally getting his paper completed. The Commission canvassed a range of alternatives in its report. For example, it noted that Professor Karmel, one of Australia's most respected academics and academic administrators, had proposed a voucher-based system based on price flexibility. It said in its report:
There is no reason why such an approach could not be developed using the HECS payback mechanism, to preserve the benefits of the policy.
Being of a helpful frame of mind, the Industry Commission went on to suggest:

. . . the Government might provide vouchers, redeemable at any institution, to all qualified students, with the amount of the voucher set at a rough estimate of the valuation of the external benefits of higher education to Australia.

It said that it assumed that the Government would wish to have an urgent thorough review of current arrangements and it requested a reference for such a review. It thought that an urgent review was necessary because of the gross inequities that it had identified--inequities which, for ideological reasons, the Minister will not shift. It identified serious inefficiencies in the Government's funding system--a system which is likely to make decisions which are incorrect and wrong in terms of the wishes of those people actually seeking higher education services. The Minister, however, has taken no notice of that.

I hope that the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) might provide a reference to the Industry Commission. But the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, of course, wanted no such independent review of his disastrous and flawed system. The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services in his paper today says that the Government:
. . . intends that the existing system in which operating resources are largely distributed in accordance with weighted student loads after negotiation of institutional profiles should stand.
The real issue, however, is whether these arrangements are going to provide for the sensible and rational development of the system of universities over this decade.

Whatever the attitude of particular institutions may be to the Government's profiles process, it is undeniable--and the Government has never denied this--that these decisions are based on nothing more than bureaucratic and political discretion. The decisions are made in each individual case, depending upon how persuasive each institution is. Institutions are making their recommendations in an environment in which certain crucial kinds of information are being denied to them by the Government, especially information about the value that Australian students are placing on their courses.

It is no wonder that the Industry Commission said that this system was flawed. But, of course, the Government does not want to know this. It has resisted the Opposition's continued exposure of the fundamental weaknesses of the process it has established and it is angered when the Industry Commission makes the same point. The Commission, of course, foresaw the possibility that there might not be a reference to it. It therefore said in the report that, in the absence of such a public review:

. . . the costs to Australians of continuing to preclude qualified domestic students from universities would warrant urgent attention. In these circumstances the Government should address the question by implementing immediately one of the more acceptable options discussed below.

The Industry Commission said that the Government should immediately implement one of these options to allow these 30,000 students in. The Government will not do so. The Minister is too committed to the centralised system to allow such a flexibility and freedom to be put into place. The queues of qualified students will lengthen because this Minister has locked the door on them.

Nor is it good enough for the Minister to now say that the pressures on institutions to amalgamate is going to be eased. Of course, this will be welcomed by some institutions. But the Government needs to say more. We need details. Will it allow the institutions to disamalgamate if they believe that this is desirable on academic grounds? The Minister may well be faced with such decisions.

This statement for the nineties lacks this detail. The statement contains only a general wink and a nod to institutions in verbal terms that the Government will not be putting quite as much pressure on them in the future as it has in the past. We will see from experience just how much freedom the Minister is actually prepared to allow the institutions.

Of course, the amalgamations process has been one of the major problems for higher education. It is a government-caused problem. It has caused upheaval, demoralised academic staff and damaged quality. Therefore, one can only view with a great deal of cynicism the following statement in the Minister's paper:
. . . the main rationale for institutional restructuring--
that is the bureaucratic language for forced amalgamations--
was to enhance quality through the enrichment of academic programs.
Has it done so? Has it increased quality?

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yes.

—-Well, the Minister's paper does not say so. He was not prepared to say that in print. He can say that in an interjection in the House but there is nothing in this paper which says that. The Minister says that he still needs to review the impact of the amalgamations process. But we have him on the record now. We will see what his review says. Why was he not prepared to allow an independent review of the performance of his system by the Industry Commission? It is very easy to make these rhetorical interjections but let us have a look at the substance of the system. Everybody who has looked at higher education knows that this process of forced amalgamations has been immensely damaging to the quality of higher education in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Is this not the time when we should have had an assessment of the impact of the amalgamation process? It is very indicative that the Government now feels it necessary to implement a whole series of new initiatives, none of which are of any substance--but new initiatives which, it says, will increase quality in higher education. Of course, quality is not something which the Government can assure. The Minister, who is leaving the chamber, knows that. He is not prepared to defend this paper. It arises from institutions which have the freedom and the incentives to set and pursue a mission of educational quality. The Minister's rhetoric in this paper is fine. He is going to give the institutions greater freedom to pursue quality.

What is more--wait for it--he is going to provide a fund of $70m every year out of which sums of money will be given to those institutions which have performed best in the expenditure of their total allocation. Who is going to give out this money? On what basis is this $70m going to be awarded to the lucky institutions? Of course, it will be awarded according to the Government's own political and bureaucratic judgments. It is symptomatic of the problem that underlies the Government's whole approach to higher education--that quality is something generated from the centre and that those people who sit in the Department of Employment, Education and Training are the best judges of what is quality education.

The Government will have this slush fund of $70m which it will dole out to those institutions of which it approves. It has the nerve in this paper to say that, of course, participation in this process of quality assurance--it sounds like the meat industry--will be voluntary. There will be this carrot of $70m, but people do not have to compete for it. It is up to them whether they put themselves into this system and try to get some money out of the pot. Who in higher education is going to believe that? It is perfectly evident that this slush fund will be there to make sure that institutions toe the line. Let us make no mistake about it: this $70m is what the Minister in this paper calls the major initiative to secure quality--a new fund to be given out at his discretion and the discretion of his bureaucrats. It is the major initiative to ensure quality in higher education.

Well, I do not think anyone in higher education will be fooled by the sort of approach which is taken here. Of course, it is characteristic of the Government's approach that it has given the Higher Education Council a reference to tell it what quality is. It has asked Professor Chubb, for whom one must have a great deal of sympathy, and the lobby groups which sit behind him on the Higher Education Council, to inform the Government what quality is--and no doubt to assist the Government in handing out this $70m. Professor Chubb is having a fairly tough time in doing this. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 8 October 1991 stated:

The task of deciding what quality in higher education is all about is proving a tough one for the Department of Employment, Education and Training's Higher Education Council. Asked some time ago by the Minister for Higher Education, Mr Baldwin, to prepare a paper on the topic, the council's chairman, Professor Ian Chubb, said: "We're ploughing through that. The problem is no two people would agree on what quality is. . . quality has been likened to love--you know what it is when you feel it, but you can't describe it.

Of course, what that means is that one cannot determine and settle it from the centre, either. Only a system which is freed up, which is responsive to the student market, which has the flexibility to get top quality staff into the courses where there is demand, and to pay the money for the researchers will be able to produce quality. Ultimately, the students and the academics themselves will determine quality in the system--not the Minister presiding over one of his slush funds, and not the Higher Education Council.

A national quality assurance structure is to be established to report on the adequacy of quality management arrangements at the institutional level. The Government is going to tell the institutions whether they are being well managed. Let us imagine anybody presiding over the structure of the Department of Employment, Education and Training attempting to tell the universities in this country whether or not they are being well managed.

In the industry statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in March, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training's effective schools program was announced. Now we have the junior Minister's effective universities program announced. Neither will succeed. Both are entirely symbolic and both show that the Government is simply not prepared to address the issues that will produce quality and diversity in higher education in this country.

I come to the final section of this paper, which states that the Government will produce diversity. Diversity is a problem for the Government because the unified national system is a centralised bureaucratic system operating under an ideology of what the Government calls equity. It is a very strange definition of equity, as we have seen, but that is what it calls equity. It means giving the same to everybody regardless of performance. It means the imposition of uniformity.

But how within this system does one guarantee diversity? Without diversity, it is absolutely certain that one will not have quality and one will not have the courses that the students, who are diverse, want. Firstly, the Government starts off by quoting the Higher Education Council's December report last year which stated that diversity is important. What was characteristic about that report was that there was not a single recommendation in it to secure diversity. It was entirely empty rhetoric.

In this section of his paper, the Minister states that the amalgamations process will be eased up. But, of course, everybody knows that it is this process which has squeezed diversity out of the system. Over the last year I have spoken to hundreds and hundreds of students in higher education throughout this country and, without exception, there is an awareness on their part that this system is depriving them of the opportunity to take the kinds of courses that were formerly available in the binary system. Once these institutions have been amalgamated, a uniform structure, a uniform format, a uniform philosophy has been applied to courses.

The fact is that in this paper the Minister has no measures which will secure institutional diversity. He is quite unclear as to whether he will allow this amalgamation. He has not evaluated the impact of the unified national system and so he is not prepared to put forward any substantial proposition whatever that would guarantee that over this decade we will have a growing diversity of appropriate institutions.

The Minister talks about the diversity of students. He talks about some minor measures relating to lifelong learning. He inflates the importance of the use of technology in distance education. He talks about credit transfers. They are all efforts to suggest that somehow or other this Government is determined to secure diversity in higher education. But there is nothing of substance.

This report fails to address any of the basic structural impediments to quality and diversity in higher education. It has taken no notice whatever of the Industry Commission report, which identified this current system as fundamentally flawed. It fails to address any of the significant labour market issues. It continues to misrepresent the impact on recruitment of the academic salary increase earlier this year. It does nothing to correct the fundamental flaws of the centralised funding system. Despite all the rhetoric, it continues on the proposition that Canberra knows best and it locks the door on over 30,000 qualified Australian students. This paper is a fraud.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—-Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—-Yes, Mr Acting Speaker, I do.
—-The honourable member may proceed.

—-It has been drawn to my attention that during Question Time, which I could not attend because I was at a memorial service in Sydney, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) saw fit to quote from a speech I made in the House yesterday. I am always flattered when honourable members opposite quote from my speeches, and I encourage them to continue to do so because those speeches always have much to commend them. However, in the process of doing so the Minister, by leaving out the second half of what I had said on the subject to which he referred, gave a rather unbalanced view of what I had said. Therefore, I should simply read the two sentences to put the matter in context. What I said about truth on unemployment was:

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose the first thing that can be done is that we ought to tell the truth about unemployment; we ought not exaggerate it; and we ought not be doom and gloom merchants.
That is fine; I did say that. However, I then went on to say something which the Minister, of course, did not refer to. I said:

But, by the same token, we should not indulge in some of the Pollyanna language which has lately come, particularly from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). On the truth stakes, when it comes to projections from the other side of the House about what is going to happen with unemployment, I would support the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) and I would reject Mr Hawke.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee of Public Accounts: Finance Minute on Report 308

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I present the Finance Minute on Report 308 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, `Parliamentary Information Systems Office unofficial account'.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Hong Kong, Singapore and Indonesia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I present the report of the visit by the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Hong Kong, Singapore and Indonesia, 24 January to 23 February 1991. It was a privilege for me to lead the parliamentary delegation to Hong Kong and Singapore in January and February of this year. The Speaker, Mr Leo McLeay, the honourable member for Grayndler, joined the delegation as leader for the visit to Indonesia.

SPEECH.PARA: The delegation's itinerary was an interrupted one, owing to the events in the Middle East and an uncertainty about security in Bangkok. The proposed participation of the delegation in the IPU regional conference in Thailand had to be cancelled, as was the planned visit to Pakistan. While these changes were a disappointment, they did not detract from the worth of the visit, and I consider this report to be an extremely productive and constructive one.

This was the first official parliamentary delegation ever to visit Hong Kong and it was a very worthwhile precedent. The delegation recommends the establishment of an Australia-Hong Kong parliamentary group in this Parliament and delegation members believe that more regular parliamentary exchanges between Australia and Hong Kong are appropriate.

The report makes some comments and recommendations on the business migration program as it applies in Hong Kong. While these comments have largely been overtaken by events, it is important that they be considered by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand). The delegation visited a Vietnamese refugee camp in Hong Kong and spoke to representatives of organisations involved in the refugee issue. Members of the delegation were surprised to discover that the majority of Vietnamese refugees were from North Vietnam. They had travelled overland through the People's Republic of China, and then by boat down the Pearl River. Events in recent weeks have supported the delegation's recommendations, particularly recommendation 1.17.

The itinerary in Hong Kong was comprehensive and included working meetings with Hong Kong and Australian business people, political leaders and government officials, as well as attending a meeting of the Legislative Council. Members of the delegation were impressed with Hong Kong's dynamism and its success in trade. We believe that there is substantial room for improvement in trade between Hong Kong and Australia. We were also impressed with the approach and performance of Austrade in Hong Kong and strongly support the McKinsey recommendations as to the expansion of Austrade in Hong Kong. We also strongly recommend the involvement of Hong Kong in APEC.

On behalf of the delegation, I would like to thank those in Hong Kong who made us feel very welcome. I would like to express our appreciation to Mr Bentley, our Consul-General, and his staff for the excellent program they arranged and for their assistance during our visit.
Our visit to Singapore was arranged at very short notice. While the program was not as extensive as that for Hong Kong, it was still extremely useful.

The delegation had the unique privilege of visiting the HMAS Success which was berthed in Singapore on its way back from the Arabian Gulf where it had been involved in the naval blockade of Iraq for some seven months. We were impressed with the morale and efficiency of the officers and crew of the vessel. I note that Captain Graham Sloper has subsequently been promoted. On behalf of all the delegation I offer our congratulations to him.

The report draws attention to some areas in which we believe our relations and trade with Singapore could be improved. On behalf of the delegation, I would like to express our appreciation to Mr Alan Brown, the High Commissioner in Singapore, and his staff for their efforts in arranging a diverse and worthwhile itinerary at very short notice, as well as to other Australian officials, including Colonel Kerry Mellor and Mr Frank Walsh from Austrade.

The Indonesian segment of the visit was led by Mr Speaker who, unfortunately, is absent from the Parliament today. This visit was both intensive and extensive. I express our appreciation to the Indonesian Government for the warmth and excellence of the hospitality provided. I also thank Mr Phillip Flood, the Australian Ambassador in Jakarta, his wife and all of his staff for their assistance while we were visiting Indonesia.

The report documents the numerous meetings and inspections that were undertaken by the delegation. Discussions were full and frank, and I believe that all members of the delegation were delighted with the growing health and maturity in relations between our two countries. Improvements in trade and investment between our two nations are mirrored by continuing development in defence and intergovernmental cooperation, as indicated by the signing of the Timor Gap Treaty whilst we were in Indonesia. It is very clear to us that Indonesia regards the signing of that treaty as a major milestone in the developing relationship between our two countries.

We had the opportunity to visit some aid funded projects in West Timor and were impressed not only with the success of the projects and the calibre of the Australian personnel involved but also with the excellent relationship that has been developed between Australia and the Indonesian villagers and officials who were involved. It is a matter of regret that these aid programs are not better understood in the broader Australian community.

The aspect of the Indonesian visit that was the most complex for the delegation was the visit to East Timor. While there are differences of opinion amongst the delegation which have led to two minority recommendations, the remainder of the report is unanimous. The report has an extensive set of recommendations resulting from the visit to Indonesia. While time will not permit me to go into them in detail, I believe that they are positive and constructive and, if implemented, would further improve relations between our two countries.

One of these recommendations is for the Indonesian Government to investigate the establishment of an office of a commercial ombudsman to assist in preliminary legal or contractual arbitrations between Australian companies and their Indonesian partners. It was clear that the difference between the Australian and Indonesian legal systems, together with the complexity of the latter, is becoming a major obstacle to further Australian investment in Indonesia, particularly in manufacturing. A commercial ombudsman to carry out preliminary arbitration could minimise disputes ending in courts with the substantial costs and delays that flow from them.

There are also a number of general recommendations in the report which are not country specific. A group of these--recommendations 4.9 to 4.12--relates to the recruiting of overseas students. I particularly commend these to the Government and to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs as a positive proposal to enhance our commercial interconnection with our Asia-Pacific neighbours.

This delegation was a hard-working and productive one. The report I am tabling today is extremely comprehensive, and in that context I particularly thank Mr John Dyer, the delegation secretary, not only for his tireless efforts in assisting us on the visit but also for his help in assembling this report. On behalf of the delegation, I extend to the Parliament our thanks and appreciation for extending to us the privilege of representing it on this visit. I also thank all of those people in the three countries we visited who extended us their hospitality.

At a personal level, I express my appreciation to members of the delegation for their efforts both during and following the visit. I believe that they served both this Parliament and their nation well. My thanks also go to those spouses who were able to accompany us at various times. Their presence was extremely beneficial, and in very many cases allowed us to glean information and attitudes that may otherwise not have been available to us.

I stated earlier that the report is extensive, but I also believe it is a very positive contribution to Australia's relationship with three of its significant neighbours. It is with great pleasure that I table the report and commend it to honourable members for their consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave --I endorse the remarks of my colleague the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), with the exception of his reference to the minority report. In opening, I should say that I enjoyed the spectacle of having two leaders of a delegation. It is a little like the Government itself: it is uncertain where its leadership lies at the moment--and so were we. We had Mr Speaker as the leader in Indonesia and the honourable member for Newcastle as our leader in Hong Kong and Singapore. I would like to thank my colleague John Dyer and, indeed, all those in the various posts overseas and in the private sector who helped us throughout our visit.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to address a few brief subjects. Obviously, the highlight of our trip was our visit to Indonesia, which is a very significant neighbour of Australia. Our relations with Indonesia are critical to our future. I have been very critical of the Government in past years for the way in which it has allowed individual differences to predominate over the overall necessity for us to maintain and establish an understanding with a country that has a different culture, a different language, enormous diversity, a country that really does not see many issues as we see them. I think the speech made by the incoming Ambassador from Indonesia to Australia, talking about the arrogance of Australians in presenting our perspective on things Asian and on the way in which they conduct their affairs, was very pertinent.

From my point of view, of course there are areas in the administration of Indonesia with which I differ. There are many in the administration of Australia with which I also differ. The difficulty in our understanding of how we can best function and operate for the future with Indonesia lies not peculiarly in the enormous population of that country but in the particular relationship of some areas of Indonesia to Australia and, of course, in the undoubted concerns there are with respect to the conduct of affairs in the relationship between East Timor and those who have come from East Timor to Australia and equally, I might say, between Irian Jaya and Papua New Guinea. So there are a number of areas where there are flashpoints in our relationship.

As one who has visited East Timor, Irian Jaya and Indonesia on a number of occasions, I can do nothing but commend President Suharto and his Government for what I see as the significant progress that has been achieved. There are, of course, matters that with Australian eyes we would see as being better administered, better managed, where human rights might well be advanced and, indeed, the process of law advanced differently from the way it is at this time. But in saying that I stress that Indonesians do have a different society, and far be it for us to impose our priorities when there are so many faults here.

I found the visit in this instance well worth while. I am most impressed with the progress in many centres, particularly in Jakarta and Surabaya. As Mrs Morris, the wife of the honourable member for Newcastle, said at a private function last night, those looking at Australian industry and visiting, for example, the factories we saw in Surabaya cannot but be concerned at how difficult it will be for us to be competitive when the Indonesians are rapidly able to utilise the same machines as we do and are technically as capable. We are foolish if we think the world owes us a living.

Indeed, Batam Island, which is adjacent to Singapore, is a venue I would recommend every Australian visiting Singapore should attempt to visit. It is a tribute not only to the Jurong industrial corporation that is developing it but to the Government of Indonesia and the cooperation it has been prepared to extend. Provided the environment is dealt with in a sensitive and sensible manner, I believe it is going to be, much as is Singapore, an illustration of how industrial development can be achieved utilising both human resources and natural resources in a sensible and responsible way.

There are several other brief remarks I would like to make with respect to the visit. As far as each of us was concerned, I do not think there was any doubt that the visit to HMAS Success was a highlight. The whole of the journey was taken at a time when the Gulf war was still imminent. In October 1991, it is a little hard looking back and imagining the crisis that existed. We were due to visit an IPU conference in Thailand. We were told of a security threat, and that part of the journey did not eventuate. We were due to visit Pakistan. We were told of security risks there too, and as a result the visit did not eventuate.

Our visit to HMAS Success was a product of that ship returning from its service in the Gulf and enforcing the United Nations sanctions. In the report there are observations about some aspects of the ship, but essentially we all had nothing but praise for then Captain, now Commodore, Sloper, and I join with the honourable member for Newcastle in complimenting him on his promotion. We had nothing but praise for the captain of the vessel and for his crew for the way in which they undertook their task. There is little doubt that Success performed its task admirably, and it is to me a great pity that the Success was not constructed at Cockatoo Island. I believe there would have been a far happier group of employees there today if the Government had proceeded on a plan that was originally in mind for forward defence planning when I was Minister for Defence some years ago.

The third area I want to mention briefly is Hong Kong. The recommendations in the report include several with respect to each of the places we visited. In respect of Hong Kong, there are two things I would say. The first is that in Australia we must register that Hong Kong is essentially an Asian city. Whatever the future of that community post-1997, it is essential that we maintain our relationships with Hong Kong and understand that, part of China though it will be, Hong Kong is going to continue to be a very critical entrepot port for access for capital, access for commercial activity, and of course for cultural and social contact indefinitely into the future.

Hong Kong is a different place. It is a stimulating, vital commercial centre and it is one that has great importance to us. There are great opportunities there for Australians, and Mr Donald Hay, to whom reference is made in the report, is one of those who through his great enterprises has done a great deal to take advantage of those opportunities. There is no doubt that those sorts of opportunities are helped by the way in which Australians conduct their affairs to enhance the reputation of this country.

The second recommendation to which I wish to refer might relate to Singapore or it might relate to Hong Kong. In any event, it applies irrespective of the port. It is essential for us, if we are looking at investment and migration into Australia--and I am delighted that the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) is at the table--to set up an instrumentality that will allow one-stop understanding of the requirements for investment and migration to this country. At the moment, it is extraordinarily difficult for an investor coming here, interested in acquiring land, in setting up in whichever part of Australia, to know that labyrinth of responsibility that stretches through local government, State government and Federal government--through all the authorities--to understand, for example, the processes of establishing a new factopower supplies, how to get planning approval and how to proceed with an environmental impact statement.

We should provide for all those interested in coming here at least a brochure which sets down fairly simply the ways by which we process their application so that they might be able to have some understanding of the needs of our various levels of government and the ways by which they can invest. I commend that report to the Government.

Finally, with respect to East Timor, I know that the honourable member who is about to follow me is about to refer to aspects of that minority report. I sympathise greatly with the people of East Timor. I know how difficult it has been for many of them, but I would hope that the Indonesian authorities, recognising as the Government and the Opposition do, that East Timor is part of Indonesia, progressively might remove the combat military presence in that province and, if need be, the construction elements of the armed forces that are so important to Indonesia, but, above all, allow that part of Indonesia to progress and develop as I believe it has since I last visited there nearly seven or eight years ago.

There has been progress; there is a long way to go. But certainly in terms of human rights and human opportunities, one way that they could be facilitated is by greater access, particularly from Dili to Darwin. I hope that in the same way as we had yesteryear, that direct link can be established so that Australians and the relatives of those in East Timor can visit East Timor and we can re-establish normal relations at a tourist and personal level. I think that would help enormously in overcoming some of the barriers of understanding that still exist in that province.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I welcome the opportunity in the short time we have available to us today to make a few comments on this report. Firstly, I would also like to place on record my appreciation to the very many people who helped us during our visit. First and foremost, our delegation secretary, John Dyer, deserves great mention. He was a very diligent worker and I certainly appreciated his hard work, tolerance, strong friendship, and the level of experience that he provided to the new members of Parliament going on their first trip.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to thank most sincerely for their hospitality the Government and the people of Hong Kong and express appreciation for the great cooperation that we received from the Australian Consulate staff, particularly Geoff Bentley, the Consul-General, and Grant Batteersby, the Deputy Consul-General. Also, my thanks go to the Government and the people of Singapore for their delightful hospitality, and to the staff of the Australian High Commission, in particular, Alan Brown and Les Luck. They had very little notice of our intention to visit Singapore, yet still managed to organise an excellent program for us while we were there.

As the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) has indicated, all members of the delegation were disappointed at not being able to attend the IPU conference that was held in Thailand or to participate in a parliamentary visit to Pakistan, owing to the security concerns that existed at the time in relation to the Gulf war.

I also wish to express my sincere appreciation to the Parliament and Government of the Republic of Indonesia for their comprehensive program, their thorough organisation of all parts of our itinerary during our visit to their country, and their hospitality and generosity. My further thanks go to Phillip Flood, the Australian Ambassador and his staff, particularly Mrs Judith Pead and Dr Mark Napier, for their advice, support and companionship on the trip.

The report being tabled covers in detail the extensive range of meetings and discussions that members of the delegation had in our three host countries. All of us learnt a great deal about the current position on trade, economic development, regional security issues, immigration and the flow of illegal immigration from Vietnam, the education of students from these countries in Australian institutions, and Australia's profile and reputation in the region. We utilised numerous opportunities to advance our nation's position on many matters and to seek to identify ways in which we can improve our economic and trading links in these rapidly growing economies.

Our educational links with these nations, through the marketing of places in Australian tertiary and secondary institutions, are a large and growing component of our trade, as well as having valuable benefits in our social, cultural and educational relationships.

Senator Nick Sherry and I visited the Australian Education Offices in both Hong Kong and Singapore and also spoke about these important education links with representatives of all three governments. I refer honourable members to recommendations 4.1 to 4.4, which we believe will improve the structural processes involved with international students studying in Australia.

The visit of our delegation to Indonesia and, in particular, to East Timor has generated the most comment and interest among the media and the community. I wish to spend some time on this part of our trip, but I do wish to emphasise that the large body of information and recommendations on the other elements of our itinerary deserve full consideration and attention by both the Government and honourable members. My colleagues have highlighted many important elements of our trip in their contributions today.

Our visit to East Timor was part of an eight day visit to a number of locations in Indonesia. We also spent quite a deal of our time speaking with senior Indonesian Government Ministers, including the President, on the situation in East Timor as well as on other issues of importance to Indonesian-Australian relations.

Our visit to East Timor was brief and limited in its opportunities for us to speak freely and frankly with East Timorese people, compared with our discussions with selected government and military officials. Therefore much of the feedback concerning the situation of the people of East Timor was learned second-hand.

Earlier this year, on 17 April, I outlined to the House the history of the conflict of East Timor and my disagreement with the Australian Government's position. In that speech I outlined my perceptions of the situation for the people in that territory of being oppressed, occupied and abused. I do not wish to repeat today all of my concerns as expressed in that speech. However, the perceptions I outlined then are confirmed by this report in our conclusions and recommendations.

During our time in Dili, the leader of the delegation, the Speaker, the Hon. Leo McLeay, was handed a letter from the leader of the resistance forces in East Timor, Xanana Gusmao, to be delivered to the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Hawke). A rough translation of this letter was also given to some members of the delegation, and I seek leave to table a copy of this translation for the benefit of honourable members.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the House. This letter is an appeal to the Prime Minister and the Australian Government to assist the East Timorese people to find a peaceful resolution to the continuing conflict. I quote from the letter:

SPEECH.PARA: We seek a peaceful political solution and call on the principal parties to the question--Indonesia, Portugal and legitimate representatives of East Timor--to meet with the United Nations to find this solution. The only way to find an immediate solution is through dialogue under the auspices of the United Nations.
This statement from Xanana Gusmao in his letter goes to the very essence of the minority recommendations of this report contained on page 140.

My colleagues the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), Senator Nick Sherry and I have sought to find a positive way of restoring peace to the people of East Timor. When the Indonesians invaded the territory in 1975, they disrupted the legitimate process of self-determination that was under way. In the years since, they have deliberately embarked on a military campaign to destroy all vestiges of opposition to their takeover.

For 16 years the Indonesians have engaged in military action which has resulted in the death of over 100,000 people, destroyed villages and uprooted many thousands more, and they have continued a campaign of oppression. It is clear that the Indonesian authorities are facing a new generation of resistance in both the towns and villages as well as in the hills and countryside. Coverage of demonstrations that were held in 1989 and 1990 in Dili and elsewhere demonstrates this.

Reports from reliable sources during our visit, such as the International Committee of the Red Cross and Amnesty International, confirm that abuses of human rights are still widely prevalent and that military offences are regular occurrences. The violence, torture and death in East Timor will not cease until a proper settlement occurs, and no amount of ostrich-type actions by either the Australian Government or some honourable members in this House can avoid this conclusion.

If Indonesia truly wishes to take a higher profile on the world stage--to be seen to be a new responsible power in Asia and the Third World--it must sit down and negotiate on the issue of East Timor. Australia has a responsibility to act to achieve this end. We must stand up for the principles of human rights and self-determination that are the foundation of our foreign policy in the rest of the world and apply them to our own backyard.

The minority report recommendations seek the United Nations to convene a conference of all interested parties to negotiate a future for East Timor. We also seek greater involvement of the Australian Government in achieving this goal. This recommendation is supported by the East Timorese people, as evidenced from the letter from Xanana Gusmao. It is supported by the East Timorese groups throughout Australia. It is the basis of a strong campaign being mounted by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid called `A Time for Talks'. I call on the Australian Government and, in particular, our Foreign Minister, Senator Gareth Evans, to utilise his obvious skills of diplomacy, as demonstrated in the resolution of the Cambodian situation, in arriving at a just peace for the people of East Timor.

As I said on 17 April, and I reaffirm today, my strong disagreement with Indonesia's actions in East Timor and the Australian Government's appeasement attitude in response in no way diminishes my support for improving the economic, trade, social, cultural and educational links between our two nations. As is clear with most other nations--particularly Japan, the United States, Canada, Britain and all of Europe--increasing relationships with Indonesia are not conditional on acceptance of Indonesia's takeover of East Timor. None of these nations accept Indonesia's hegemony. They have been able to develop a mature relationship with Indonesia without prostituting their foreign policy principles. It is a time for Australia to do the same.
I commend both the full report of our delegation and the two minority recommendations to honourable members and the Government and urge their full consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Riggall Mr J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--First and foremost, I would like to add my thanks to those people who led the delegation, the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) and the Speaker. I make special mention of the right honourable member for New England in his position as deputy leader. With the experience that he showed on that trip, it was certainly a great privilege to be there with him and to be able to participate in some of the many meetings that we had there. The great reputation that he has developed overseas as well as in Australia was very much exemplified in that trip. I also thank the staff of the embassies in the various places we visited who looked after us so superbly. One would be very remiss if one did not mention John Dyer, the secretary to the delegation, who did an extraordinary job and was very much instrumental in putting this report together. I am grateful for his help during the trip.

SPEECH.PARA: Being my first overseas trip, it was a great privilege to be chosen by the party room to go on this delegation in my first year as a parliamentarian. Therefore, to me it was very much a learning experience and a learning curve that one seldom gets the privilege of undertaking. I hope that I took full opportunity of that experience.

Starting off in the chronological order of where we went, Hong Kong was the first city we visited. My first impression was that Hong Kong is undoubtedly a Chinese, or Asian, city. It is not an outpost of England. This was very clearly demonstrated, as was said in the report, by the fact that 98 per cent of the information was obtained through Chinese language newspapers. There seems to be extraordinary opportunities for Australia in the 1997 changeover. It seems to me that when this extraordinarily dynamic colony becomes part of China it will be a gateway and an opportunity for us in trade. I can only encourage many business people to take up this opportunity to see how it goes.

One of the sadder notes was to see what I would call nothing more than the illegal immigrants from Vietnam. Australia should very much recognise that these people are queue jumpers and we should encourage their return to Vietnam to join the queue. If they have genuine refugee status, they will be accepted as such. Those who jump the queue in Hong Kong are no different from those who jump the queue in Australia. I would support Hong Kong in its return of these people back to their native land.

During the visit I, along with the right honourable member for New England and the delegation secretary, was privileged to be a guest at a lunch with a division of the Ghurkhas. These people have a great history which is part and parcel of our history. It was interesting to look at what is being done. At that particular time we were advised that the Ghurkhas were in the Gulf doing all the satellite communications for the British Army. They are a group of people who have a great history that is connected with Australia. It seems to me that it would be very compassionate of Australia after 1997, when these people lose their home, to look very favourably on the immigration of Ghurkha soldiers and perhaps look very much at their British Army qualifications to see whether they can go onto the points which are required for immigrating to Australia. I recommend that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) look at this suggestion to see whether we can look on very compassionate grounds at these excellent people with a great record of history who would certainly make wonderful Australians and wonderful immigrants to this country.

After visiting Hong Kong we made a rather rushed visit to Singapore. One of the things that came home very quickly to me in both Hong Kong and Singapore is Australia's trade with both those nations. The first thing that was pointed out was that the quality of manufactured goods and foodstuffs that go from Australia to that part of the world is recognised as being excellent, second to none. It was great to hear that. We were also advised that the prices of our goods are in the ball park, that they are competitive. I was also delighted to hear that.

The one thing that was repeated to us time and time again is that it is a joke to deal with Australia and to try to get goods delivered on time. Contract after contract has been jeopardised because of our inefficient waterfront and because of the inability of our manufacturers to deliver into Hong Kong and Singapore on time. We have to take urgent action with our trading partners to ensure that when we give a delivery time the goods get there on time, regardless of what we have to go through to do that, otherwise Australia will be in jeopardy of becoming irrelevant in those markets.

One of the stories that was told in Hong Kong was about the excellent underground rail system there. When it was being built the Governor gave the promise that it would be opened within 36 months, and he gave the date. On opening that railway line he apologised because he was 10 minutes late. How that differs from major projects in Australia, which seem to go over budget time and time again. I must say that for that particular underground railways project there was an Australian tenderer who told us that his tender was competitive but that the people calling for tenders felt he would not be able to complete the job on time because of delays in supplies coming out of Australia and therefore he was knocked out and was not among the last two or three tenderers.

While in Singapore we had the opportunity to visit with Colonel Kerry Mellors the war cemetery at Kranji. I have to thank Colonel Mellors for this particular trip. He has taken on the role of local historian and was able to fill us in on many of the details of what happened during the war and the various actions that took place. It was a great privilege to go round with him and hear the stories. He also pointed out that next year is the fiftieth anniversary of the fall of Singapore. We were also taken to the factory, which was the old Ford factory, where the surrender was actually signed. The emotion that one felt when going into that factory, which is now a Japanese tyre factory, was quite overwhelming. The road and the old photographs were there. One could see photographs of the surrender flag being carried. It was a very emotional time.

When we were at the war cemetery we had an opportunity to read the inscriptions on many of the gravestones and note the ages of the men and women who lost their lives during that conflict. They were so very young, and it was frightening that so many good people from Australia, England and other parts of the world lost their lives so tragically at such a young age. The next day we went down to HMAS Success, freshly back from the Gulf war, and there we met young men and women of the same age. It struck me what such a tragic waste war is, and I was grateful that we did not have any loss of life during that conflict.

I believe that by far the most important part of the trip was our visit to Indonesia. I am reminded of the old adage: if one comes from the land one does not have to get on with one's relations, but one does have to get on with one's neighbours. In a sense, that is very true at a national level. Indonesia is our closest neighbour and it is important that we have good material relations with it. It is important for us to understand that Indonesia is a young democracy, some 40 years old, and is fighting its way to establish itself through all the huge problems that it has within the nation, made up of some 1,200 islands and a great number of mixed and various cultures, all put in together and trying to make it work. It has not been easy for the Indonesians, and I believe that they are now coming of age and will present great opportunities for Australians to go in there in business partnerships with Indonesia.

It came through time and time again that they are very keen to have closer relations with Australia. I can only recommend that my colleagues, both within the House and outside it in business, take the opportunity of talking with the Indonesians to see what investment opportunities are there. A very interesting anecdote came from one of the Indonesian Ministers, when he said, `Thou shalt not kill thy customer'. In a sense that expresses what they want to do. They want to be a trading nation and they want to lift their standard of living. Although the Indonesian population is somewhere between 180 million and 200 million, we heard evidence that only 30 million are actually in the cash economy. So Indonesia has very much a rural and tribal society in many ways, and it has huge problems to overcome.

As the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) said, we did not spend a great deal of time in East Timor and there was a heavy military presence there. As I have said before in this place, I believe that Australia's relationship with Indonesia and East Timor are right and proper. It was noted that, of the money that was spent on developing East Timor, 97 per cent came from Consolidated Revenue, other than that which was raised locally. So the Indonesians are putting assets and money and time and effort in there, and we got the feeling that the military presence would gradually drift. I must agree with the right honourable member for New England that, if we can have some sort of tourist link with East Timor, that military presence will get smaller and smaller.

One thing that was quite striking to me when we were flying over East Timor in a helicopter was just how poor the country is. It is very poor country, hilly, shaly, suffering from a lack of rain, a lack of depth of soil, huge erosion problems and huge slips. It has very few what one would call natural advantages for those people to lift their standard of living. So I believe it is vital that they get continued support from other nations and I would encourage that. If Australia could put aid groups in there, it should do so because there is an urgent need for those sorts of things in order to try to lift the standard of living.

When we flew over a mountain village the actual land degradation that we saw occurring was quite frightening, and I think there is a need for our expertise to help people resolve those problems in an Indonesian sense so that they can go on to a more sustainable yield of agriculture.

Another thing I was delighted to see at the time was the signing of the East Timor Gap Treaty. I think this was a breakthrough in relationships between Australia and Indonesia, and it is most important that that sort of international cooperation keeps going. I hope and urge that there be some financial spin-off to East Timor.

As time is of the essence in this debate, I will conclude my comments, but once again I thank my fellow parliamentarians and their wives who came on that trip for a most enjoyable experience, for the company that I had and for the very good dinner that we had last night as some sort of celebration. Despite the diverse points of view that we started off with, it was extremely pleasing to me to see that in general the delegation report was in the main agreed to, and I recommend it to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, for Mr Staples, and read a first time.
