SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 gives effect to a number of measures most of which were announced in the 1991 Budget. In his Budget Speech the Treasurer recalled that in 1987 the Government introduced the family allowance supplement to provide a basis for targeting income support to families and that during 1991-92 the Government would be building on that work. The Treasurer announced that a major families package would be introduced to provide additional assistance to low and medium income families with children and target family allowance more effectively. This Bill provides for the first stage of that package.

From 1 January 1992, the existing parental assets test of $347,500, indexed each 1 January, for family allowance supplement, FAS, will be replaced by a family assets test. The existing assets test for FAS is based on parental assets only. This can be avoided by rearranging assets among family members to ensure parental assets fall below the test threshold. As a result of the changes this possible avenue of avoidance will be closed.

Family allowance is the only major social security payment not subject to an assets test. This Bill provides for the introduction from 1 January 1992 of a family assets test of $600,000 of net assets, excluding the family home. Currently, the parental assets test on FAS removes entitlement when the value of net assets, excluding the family home, exceeds $347,500. In the prevailing economic circumstances, especially the effects of the rural downturn, the Government is concerned about the welfare of children in families with assets above the test threshold but where those assets are returning very low incomes.

The Bill proposes to introduce a special financial hardship test to operate for the next two years from 1 January 1992. This change will protect these families by allowing them to continue to receive FAS if the value of their net assets does not exceed $600,000. If the value of their net assets exceeds $600,000, they may continue to receive family allowance only.

From 1 April 1992, the income threshold at which full rate FAS is payable, currently $18,000 a year, will be increased and aligned with the Austudy income threshold. This is currently $19,300. From January 1992 this will increase to $20,700 a year, indexed each January. This increase in the FAS income threshold will increase both the number of families eligible for FAS and the entitlements of families receiving less than the maximum rate of FAS. It will also achieve greater consistency between the Austudy and FAS income tests.

Under current arrangements, all FAS recipients, irrespective of whether a full or part rate is payable, are entitled to a health care card. In order to bring entitlement to health care cards more into line with the income test arrangements for eligibility for health care cards for low income earners, from 1 January 1992 health care card entitlement will be limited to existing FAS recipients--full or part rate--and new recipients of full rate FAS.

Provisions to give effect to the second stage of the package, namely, integration of family allowance, FAS and additional pension and benefit and the continuation of payment of family allowance until the end of a young person's secondary studies or to the end of the year in which the young person turns 18, whichever is the earlier, will be introduced in the autumn sittings next year. From 1 January 1992 a person's FAS will be recalculated where the person's income increases to 125 per cent of his or her base tax year income even though the increase was not related to a notifiable event.

The Bill will also effect a number of minor changes, from 1 January 1992, in the area of families administration. Other measures contained in this Bill will also benefit families. First, on 1 January 1992 there will be an increase in the rate of child disability allowance by $2.15 a week, after the annual 1 January indexation has occurred, to help restore child disability allowance to the same value it had in real terms when introduced in 1987. The youth disability supplement will be increased by the same amount. Second, family payments will be back paid to the child's date of birth if a claim is lodged within 13 weeks of the date of birth where the child is born on or after 1 January 1992. At present back payments apply only if a claim is lodged within four weeks of the date of birth.

Sole parent pensioners face substantial up-front costs when undertaking education. Although those undertaking vocational training have course fees, books and equipment paid for, no similar assistance is available to those undertaking general education. Accordingly, this Bill provides for a $200 up-front payment to be made each year to sole parent pensioners who are starting or continuing full time or part time education courses and who are eligible for the Austudy supplement. This will apply from 1 January 1992.

There can be no doubt that young persons who have to live away from home or who leave secondary studies at an early age face considerable social and economic disadvantages. With this in mind, this Bill provides for initiatives directed at young persons under 18 years of age.

The current Job Search allowance and sickness allowance provisions relating to young persons aged 16 to 17 years have helped to improve the circumstances of many young people. However, many face hardship because, although they have lived away from home for a substantial period, they are precluded from Job Search allowance or sickness allowance as they do not meet the employment requirement set down in this definition. This Bill provides that, from 1 January 1992, for an `independent young person', 13 weeks registration with the CES will be accepted. At present the definition requires that the young person must actually have been employed.

At present, a 16- to 17-year-old person in substitute care for whom no substitute care or similar allowance is being paid receives the basic rate of Job Search allowance or sickness allowance unless he or she qualifies for the independent rate under other criteria. From 1 January 1992, this Bill provides for social security arrangements to be brought into line with Austudy entitlements for 16- to 17-year-old persons in substitute care.

There are currently unemployed and sick 15-year-olds who receive special benefit on the ground that they would, apart from age, qualify for Job Search allowance or sickness allowance respectively. These special beneficiaries are required to comply with all the usual Job Search allowance or sickness allowance qualification and payability conditions but are subject to more rigorous income testing, that is, dollar for dollar reduction in benefit for each dollar of income earned. Persons in this category are not eligible for transition to work incentives such as the employment entry payment and are not generally eligible, under Department of Employment, Education and Training guidelines, for the labour market assistance available for 16- and 17-year-old Job Search allowance recipients. This places 15-year-olds who are essentially in the same position as their 16- and 17-year-old Job Search allowance counterparts at a distinct disadvantage.

This Bill extends qualification for Job Search allowance to 15-year-olds who meet the requirements for Job Search allowance apart from age, who are above the minimum school leaving age or have a formal exemption from attending school, who have an employment history and who are not living with or being supported by a parent. (Quorum formed)

Mr Deputy Speaker, there is a need to ensure that any anomalies in social security legislation or administration are removed. To that end, from the day of royal assent neither Job Search allowance nor Newstart allowance will be payable to persons receiving income that is paid by a community or group from funds provided under a Commonwealth funded employment program. If the person's partner is receiving such income, the person will not be entitled to an additional payment in respect of the partner.

There can be no person in Australia today who is not aware of the special difficulties being faced by the rural community. Although many primary producers are `asset rich', they are often `income poor'. As a result, they may receive reduced social security payments or none at all as a result of the application of the assets test. This may be the case even though they have considerable liabilities. At present, the assets test works by compartmentalising debts so that they can be offset against only the particular asset which provides primary security for the debt and then only if the owner of the asset and the primary debtor are the same person. An example of the problems this causes is where the value of a person's farm is included in the person's assets thus precluding payments. Assume there is also farm machinery valued at $100,000 but it is subject to a bank lien of $150,000. Effectively the machinery has a negative value of $50,000. At present the liability of $50,000 cannot be offset against the value of the farm to allow the person to qualify for payments.

This Bill modifies the assets test from 1 January 1992 to allow primary producers to deduct all liabilities which relate to carrying on of primary production from the value of all assets used in that production. The Bill will also ensure that, with effect from the day of royal assent, the value of a person's asset will be taken to be reduced by the value of a charge or encumbrance on the asset only if the person or the person's partner gets the direct benefit of a loan secured by the charge or encumbrance. This amendment will close a loophole highlighted by the recent Federal Court case of Clayton whereby mortgages taken out for the benefit of others were held to be allowable deductions. From the day of royal assent, the rules for assessing notional ordinary income within the hardship rules will be modified so that owners of residential premises that are occupied by family members in certain situations will not be penalised because the premises are not attracting commercial rates of rent.

This Bill provides for the implementation of two initiatives relating to rent assistance. First, the rent assistance waiting period for recipients of Job Search allowance, Newstart allowance, sickness allowance or special benefit who have no children and who are aged between 18 and 60 years will be reduced from 26 weeks to 18 weeks. This will apply also for disability support pensioners aged between 18 and 20 years. This will start on 20 March 1992. Also, from 20 March 1992 eligibility for rent assistance will be extended to under-18-year-olds who receive the homeless/independent rate of Job Search allowance, sickness allowance, disability support pension or special benefit and who have been receiving social security income support for at least 18 weeks. A further initiative relating to rent assistance will be included in a Bill to be introduced later in the current sittings.

The Bill also provides for the extension, from 1 July 1992, of bereavement payments to certain long term social security recipients and their partners. The bereavement provisions generally work by allowing the survivor of a pensioner couple to get paid more for a period of 14 weeks. In some cases a lump sum may be payable. However, at present the bereavement provisions do not extend to beneficiary couples. The Bill also extends from 12 to 14 weeks the period in which a person receiving a widowed person allowance will be entitled to a bereavement payment. This measure will apply from 26 March 1992.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the aftermath of the recent deaths of people at Strathfield highlighted an unfortunate aspect of current social security legislation whereby child bereavement payments were not available to some families. My colleague the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) gave an undertaking to correct this deficiency at the first opportunity. This Bill gives effect to that commitment and provides that, on the death of a child, a parent may be eligible for payment for four weeks of family allowance, child disability allowance or double orphan pension as is applicable in the particular circumstances. This measure is to be taken to have commenced on 17 August 1991.

The Bill also makes some minor consequential amendments to various Acts mainly as a result of initiatives effected by this Bill and the introduction from 12 November 1991 of the disability reform package. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ruddock) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Free, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill is to put arrangements in place for the provision of general purpose assistance to the States and the Northern Territory in 1991-92, consistent with the decisions taken at the Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting on 31 May 1991. The Bill will replace the States Grants (General Purposes) Act 1990 and its provisions closely follow those of that Act.

The current estimate of general purpose funding for the States and the Northern Territory under the Bill totals $13,734m or about 13 per cent of estimated Commonwealth Budget outlays in 1991-92. As such, these payments constitute a major element of the Commonwealth's Budget. In combination with the global borrowing limits agreed at the Loan Council meeting, they also have a major bearing on the spending and borrowing of State governments.

In recent years there have been significant real reductions in payments to the States and in the size of their global borrowing limits. These reductions in payments and borrowings have been a key part of the Commonwealth strategy to ensure a continuing process of fiscal consolidation by encouraging restraint in expenditure at all levels of government but, at the same time, targeting that restraint so that the burden is shared equitably and sensibly.

We acknowledge that in recent years the States have borne substantial real adjustments in the level of Commonwealth assistance. Against that background, and in response to requests from the States for greater certainty in funding levels for the purpose of planning their medium term budget strategies, the Commonwealth agreed at the 1990 Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting to maintain the level of general revenue assistance in real terms for the three years 1991-92 to 1993-94. This commitment was subject to the qualification that Australia not suffer a major deterioration in its economic circumstances.

At the 1991 conference, the Commonwealth agreed to honour that undertaking, notwithstanding the sharp slowdown in economic activity and the consequent deterioration in its own budgetary position. In return, the States undertook to focus their adjustment efforts on restraint in current outlays and to consider increases in taxes and non-routine increases in tax charges only as very much a last resort. This undertaking has been honoured by the States in their 1991-92 budgets, and the Government is confident that excessive increases in State taxes and charges will not threaten to erode the substantial progress we have made in reducing inflationary pressures.

Most of the assistance to be provided under this Bill is in the form of general revenue grants, which are currently estimated to be $13,382m in 1991-92. By far the larger part of this amount comprises financial assistance grants, but it also includes special revenue assistance to the Northern Territory and a separate new interim category of assistance, namely, identified road funding, which gives effect to the October 1990 Special Premiers Conference decision to untie local road funding.

Consistent with the arrangements in previous years, financial assistance grants, special revenue assistance and identified road funding will all be adjusted for the difference between the actual increase in the consumer price index in the year to the March quarter 1992 and the forecast at the time of the Premiers Conference, so that the real level of assistance agreed at the conference is maintained.

Financial assistance grants are to be distributed on the basis of the Grants Commission's updated per capita relativities based on the five-year review period included in the Commission's 1991 report. As in recent years, the relativities are applied to a combined pool of financial assistance grants and the base level of hospital funding grants.

As noted earlier, the Northern Territory is to be provided with special revenue assistance in 1991-92. Similar special assistance has been provided to the Northern Territory in each year since its inclusion in the pool of general revenue assistance for the States. In line with the intention to progressively move the Northern Territory to a financial basis comparable with the States, the base level of this assistance has been reduced from $50m in 1990-91 to $40m in 1991-92.

Turning to the identified road funding to be appropriated under this Bill, while the greater part of the funds for local roads that are now untied are paid to local government there remains a small amount of these funds which, under the agreed arrangements for 1991-92, are to be paid to State, rather than local, governments. This Bill will authorise those payments. The overall distribution of these funds between the States reflects the existing distributional principles pertaining to previous tied grant arrangements. The arrangements for payments to local government bodies in 1991-92 were incorporated in amendments to the Local Governments (Financial Assistance) Act passed by Parliament last June. This will make a modest, but nonetheless significant, contribution to enhancing State and local government budgetary flexibility. The final arrangements to apply beyond 1991-92 will be determined with an eye, inter alia, to the implications of other such changes in Commonwealth-State financial relations which might be agreed in the context of the current Special Premiers Conference review processes.
The Bill also provides for the payment of $296.8m in interest free capital grants to the States and the Northern Territory. This is the same amount as provided in 1990-91.

No provision is made in this Bill for payments of general purpose assistance to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). However, provisions in Appropriation Bill No. 2 allow for analogous payments to be made to the ACT.

Mr Deputy Speaker, this Bill is an integral part of the Commonwealth's financial relations with the State governments and the Budget. I commend the Bill to the House and present the related explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ruddock) adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 6.32 to 8 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Free, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Financial Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 will simplify the statutory procedures for approval of new coin issues under the Currency Act 1965 and remove potential ambiguities in the wording of sections 13 and 14 of that Act. The Bill also effects two minor amendments to the Financial Corporations Act 1974, and repeals the Special Employment-related Programs Act 1982.

The statutory procedures under the Currency Act 1965 for the approval of new coins, or variations to design or other characteristics of existing denominations, were drawn up at a time when the number of new numismatic or collector coins was very small. However, in recent years there has been a considerable increase in the number of such coins being issued under the programs of both the Royal Australian Mint and the Gold Corporation, a statutory authority of the Western Australian Government that produces precious metal coins.

Under the present arrangements, considerable administrative effort is required before the necessary Executive Council approval is obtained for any variation to the currency regulations. Apart from the drafting and preparation of additional documentation, the procedures can involve time delays, particularly as Executive Council meets only periodically. Such delays can create difficulties for the marketing programs associated with the launch of new collector coins.

The proposed amendments to sections 13 and 14 of the Currency Act contained in this Bill are designed primarily to provide the Treasurer with the authority to approve new coins or determine variations to designs or other characteristics of existing denominations
by means of a disallowable instrument, thereby dispensing with the need to refer such matters to the Executive Council.

It is anticipated that this simplified procedure will offer administrative savings. In all other respects, the effect of the arrangement will be the same as the making of a regulation. In particular, there will be the same opportunity for parliamentary scrutiny as that which currently exists.

The remaining amendments to sections 13 and 14 of the Currency Act are designed to remove possible ambiguities arising from the amendments to the Act made in 1987 to facilitate the production of the same coin denomination in different metallic compositions.

The amendments to the Financial Corporations Act 1974 will permit the Treasurer to delegate to the Governor or Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia the responsibility for varying and publishing the list of non-bank financial institutions which fall under the Act. The amendments will also permit the Treasurer to publish the varied list in a manner or form he or she thinks appropriate. These amendments are intended to simplify administrative processes but do not affect the substance of the Act.

The Special Employment-related Programs Act 1982 was enacted by the former Fraser Government to appropriate moneys saved under wage pause arrangements for Commonwealth employees up to a total of $300m for the purposes of employment generating programs. The Act provided that subsidies were not to be payable in respect of employment after 30 June 1984.
By agreement with the States, which administered the program, $200m was allocated for employment programs and the remaining $100m was provided for welfare housing.

All activities under the Act are obviously complete and all moneys paid out have been satisfactorily accounted for. As the Act is now spent, the Government is taking the opportunity afforded by the Financial Legislation Amendment Bill to remove it from the statute books. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Dr Wooldridge) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Free, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
This Bill will amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986 to increase the fringe benefits tax rate from 47 per cent to 48.25 per cent.
This amendment will align the fringe benefits tax rate with the top marginal tax rate plus the Medicare levy.
I present the explanatory memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Wooldridge) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Free, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I am pleased to introduce this Bill, which will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of comprehensive double taxation agreements between Australia and India and Australia and Poland. The Bill will insert the texts of the agreements into the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953 as schedules to that Act.

The Polish and Indian agreements, which were signed on 7 May 1991 and 25 July 1991 respectively, deal with all substantial forms of income flowing between Australia and those countries. Details of each agreement were announced and copies made publicly available at the time of signature.

Both agreements generally accord with other comprehensive taxation agreements concluded by Australia in recent years but the agreement with India differs from them in certain respects. Those differences reflect a balancing of Australia's interests with India's position as a major developing country and importer of technology.

A notable feature of the agreement with India in that regard is the royalty provisions, which prescribe different source country tax rate limits for various categories of royalty payments and provide for fees for services to be treated as royalties in specified limited circumstances.

Another feature of the agreement with India is that it provides for `tax sparing' credit relief to be extended by Australia for tax forgone by India under specified development incentives for the encouragement of foreign investment.

Where income derived by an Australian resident taxpayer has benefited from one of the nominated development incentives, the agreement calls for a tax credit to be allowed by Australia for the Indian tax forgone. By this means, the development incentives will retain their attractions for Australian firms and allow them to compete for business in India on favourable terms.

The agreement with India will enter into force when the Australian and Indian governments have exchanged diplomatic notes advising each other that the necessary constitutional processes to give the agreement the force of law in their respective countries have been completed. The enactment of this Bill will complete the processes required of Australia for those purposes.

Conclusion of the agreement with Poland is indicative of Australia's support for that country's moves towards democratic structures and economic reforms. That agreement will enter into force on the date of exchange of instruments of ratification. This ratification process would also follow the enactment of this Bill.

The Government believes the agreements will contribute positively to the strengthening of trade, investment, and wider relationships between Australia and India and Australia and Poland, but it is not possible to predict the eventual effect on the revenue. I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Wooldridge) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Free, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. The Bill will give effect to the announcements in the March industry statement that the tax concession for research and development will be retained as a permanent feature and that provision be made for the deductibility of environmental impact study expenditure.

The Bill will exempt from tax the pay and allowances of members of the Australian defence forces allotted for duty in Iraq and Kuwait in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. It also contains amendments to support the existing tax file number arrangements. Another amendment will give effect to the announcement of the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) on 13 June to provide relief for small business by deferring the initial payment of company tax in respect of the 1990-91 income year.

The Bill will also give effect to the announcement on 2 August that living away from home allowances paid to offshore oil and gas rig workers will be treated as fringe benefits. Other announcements to be given effect by this Bill relate to foreign source income measures, gifts to funds administered by cultural organisations, deductibility of petroleum resource rent tax payments and Medicare levy exemptions.

This Bill will also give effect to certain changes announced in the 1991-92 Budget. One Budget announcement is an amendment to include the winnings of certain investment related lotteries in the assessable income of the winner. Another will accord friendly societies and other registered organisations the same treatment for dividend imputation purposes as mutual life companies and government insurance offices. Other Budget announcements to be given effect by this Bill relate to general mining exploration and prospecting expenditure, the timing of franking credits, capital gains tax and protection levy payments by life insurance companies.

The Bill introduces new procedures to be followed by taxpayers seeking review by the Federal Court or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation. The Bill also simplifies the law by consolidating objection, review and appeal provisions that are common to various taxation laws administered by the Commissioner. The Bill will also amend the garnishee rules and PAYE provisions of the tax laws as well as propose several minor changes to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987. Finally, the Bill contains a number of minor technical or consequential amendments of the tax laws. I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.
Environmental Impact Study
Expenditure

The Bill will allow a deduction for expenditure incurred on or after 12 March 1991 on environmental impact studies. The expenditure, other than for plant and articles, will be written off over the lesser of 10 years or the life of the project to which the studies relate. The cost of plant and articles will be depreciable. The proposed deduction was announced by the Government in the March 1991 industry statement. The cost of this measure is expected to rise to an estimated cost of $45m after 10 years.
Exemption of pay and allowances
of members of Defence Forces
serving in Iraq and Kuwait

As announced by the Minister for Defence, Science and Personnel on 14 August 1990, the pay and allowances earned by Defence Force personnel allotted for duty in Iraq and Kuwait in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait will be exempt from income tax. The amendment proposed by this Bill will extend the existing operational area for the exemption to include the countries of Iraq and Kuwait with effect from 23 February 1991. The amendment will also cease the exemption after 9 June 1991. The revenue cost was in the order of $8.75m in the 1990-91 income year.
Capital Gains Tax Cost Base

The Bill will implement the change announced in the 1991-92 Budget to the capital gains tax provisions. Taxpayers will now be allowed to offset non-deductible costs such as interest, repairs, rates and taxes and insurance premiums against the taxable capital gain made on disposal of an asset. The change affects assets acquired on or after 21 August 1991 and is not expected to have a significant revenue cost.
Research and Development

The tax concession for research and development at the rate of 125 per cent of expenditure incurred will be retained as a permanent feature of the Income Tax Assessment Act beyond 1995. The Government has decided to retain the concession in order to keep promoting research and development activities by industry in Australia. This Bill will give effect to the Government's decision which was announced in the March industry statement. The estimated cost is $180m per annum in the first year of impact, 1996-97, rising to $280m per annum by the year 2000-01.
Direct lodgment of taxation appeals
and applications for review

Under the present law a taxpayer who is dissatisfied with the decision of the Commissioner on an objection against an assessment or similar decision may request the Commissioner to refer the decision to the Federal Court or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This right of appeal or review is given to taxpayers by various taxation laws. Following an independent review of the processes for resolving taxation disputes, a recommendation was made to the Government that taxpayers should--like litigants in fields other than taxation--lodge their own appeals and applications for review direct with the Court or the Tribunal. The Government has accepted this recommendation. As a result, this Bill proposes amendments of provisions in various taxation laws to remove the requirement that appeals and applications for review be lodged through the Commissioner. These changes have also provided an opportunity to simplify the law by consolidating the common objection, review and appeal provisions of the different statutes in the Taxation Administration Act.

The new provisions adopt more modern language and drafting approaches. Existing provisions of that Act which modify procedures in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for taxation matters have been rewritten to take account of the new method for seeking review. Their effect is unchanged except in two minor respects. One is that many documents formerly supplied by the Commissioner to the Tribunal as a matter of course will be supplied only if the Tribunal calls for them. This will save a lot of unnecessary time and expense.

The other change relates to the review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of decisions of a training advisory body to issue a training advisory certificate under the training guarantee legislation. They are not decisions of the Commissioner and, in future, review by the Tribunal of such decisions will not be subject to the procedural modifications I have referred to.

These amendments will apply to all taxation decisions made on or after a date to be fixed by proclamation. Transitional provisions will ensure that the amendments also apply to appeals or applications for review made after the commencement date even though the relevant assessment was made before that date. This means that appeals or applications for review in respect of any objection decision made after the proclaimed commencement date will need to be lodged direct with the Federal Court or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
Tax File Number

This Bill will amend the income tax law to provide for the assessment and collection of a tax file number withholding tax where an investor has not quoted a tax file number for certain deferred interest investments. A separate Bill, the Income Tax (Deferred Interest Securities) (Tax File Number Withholding Tax) Bill 1991, will impose the tax file number withholding tax. The new arrangements, which will not impact on the revenue, will provide that, where a tax file number is not quoted by the investor for certain deferred interest investments, a tax file number withholding tax will be payable jointly and severally by the investor and the investment body. Investment bodies which pay the tax file number withholding tax for a deferred interest investment will be able to recover the amount paid from the investor. As a result of industry consultations, the Government has decided that the new rules will only apply to investments made on or after 1 February 1992. This will give investment bodies sufficient time to make any necessary changes to their existing practices to give effect to these amendments.
Investment-related Lottery Winnings

The winnings of certain investment-related lotteries which are drawn or decided on or after the day on which this Bill receives royal assent will be treated as assessable income of the winner. The winnings will not be taxed by this amendment if either the prize won or the right to participate in the investment-related lottery is already liable to tax under existing rules. Prizes will be taxed only if the lottery is in the nature of a return on an investment. Prizes won in ordinary lotteries such as Lotto are not affected. The proposal was announced in the 1991-92 Budget. The amendment has no direct impact on revenue, but will prevent revenue losses by ensuring that otherwise taxable investment receipts such as interest cannot be replaced by non-taxable lottery winnings.
Registered Organisations

The Bill will accord friendly societies and other registered organisations the same treatment for dividend imputation purposes as mutual life companies and government insurance offices. A company's tax liability gives rise to franking credits which can be used to frank dividends paid to shareholders. Registered organisations, such as mutual life assurance companies and government insurance offices, do not have shareholders and therefore cannot use the franking credits that accrue from the tax paid on their insurance and superannuation business. This Bill will give effect to the 1991-92 Budget announcement to deny registered organisations the right to maintain a franking account and to cancel any surplus of franking credits held by them at 3.00 p.m. on 20 August 1991.

The measure will have no direct impact on the revenue. However, there are potential revenue savings, in that it will prevent new shareholders of any friendly society that issues share capital from having access to franking credits accumulated before capitalisation.
Timing of Franking Credits

The Bill will give effect to the announcement in the 1991-92 Budget to change the basis on which companies receive franking credits under the dividend imputation arrangements. The effect of the measure will be that only the payment of company tax will give rise to a franking credit.

The present law allows companies to pay franked dividends on the basis of imputation credits that are generated when a notice of assessment is served rather than when the assessment is paid. Shareholders are presently entitled to a franking rebate on the franked dividends received, even if the company tax liability that allowed the company to frank the dividends is never paid.

The amendments proposed by this Bill will apply to assessment and other notices increasing tax liability which issue after 20 August 1991. Appropriate transitional measures will cover cases where tax has been paid prior to issue of such notices. Changing the source of imputation credits from assessment to a payment basis will eliminate the scope for compounding the revenue losses that occur under the present law when companies fail to pay their tax liabilities. These revenue gains, however, cannot be quantified.
Deferral of Initial Payment of Company Tax

The Bill will provide the legislation necessary to give effect to the Treasurer's announcement of 13 June to provide relief for small business by deferring the initial payment of company income tax in respect of the 1990-91 income year. The companies affected are those with a tax liability of $1,000 or more but less than $400,000 and which pay their tax in two instalments. The date for the initial payment of tax was deferred by seven weeks from the twenty-eighth day of the month following balance date to the fifteenth day of the third month following balance date.

The amount of initial tax payment affects the amount of a company's franking deficit tax and franking credits and debits. The amendments, which will not affect the revenue, will ensure that those amounts will be determined as if there had been no deferral of the initial tax payment.
Foreign Source Income

The Government has always been willing to finetune the foreign source income measures to ensure their smoother operation. To this end, three of the amendments proposed by this Bill will operate to relieve double taxation that could arise under the measures. In the first instance, further relief from double taxation will be provided in relation to an Australian controlled foreign company that has changed its residence from a low tax country to either Australia or a listed--comparable tax--country.

Secondly, corporate unit trusts, public trading trusts and superannuation trusts will be treated similarly to other resident taxpayers by being granted an exemption from Australian tax for distributions from a controlled foreign company out of income previously attributed to them. The third amendment will ensure that taxpayers are not disadvantaged by the operation of the rules for the conversion and carry-forward of foreign losses incurred before 1990-91.

However, the Government is determined to act against attempts to erode the integrity of the foreign source income measures. Therefore, one amendment will deny taxpayers a tax advantage they have sought to obtain through changing the residence of a controlled foreign company from a comparable tax country to a low tax country. These taxpayers will be denied foreign tax credits on dividends paid by the company out of pre-1990-91 profits accumulated in the comparable tax country.
Fringe Benefits Tax--Living Away From Home Allowances

On 2 August 1991 the Government announced that living-away-from-home allowances paid to offshore oil and gas rig workers will be treated as fringe benefits. When the fringe benefits tax law was introduced in 1986 it was the Government's intention that these allowances would be subject to fringe benefits tax. The Bill will amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act to achieve that result. The amendment will have a negligible effect on revenue.
Gifts to Gift Funds of Cultural Organisations

The Bill will give effect to the announcement of 24 March 1991 introducing new arrangements for gifts to gift funds of cultural organisations. The amendment will take effect from 25 March 1991. Under the new arrangements tax deductible gifts may be made to gift funds listed on a register of cultural organisations. To be listed, a fund must be approved by the Treasurer and the Minister responsible for the arts. As a consequence of these new arrangements, the Bill will also remove the names of seven cultural organisations that are presently listed in the gift provisions of the income tax law. Although the financial impact of the amendment cannot be quantified it is unlikely that the amendment will have a substantial impact on revenue.
Life Insurance Protection Levy

The Bill will amend the income tax law to provide for the taxation treatment of various payments associated with the measure to assist policyholders of Occidental Life Insurance Company of Australia Ltd and Regal Life Insurance Ltd. For instance, protection levy payments will be tax deductible to life insurance companies. This proposal was announced in the 1991-92 Budget and the estimated cost of the amendments is $25m.
General Mining Exploration and Prospecting Expenditure

The mineral exploration and prospecting provision in the income tax law will be amended by this Bill. The requirement that general mineral exploration and prospecting expenditure needs to be incurred on a mining tenement to be eligible for a deduction will not apply on or after 1 July 1991. The change, which was announced in the 1991-92 Budget, will ensure that deductibility for such expenditure is the same as that which is available to petroleum and quarrying exploration expenditure. There is expected to be a small but unquantifiable impact on revenue.
Medicare Levy

The Bill gives effect to the announcement on 9 July of the Government's intention to remove an anomaly which has arisen in the Medicare levy exemption arrangements. The amendment will continue to guarantee that blind pensioners and sickness beneficiaries are exempt from paying the Medicare levy regardless of the level of their income. The amendment avoids an additional unintended cost to revenue.
Amendments Relating to Garnishee Notices

The Bill will amend the garnishee rules in the tax laws so that, in relation to building society shares, only withdrawable shares--and not permanent or fixed shares--in the capital of a building society can be garnisheed from such a society. This will provide for similar treatment for shares in companies and building societies in relation to the garnishee rules. The amendment will apply to garnishee notices issued after the date of Royal Assent to the Bill.
PAYE Amendments

The Bill will also amend the pay-as-you-earn provisions in the income tax law. The amendment will restructure and update the definitions contained in the provisions. The update will clarify the scope of the PAYE arrangements and remove existing references to arrangements between the Governor-General and the States. These references are no longer required.
The amendments will also correct a technical inconsistency between the definition of `employer' and the penalty provisions in the PAYE arrangements. The amendments will not affect the revenue.
Occupational Superannuation Standards

The Bill proposes that all payers of eligible termination payments be required to report such payments to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. This will remedy deficiencies in the current legislation whereby some payers are not required to report such payments because of inadequacies in the existing definition of payer.

The Bill also provides that, where a superannuation fund fails to comply with a request by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to commute the excessive component of a pension, the Commissioner may exercise a discretion to treat the fund as though it were a complying fund. The legislation currently provides that a fund which does not commute an excessive component of a pension as requested by the Commissioner becomes a non-complying fund and loses its entitlement to concessional taxation treatment on its income.

The Bill proposes that the existing deadline of 31 December 1991 for applications for pre-1 July 1988 funding credits be removed from the Act and that the date by which applications must be made be prescribed in the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations.
Petroleum Resource Rent Tax

The Government foreshadowed when introducing the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 into this House on 9 May 1991 that a minor change in the treatment of Petroleum Resource Rent Tax payments would be made.

Under the existing law, PRRT is deductible for income tax purposes only after the final assessment has been made. Therefore, instalments of PRRT are not deductible until a later income year when an assessment of PRRT is made.

This Bill will allow instalments of PRRT paid on or after 1 July 1991 to be deductible for income tax purposes in the year in which the instalment payments are made. The new provisions will be consistent with general income tax principles. This change will apply to all PRRT instalments paid on or after 1 July 1991. The estimated cost of the amendment will be $125m in 1991-92 and $205m in 1992-93.
Provisional tax changes
The Bill also contains amendments that relate to the measures enacted by this Government last year requiring the payment of provisional tax on certain salary or wages income.

These amendments, which will have negligible effect on the revenue, are designed to prevent certain taxpayers from receiving an income tax deferral advantage. The law will also make it clear which amounts are to be taken into account when a taxpayer varies his or her provisional tax.
Minor and Consequential Amendments

The Bill will make a number of minor technical amendments to the income tax law. Consequential amendments are also required to bring the income tax law into line with amendments to social security and veterans' entitlements legislation.

A minor technical amendment will also be made to the Wool Tax (Administration) Act 1964. I present the explanatory memorandum, which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Wooldridge) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX (DEFERRED INTEREST SECURITIES) (TAX FILE NUMBER WITHHOLDING TAX) BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Free, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will impose a withholding tax jointly and severally on investment bodies and investors where a tax file number is not quoted for certain deferred interest investments made on or after 1 February 1992. The new withholding tax will not represent a new source of revenue to the Government. Rather, the measure will, in conjunction with the amendments proposed by the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991, support the existing tax file number legislation and ensure that an effective sanction is applied where a tax file number is not quoted for the deferred interest investments covered by the new arrangements.
The explanatory memorandum accompanying this Bill contains more detailed explanations of these provisions of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Wooldridge) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Free, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: -Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1991 will amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986 to increase the income thresholds below which married couples and sole parents will not be called on to pay any levy. For 1991-92, individuals with taxable incomes of up to $11,745 will not be required to pay the levy. This threshold is unchanged from the previous year. Married couples and sole parents with family incomes of up to $19,674 will not be required to pay the levy for the income year 1991-92. The income threshold for married couples and sole parents will continue to be increased by a further $2,100 for each dependent child or student. For example, a married couple with three dependent children will pay no levy until their combined taxable incomes exceed $25,974.

The estimated cost of the increased low income threshold is nil in 1991-92 and $10m in 1992-93. The change in low income thresholds will not be reflected in provisional tax raised for 1991-92 as the amounts involved would be very small for individual taxpayers. It is not proposed to amend the tax instalment schedules to take account of the change until 1 July 1992. The number of people from whom the levy is deducted in PAYE instalments and who would be affected by the change would be relatively small. On the other hand changing the PAYE instalment schedules would involve an administrative cost to the Government and there would also be a substantial administrative cost to the business community.
The explanatory memorandum accompanying this Bill contains more detailed explanation of the provisions of this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I want to address my remarks in this debate to the Budget provisions relating to the Department of Veterans' Affairs entitlements. I will link these provisions to the extension of repatriation medical entitlements to wartime merchant mariners. On 20 June I told the House about the role that our wartime merchant mariners had played in the defence of our country; about their contribution to the Allied effort around the globe; and about the difficulty in gaining accurate statistics on how many men lost their lives. Certainly, I referred to the paucity of information about the injuries suffered by the wartime merchant mariners.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to quote a couple of paragraphs from the report of the McGirr inquiry which was set up by this Government. Paragraph 3.91 says:

It is difficult to ascertain the number of Australian merchant mariners who were injured, but not killed, as a result of enemy action. If the injury was sufficiently serious to disable a mariner or to bring it to the notice of the ship's master, it should have been recorded in the ship's log. Some records, such as ships' logs, were lost when ships were sunk.
The next paragraph goes on to say:

Very few merchant ships had medical staff or facilities on board. Some of the larger cargo ships, in particular those that also carried passengers, carried a doctor or trained medical staff. However, in the majority of cases there are very few, if any, medical records available for Australian merchant mariners during the war.

That is the background to the paucity of information that is available on injuries suffered by our wartime merchant mariners. I have been unable to fathom the reasons for the historical reluctance to give proper recognition to the role that shipping has played in the development of our nation and to the role that Australian merchant mariners have played in the fight for liberty and independence in the defence of our nation.

I am sure that in sectors of Australian industry and in sections of the Federal bureaucracy there has been a longstanding antipathy towards Australian mariners. I have no doubt that this has been a major factor in the failure of successive Australian governments to grant proper recognition to wartime merchant mariners and to grant the proper entitlements due to them. It has only been in recent years that a change in attitude has brought about some of that recognition.

I have some ideas of the reasons for that antipathy but I do not want to go into them. Suffice it to say that I think it is time they were put aside and that our wartime merchant mariners were given the proper recognition that is due to them for the role that they played in fighting alongside our servicemen in uniform in times of need and in the defence of this nation.

Next year is the fiftieth anniversary of the Coral Sea battle. Yesterday we saw the first meeting of the Australia-United States Coral Sea Commemorative Council. That council is to be chaired by Sir Eric Neal AC with Admiral Mike Hudson AC the deputy chairman. The Council has an important role to play in ensuring that all activities associated with the Coral Sea fiftieth commemoration are a spectacular success. I am especially pleased that the Federal Secretary of the Seamen's Union of Australia, Patrick Geraghty, is part of that committee. This means that merchant mariners will not be forgotten when those celebrations and activities in respect of the fiftieth anniversary of the Coral Sea battle are being organised next year.

Our merchant mariners made a significant contribution to our wartime effort and certainly they made a contribution in the battle for the Coral Sea. In the Budget they were recognised as being equal with Australian veterans in respect of repatriation treatment benefits and they will be recognised during next year's commemorative activities. In fact, a number of memorials will be erected to recognise the efforts of our merchant mariners and they will be unveiled during the course of next year.

Next year also will be the fiftieth anniversary of the sinking of the first Australian ships on the Australian coast during World War II--the Iron Knight and the Iron Chieftain, both BHP owned ships. A committee in the Hunter is working to build and unveil a regional memorial to wartime merchant mariners in recognition not only of the sinking of those vessels but also in recognition of the contribution generally made by merchant mariners during that war.

I have mentioned the difficulty of getting information on the number of crew that were injured and I will come back to that in a moment. I want to refer to the activities in our own city of Newcastle and our own region of the Hunter. Organisations and people who are working with the committee to erect a memorial to wartime merchant mariners include: the Newcastle City Council; the Company of Master Mariners and their Federal master, Captain Allan Irons; Captain Les Packman, a former BHP captain; Bob Nelson of Mount Hutton; officers of council; Captain Geoff Fair; and me. So there is a cross-section of people associated with the industry in our region and with direct links with BHP and the industry. There is a very strong relationship with and recognition of the role of our wartime merchant mariners and of the role that shipping and shipbuilding have played in the Hunter.

The Hunter is renowned as the great shipbuilding centre of Australia. The first steamship ever built in this country, the William the Fourth, was built in the Hunter by a family called Lowe. Shipbuilders were brought out from Scotland for that purpose. The vessel was built of local timbers on the shores of the Williams River just north of Newcastle at Raymond Terrace. We have constructed a full-scale operating replica of that first steamship built in Australia. Currently the William the Fourth is at Darling Harbour on exhibition. It will sail back to Newcastle in the next few weeks to participate in the major maritime festival we have organised in Newcastle at which we will be conducting a `walk-the-plankathon'. I invite all members of this House and all Ministers of this Government to contribute to that worthy cause by making a contribution to the Newcastle regional museum.

I will accept the very honourable and welcome tax deductible donation from the Minister for Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons), who is at the table. Those donations will go to a very important cause--that is, a recognition of our maritime heritage and a recognition of the role that our merchant mariners have played and will play in the development of this country.

In trying to identify how many people lost their lives in World War II, I again go back to the reference in the McGirr report to the seeking of further information. The inquiry contacted the Australian War Memorial. The War Memorial used a variety of sources to compile a list of names of Australian merchant mariners who lost their lives in wartime. Approximately 520 names are currently listed and I have referred to that in debates in this House before. I make the point that the project is an ongoing one and that names are still being added.

I want to conclude by saying that wartime merchant mariners have brought their case to this Parliament year after year after year. Almost half a century after the event we are now extending to them medical entitlements similar to those available to our veterans. We want to see those entitlements extended now so that wartime merchant mariners are placed on an equal footing with veterans of our defence forces. They are entitled to that. But in saying that, we want to commend especially the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) for his determination and for his commitment.

When I spoke in the House on 20 June, I put the case for wartime merchant mariners to him and to the House. He obviously responded to that and argued successfully in Cabinet for the extension of those medical entitlements to wartime merchant mariners. They have asked me to convey to him their very warm appreciation of his commitment, his effort and his success in convincing his Cabinet colleagues that this was a right decision to make. We look forward now to a further recognition of those wartime merchant mariners in terms of the extension of full entitlements on an equal footing with veterans of World War II.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: --I share the regard of the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) for the present Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), whom I have always found to be interested in veterans affairs. I believe that he takes his portfolio very seriously. In the correspondence I have had with him on numerous occasions, I have found him to be very helpful. However, he is a member of the Government which, through its Budget, has missed many opportunities in respect of the appropriation and handling of funds for the Department of Veterans' Affairs. In the speech I made in this place last night relating to defence, I said that I seriously doubt the commitment of this Labor Government to the defence of this country, not only because of the Minister's May statement, but also because of what followed in the Budget. There are some very disappointing aspects of the Budget in respect of its treatment of veterans affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government does not use the Budget to redress the inequalities faced by war widows as compared with their social security civilian widow counterparts. Once again, another Budget is passed without recognition in the form of the Vietnam medal for those who served on HMAS Sydney and other logistical support vessels. The Government did not take the opportunity in this Budget to reform the artificial limbs scheme. I could go on. There are other examples of what I see as plain insensitivity, or even ignorance in a sense, when it comes to veterans affairs.

As you will recall, Mr Deputy Chairman, earlier this year we had the debacle over the introduction of an entry fee to the Australian War Memorial. I notice that in this Budget the Government has almost rubbed salt into the wounds that it created in its attempt to restrict access to the War Memorial through placing a charge on that access. The Budget cuts the funding for the War Memorial by some $80,000. I believe that is a disgrace. It must be a bitter pill to swallow not only for our ex-servicemen whose mates gave their lives in the active service of our country, but also for today's service personnel who must surely view this as a further denigration of the vital role that they are playing in our country's future.

I could speak at length on the blows that our Defence Force has had to face in recent times. In dealing with the defence appropriation last night, I took the opportunity to do just that. I will not dwell on defence tonight; I want to talk particularly about veterans affairs.

I believe that the Labor Government's treatment of veterans mirrors the low priority it places on defence. I ask: why has not one veterans organisation been given formal representation on the Australian War Memorial Council? If anyone deserves a seat on the Council table it is a representative of ex-service organisations, given the important role that they have traditionally played in remembering our war dead. I see this as yet another example of the Government's insensitivity.

Another issue that is of concern--it is one that we have debated in this Parliament in recent times--is the absence of a war service home loan within the current defence housing scheme. Apparently, when the scheme was devised the Government did not anticipate that Australia would be engaged in a war again. That turned out to be rather naive and short-sighted because only shortly afterwards we were sending troops to serve in the Gulf war. When the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was farewelling the troops that we were sending to the Gulf--mainly Navy personnel who equipped themselves extremely well--he was doing that in the full knowledge that for the first time since World War I those particular service personnel would not be eligible for a war service loan on their return to Australia. Of course, there was an outcry about this. The Opposition was successful in having that problem addressed and redressed. The Government subsequently introduced amendments to the scheme which would mean that war service loans are reinstated for those who served in the Gulf.

However, the problem remains--we pointed this out in the debate when we dealt with the correction of that problem involving Gulf personnel--that there is still no provision beyond that for war service loans for those who serve in any future conflicts. That shows a real disregard for the interests of those who currently serve in the Defence Force. After all, at any time they may be required to serve this country in an overseas theatre of war. I think it shows that we are ill-prepared for the future. As I said in the debate last night, that underlines the Government's whole attitude to the defence of this country.

Earlier the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) alluded to a number of the important events which will shortly be upon us as we approach a number of significant fiftieth anniversary celebrations. It is now 50 years since many of the important events of World War II that Australian troops were engaged in. In April last year we had the seventy-fifth anniversary of Gallipoli. Recently we had the commemoration of the Battle of Long Tan in South Vietnam.

Next year we are to commemorate the fall of Singapore, the bombing of Darwin, the Battle of the Java Sea and the Battle of the Coral Sea. It was that event which the honourable member for Shortland alluded to. Like him, I was pleased to note that in Sydney yesterday a Coral Sea commemorative council was formed, to be headed by Sir Eric Neal. It is to embark on the raising of $2m specifically for the purpose of commemorating the Battle of the Coral Sea next year. That particular event underlines for veterans the very important relationship which we have enjoyed over the years with our close friend and ally, the United States of America.

We look forward later this year to a visit from the President of the United States. He is a World War II veteran. No doubt he will be the last American President to be a veteran of that war. I am looking forward--as, I am sure, are honourable members on both sides of this House--to welcoming President George Bush to Australia in December this year. I note, in particular, that he served with great distinction in the Second World War. We have other events to look forward to, including the Battle of Milne Bay and Kokoda. It is important for those who served in those events to commemorate them. It is extremely significant. It is even more significant in some respects for the relatives of those who served who did not live to look back.

In October next year we will also see the dedication of the Australian Vietnam forces national memorial in Canberra--a particularly significant event for the three of us in this place who saw active service in South Vietnam. Yet Vietnam veterans, many of whom I am particularly close to, continue to suffer. Hardly a week goes by in this country where there is not a suicide of another Vietnam veteran who has been unable to cope with the memories of that particular conflict. Many of them were very young when they served.

In looking back at many of these significant events, apparently very little money is available from the Government coffers to help subsidise reunions and commemorations of historic battles. I wrote to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs recently about this. In his reply he says:
My assistance must be drawn from a small fund which I have at my discretion as almost the entirety of my portfolio's budget is required for the provision of pensions and health care.

It may well be that that is the case, but I think it is pretty poor that the Government is not able to allocate more than it has towards supporting the veterans in the commemoration of these particular events. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish to focus my comments on the health area and, in particular, the appropriations that come under the heading of AIDS control, which is found on page 3-83 of Budget Paper No. 1. In this paragraph details are given for grants provided for education and prevention, treatment and support services, the national media campaign and research activities. Expenditure for these areas during 1991-92 is estimated at $51.7m, which of course is not an insignificant amount.

SPEECH.PARA: In Budget Paper No.3, on page 199, under the heading `Health Promotion and Disease Prevention', an objective is clearly articulated which I believe proves most interesting reading. The objective reads:
To reduce the burden of preventable disease and disability amongst all Australians and improve the equitable access for all Australians to opportunities and prerequisites to good health.
To reduce the incidence, morbidity and mortality of communicable diseases in Australia, with particular emphasis on minimising transmission of the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV).

The objectives then go on to cover the assistance the Government will provide for sufferers. I admit that unfortunately our education programs continue to assume a maturity that is not present. They assume moral relativism and promiscuity and in doing so legitimise both. They give our young people false confidence. In fact, I believe these programs even betray them.

Sadly, research conducted in South Australia by Dr Gavin Hart, and published in a recent edition of the Medical Journal of Australia, documents the failure of many to associate the HIV infection with other sexually transmitted diseases. Professor John Dwyer, Professor of Medicine at the University of New South Wales, said that Dr Hart's study `confirmed suspicions, generated concern and suggested direction for future HIV educational programs'. The study involved 2,249 men and 1,153 women and identified a number of key areas for concern. They were: firstly, many men and women, unconcerned about HIV infection, admitted to having multiple sexual partners and actually had a sexually transmitted disease; secondly, those who had previously had a negative test for HIV and who continued to engage in dangerous sexual activity saw no reason for further testing; thirdly, despite educational efforts, it was largely believed that only gays and IV drug users are at risk of infection of HIV.

In discussing these findings with directors of socially transmitted disease services in Victoria and New South Wales, Professor Dwyer concluded that the South Australian results are typical, indeed representative, of national attitudes.
I would like to quote Professor Dwyer from a recent paper he had published in the Medical Journal of Australia. His comments are most interesting. He says:

The simple truth of course is that unless sexual behaviour is modified in a manner that sees a dramatic fall in the incidence of all socially transmitted diseases in our community, we must consider our anti-HIV educational programmes to have failed. Education which informs but does not alter behaviour is useless.
Professor Dwyer goes on to say:

The World Health Organisation estimates that 10,000 new HIV infections occur daily and while most infected are in the third world, increasing numbers of infections in the heterosexual communities of western countries are being reported. This is particularly true for women who are more readily infected than are men. Any belief that we have beaten the AIDS epidemic in Australia will ensure that we have not.
Professor Dwyer then says:
AIDS/HIV education programmes have lost their way in Australia.

This evidence reinforces my belief that we need to tell young people that if they fool around, it is very likely that they will die a lonely and miserable death. They should be warned that through self-abuse of drugs or sexual irresponsibility, they break a trust with the community, forfeit certain rights and can expect certain sanctions. This should be the view put bluntly as adults to adults, heterosexual or homosexual, who in the AIDS context are acting like children.

In October 1987 I put to this chamber a suggestion that the community, Parliament and the Government had not come to grips with the fundamental questions that the AIDS epidemic poses. I said then that we were ignoring to our peril five fundamental questions, and I believe quite strongly that we continue to ignore them. For that reason I ask those questions again in order of priority. Firstly, what is the role of government in nurturing or moulding community values and individual behaviour? Secondly, what is the obligation of government to prevent harm to innocent individuals caused by the behaviour of other individuals, if necessary, by restricting freedom of those other individuals? Thirdly, what is the nature and extent of individual accountability to the community for behaviour which creates significant financial burdens on the community? Fourthly, what balance is to be struck between individual privacy and liberty and community interest when dealing with an extreme epidemic of the type the AIDS epidemic represents? Finally, do our young people in schools have the maturity, conceptually and morally, that sex and AIDS education programs assume that they have?

I said it then in 1987 and I say it again in 1991: I do not believe that our allocations will be effective until we have gone through the process of addressing these questions. The Government will continue to be directionless and constantly responding to various pressure groups if it does not consciously clarify its views on these five very important questions.

What the AIDS epidemic has revealed, above all else, is what has been called AIDS in the moral and spiritual realm. In reflecting on the strategy we should adopt to address the spread of AIDS, we should focus on the success of an intellectual virus which has first invaded the various areas of this society's intellectual and moral defence system, and then rendered that system incapable of discerning those ideas and behaviour which produce fundamental social degeneration.

One of the main contributing factors in this gradual loss of the capacity to identify what is right and wrong has been the paralysis of this Parliament and governments of all political persuasions. We see evidence of the now familiar pattern in liberal democracies of powerful minority interest groups vetoing or intimidating policy makers. In this case the political power of homosexual groups and so-called progressive opinion makers in our community has prevented parliaments and governments from even speaking the truth about the centrality of promiscuity and homosexuality in spreading death.

It has been the blurring of the truth, the watering down of what we say to our young people and ourselves about sexuality, about human relations, about love, about self-control, about human nature and about God, that has produced the obviously weak and self-indulging AIDS policies and laws that we have put in place. When we take the lead in speaking the truth about promiscuity, drug self-abuse and sodomy, and when we place ourselves under the authority of what is right, then we will be able to equip our children and young people to move from technical knowledge of their bodies to the wisdom and prudence which enables judgment. Then we will be fulfilling the high duty to the public good which so often goes unfulfilled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: --In addressing the estimates for the Department of Veterans' Affairs, I point out to the Committee that in Australia today there are approximately 625,000 surviving veterans from the various wars, conflicts and campaigns involving our nation, including World War I, World War II, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam, and other overseas roles. Together with other ex-service personnel and all surviving war widows, the ex-service and related community numbers about one million people. Significantly, the average age of the biggest single group, that is, the World War II veterans, now exceeds 70 years. Many of these veterans are reaching a critical phase of their lives when various medical services are in heavy demand.

SPEECH.PARA: To give some indication of the magnitude of this nation's commitment to its veterans, the Department of Veterans' Affairs will expend over $5 billion in the coming year, employ about 13,000 staff and provide about 625,000 veterans with some form of benefit. About $2.9m has been provided in the 1991-92 Budget for the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Despite the size of those figures, it is regrettably true that throughout the eight years of this Labor Government there has been a progressive whittling away of veterans' entitlements. What this nation must never lose sight of is our commitment to the veterans, and to the disabled veteran in particular, for the debt owed by a grateful nation to those who fought for this country in time of war.

In meeting that commitment the Government seems all too often to forget two fundamental features of that responsibility. Firstly, veterans' benefits and care must be based on the principle of compensation, not welfare. Secondly, the elderly generally, and especially the ageing veteran population, should not be subject to unnecessary or uncertain changes that are alarming and unsettling. Unfortunately, the Government has not always acted with this in mind. Consider, for example, its approach to the proposed transfer of repatriation general hospitals to the State health system; or the application of the assets test to veterans' service pensions from 1985 onwards and the resulting pension reductions or cancellations for over 13,000 veterans; or limitations imposed on the dental scheme; or totally and permanently incapacitated pension criteria being tightened, with the result that many veterans are no longer eligible for that special assistance; or the deferment of CPI-related increases to pensions; or the provision for the Government to claim from private health funds the cost of veterans hospital and medical treatment where a veteran has private insurance; or indeed a number of restrictions affecting access to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

The most recent changes to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme occurred in the 1991 Budget and could be described only as niggling in the extreme. The Government has announced that from 1 January 1992 personal treatment entitlement card holders, that is, the yellow card holders, and specific treatment entitlement card holders, the white card holders, will be required to pay a patient contribution charge of $2.60 per prescription. Veterans will be compensated by the payment of a fortnightly pharmaceutical allowance of $5.20, together with the provision of a safety net of $135 to protect the chronically ill.

I appreciate that this allowance and safety net will operate in such a way that a veteran will be fully compensated over the year for all the patient contribution charges a patient must meet from his or her own pocket, but the key words are `over the year'. What this change means in practice is that a veteran whose need for medicines exceeds one script per week, and most of them are in this category, will be out of pocket by up to $135 and that he or she will be progressively repaid that amount over the year as the fortnightly allowance is received.

It is true that under this scheme it will be possible for some veterans who need fewer than 52 scripts per year to come out in front. But a pharmaceutical benefits scheme for veterans should be all about helping those people with very heavy pharmaceutical needs, such as the TPIs. What on earth is this Government up to in insisting that veterans who do need more than 52 scripts per year must pay for their scripts up front and then wait up to 12 months before they are fully compensated?
