This Government has created the principle that the more severe the prescription needs of the veteran, the sooner he or she will be out of pocket to the tune of $135 and the longer he or she must wait for compensation. In other words, the person who in all likelihood is least able to cope with the inconvenience and stress of any additional financial drain will be the very person who has to find up to $135.

I believe that the majority of Australians recognise the need for a strong commitment to the veteran community, and to the disabled veteran in particular. I must say that this is one of the worst examples of unfeeling bureaucratic petty-mindedness that I can recall, and it should be withdrawn immediately. Veterans in particular do not deserve such mindlessness. They are entitled to the greatest understanding, recognition and support any government can afford, and I am confident that most Australians would agree with me when I say that it is shabby treatment in the extreme for this Government to be insisting that totally and permanently incapacitated veterans have to pay for their medicines up front, and from an already tightly stretched and barely adequate pension.

Having said that about veterans, I turn to the health aspects of the Estimates debate to speak briefly about the Disability Services Act 1986, which was an historic and important step in the process of integrating Australians with disabilities into the general community. In particular the Act provided a framework for developing a range of support services in the areas of employment, rehabilitation and accommodation. It was supported by the Opposition and came into effect on 1 July 1987. Its provisions were to be implemented over a five-year period to June 1992.

The Government undertook to consult regularly over this transitional period with the providers of disability services, but I am receiving increasing evidence of widespread dissatisfaction with both the consultation process and the way in which the transitional period is being administered. I am also aware that the Opposition spokesman on community services is sufficiently alarmed about this process to have tabled a private member's Bill seeking amendments to a number of areas of concern and for an extension to the transitional period from 1992 to 1995.

An area of particular concern to a number of constituents, and to me, is the manner in which the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) is administering changes to sheltered workshops. The Minister is insisting that people with disabilities must be integrated into the work force, regardless of whether they wish to or, more importantly, can be placed in open employment. Similarly, the Minister and his Department have apparently indicated to service managers that all existing workshops, regardless of the excellence of their existing standards, must reprofile if government funding is to continue after June 1992. The operative word is `indicated' because, four years into the transitional period and only eight months before it is to be completed, managements of sheltered workshops have had no official advice as to the guidelines they will have to meet to satisfy ongoing profiling and financial requirements. Is it any wonder that this uncertainty is desperately worrying the parents and carers of disabled people who are presently placed in a sheltered workshop.

To further aggravate this unsatisfactory situation, the Government gave a commitment that no service will be closed during the transitional period, yet it is cutting back on funding to an extent that it is jeopardising the viability of many services and may well cause some to close before June 1992. Four years into the Disability Services Act the parents and carers of disabled people have a right to some certainty as to the future of sheltered workshops and the people who work in them. Instead, this uncertainty is inevitably causing growing alarm amongst a group of people who already carry an enormous load as carers for disabled people.

If the Government is proposing to continue to support sheltered workshops, I suggest that full funding should be restored on the basis of existing minimum standards; that the new eligibility profiles should be decided upon in consultation with the industry; that special attention should be given to those people with disabilities of a nature that will make integration very difficult or even impossible; and that workshops be given at least three years in which to meet those new guidelines. However, if the Government's real intention is to close down existing workshops in favour of some form of open, commercially viable organisation, it must be prepared to accept responsibility for a decision that will cause the most distressing trauma for the many disabled who are simply unable to make that step.

I should declare a special interest in this area. I have a disabled son. He is a person who is unable to meet the requirements of the disabled workshop under the present circumstances and yet, because of this present situation, he is unable to be trained to meet those requirements. He is one of those unfortunate people who fall between two criteria--too good for the nursing home situation but not good enough for the sheltered workshop. This is a very great area of concern for an enormous number of people, and the Government should address it as a matter of the greatest urgency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-One of the many great achievements of the Hawke maladministration has been to send women back into the work force in unprecedented numbers to help offset the crippling effects of high interest rates on their families. High interest rates meant hikes in mortgage rates and repayments that demanded the return of mothers, often with babes in arms, back into the workplace. This has resulted in huge new pressures on child-care centres for extra places. The recession has now turned around that demand in pockets of urban and rural Victoria and elsewhere throughout the country. If the baby has not been thrown out with the bath water, in this case the Government has at least let out the bath water.

SPEECH.PARA: In areas of the greatest unemployment, particularly in the industrial heartlands of the northern, western and north-western suburbs of Melbourne, child-care centres today are struggling to survive because unemployed and underemployed people cannot afford these services. Two centres have closed and others are on shaky ground. In order to survive, the centres have had to top up their operations with the children of non-working parents who need respite from the rigours of coping with children. Now their continued viability is in doubt and general access to child-care places has been reduced by the changes in government funding sneaked in with this Budget. While putting up new centres, the Government is, with its usual sleight of hand, reducing the affordability of the existing places. The message of the Government to the centres whose budgets are severely out of whack because of this Government-led recession is that they must wear it. This means that these centres have to put up fees and more parents are unable to afford to use them, thus creating a vicious cycle.

To this situation the Government has added a new two-tiered apartheid system of fee subsidies for all child-care services. Until now, access to fee relief was based solely on inability to pay, which was fair as far as it went. But from 1 January next year people are to be discriminated against in terms of fee relief on the basis of their reasons for wanting child-care--echoes of the old socialist credo: `The end justifies the means'. This means that those who use the centres for certified work-related activities get the top level of relief, but those who are not working, are not registered with the CES, are not on a disability pension or do not have a child on a disability pension will receive only the lower level of fee relief. This discriminates against parents who are at home and need occasional respite from children, against parents who are enrolled in what are deemed non-vocational courses, against parents who have ceased to look for work because none is available, and against parents who have children with developmental problems.

The new apartheid of assistance takes into account none of the permutations of real life; everything is either black or white. The difference in the two tiers is about $8 a day, or $40 a week--a not inconsiderable amount for people already suffering the worst depression since the 1930s. Typically, these changes are testimony to the Labor Party's ongoing love affair with shuffling papers. The corollary of this new apartheid system is the expansion of the Department of Social Security administrative apparatus to assess whether a child is at risk--a field in which it has absolutely no expertise. This will demand that people then label themselves in order to receive the benefits--benefits that the experts say are unlikely to occur anyway.

Then there is the matter of assessing whether people--almost invariably women, who are the major caretakers of children--are doing courses likely to lead to work. The nexus between work and the preparation for it is not as straightforward as this policy suggests. In fact, women do courses--in their neighbourhood houses or wherever else--to get back their confidence to go to or even apply for work. Yet these niggardly prescriptions which have been introduced in this Budget will preclude many of these women from the so-called non-vocational courses. At the level of the child-care centres themselves, the chairperson of community child-care in Victoria suggests that the increasing administrative demands of the ever-burgeoning bureaucracy which this Government is imposing will increase the charges on the hapless parents to whom they are passed on because of this policy.

The Government's Alice in Wonderland version of social equity is to be found in its slashing of support for out of school programs, which care for children either before or after school on a permanent or temporary basis. This service, which is run from neighbourhood houses, schools, churches and the YWCA, is the fastest growing area of all child-care. There are some 22,000 places in out of school programs in Victoria and 80,600 throughout Australia. Any one place may be taken up by as many as three children during the course of a week. The total number of child-care places in Australia is some 255,000. So the out of school care sector makes up about one-third of the total of child-care places and it is the fastest increasing area in which these services are provided.

The Budget made noises about bringing the service into line with other child-care services, which gave the unwary out of school coordinators a warm, fuzzy feeling of good about this Government. To their horror, in the last couple of weeks it has transpired that the details of this plan, which were written in invisible ink in the Budget Papers, meant a cut of 50 per cent in the operational subsidy provided by the Government. The operational subsidy for these services has been slashed from $9,828 to $5,292 for each school program from 1 January next year. In hourly terms this is a reduction from 54c to 28c an hour. The other child-care services receive less funding because their longer hours bring in fees of commensurate size.

To add insult to injury, those using the out of school program can receive only the second tier of funding relief, a logical inconsistency and nonsense in itself because these are parents who are going to work and, therefore, using the child-care places. We are talking about a difference in fee relief of $2 on the top tier and about $1.15 on the second tier subsidy. The Government's excuse that these programs do not cost as much is a chimera because the costs are hidden in subsidies by local schools and by local government.

Increased administration necessitates one of the two out of school program workers actually having to use some of his or her valuable time on the administration of the program. As usual, the Government cannot see the wood for the forms to be filled in. While the Government can say that it has increased fee relief and that now people on combined incomes of up to $46,000 get some relief, the reality is that this is only a drop in the ocean of higher costs and higher fees. By reducing the affordability of out of school care we are now creating a new generation of latchkey children. Is this social justice?

The provision of affordable child-care is essential if we are to facilitate people getting back to work, but what we have now is the worst of two possible worlds. As more and more people are unable to use child-care services, or to use them as often, fees escalate to cover the cost of the child-care services and the difference between operating costs and the government subsidy increases.

A gap fee--which, on average, is from $25 to $30, but can be up to $45--is charged on top of the fees which are subsidised for the parents and on top of what is based on the parents' income. The gap fee goes to the heart of the affordability problem and, because it is non-variable, has a greater impact on lower income families. Anyone whose income is $22,000 can now get full fee relief. But from 1 January next year they will pay an additional $30 on their assessed fee, on top of an ever-increasing gap fee, if they do not fall into the tier one category. Yet this Government is throwing money at new child-care Taj Mahals while the sound of childish chatter and the patter of little feet grows ever dimmer in the existing centres which are being deserted by economically stressed parents. In the meantime, Labor's Tweedledum and Tweedledee go on fighting over the leadership rattle. The Government has surely thrown the baby out with the bath water. (Time expired)
Proposed expenditures agreed to.
Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade
Proposed expenditure, $1,554,597,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In speaking to the estimates of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, I wish to address my comments to an area of expenditure relating to a major foreign affairs issue facing Australia at this time. In the space of 10 minutes, it is very difficult to address all of the complexities and difficulties that arise in the area of foreign affairs and all of the issues that one would like to refer to. Having spoken this morning about the problems arising from the disintegration of the Soviet Union, this evening I wish to comment on the issues now facing us in Yugoslavia.

SPEECH.PARA: The international community has faced many such challenges in recent times. There is a growing desire for self-determination by many individuals in states that have previously been trapped within the boundaries of imperial structures. Within these newly independent states are several ethnic minorities, each of which is anxious to regain and assert its cultural and religious heritage. We are grappling with these problems with the present disintegration of Yugoslavia. The tragic civil war that we are now seeing is a result of a failure of the newly emerging independent components to negotiate the terms of new political and economic arrangements.

This issue is of great concern to many people in this country. The census records that in 1986 there were 150,000 Yugoslavian born people in Australia. Of this number, 82,546 record Yugoslavian ancestry; 27,265 Croatian ancestry; 5,936 Serbian ancestry; 3,605 Slovenian ancestry; and about 20,800 Macedonian ancestry. All of these groups have some real concerns about the events that are unfolding in the Balkans at this time.

Undoubtedly, some families have experienced the tragic loss of a loved one and many more are still anxious for the safety of family members and friends caught in the conflict. Families are turning in desperation to the Government for some hope and constructive support which will lead to a swift conclusion of this terrible situation.

However, what the Government has offered is very short of even simple consolation. On the other hand, the Opposition has been constructively participating in and leading debate and it is pushing the Government to take some initiatives. It has urged the Government to protest in the strongest possible terms to the Yugoslavian Government. And, of course, the Opposition has called for intervention internationally, including the involvement of the United Nations.

Honourable members will recall that the current crisis followed on the heels of events which had given us some real cause for optimism. A week or so before the Yugoslavian army launched a military attack in Slovenia, Presidents of the six republics reached an agreement in principle which would allow for a loose confederation to provide for a common army, foreign policy and economy. At the same time, each republic would have its own army, diplomatic missions and United Nations membership. My colleague Senator Hill expressed the hopes of many of us when he said:
Agreement to consider this plan as a basis for negotiation shows that a solution to the problem of reforming Yugoslavia can be achieved peacefully.

On 26 June, representatives of both Croatia and Slovenia declared independence from Yugoslavia after a plebiscite expressed an overwhelming majority vote for independence. These declarations were seen as an important step in the process of resolving constitutional problems which were facing the region. However, as I noted in the House earlier today when speaking on the motion in relation to the Soviet Union, the democratic impulse can be so easily undermined and our optimism short-lived if we do not face squarely the realities of these very volatile times.

On 28 June--the day of the Yugoslav invasion--the Opposition condemned the use of military force and called for immediate dialogue between the parties. In August, as acting Foreign Affairs spokesmen for the Opposition, I urged the Australian Government to support the mission by three European Community foreign Ministers to try to negotiate a cease-fire. On 6 August, I condemned the Government's inactivity and urged it to back a role for the United Nations in mediating a, by then, escalating conflict.

On 16 August, Senator Hill had returned and urged the Australian Government to recall its Ambassador to Yugoslavia for talks. He moved in the Senate a motion deploring the violence which had taken place in Slovenia and Croatia and called on the Government, again, to support international efforts for a negotiated settlement. The Australian Government offered some pious platitudes but had taken no real initiatives to support the peaceful transition to the establish the of new independent states.

Unbelievably, the Government opposed this motion of Senator Hill's in the other place after changing its mind several times. This clearly demonstrated the indifference to the deep concern expressed in Australia by those of Balkan origin. The motion was finally passed with the support of Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine.

On 26 August, Senator Hill again called on the Government to seek action in the international community to negotiate a withdrawal of the Yugoslav federal army from Croatia and to urge the United Nations Security Council to step in to avert this disaster. The Opposition also urged the Government to press for the International Red Cross to be permitted to help refugees from its headquarters in Geneva, rather than in Belgrade. Clearly, it is unlikely that the Croatian refugees or asylum seekers would be able to travel with impunity to Belgrade to ask for asylum.

We also called for the Australian Government to give relief via the International Committee of the Red Cross. A week later, the Government acceded and announced $100,000 in relief. A further $100,000 has been announced in the last day or so.

The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) urged the Government to provide humanitarian support directly in the form of urgently needed medical requirements and the provision on consular support in Zagreb so that people of Croatian origin seeking visas would no longer need to apply through Belgrade. We urged the Government to support the European Community proposal for a peace conference. The inactivity and indifference of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) on this issue forced the Opposition to approach the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to actively support the European Community's proposals.

When the first cease-fire was breached late in August, the Opposition again approached the Government to end its inactivity on the crisis and lodge an immediate protest with Belgrade. Still no action was taken. Even the Opposition's suggestion to back UN involvement and the Prime Minister's indication on a national television program that he would pursue the matter was not followed by positive government action.

While the Government has remained quiet, the crisis has deepened and there has been a tragic escalation with the loss of life and an increased possibility that the conflict could spread beyond Yugoslavia. My colleague, the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), moved in the House a motion on my behalf two or three weeks ago deploring the violence, loss of life and destruction of property in Slovenia and Croatia. In the last few days we have seen the very tragic loss of some of the most historic and important national estate properties on the Adriatic coast. The honourable member noted the potential for further conflict if the aspiration for self-determination was confronted by military force.

We welcomed the efforts of the European Community to act as a mediator and again called upon the Government to support international efforts for a negotiated solution which might achieve independence for the Slovenian and Croatian people. We demanded protection of ethnic and religious minorities within all of the republics of Yugoslavia. This is a matter of very considerable concern. We repeated our call for the Australian Government to recall its Ambassador. However, this and statements by the Chairman of the Yugoslav Presidency, Mr Mesic, which indicated that the Yugoslav forces were not under constitutional control, still failed to elicit a positive response from the Government. The Prime Minister's response to the clear and immediate concerns of the Opposition was that the Australian Ambassador to the UN was keeping abreast of developments.

Throughout this entire crisis, the Opposition has been actively and constructively involved in trying to find an appropriate solution to the complex and difficult problems in Yugoslavia. As late as Tuesday, we again had to push the Government to consider taking action in the United Nations to seek sanctions and an oil embargo on Yugoslavia. Even in relation to that matter, Senator Evans has, to date, refused to commit the Government to this action. As Senator Hill has said:

At a time when all vestiges of constitutional authority have broken down and the Croatian capital of Zagreb is being pounded by Yugoslav forces, it is simply not good enough to say that Australia is still thinking about action in the UN.
For the sake of those suffering from the appalling violence being perpetrated in Croatia, Australia should move now.

I wholeheartedly support those sentiments and I imagine that all honourable members, as they are conscious of the meetings and discussions that will be taking place throughout Australia, appreciate the concern of those who live within this country who are aware of the difficulties and who want to seek the good offices of Australia in trying to mediate successfully to ensure a peaceful and sensible outcome to this very difficult situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am pleased to speak in the committee stage of this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) dealing with appropriations for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I sometimes wonder, when we are talking about foreign affairs, about our diplomatic missions abroad. I note in recent days that there has been some discussion about some of our missions and talk of the closure of some. I wonder whether it is always necessary to have such large missions and so many Australian based staff in some of our missions instead of perhaps missions of two and three people. I am particularly concerned that we no longer have a mission in Ethiopia. I believe it is very important that we reopen our mission in Addis Ababa. In fact, I thought it was a tragedy that that was closed, and I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to look carefully again at the reopening of the mission in Addis Ababa.

SPEECH.PARA: The past 12 months have seen dramatic changes in the international community. Events in eastern Europe have changed the political map. Indeed, who could have imagined the changed situation that we see today in the Soviet Union or indeed, as the previous speaker mentioned, the tragedy that is Yugoslavia today.

Equally dramatic but perhaps more inevitable have been the changes in South Africa. No longer do black and white live as total strangers in the same land; but they are still strangers. I fully support the approach that Australia is taking in regard to South Africa. We should not rush to lift economic sanctions, but I believe it is appropriate for a relaxation of the bans on person to person contact. Sanctions have had an impact. Those who for years opposed sanctions and were apologists for the apartheid regime in South Africa should ask themselves this question: without sanctions would the majority of South Africans have ever had the opportunity, as now promised if as yet undelivered, of being fully participating members in the country of their birth?

Those who were among the last to impose sanctions were among the first to lift them. This must raise the question of how genuine was their commitment to the process. One does not have to be unduly cynical to suspect that many governments have been more interested in dollars than in the well-being of the black South African population.

South Africa will need help in the years ahead. The need to rebuild the economy is shown by the fact that over the next 30 years the population of South Africa will double. By the year 2020 the population will reach 80 million. This will cause tremendous challenges and a huge expenditure on health, housing, welfare and education. Of all the education programs, perhaps family planning is the most important.

The next few years will be a testing time for South Africa, but one suspects that it will be many years before the black majority really enjoy the benefits of what could be one of the most prosperous nations on earth for all its inhabitants.

On the other hand, South Africa has the opportunity to show the world that a truly multicultural, multiracial, democratic society can exist and prosper. The knowledge of many Solomons will be needed to work out which way South Africa will go. The task ahead of South Africa is awesome. The legacy of apartheid, in social and economic as well as political terms, is appalling. Those contemplating the future of South Africa through the current period of change and beyond might be forgiven a degree of pessimism. Yet the very enormity of those difficulties has forced South Africans of all races to contemplate fundamental adjustments to entrenched positions on political and economic issues. There is justification for optimism in this evidence of flexibility. We must look forward keenly to the time when that flexibility provides justification for the removal of sanctions and the integration of a multiracial South Africa into the international community.

Another area of concern to Australia is Papua New Guinea. Australia has a significant role to play with the people of that country, not in a neocolonial way but in a helping way, respecting the sovereign independence of Papua New Guinea. We make a significant contribution through aid to Papua New Guinea. Questions have been raised about our aid. Many suggest that the greater proportion should be tied aid--aid for projects rather than as now happens with untied or Budget supported aid.

One of the great challenges for Papua New Guinea is education. Through our aid, Australia can be of great assistance. Papua New Guinea is still retarded in implementing many of its plans for development by its lack of trained people. Another area of concern is law and order. Perhaps more of our aid could be directed towards training and equipping the Papua New Guinea police.

Despite its many problems, everyone should be heartened by the obvious strength of Papua New Guinea's democracy as shown in the recent constitutional crisis. It must be stated that democracy has remained strong since independence. Changes to government have always been made in a constitutional way. In the area of international relationships, I would like to see more emphasis on our relationship with India. Many people, including me, have felt that the relationship between Australia and India has not developed as dynamically and robustly as it could have. Perhaps we have taken each other for granted too much. I believe that we must work harder for a better relationship between India and Australia. We mean more to each other than competitors on the cricket field. More attention to this important relationship will bring political and economic rewards to both countries.

Australia has been a world leader in protecting Antarctica. Last week in Spain Australia and 38 other nations signed an agreement that will guarantee protection of, and ban mining and oil exploration on, the Antarctic continent for 50 years. I applaud Australia's efforts in protecting Antarctica for future generations.

Australia has just taken its most significant and effective step for 16 years to promote human rights in Australia, in our region and in the world. On 30 September 1975 Australia ratified the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination, which was opened for signature on 21 December 1965 and entered into force on 2 January 1969. The Racial Discrimination Act of 1975 had given approval for ratification and made the provisions of the convention part of the law of Australia.

On 25 September 1991 Australia acceded to the first optional protocol to the 1966 International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Those within Australia aggrieved by a breach of human rights are now entitled to communicate with the Human Rights Committee which was established 15 years ago. As one who has spoken on this matter many times and who has put many questions on the Notice Paper since 1985, I applaud this highly significant step by the Hawke Labor Government. I also believe that there should be no further delay in Australia's making a declaration under article 14 of the racial discrimination convention, recognising the competence of the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination to receive communications against a state party by individuals or groups of individuals within its jurisdiction.
History shows that the Aborigines sorely need an international forum in which to address their grievances, for which they have exhausted all domestic remedies.

I also welcome the latest increase in the Budget of the contribution to overseas aid. I am appalled by comments made by both the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) that overseas aid would be cut if they came to government. But I suppose we can console ourselves that it is most unlikely that they will come to government. Nevertheless, they have made this commitment that one of the first areas that would be cut under a conservative government in Australia would be overseas aid.

Australia cannot isolate itself from the rest of the world. Not only do we have a duty to assist people who do not always enjoy a similar degree of wealth or standard of living to ours; in the long term it makes good economic sense to assist those people. I am just appalled that the Opposition would target overseas aid as one of the areas it would cut in the unlikely event that it came to government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: --The ministerial statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in the Senate on 6 December 1989 referred to the rapid and fundamental changes then taking place in central Europe and the USSR and offered a timely consideration of their impact on Australia's national interests. In view of the quite incredible rate and nature of those changes and their implications for Australia's sphere of interest, I think it is an appropriate time to review that statement and to assess the Government's success or otherwise in meeting Australia's foreign policy objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: I have little disagreement with much of the statement's conclusions as to the strategic importance to Australia of South East Asia and the South Pacific and of the uncertainties created by the passing of the bipolar Cold War era. Senator Evans responds to that challenge by identifying seven objectives which constitute what he calls Australia's multidimensional approach to regional security.

The first and second of those objectives relate to military capacity and application; the third to the use of traditional diplomacy; the fourth to trade and investment; the fifth to foreign aid; the sixth to so-called neighbourly assistance; and the seventh to what I would describe as a call to close the cultural distance and, in the words of the Foreign Minister, `to overcome the significant image problem we still tend to have in South East Asia and the South Pacific'.

My concern with Senator Evans's multidimensional approach is fourfold. First, he acknowledges the importance of traditional diplomatic skills and says that his statement `carries some important implications for departmental resources'. Those implications are not discussed in the document; nor are they mentioned in the Department's annual report for 1989-90, which talks only of a new corporate plan and evaluation procedures. However, from a departmental discussion paper released earlier this year and from recent press reports of the closure and pending closure of several missions and of a commitment to new missions in Cambodia, Europe and the Middle East, we must assume that these are the implications referred to in the Minister's 1989 statement.

The reality is that it has taken almost two years to see any evidence of a tangible response to the new international circumstances. I must say that this falls disappointingly short of the urgency warranted by events in central Europe, by their implications for the Australasian region, and by the importance given to them by the Minister in December 1989. Furthermore, from the 2.2 per cent increase in the Department's division 315 funding for 1991-92, which in fact is a drop in real terms, it is clear that the Department is being asked to respond to the most important diplomatic challenges for the past 50 years with fewer resources. From the little we know of the redirection of resources taking place within the Department, I must admit also to some doubts as to whether this is a sufficient response to the new world order, whatever that really means, and its implications for our region.

My second concern is that Senator Evans's statement fails to identify properly one of the most significant elements needed for the successful achievement of our foreign policy objectives. Third, the seven multidimensional objectives are offered without any discussion as to their relative importance or priority. My fourth concern centres around the conclusion that must be drawn from an analysis of Australia's foreign policy track record in recent times.

Returning to that second concern, it seems to me that a particularly important objective of foreign affairs must be the achievement and maintenance of highly developed relations with and expertise in the affairs of our South East Asian and South Pacific neighbours. The key words I stress are `highly developed' and `expertise'. That objective is not acknowledged by Senator Evans, yet it seems unarguable to me that if we have soundly and sensitively developed relations with our neighbours then other objectives such as military cooperation, the diplomatic management of tensions and misunderstandings, trade, investment and aid considerations and cultural ties all become more amenable to mutually beneficial solutions.

This can be extended into the third area of my concern, that is, Senator Evans's failure to consider priorities. I suggested in what I have just said that the establishment of highly developed relations is a matter of the highest priority. Senator Evans gives this only an oblique mention in his multidimensional objectives, at points 3 and 7. In point 3 he talks about the use of traditional diplomatic skills. He clearly considers this to be a tool to be applied in the limited and negative role of managing tensions and frictions. In fact, I see it in the reverse role. I see it as a positive role, a role which allows us to develop to a very high order an expertise in and understanding of the nations of our region and to use those skills in building relations that directly and positively contribute to our national interest.

Senator Evans also vaguely touches on this same subject in his point 7 when he talks of cultural ties. Here an even more serious criticism must be made of the ministerial statement, for it is in regard to this last point, and only after acknowledging the need to close cultural distances with our neighbours, that Senator Evans makes his damaging admission that Australia still has a significant image problem in the region. I join with others when I say that honesty must always be admired; but does the Foreign Minister not appreciate that after eight years of Labor administration and three years of his own stewardship his comments are in fact an admission of failure?

The Hawke Government has had some notable foreign policy successes, such as its role in Cambodia and the formation of the Cairns Group. However, the past eight years have coincided with, at best, a period of uncertain and unstable relations with much of our region and, at worst, an identifiable erosion of those relations. I believe that there is ample evidence to substantiate those claims. For example, there have been instances of sheer thoughtlessness, such as Senator Evans's insult to the memory of hundreds of young Australians killed in the Vietnam campaign by his wearing a Ho Chi Minh lapel badge during a visit to that country. There was the tactlessness of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in describing the hanging of Barlow and Chambers by the Malaysian Government as a barbaric act.

There are many instances of foreign policy being shaped largely in response to left wing Labor Party pressures, such as the Prime Minister's MX missile backdown and the cool, even non-existent, response to the American SDI program; the one-sided financial assistance to the African National Congress; and the nature of the Government's support for the Fijian trade union movement. There have been errors of judgment such as the sale of jets to Pakistan and the way in which we have managed our overseas aid programs to Papua New Guinea and South Pacific nations.

Those who have an interest in and an appreciation of the importance of foreign affairs will be aware that this is a very modest selection from a wide field of diplomatic mistakes and totally insensitive actions. What they add up to is a sorry story of strained and uncertain relations with Malaysia, Indonesia, South Africa, China, Papua New Guinea, Fiji and a number of other South Pacific nations. We have been gently criticised by Singapore's Lee Kuan Yew, snubbed by the Solomon Island's Prime Minister, bypassed in the Bougainville dispute negotiations, sidelined by the ASEAN group of nations, and had a Foreign Minister told in very forthright terms that he was not welcome in Fiji and publicly humiliated in South Africa and Malaysia. Having taken that into account, Senator Evans is certainly correct in admitting to an image problem in our region.

I believe that a consideration of the above circumstances indicates a worrying pattern of a government that is allowing its political ideology to interfere with Australia's national interests; a misreading of the feelings of neighbouring countries and their leadership; and a personality in our present Foreign Minister which has shown itself to be a complex mixture of intellectualism, naivete and outspokenness. These three influences--party ideology, errors of judgment and personality factors--make for circumstances that are inimical to the need for highly developed expertise in foreign affairs matters.

I suggest that the Foreign Minister has shown a particular lack of judgment in the management of his Ministry, and I mention three specific areas. It was unforgivable that during his recent South African visit he should be so naively partisan as to give direct financial assistance to the African National Congress and then be very surprised at the reaction of the Inkatha Freedom Party. Can honourable members recall any circumstance in living memory in which a Foreign Minister has been so publicly rebuked? In my opinion, the most basic error of judgment made in regard to Senator Evans's trip to South Africa was his decision to undertake a fairly long visit--an eight-day visit. Given the background to our relations and the present circumstances in that country, I believe that a much shorter visit was a diplomatic necessity. I think reference must be made to Senator Evans's obsequious behaviour in Malaysia last year. Such behaviour was not the action of a country that has successfully conducted its foreign relations. Diplomacy is all about avoiding precisely such demeaning behaviour.

Finally, we have our relations with Fiji. This must be close to a textbook case in how not to conduct foreign relations--from our initial lack of intelligence about the Rabuka coup to the confused assessments as to its motives, a suggestion of gunboat diplomacy, the trade union connection, and our downright arrogance over subsequent constitutional developments. Is it any wonder that the Fijian Government has taken the attitude it has? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise to wholeheartedly congratulate the Government for the increase in overseas aid in this Budget. Overseas aid went up by about $54m, a one per cent real increase, at a time when Budget outlays were very severely constrained. That is a very important contribution to reducing poverty in developing countries. As anyone who is concerned about what happens in the rest of the world knows, there has been a very severe depression in much of the developing world throughout the 1980s. So it is essential for anyone concerned about international justice as well as domestic justice to urge governments to do what they can to alleviate that poverty, and this increase in aid will make an important contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: That increase in aid is in sharp contrast to the position of the Opposition. At the time of the last election, the Opposition said that it would cut overseas aid by $200m. Only three weeks ago, in a major statement on foreign policy the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) said:
We believe that in Australia's current economic circumstances there is no responsible alternative to a short-term cut in the level of Australia's foreign aid.

What that means is that, despite the fact that 1,000 million people are living in absolute poverty--meaning that they end every day still hungry--the Opposition would further cut our overseas aid. That would be anathema to anyone with a modicum of a sense of fairness. It emphasises again that the Labor Party is the one party that has consistently worked to ease poverty in the developing world, as it works to ease poverty within Australia. It was the Whitlam Government, for example, that established what is now the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau.

For those of us in the Labor Party concerned with development cooperation, our main focus has been to lift Australia's official development assistance as a proportion of national income. We have been successful in incorporating aid targets into ALP policy. For example, at the National Conference in June, the target of giving 0.7 per cent of our national income to official development assistance was reiterated. We have, I must admit, been less successful in getting those targets translated into reality. But the 1991 Conference did include an interim goal of achieving 0.4 per cent of GNP by 1995. That would be a significant increase on the present level of 0.35 per cent.

It is true--and it is something that I strongly regret--that the ratio of aid to national income has fallen in the last six years. But it would be unfair to place too much of the blame for that on the Labor Government. The reality is that the ratio of aid to national income has been falling since the late 1960s, and the principal reason for that fall has been the declining assistance to Papua New Guinea--which is a welcomed and natural consequence of Papua New Guinea's increasing economic independence.

Viewed in that way, the falling aid to national income ratio is not so much a deliberate and mean spirited cutback as an unwillingness to compensate by more rapidly expanding the non-PNG parts of our aid program. Perhaps we have focused too heavily on an important but simplistic aid to national income target and not enough on arguing for increased aid for specific purposes. Perhaps we have spent too much effort in criticising parts of the aid program and too little in seeking to expand those areas that are most developmentally beneficial.

The motion that went through the Labor Party Conference in June had as it emphasis development cooperation which focuses on the most vulnerable people, increasing the focus on eliminating poverty and making a substantial contribution to the life chances of the billion people who live in absolute poverty. That focus on poverty is the basis of our struggle for a larger and better Australian aid program, but to achieve that goal we need to argue for high priority projects which the aid program can concentrate on.

Existing aid programs are partly protected by precedent and vested interest. It is the new programs--the initiatives--that require our strongest support. These are also the best means for increasing the total aid to GNP ratio. The environmental groups, with support from others, have successfully applied this principle. Much of the 1991-92 aid increase comes from an $80m--over four years--environmental assistance program, which itself is a quadrupling of a 1989 initiative. Similarly, there is an increase in this aid budget for spending on population programs. That must be one of the highest priority areas for increased support, because those programs will enable developing countries which want additional funds for their population programs to increase their effectiveness so as to reduce their population growth rates. And the reduction of population growth rates is one of the principal requirements for both economic development and protection of the environment.

Other major increases in the 1991-92 Budget are 10 per cent increases in funding for both non-government organisations and for the Development Import Finance Facility. Those programs are strongly supported by community groups and by business, demonstrating that the Government is willing to act on pressure from outside the portals of government. The Development Import Finance Facility exemplifies well the efficacy of calling for specific projects. DIFF projects are proposed by Australian businesses seeking finance for developmentally sound projects overseas, and there are many more projects proposed than can be funded. This backlog provides a continuous pressure on the Government to increase funding. Non-government organisations would find much community support if they spoke about poverty projects being delayed by a lack of funding. Precious public attention might be better directed to this more positive criticism than to the unfortunate but inevitable failings in funding our total aid program.

We should be preparing funding increase requests for specific and realistic projects which meet our poverty alleviation objectives. More basic preventative health projects, primary and vocational education projects, revolving credit schemes and so on will not naturally grow out of AIDAB as it is currently structured. It is up to the supporters of poverty alleviation to propose and advocate those sorts of projects with the Ministers responsible.

Our emphasis on poverty alleviation has been central to our success in convincing the Government to renew funding for the International Fund for Agricultural Development. Also in this Budget, Australia has rejoined the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation, meaning that we are now a member of all the UN agencies and that we can contribute through that particular agency to the process of industrialisation within developing countries.

To conclude, I reiterate that anyone who is concerned about poverty alleviation overseas, as with poverty alleviation in Australia, should realise that it is the Labor Government that is in the position most effectively to implement programs of that type. It is quite clear that the Opposition has lost its way and its sense of compassion, and that it is now advocating cuts in the aid program beyond those which have already occurred. At the same time, the Labor Government is substantially increasing in real terms its allocation to poverty alleviating aid programs. I commend and praise the Government for that decision, and I hope that the Opposition will reconsider its position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish first to take up a point made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), on the issue of aid. I am disappointed not only by the honourable member for Fraser but generally by this debate about assistance to developing countries because so much of the debate is about aid and so little of it is about trade. There is no doubt that the best way to help the vast majority of developing countries is by giving them greater access to the markets of developed countries and, in particular, markets in the European Community and the United States and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that if one is going to claim to be the most compassionate person, which seems to be a game this Parliament plays these days, the best way one can be compassionate and helpful towards people living in developing countries is to ensure that markets in developed countries are properly open to them. I speak with real experience, having worked in the north and south unit of the Department of Foreign Affairs for some time and having seen all sorts of programs of the kind that the honourable member for Fraser so passionately advocates--a little bit here and a little bit there. In terms of the totality of the need in developing countries, trade can do so much more for them than aid ever will be able to do.

To carry on with that theme, though, the burden of my remarks tonight was going to rest on trade because I have noticed in this debate, as is so often the case, when one talks about the portfolio of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade it is interesting that people say so little about trade and talk inevitably about the perhaps more high profile and politically exciting foreign affairs issues. But I must say, without wishing to criticise other speakers, that I think the trade function of that department is a vastly important function, particularly at a time when our economy is simply on its knees.

This year is the first year that Austrade will ever have come under the auspices of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade--and I welcome that change. I have always thought it was logical for Austrade to be a part of or come under the auspices of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. It has been an anomaly since 1986 that it has somehow found itself under the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, despite the pleadings of Senator Evans and clearly following, initially, the Cabinet victory for Senator Button.

Senator Button's tutelage of Austrade, though, has not been a happy one. His period as the Minister responsible for it was one of benign negligence. I hope very much his successors as Ministers responsible for Austrade, in particular the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Mr Blewett), will show a greater interest in the activities of that organisation and ensure that it changes for the better.

Austrade is undergoing at present a process of very significant change as a result of the McKinsey and Co. report. It remains to be seen how successful the implementation of that change is really going to be. One of the concerns I had about the McKinsey report was not the work done, but the fact that the terms of reference did not take into account the need to at least give consideration to redesigning the charter and long term strategy of Austrade. It is worth reflecting that McKinsey has made precisely that point in the report on Austrade that it gave to the Government.

So the McKinsey report was limited by its terms of reference and, as a result of it, there have been substantial changes within Austrade, including in personnel. Mr Ralph Evans is now the Managing Director and I wish him well in his work. I have every confidence he will do a competent job within the confines in which he has to operate. However, there is no doubt whatsoever that the recent debate in the community about Austrade--in the business community, the media and, to some extent, in this Parliament as well--has been brought about by a lot of concern that one hears from the business community about all over Australia about the historic performance of Austrade and the trade commissioner service.

There are two aspects to that. Firstly, there is its past administration, happily is undergoing change now; and, secondly, the actual effectiveness of the organisation. I do not want to dwell too much tonight on the past administration, except to say that my mailbox has been full day after day with anonymous letters from officers of Austrade providing more and more information on goings-on within Austrade. I must say that, whatever one may think about the information--which has all turned out, I must say, to be entirely accurate--it does reflect a lack of morale in an organisation when its officers feel that they really want to show up maladministration that has taken place over recent years. I am happy to accommodate them in doing that, particularly as an awful lot of taxpayers' money has been involved. Some of it, without any doubt, has been squandered in ways that I could only describe as quite extraordinary. There is more to come on that, but I will not talk about it tonight.

However--and this will be where the burden of my remarks rest tonight--one has to ask about the effectiveness of Austrade. The McKinsey report made a range of criticisms about it: that it needed to adopt a more market driven approach; that it needed to push more resources and responsibility into the field and away from the head office; and that the international and domestic network had to be revitalised and re-engineered to improve service delivery--and so the list goes on. I will not go right through that list, but I think those criticisms and some of those sorts of recommendations were really motherhood recommendations.

I do not think anyone would disagree with the recommendations of the McKinsey report. I would only say that they were not as specific as I would really have liked. It explained what would be nice, new, fresh objectives for Austrade, but did not outline in detail how they could be achieved. In fact, if we look at both volumes of the McKinsey report, they are surprisingly slim. So the challenge is how to achieve the sorts of changes that McKinsey has recommended. I want to make four points about that.

Firstly, is Austrade going to be an organisation which will pick winners? Is it going to be an organisation which will help what McKinsey has described as `high potential clients'; and, if it is going to do that, how is it going to do it? Of course, it is axiomatic to say that we would like to feel that, if Austrade is to continue to exist--and I believe it should--it must help high potential clients. It is easy to say that, but who are the high potential clients? How will we ever find them? Within Austrade over many years there has been a debate as to whether it should help big business, medium sized business or small business--and I do not think that debate has been resolved satisfactorily.

There is one conundrum that Austrade has to face: should it help firms that are already efficient and proven operators in export markets, or should it just help people who really desperately need help and are not doing very well? The fact is that, if people are efficient in export markets, it is questionable that they need help: if they are not and they show themselves to be struggling overseas, perhaps help is going to be a waste of money. It is a conundrum and one which Austrade has yet to find a simple way of resolving. One of the solutions is clearly to commercialise the organisation and to charge firms--and of course there is a system of charging already--on a more commercial basis for the services provided. One of the responses we get from the business community to that proposal is: why should they pay for a service which is of such poor quality? The answer to that is that, if the service were of high quality, if it were a commercial service, commercially oriented, I am sure the business community would be happy to pay a higher charge than is currently the case.

Secondly, Austrade needs to be better integrated with the business community, with business associations, business organisations and individual firms. I do think that it needs to demonstrate very clearly how it is linking directly with business associations and, in particular, using those associations with its extensive membership as a conduit for market intelligence collected by Austrade.

Thirdly, I do think that the smaller firms are the ones who need marketing assistance overseas. The South African Foreign Trade Organisation serves as a very good example of how that can happen. Firms go to SAFTO, they buy marketing services there at a commercial rate, and the marketing is handled on their behalf by SAFTO. It is a system that works very well and I would like Austrade to have a look at that.

Fourthly and finally, the trade commissioners themselves, many of whom are excellent, able, hardworking people, need to have a system of reward for success rather than the system which they have at present which is simply bureaucratic and where they get paid the same, regardless of whether they do a good job or bad job. I wish Austrade well in the future. I hope it becomes more dynamic, more commercial and more market driven. It has potential. It could become a really effective organisation of which all Australians could be proud. It has not quite made it yet, though. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: --Like the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), I feel there has been inadequate reference made to the trade responsibility of this amalgamated Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I should say that I remain totally cynical about the amalgamation and I am greatly concerned about the way in which the foreign affairs and trade components of the Department still seem to be unhappy partners. In my view, the Department is still a bureaucratic nightmare. I do not believe it functions as well as it should. I believe there are enormous problems in getting efficient output from its present structure--not peculiarly because of the marriage between foreign affairs and trade, but that certainly does not help to ease the problems. I say that with due respect to Dick Woolcott, the Secretary, for whom I have a high personal regard.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there are enormous problems in the functions of the Department at the moment and, frankly, I think it would do well if it were split and if the way in which the bureaucracy has taken over the Department were examined to ensure that there was greater efficiency and, I suspect, less bureaucracy. I would see greater advantage in pruning the Department here in Canberra than cutting posts such as that in San Francisco at a time when in San Francisco there lies a great market, a region which is of vital importance to us. Certainly, I do not believe that that decision can be offset by any advantage arising from the decision to fund, as I understand it, the new embassy in Phnom Penh.

There are a series of aspects of the Department's estimates to which I wish to refer. I was delighted too to hear the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) refer to his concern about the approach of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Government's approach to the conduct of foreign affairs. Like the honourable member for Warringah and others on this side of the House, I believe the Minister has been overemotive in his response and reaction to so many issues. We saw it most recently in his visit to South Africa. But it also has occurred in other attitudes with respect to the peacekeeping negotiations in Cambodia. We have seen it in his own approach to issues in Europe, and we have certainly seen it in the way in which we have had an on-off relationship with Indonesia.

I believe we need to develop stability in our foreign relationships. We must give priority to our relationships with the countries of South East Asia, our relationships with Papua New Guinea and our relationships with the nations of the South Pacific; they should be way up at the top in the priorities for our conduct of our foreign policy. Yet, I am afraid that there seems so often to have been priority given to emotional issues such as the eradication of apartheid, with which we all agree philosophically, but certainly do not agree in respect of the maintenance of sanctions which still continue against South Africa or in the delay that has occurred in the re-establishment of an air service with that country, or even the establishment of direct air links with Taiwan--although, with respect to the latter, I am delighted to see that this week it looks at long last as though the air service on both sides will commence.

There are a number of particular areas in the estimates to which I want to refer. The next one is with respect to the construction of embassies. There are two aspects to this. First, it is extraordinarily difficult to find how and in what respect funds are being provided for which posts and in what time. I would like to refer honourable members to the Administrative Services estimates, to the reference to funds allocated for new posts. If one turns to the Foreign Affairs estimates, one finds that there too there is reference in the measures table on page 3-225 of Budget Statement No. 3 to particular new posts and funds provided.

Of course, it is not only in new posts; it is also in the $17.5m that is allocated towards Australian participation in Expo 92 in Seville, including $12.9m to construct a pavilion. But there is reference to money allocated for posts within which Australia will, of course, in the future hold its foreign affairs and trade representatives or, in the instance of Expo, its display representatives. I am quite horrified at the design capability of those who produce these new embassies. Those honourable members who have been to the embassy in Japan, for example, would be as embarrassed as I am at a building which replaces one of the most gorgeous old traditional homes within the city of Tokyo. The new building is an absolute disgrace to the architect, to the Department, to the Government, and indeed to everybody responsible.

In my view it should be sold for whatever we can get, and we should try to get a building that in some way reflects Australia's honour, dignity and the significance of our relationship with Japan. Indeed, that building is more like Alcatraz or perhaps Long Bay gaol. If one of the corrective services departments of the States were to build a building of that ilk here, I would be more understanding than I am in respect of the building to house Australia's representatives and interests in Tokyo.

According to the estimates, we are still completing the Beijing property; we are constructing or about to construct a new embassy in Jakarta and a new embassy and deputy head of mission residence in Suva; we have negotiated a new Manila embassy lease, presumably at some stage for either a new building or the continuation of an existing lease. I find inadequate detail in the estimates.

Of course, we also have new posts in Phnom Penh and the Gulf, and new posts in Prague and Berlin. There are overseas feasibility studies and design works in Bangkok and Port Moresby, and, of course, there is also secure staff housing in Port Moresby. I say to both departments--that is, Administrative Services and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade--for goodness sake, get some Australian identity; get some reasonable, practical, common sense in building those edifices which represent our national character.

In my mind, in Canberra, we have been extraordinarily fortunate with some wonderful embassy and chancellery buildings around this city. With some of ours overseas, firstly, one would know little from the exterior design that they were Australian premises; secondly, in some instances even the colour offends Asian sensitivities, as Asians have slightly different emphasis and in some instances totally different cultural and religious preferences for colour from those of us who look at these things with Western eyes; thirdly, we do have some tremendously innovative and Australian related concepts and designs which I believe could so well be translated into those buildings.

For example, all one has to do is to go to Longreach to see what has happened in that magnificent building that has been constructed to preserve something of the history of those who established the bush identity in this country--the Stockman's Hall of Fame, which has an Australian identity. I think that we can do that in buildings. We can certainly do it to a far greater degree than we have in the Australian embassy in Tokyo.

Indeed, I regard some of the other embassy buildings I have seen--those in Paris and Jakarta--as being less than adequate and certainly have nothing like the character, in the Paris instance and certainly in the Tokyo instance, of the buildings they have replaced. I would suggest that it would be appropriate for us to start not just to do it with embassy buildings but, for example, in that Australian building in Expo 92 in Seville.

I have seen in many instances New Zealand buildings which are a great tribute to that country. They spend the money and they certainly produce something that has the warmth and character of New Zealand. Somehow we just do not seem to achieve that.

The other area I wish briefly to address is Papua New Guinea. I note that we are still in the process of running out of that five year development cooperation treaty signed with Papua New Guinea in 1989. That of course was a disaster attained by the previous Foreign Minister, the present Governor-General when Foreign Minister. He then, we recall, let down totally Papua New Guinea. Having made a commitment, he changed the character of that aid program. There is still a difficulty in knowing just where the aid should go. There is the debate on whether it should be budget aid or whether it should be project oriented.

I certainly think we need to move away from the budget support, but I am concerned that in the present climate we need to recognise the particular relationship that Papua New Guinea has with us. I think it is not sufficient that we only look at providing help in the law and order field. I would like to see more aid given to education, more aid given to employment related activities, and perhaps more assistance given so that there can be a better quality of administration in a country which at one stage was our colony. I think our relationships with Papua New Guinea should be at the top of our priorities and I do not believe that the priorities the Department has given quite amount to that.

Like the honourable member for Mayo, can I advert to the fact that as far as the trade connections are concerned, I am interested to see Austrade coming in this Budget portfolio for the first time. However, for my money, I would scrap Austrade and get back to the stage where we had those senior trade commissioners and trade commissioners working for the Government, with the rest of it to be handled by the private sector. (Time expired)
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Progress reported.
