SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise tonight to bring to the attention of this House and of this nation an inequity which is absolutely beyond belief. I wish to quote from a recent newspaper report:

SPEECH.PARA: Rebel lawyer John Little faces another two months in jail after a Supreme Court judge yesterday set a fixed term for his contempt of court sentence.
As Mr Justice McGarvie ordered Little, 52, to be taken back to Pentridge, the disbarred solicitor shook his head and said: "This is ridiculous.
He was led away in handcuffs comforted by his wife Dokhi and surrounded by 30 supporters who demonstrated outside the court.
Little, who has already served a month of what was originally an indefinite jail term, said the whole situation was a joke and he would sue the Law Institute for damages.
"It was a parody of justice," he said. "They should be embarrassed. I have committed no crime.
Little has fought a one-man battle for a number of years against the institute over compulsory professional indemnity insurance and solicitors' practising fees.
He claims the institute illegally uses the money it levies from lawyers to fund cocktail parties, subsidise meals and market superannuation schemes.
Little's defence has moved the Law Institute to set up an inquiry into solicitors' practising fees.
Little was fined $10,000 for contempt of court in June after he defied an earlier court order by practising without a certificate. He was also struck off the solicitors' roll.
Little was before the court yesterday at the request of the institute, which claimed there was public concern that he was imprisoned indefinitely.
Mr Justice McGarvie said he was satisfied Little would never pay the fine and it was left for him to be punished for his contempt.

That is ridiculous. In this country we believe in the individual rights of women, we believe in rights for animals, and we believe in citizens' rights of almost anything we can think of but, for heavens sake, a solicitor has no individual right not to belong to an organisation. That is ridiculous. I maintain that it is long past time that this House and this Parliament gave credence to my private member's Bill for voluntary membership of organisations which offers all Australians the right to belong or not to belong to an organisation. It does not matter whether that is an organisation of membership of a union--that is, a union of workers--whether it is an organisation of professional bodies or an organisation of solicitors or lawyers, as my friend the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) will attest.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Used to be.

—-Yes, used to be. The point is that this iniquitous situation exists in our country, where we have no freedom of association. All of us would reckon that our position in regard to the Constitution gives us the right to do what we like, but in law we are not allowed that right. In law, we are required in many cases throughout this country to belong to a union of our peers or an association of our peers. It is my position that it is long past time that we gave away this ridiculous situation and gave to all those members of unions who wish not to belong to unions the right not to belong. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As you would be well aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, this week has marked a dramatic turning point in the fortunes of politics in this Government. All the opinion polls are now showing that the Federal Government is going to come back at the next election. The Bulletin poll this week shows that the number of people who expect the Liberal-National coalition to win the next election has dropped by 8 per cent and those who expect the ALP to win has risen by 8 per cent. The number who think that the Liberals will win the next election has gone from 62 per cent to 44 per cent, and the ALP has risen correspondingly very rapidly.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that the reason for the increased popularity of this Government is its capacity to take unified, tough reforming decisions in the overall interests of this country. But there are three other factors that should be taken into account. One is that the economy is coming back; the second is that the Opposition is being increasingly exposed for the right wing extremist rabble that it is; and the third is that its tax on consumption is being exposed to the general public and they can see how unpopular it is.

First of all, the economy has turned dramatically this month. The current account deficit is down, the inflation rate is down, savings are moving up with our superannuation schemes, and the eight-year business cycle is generally turning in the other direction--that is, upwards. Even honourable members opposite are well educated enough to know that the last factor that will turn will be the unemployment rate. They know from experience, and even their Leader with his absurd brand of dry economics is aware, that the upturn in the business cycle is now taking place.

Secondly, the Opposition's extreme right wing policies are being seen by the public for what they are. It has no health policy. We have just reaffirmed a reforming, equitable, universalist health policy. The Opposition's education policy is lurching towards vouchers for students. It still has not itemised the extra $3 billion cuts in government expenditure that it promised at the last election.

The Opposition wants to privatise madly, including the entire social welfare system. Not satisfied with that, its Leader went to ACOSS last week and gave these people a bath--the people with the greatest conscience in this country about the poor and the underprivileged who have had a symbiotic relationship for the last 8 1/2 years with our great Government. It wants to kick the unemployed off benefits after nine months and give them who knows what, and it wants to abolish and dismantle the great savings scheme we have implemented-- compulsory superannuation for all workers in this country, not the 25 per cent that were covered under the Opposition's schemes.

Finally, to cap it all off, the Opposition is sticking with this absurd consumption tax, although it is reluctant to reveal the final details because it knows with what horror they will be greeted by people generally in this country. What do honourable members opposite intend to do? They intend to introduce an across-the-board consumption tax that will have the effect of increasing the price of football tickets, of betting, of homes, of funerals. It will have the effect of decreasing the price of diamonds, fur coats, French perfumes and imported luxury cars. School fees will go up. Private health insurance will go up. Graveyard monuments will go up. Wedding receptions will increase in price. Of course people do not like the idea.

Who does the Opposition propose will benefit from this? The people in the upper income brackets will benefit from a reduction in the income tax rates applied to them. The people who will benefit are the 2 per cent of taxpayers who pay capital gains tax amounting to $1 billion, which will be abolished. No wonder the consumption tax is unpopular. It is not only unpopular with the general public; we find that it is also unpopular with specialist commentators on the subject. We find Eric Risstrom, the national director of the Australian Taxpayers Association, saying that the purchasing power of superannuation, life insurance policies and savings would be ripped away; the coalition would not win the next Federal election if it vowed to introduce a consumption tax. True enough. We find Bob Santamaria, who has hardly been a friend of this Government over the past couple of years, saying that the consumption tax does not fulfil the qualification; there is little if any evidence that it will increase the fund of national savings or provide an increase in internal and investable funds.

Why is it being introduced? It is being introduced for one reason only, and that is to redistribute wealth and income from the poor to the rich. It has that feature in common with most of the other policies that have been cobbled together under the guise of dry economic policy. This Opposition is a redistributive Opposition, intent on redistributing income and wealth from the needy and poor in this society to the already wealthy who back its parties. It will not win the next election because the public will become more aware of its intentions, as was reflected in the opinion polls this week and will be again over the next couple of weeks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I feel very privileged to get the call tonight, Mr Deputy Speaker. I wish to address the question of the Australian International Defence and Equipment Exhibition (AIDEX). I do not seek to discuss the merits, because time is short in the adjournment debate, but to express the views of some constituents who have written to me in relation to this matter. In particular I mention the Ballarat Diocesan Council of Priests and particularly the Reverend Father Peter Sherman, who is the Secretary of that organisation. I also mention Mr Kevin Lenehan, J. P. McCulloch, Mr and Mrs Martin, and in particular the parishioners of St Columba's Parish.

SPEECH.PARA: I had a petition from 117 people on this matter. Regrettably, the petition was not in the correct form and was therefore unable to be officially lodged with this House, but I will take the opportunity to read the letter that accompanied the petition. The letter reads:

We are writing to you as Australian citizens and voters to voice our concern about the plan to hold an Australian International Defence and Equipment Exhibition (AIDEX) arms fair in Canberra on 26 to 28 November 1991.

We believe that the Australian Government has decided to support what is considered to be the largest arms fair ever in the Southern Hemisphere. We do not believe that the Opposition has, as yet, stated its position on this decision.

It seems to us that Australia is a privileged country in the Southern Hemisphere and especially in the Asia-Pacific region, despite its current recession. It is apparent to us that armaments are used by some countries for so called `national security' as well as for acts of aggression and `defence'. It also is evident that poverty and ill health in some countries are aggravated when large funds are being spent on armaments.
In the current world situation, following the end of the Cold War, it seems that international negotiation is now more a possibility rather than the use of armed force in resolving disputes.
We would hope that Australia could be making real contributions to the region and the world by offering to take part in and mediate in negotiations.

To promote AIDEX and to support the sale of armaments in our National Capital in these circumstances would weaken Australia's credibility as a negotiator and mediator in disputes. It would also open possibilities for oppression and aggression to continue and spread in countries in this hemisphere.

We are signing this petition with the firm hope that you will see the reason of our arguments and take steps to voice your opposition to this proposal. To take this initiative would, we consider, be in keeping with Australia's character and something that we as future voters would support strongly in you.

I agree with some of the sentiments expressed by those 117 parishioners, and I thank them most sincerely for taking the time to organise this petition. The question of AIDEX has aroused considerable community discussion throughout Australia, both supporting and opposing. In some respects it might be unfortunate that AIDEX comes after the Gulf conflict earlier this year, when these sorts of matters are still very much in the public arena and are very much of concern.
I have not got time to read my full reply to the parishioners, but I would like to read one paragraph:

I am sure that you all share my very great joy at events in Europe and particularly the USSR. I believe that we finally are heading towards an achievable world peace. We must however, be mindful of the potential for the likes of Saddam Hussein to breach that peace and the fact that all the world powers were prepared to address his unconscionable aggression also gives me great hope. Regrettably it was only through armed force that Saddam Hussein was able to be dealt the contempt of the world and it is my fervent hope that the necessity to deal with the likes of Hussein by military aggression will eventually disappear.

My great concern is that the current export guidelines are not sufficient. I am pleased that the Opposition is undertaking a study with the ultimate goal of correcting the deficiencies in those guidelines.
I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Mr H.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In the past 12 months or so I have had to admit that there is a remote possibility that there will be an election which the Opposition would win--a very remote possibility, but a possibility nevertheless. However, in recent days--and the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley) has told us about some polls that were done--that remote possibility is becoming ever more remote. There is very little chance of its happening now. But even given that, a fair-minded person has to say that in a two horse race there is still a mathematical possibility that the Opposition will win an election.

SPEECH.PARA: That very remote possibility is a bit of a worry to me. It is a worry to this side of politics. It is a worry, and should be, to the Australian people. But especially it is a worry to the people of my electorate, which reflects so many other country electorates of Australia. It will knock the hell out of country people of Australia if the Opposition happens to win an election, because its policies will be disastrous for country people.

The statistics concerning the make-up of my electorate of Page, which is similar to many other country electorates, show that there is a large number of people, of families, the vast majority of whom are on below average incomes. That is in comparison with the rest of Australia, but most especially, it is in comparison with Liberal Party electorates, which are very much wealthier. That is the difference. That is not a new thing; it has been going on for years. It is not because of the recession or statistics. The records I looked at were census records from 1986 and prior to then. When the recession has gone, country electorates like mine will still have large numbers of people, the majority of their people, on lower than average incomes, whereas some of those wealthy Liberal Party electorates will have up to 70 per cent of people and families earning in excess of $70,000 a year. In my electorate less than one-tenth of that percentage earn that sort of money.

One has to look at the sorts of policies the Liberal Party is putting forward. The consumption tax is the major one at the present time. One has to look at whom that helps and who pays for it. The Opposition has admitted that it is looking for ways to compensate low income earners. The Opposition admits that the consumption tax will hurt lower income people, people below the average income, who make up the vast majority in my electorate and in other country electorates. The people who will benefit are those in the wealthy areas, in Liberal Party electorates, the electorates where there are Ferraris. I can tell honourable members that in Grafton, Albury and Moree it is rarely that a Ferrari is seen being driven down the street.

How are these lower income earners to be compensated? If one looks at the Australian Taxpayers Association chart that was put out recently, one sees that lower income earners have to be compensated by up to and exceeding 100 per cent of the tax they are paying now. That will just not happen. The reason why I worry about the people in my electorate should the Opposition get into power is plain to see. The people in my electorate will pay the price, and the people who will benefit are those in wealthier Liberal Party electorates.

I challenge the National Party to start asking questions. The people represented by the National Party are the same people, the same sort of people, as I represent. If members of that Party are not willing to start asking questions of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), they are not representing the vast majority of the people in their electorates.

The Leader of the Opposition is going up to the north coast in my area next week. I challenge him to start telling us about this consumption tax. I challenge him to start telling us how he will adequately compensate the vast majority of people on the north coast of New South Wales who have below average incomes. The Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) was up there last week. I challenged him to do the same, but he refused. He could not and he would not take up the challenge of explaining the consumption tax because, when one has to explain it to people who will have to pay for it, it cannot be explained. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-If I were the honourable member for Page, I would be extremely worried as I faced the next election. Nice fellow that he is, I do not think he will be here after the next election. I feel for the people of Grafton too. Grafton used to be a thriving metropolis. Today it is depressed and run down. I cannot see any hope that the people of Grafton would want to return this Labor Government at the next election. I am absolutely certain they will not.

SPEECH.PARA: What is thriving, of course, is the Gold Coast. I want to speak about tourist promotion. Recently the subject of tourist promotion has become a hot issue in my electorate, the Gold Coast. The local council, the Gold Coast City Council, has proposed the introduction of a tourism levy, which would be an additional rate for commercial properties. The issue has become extremely controversial. The matter has raised the whole issue of how tourist promotion should be funded.

It is fairly obvious that the Queensland Government has not accepted its responsibility for tourist promotion funding. The Goss Government rips the Gold Coast off to the extent of $70m per annum in land tax levies. It gets an enormous windfall from stamp duty through property transactions on the Gold Coast. Out of all those millions of dollars, the Queensland Government gives us back for tourist promotion the princely sum of $1,000,000 per annum through the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation. That is the same amount it gives for tourist promotion in Mount Isa, Bundaberg and perhaps even in Ipswich. I do not know whether it funds tourist promotion in Ipswich, Mr Deputy Speaker. Perhaps at some time you could tell me. Beautiful place that it is, perhaps it ought to attract tourists.

The Gold Coast needs tourist promotion funds. The Gold Coast Visitors and Convention Bureau is largely charged with the responsibility of promoting the Gold Coast and does a terrific job. However, unfortunately, it is vastly under-funded. The question of the tourist promotion levy came up simply because to a large extent the Visitors and Convention Bureau relies for its financing on private membership. Unfortunately, a significant number of businesses do not choose to join. They benefit from tourism, as almost every business on the Gold Coast does, directly or indirectly, but do not contribute.

I do not believe that the Gold Coast City Council should impose an additional levy, what amounts to an additional tax on small business. I acknowledge that there must be funding for tourist promotion. Tourist promotion is clearly a good investment. There is no doubt in my mind about that. Money put into tourist promotion has immediate benefits for the Australian economy and for the local economy on the Gold Coast. It creates jobs and earns export income. We desperately need both of those things in this country at the moment.

I do not believe the answer is a further impost upon small business by virtue of another tax. The Goss Labor Government in Queensland should accept its responsibility to put more money into tourist promotion on the Gold Coast. As I said, it takes an enormous amount of money from the Gold Coast and puts very little back.

There is, in addition, a case for boosting Federal Government funding of tourist promotion. The Budget this year increases the amount to $64m, but I believe at the moment we attract only about one per cent of the world tourism market. I think there is a tremendous opportunity, a tremendous potential, for us to increase that. If we can double the number of international visitors to our shores by 1995 and then perhaps double it again by the year 2000 we will have created more than a million jobs for Australians and earned, in today's dollar terms, $26 billion in foreign exchange.

I suggest that in the Budget the Government could have done more for tourist promotion. Even increasing the amount of money to $130m would have been a step that would have paid off enormously in the creation of jobs and the earning of foreign exchange.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 30 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Australian Wool Corporation appointed Smith Shelston Beadle, patent attorneys, Melbourne, to oppose the sealing of the letters patent of the Newman `No Drag' elevated sheep delivery system; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In June 1990, the AWC instructed Smith Shelston Beadle, (now Carter Smith Beadle) Patent Attorneys, to lodge a Notice of Opposition to Mr F J Newman's Australian Patent Application No 14645/88--Sheep Delivery System.

In September 1989, the AWC was made aware of Mr Newman's patent application which described and claimed a number of features that were considered by the AWC to be `prior published material' and/or `prior public use' resulting from a Wool Research and Development Fund (WRDF) project at the University of Melbourne.

In November 1989, Smith Shelston Beadle were instructed to write to Mr Newman's patent attorney drawing Mr Newman's attention to the prior material and inviting him to suitably amend the claims in his patent application.

The AWC's attitude to the Newman application arose from the Corporation's endeavour to allow the results of certain WRDF funded wool harvesting projects, including the above-mentioned University of Melbourne project, to be available to growers either free from the patent monopoly or on not more than a `break-even' returns basis. It was for this reason that the AWC, and the project team, elected to publish rather than apply to patent the results of that University of Melbourne project. Having taken that course, it was entirely inconsistent with the AWC's approach that a patent application which it believed relied upon the prior University of Melbourne project insights should be allowed to proceed without challenge. This is not to suggest that the AWC held, or now holds, any view that Mr Newman's application was not in good faith or involved plagiarism, but rather, that the AWC's opposition was legitimate to prevent even bona fide coincidental inventions from achieving subsequent patent monopoly status.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 22 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) responsible for inspecting imported foods to ensure that the imported foods meet Australian food standards.
(2) Is there a prohibition on the importation of irradiated foods into Australia.
(3) Does AQIS inspect imported foods to ensure that they have not been irradiated.

(4) If AQIS inspects imported foods and it is not possible to establish by scientific means whether a food has been irradiated, does AQIS require importers to produce a declaration that the foods have not been irradiated; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) is responsible for inspecting imported foods, as identified by the Imported Foods Risks Advisory Committee (IFRAC). Foods are subject to inspection where there is evidence of significant risk to human health. Imported foods considered to pose low risk to consumers are not subject to point of entry examination by AQIS.

(2) By decision of the Government, a moratorium was placed on the use of food irradiation technology within Australia, and on the importation of irradiated foods, for a period of three years from the end of 1989. A review of food irradiation technology by the World Health Organisation, considering data on safety, nutritional defects and means of detection of irradiated food, has been requested. This review process has commenced and should be completed by about October 1992.
(3) and (4) AQIS does not inspect imported foods per se to ensure they have not been irradiated.

A limited number of risk categorised foods currently fall within the scope of the imported foods inspection program administered by AQIS. Other foods are allowed unrestricted access to the Australia market and typically pose a low risk to consumers.

With respect to those foods which are subject to inspection, if AQIS inspectors observe through label checks that food has been irradiated it will be denied importation. At present there is no practicable scientific procedure for determining directly whether food has been irradiated. If, however, analysis of imported food led to an inference that food may have been irradiated, the matter would be referred to State health authorities for investigation. Such a circumstance might conceivably arise where a food usually prone to micro-biological contamination, such as crustacea, is found to be micro-biologically sterile.

Importers are reminded from time to time that irradiation is not an approved treatment for food for consumption in Australia, but declarations that imported food has not been irradiated are not required from importers. AQIS will refer the matter to IFRAC for further consideration at the earliest opportunity with a view to determining what other measures, if any, may be appropriate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 5 September 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Has his attention been drawn to concerns that the silver-lipped oyster, which is found only in Western Australia, may fall into foreign hands and be produced overseas; if so, what preventive action will the Government take.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Shadow Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is misinformed about the natural distribution of the silver-lipped oyster known scientifically as Pinctada maxima. In Australian waters silver-lipped pearl oysters are found primarily off the northern coast of Western Australia, and to a lesser extent in waters off the Northern Territory and in the Torres Strait. They also have a wide geographical distribution within the western tropical Pacific and South East Asian regions. Silver-lipped oysters are found in commercial quantities in waters off Papua New Guinea, Indonesia, the Solomon Islands, the Malay Archipelago and the Philippines.

It has been estimated that the Western Australian pearling industry produces 40 per cent--50 per cent of the world's supply of South Sea pearls, which come from silver-lipped pearl oysters. The balance is produced primarily by our South East Asian neighbours.
Pearl production in Australia is controlled by Australian companies. Currently Indonesia and some other countries lead Australia in hatchery-produced pearl oysters.

Exports of live pearl oysters from Australia are prohibited under the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations, Third Schedule, Item 13. In addition the importation of live pearl oysters is prohibited by Proclamation 108A under the Quarantine Act.

The Government closely monitors developments both internationally and domestically, in respect to the production of the highly prized South Sea pearls from silver-lipped pearl oysters. It does this through its Chairmanship of fisheries Joint Authorities responsible for the management of the Western
Australian, Northern Territory and Torres Strait pearl oyster resources.
